title: Clintons High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
description: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty. Several months ago he wrote and produced Hillary4U&Me, a song that begat a YouTube video that begat a, well, mixed reaction.

title: Years of Satisfaction
description: When the Rolling Stones performed on May 9, 1965, in Chicago, a high school senior named Hillary Rodham was part of the screaming crowd. Nowadays, Hillary Rodham Clinton may be on a first-name basis with Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, but at heart, she confessed early Sunday to reporters traveling with her on the campaign trail, she is still very much a fan.

title: Obama's Pennsylvania Stump Speech
description: At an event Sunday in Harrisburg, Pa., Barack Obama brought a bit more of a focus on policy specifics into the lofty rhetoric of his stump speech.

title: Lets Par-Tay Till 4 A.M.
description: Might the Republicans want to drink until 4 a.m. at their convention in St. Paul in the summer? Some legislators there think so.

title: Texans Take Their Time
description: Updated | 1 p.m. As of this morning, The New York Times delegate count shows Barack Obama ahead in Texas, with 99 delegates to Hillary Rodham Clintons 94.

title: Wisconsins Turris Joins the Coyotes
description: Kyle Turris, one of the top prospects not in the NHL, has signed with the Phoenix Coyotes, the team that drafted him third over all last June.

title: The Pennsylvania Campaign
description: The Democratic campaign took on the feel of the early voting states on Monday as the candidates buses crisscrossed paths in Pennsylvania.

title: Bjork in 3-D: The 'Wanderlust' Video
description: Melena Ryzik talks to Bjork and the directing team 'Encyclopedia Pictura' about the making of their new 3-D music video 'Wanderlust.'

title: Esprit de Corps
description: In patches decorated with rockets, bombs and dragons, a photographer and author, Trevor Paglen, finds a coded guide to a secret world of military research.

title: Notes from an Intergenerational Conversation
description: Authors Deborah Siegel, 39, and Courtney E. Martin, 28, have been traveling the country talking about their recent books about young women and also as part of an intergenerational conversation series with the name: WomenGirlsLadies: A Fresh Conversation Across Generations. (The name is adapted from an old country western songTheres girls and theres women and theres ladies. Theres yeses, theres nos, and theres maybes and includes author/activists Gloria Feldt  and Kristal Brent Zook as well.)

title: Colorado Proposes Tough Law on Executive Accountability
description: DENVER  For 30 years, Lew Ellingson loved being a telephone man.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,997 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Turkey Court Takes Politically Explosive Case
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys highest court said Monday that it had decided to hear a case on shutting down the governing party and banning its political leaders, moving the country closer to a final confrontation between religious and secular Turks about who will rule the nation.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Insists Mugabe Lost
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The nation lingered in political limbo Monday, with its election commission staying silent on the results of Saturdays presidential race, raising additional concerns that President Robert G. Mugabe was intent on rigging the outcome.

title: G.A.O. Report Points to Rise in Cost Overruns at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Inefficient Pentagon management led to cost increases for key weapons programs that often fell short of production goals last year, government auditors said Monday.

title: Opponents of Musharraf Assume Posts in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A stern-faced President Pervez Musharraf swore in a new cabinet on Monday that was filled with political opponents from the main opposition parties, including several who served time in prison under his military government.

title: Mexico: American-Owned Bank Bombed
description: A homemade bomb destroyed the entrance of a branch of Citigroups Mexican subsidiary, Banamex, in southern Mexico City, causing no injuries. No one claimed responsibility, but small guerrilla groups have previously attacked foreign-owned banks.

title: Thunder Out of Russia, Courtesy of Both Orchestra and Pianist
description: BROOKVILLE, N.Y.  Although it is not the oldest Russian orchestra now active, the State Symphony Orchestra of Russia is certainly among the more venerable. Founded in 1936, it earned a sterling reputation under the leadership of Yevgeny Svetlanov, its principal conductor from 1965 to 2000.

title: As Fight for Water Heats Up, Prized Fish Suffer
description: WISDOM, Mont.  Its a simple fact of life across the rural West, as it is here in Montanas mountain-ringed Big Hole River Valley. Flooding river bottoms to grow hay sustains the economy but means less water in the river for the prized wild trout population.

title: The Claim: A Fever in a Baby Is a Sign of Teething
description: THE FACTS

title: Agency Faulted on Protection at Utah Mine
description: DENVER  Federal mine regulators were negligent in protecting the safety of workers at a deep underground coal mine in Utah where nine people died last August in cave-ins, the Labor Departments inspector general said in a report released Monday.

title: On a Crowded Stage, Works Bursting With Cheer
description: Different in their methods and their messages, Mozart and Gunther Schuller had at least one thing in common on Sunday afternoon: a desire to please. The Met Chamber Ensemble, led by James Levine, was convening at Zankel Hall. The music was two Mozart serenades, the Gran Partita and Eine Kleine Nachtmusik, and Mr. Schullers Grand Concerto for Percussion and Keyboards.

title: Parts Maker Talks of Strikebreakers and Labor Abroad
description: DETROIT  American Axle and Manufacturing, the auto parts maker, is trying to force an end to the industrys longest strike in a decade by calling back laid-off employees, advertising for replacement workers and threatening to move production out of the United States.

title: Gun Supplier Is Given 20-Month Sentence in Fort Dix Case
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  A 25-year-old man who admitted he supplied guns and ammunition to friends accused of plotting to attack soldiers at the Fort Dix military base in New Jersey was sentenced on Monday to 20 months in prison, a term that exceeds the federal guidelines but falls short of the five years prosecutors had sought.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 17 about internal disagreements and accusations of favoritism at Wikipedia misstated the name of the Canadian network that once employed Sue Gardner, executive director at the Wikimedia Foundation, which runs the various Wikipedia projects. It is the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, not the Canadian Broadcasting Company.

title: Passenger in Sean Bells Car Recounts Shooting
description: Trent Benefield said he was in the back seat of Sean Bells sedan when he saw, through the windshield, a man standing in front of the car, pointing a pistol at Mr. Bell.

title: Pressed by Rice, Palestinian Leader Agrees to Return to Peace Talks With Israeli
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, said Monday that he would return to the bargaining table next week for face-to-face peace talks with Ehud Olmert, the Israeli prime minister.

description: Johannesburg

title: Kirovs Travel Plans Exclude the Director
description: The Kirov Ballet begins its New York engagement on Tuesday with a program not at its usual home away from home, the Metropolitan Opera House, but at City Center for the first time. That will be the most transparent change to audiences. What they wont be seeing is the turbulence behind the scenes, where questions about the ballets leadership surround the company.

title: Cautious Optimism, Even for Opener
description: MIAMI

title: Inflation Accelerates in Nations Using Euro
description: Euro-zone inflation accelerated in March to the fastest pace since 1992, official data showed Monday, giving the European Central Bank more reason to look with concern on the announcement of a big wage agreement in Germany.

title: Beloved Hospitals Plans Cause Furor in the Village
description: At a highly anticipated public landmarks hearing on Tuesday, preservationists are expected to battle a controversial development proposal for St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village.

title: Put the Housing Back in HUD
description: As relieved as we were to see Alphonso Jackson resign on Monday as the secretary of housing and urban development, it was a sad comment on the Bush administrations low regard for HUDs mission that Mr. Jackson was permitted to remain in office so long.

title: Stocks Surge on Hopes Financial Woes Are Easing
description: Only on Wall Street can billion-dollar bank losses be a good thing.

title: 15-Year Term Is Given on Gun Charge
description: A Brooklyn man with a history of attacking police officers was sentenced on Monday to 15 years in prison on a weapons charge. The charges arose from a case in which the man, Damion Henry, was initially charged with attempted murder after the authorities said he had fired an Uzi submachine gun at two police officers outside a nightclub in East Flatbush.

title: Once and Future NATO
description: NATO plans to add three new members at its summit this week, proving that it is still a club that European states want to join. The chance of membership has proved to be a good carrot for encouraging democracy in the 11 nations that have joined since the end of the cold war. We hope it would do the same for the newest aspirants: Albania, Croatia and Macedonia.

title: Take Beethoven, Instill Period Flavor, Heighten the Drama
description: Does the world need any more Beethoven recordings? That question has been raised time and again to indicate the folly of companies that continue to record his works. Our digitized Toscaninis, Szells and Karajans, after all, should last a lifetime.

title: Doubts Greet Treasury Plan on Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  As Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. laid out an ambitious plan to overhaul the regulatory apparatus that oversees the nations financial system on Monday, lawmakers and lobbyists from an array of industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.

title: More Morning Television for Kathie Lee Gifford
description: Kathie Lee Gifford, right, the former longtime co-host of Live With Regis and Kathie Lee, is returning to morning television as the host of the fourth hour of NBCs Today program, the network confirmed Monday. The feature-heavy fourth hour of Today, introduced in September, competes directly against Live in some markets, so Ms. Gifford will go up against her former colleague, Regis Philbin, and the woman to whom she ceded her chair in 2000, Kelly Ripa. The assignment, beginning April 7, will be Ms. Giffords third morning show stint: she reported for Good Morning America before becoming Mr. Philbins co-host on Live for 15 years. Ms. Gifford was introduced on Today by Matt Lauer and Meredith Vieira, the hosts of the first two hours. Im 8 years older, 10 pounds heavier and a half-inch shorter, just in time for HD television, Ms. Gifford joked. With seven hosts sitting on the set, the cameras could barely show the entire ensemble. But the addition of Ms. Gifford will reduce the workload for some of the others. Ms. Gifford will join Hoda Kotb, her co-anchor for the fourth hour. Ann Curry and Al Roker, two members of the 7 to 9 a.m. team, will continue as co-hosts of the third hour but will no longer contribute to the fourth. Natalie Morales, who was named a co-anchor of the fourth hour last September, will become a host of the third hour.

title: From a Burial Pit in Southern Peru, a Golden Oldie
description: Archaeologists have discovered what appears to be a gold necklace from a 4,000-year-old burial pit in southern Peru. It is the oldest example of worked gold ever found in the Americas.

title: Reining in Medicare: The Budget Directors View
description: To the Editor:

title: The Little Tingle Tells You Its Working
description: Some people think that giving their houseplants an occasional talking-to is a good thing. But how about a little shock treatment?

title: March Sales Decline for Top 4 Automakers
description: DETROIT  Sales fell in March for each of the four largest automakers, and executives said they are bracing for the industrys slump to continue for at least several more months.

title: Warm Welcome in Los Angeles Helps Torre Keep New York in the Past
description: LOS ANGELES  Joe Torre had barely nestled into his new perch, the top railing of the third-base dugout at Dodger Stadium, when Dave Roberts singled and took off for second base.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The caption for a photograph in some editions on March 23 with an article about a new pipe organ at Christ and St. Stephens Episcopal Church in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the pipes being examined by Paul Jacobs, the artist-in-residence at the church. They were decorative pipes that do not produce sound when the organ is played; they line the outer wall of a specially built chamber at the front of the church that houses the 1,042 pipes mentioned in the article.

title: Inside the Black Budget
description: Skulls. Black cats. A naked woman riding a killer whale. Grim reapers. Snakes. Swords. Occult symbols. A wizard with a staff that shoots lightning bolts. Moons. Stars. A dragon holding the Earth in its claws.

title: Mr. Schwarzs Lamented Exit
description: It is not easy being the chairman of the citys Campaign Finance Board. Candidates, who benefit from public dollars, complain that the board goes too far in enforcing rules and meting out punishment. The City Council must approve any reforms  a tough sell when most members benefit from special-interest money. Self-financed candidates, like Mayor Michael Bloomberg, have made it harder to keep others in the system.

title: Carrying a Torch, or at Least Sprigs of Grass
description: Amazon river dolphins, or botos, have a curious habit: occasionally one will grab some river grass or a rock in its mouth and pop its head above the surface, showing its prize for all to see.

title: On Paper, Wall Street Gets Its Way
description: More than a year ago, when the markets were flying high, a chorus of alarm went up on Wall Street. Talk spread that the United States risked losing its edge in the financial world.

title: Am I Looking at a Malignant Melanoma?
description: It was bigger than a pencil eraser and irregular in shape. That put the odds against her. But it had smooth edges; that was in her favor. From four seats away, in the diffuse light of the bookshop, it looked black. But I couldnt be sure.

title: At Risk: Pot Belly in Midlife Is Linked to Dementia
description: People with a large pot belly in midlife are at increased risk for dementia in their later years, according to a new study, and the bigger the belly the higher the risk.

title: Energy Dept. Hesitates on Dealing With Uranium
description: WASHINGTON  The government is sitting on an inventory of partly processed uranium that could be sold for billions of dollars while prices are high, but the Energy Department is dawdling in deciding what to do with it, according to the Government Accountability Office.

description: ALAIN DELON:

title: Italy: Unions Extend Talks With Alitalia
description: Alitalias main unions agreed to extend talks with the Air France-KLM Group beyond a midnight deadline in an effort to reach an agreement on its takeover bid for the Italian carrier. Alitalias unions said they would continue negotiations on Tuesday.

title: Lending Plan Won Prize, but Will It Work Here?
description: The maroon couch was big enough to take up half the living room, but by the time the 10th woman arrived it could hold no more.

title: Girardi Gets an Early Start With the Yanks, a Day Early
description: Joe Girardi had sleepy eyes, the kind of slits that someone who had awakened only 20 minutes earlier has. It was almost 7 a.m. and Girardi was standing near his silver sports utility vehicle in a town in Westchester County. He was 25 miles from Yankee Stadium, 25 miles from a day that he said was too immense for him to even fantasize about.

title: In Gaza, Hamass Insults to Jews Complicate Peace
description: GAZA  In the Katib Wilayat mosque one recent Friday, the imam was discussing the wiliness of the Jew.

title: Dell Weighs Alternatives to Its Link With CIT
description: SAN FRANCISCO (Dow Jones)  Dell Inc. said Monday that it was undertaking a strategic assessment of ownership alternatives for its Dell Financial Services division, which has ties to the CIT Group, a commercial lender snared by the subprime crisis.

title: The Polish of a Trained Voice, the Passion of a Folk Singer
description: The British soprano Kate Royal last performed in New York as the soloist in Paul McCartneys most recent orchestral work, Ecce Cor Meum, in 2006, and since then has made an endearing recital disc for EMI Classics, devoted to repertory that skirts the borders of the mainstream. On Sunday afternoon Ms. Royal devoted much of her program at the Frick Collection  her first recital there  to showing how ravishing these works can sound.

title: In Village, a Proposal That Erases History
description: The passionate battles surrounding the birth of New Yorks preservation movement nearly a half-century ago seem like distant memories now. For some New Yorkers the main threat to architecture in the city is no longer the demolition of its great landmarks, but a trite nostalgia that disdains the new.

title: Curbing the Carbon Habit (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Require States to Use a Single School Dropout Formula
description: Moving to sweep away the tangle of inaccurate state data that has obscured the severity of the nations high school dropout crisis, Secretary of Education Margaret Spellings will require all states to use one federal formula to calculate graduation and dropout rates, Bush administration officials said on Monday.

title: From Behind Bars, Milwaukee Alderman May Be Re-elected
description: MILWAUKEE  For 10 months, a section of this citys North Side has had no alderman at City Hall. Michael McGee Jr., the man its residents elected to the Common Council, has been behind bars, awaiting trials on federal charges of extortion and soliciting bribes from business owners in his district and state charges including paying for votes and conspiring to have a man beaten.

title: Acrobatic Adventure Vaults Onto Broadway
description: Cirque Dreams Jungle Fantasy, described as a theatrical, acrobatic and musical adventure, will play a 10-week engagement this summer at the Broadway Theater, empty since The Color Purple moved out and waiting for Shrek to move in. Cirque Dreams (which has nothing to do with Cirque du Soleil and has weathered a lawsuit to prove it) is the latest show from a 15-year-old production company based in Florida that puts on touring circus shows. Jungle Fantasy, involving giant butterflies, giraffes and flowers, has already toured the country. The show is scheduled to start performances on June 16, with June 26 as the official opening date. Tickets will cost $25 to $85.

title: College Basketball Propels CBS Forward
description: With a boost from its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament, CBS eked out a slight ratings victory on Sunday, edging past ABC as the nights most watched network. According to Nielsens overnight estimates, the 23-minute college basketball overrun into the 7 p.m. time slot meant that more than 17 million viewers were tuned in to CBS during the first half-hour of prime time. Directly after the live coverage ended, CBS drew about 12.3 million viewers for 60 Minutes, followed by an above-average audience of 8 million viewers for CBSs Big Brother. Despite its second place finish, ABC outpaced CBS among adults 18 to 49 thanks to Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (12.8 million) and Oprahs Big Give at 9 (11.3 million). Fox was third for the night in that demographic, trailing both ABC and CBS with its animated comedy lineup. NBC, which drew slightly more total viewers than Fox, finished a distant fourth in the 18-to-49 set. NBC broadcast repeats from 9 to 11, following a special showing of MSNBCs Countdown With Keith Olbermann at 7 (3.4 million) and Dateline at 8 (6.7 million).

title: Roths New Book Looks Backward
description: Philip Roth, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist and recent chronicler of the vagaries of old age, will return to the anxieties of youth with his 29th book, Indignation, to be published in September by Houghton Mifflin. Mr. Roth, whose last novel was Exit Ghost (2007), the ninth and final book about the authors literary alter ego, Nathan Zuckerman, has set the new book during the Korean War. The story follows Marcus Messner, a young man from Newark who is obsessively worried about being drafted into the war. He ends up at a conservative college in Winesburg, Ohio, to escape his overbearing father. The novel tracks him trying to find his place and fit in and having the tough time of it that he does, said Becky Saletan, publisher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

title: Robert F. Goheen, Innovative Princeton President, Is Dead at 88
description: Robert F. Goheen, who as president of Princeton revolutionized the university by admitting its first women, pursuing minority faculty members, buttressing finances and doubling the space in campus buildings, died on Monday in Princeton, N.J. He was 88.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Saturday about a legal victory for the heirs of Jerry Siegel, a creator of the Superman action character, misstated the given name of his co-creator. He was Joe Shuster, not Max. The article also misspelled Mr. Siegels family name as Seigel in one reference.

title: Patriots Owner Defends His Team
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Robert K. Kraft, the chairman of the New England Patriots, strongly  sometimes angrily  defended his team Monday, saying he was eager for the N.F.L. to talk to a former Patriots employee who has intimated that he has evidence of the teams videotaping practices.

title: As Budget Deadline Looms, Spending Cuts Remain Elusive
description: ALBANY  As the midnight deadline for approving the states budget loomed on Monday, legislators found themselves trying to solve an impossible equation: how to keep the budget from growing when they keep adding to it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A listing of information in the New Jersey section on Sunday with an article about the Garden State Film Festival in and around Asbury Park misstated the date of one screening and gave an incorrect price and admission details for another. Legends Behind the Comic Books will be shown at 1 p.m. on Saturday, not Sunday. Greetings From the Shore, on Saturday at 8:15 p.m., costs $10, not $20, and is not accompanied by a cocktail party and reception.

title: A Deli Destination, Now a Pastrami-Scented Memory
description: SUNNY ISLES BEACH, Fla.  Elaine Rothman could hardly believe her eyes. Two construction workers tearing up one of Rascal Houses old red booths? The kitchen of her favorite deli being drilled to pieces? It was almost too much for a not-so-young lady in a hot-pink T-shirt to take.

Getting a Platoons-Eye View of the War on the Ground
description: Deborah Scranton had a good idea with The War Tapes, the 2006 documentary about the Iraq war that she made from video shot by soldiers themselves, and she shows that its still an illuminating gimmick in Bad Voodoos War, a Frontline installment on Tuesday night.

title: Food Prices Rise, Farmers Respond
description: CHICAGO  Faced with strong worldwide food demand and the accompanying higher prices, American farmers are beginning to respond to the signals of the market. In a new government report, farmers said they would make significant cuts in corn acreage this year in favor of soybeans.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: National

title: A Womens Mariachi Band Sings Its Way Through Traditional Male Turf
description: LOS ANGELES  In Compaeras, a documentary about the female mariachi band Reyna de Los Angeles, one of the members explains why she is loath to see mariachi music as work.

title: Washington State Debates Strict Bill on Child Products
description: SEATTLE  Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington is expected to sign a measure on Tuesday that would give the state some of the toughest rules in the nation restricting toxic materials used in childrens products, though it was unclear just how broad the measure would be.

title: Iraq Seems Calmer After Cleric Halts Fighting
description: BAGHDAD  Militiamen with the Mahdi Army, the followers of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, mostly vanished from the streets of Basra on Monday, a day after he ordered them to lay down their arms and also insisted that the Iraqi government grant a general amnesty for his followers, and made other demands.

title: Insurers Faulted as Overloading Social Security
description: The Social Security system is choking on paperwork and spending millions of dollars a year screening dubious applications for disability benefits, according to lawsuits filed by whistle-blowers.

title: Blind to Change, Even as It Stares Us in the Face
description: Leave it to a vision researcher to make you feel like Mr. Magoo.

description: The last time New York City welcomed Boredoms, an experimental rock band from Osaka, Japan, the encounter took on monumental proportions. It was last July  7/7/07, to be precise  when the group convened 77 drummers in a giant spiral on the Brooklyn waterfront. For a few hours that evening the Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park became a site of conceptual and ceremonial abstraction.

description: DENVER  Freddie Whitney was walking out of a King Soopers supermarket here this winter when she was approached by three young men.

title: Seeking Answers to Stop Another Stillbirth
description: Victoria Tapia, then 19, was having a perfect pregnancy at 29 weeks until one morning she no longer felt the fetus moving. An ultrasound confirmed that it had died in utero.

title: New Competition and Cancellations at Heathrow Vex British Airways
description: LONDON  British Airways canceled 54 more flights at its new terminal at Heathrow Airport here on Monday as it struggled with a computerized baggage-handling system that has already led to the misdirecting of at least 15,000 pieces of luggage.

description: Woody Allen has sued a clothing maker and retailer, American Apparel, for $10 million, saying it used his image without permission on billboards.

title: Patterns: Another Reason to Choose a Mate Wisely
description: Happily married people tend to have lower blood pressure than their single peers, but being single may be healthier than being unhappily married, a new study suggests.

title: The Bricklayers Sons: The Family That Spawned 9/11
description: Steve Colls riveting new book not only gives us the most psychologically detailed portrait of the brutal 9/11 mastermind yet, but in telling the epic story of Osama bin Ladens extended family, it also reveals the crucial role that his relatives and their relationship with the royal house of Saud played in shaping his thinking, his ambitions, his technological expertise and his tactics.

title: Patagonia Without Dams
description: Recently, environmental activists and local residents gathered near the small Chilean town of Cochrane to protest a plan to build a series of hydroelectrical dams. Cochrane is part of Chilean Patagonia, and it would be transformed beyond recognition if the project goes ahead. But the change in Cochrane would be nothing compared with the change in Patagonia.

description: United States Representative Peter T. King, a Republican from Long Island who is known for his independent streak, is quietly exploring the possibility of mounting a bid for governor in two years, according to people close to him.

title: Award Plans Earn Cash for Airlines
description: Travelers have been complaining more often about frequent flier programs  namely, the lack of award seats on desirable flights, escalating fees for ostensibly free tickets and quicker expiration dates for miles.

title: New Therapies Fight Phantom Noises of Tinnitus
description: Modern life is loud. The jolting buzz of an alarm clock awakens the ears to a daily din of trucks idling, sirens blaring, televisions droning, computers pinging and phones ringing  not to mention refrigerators humming and air-conditioners thrumming. But for the 12 million Americans who suffer from severe tinnitus, the phantom tones inside their head are louder than anything else.

title: Williams Gets His Ideal Setting for the Game He Did Not Want
description: The game that North Carolina Coach Roy Williams never wanted to schedule is going to be played Saturday. He cannot avoid Kansas.

title: Issue for Athletes: Protest on Darfur at Olympics
description: Whether speaking to a group of young softball players or plying her teammates with literature, Jessica Mendoza, a 27-year-old outfielder on the United States Olympic softball team, does not hesitate to speak her mind about the killings in Darfur.

title: Tibetans Protest in Delhi, but March Is Off
description: NEW DELHI  Tibetan exile groups staged another spirited anti-Chinese demonstration here Monday, but the most radical among them have quietly called off a controversial march into Tibet, apparently heeding requests from their spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.

title: Miami Spice: Saucy Club Crawlers Flirt, Sulk and Spar to a Crossover Beat
description: MIAMI  Throughout its current program of four works, Miami City Ballet proves marvelous. Standards of musical playing are good; lighting is (mainly) excellent; the dancers are individual, skilled, colorful, confident, engaging. Since three of the ballets are choreographically first rate, this is rich fare.

description: Former Vice President Al Gore and a nonprofit climate group have begun what they say will be a three-year $300 million advertising blitz to recruit 10 million advocates to seek laws and policies that can cut greenhouse gases.

title: Dancers and Their Musicians Bring Intimate Room to Life
description: The expanded awareness that live musicians bring to a dance stage is always part of the experience of watching Miro Magloires New Chamber Ballet, which performed on Friday night in City Center Studio 4. Mr. Magloire first trained as a musician and composer in his native Germany before moving to New York to study dance, and he has used the violinist Erik Carlson and the pianist Melody Fader as an essential part of this small ensemble almost since its beginnings in 2004.

title: Few Lives Saved by Home Heart-Starting Devices
description: Researchers had bad news Tuesday for makers and buyers of portable devices that deliver electrical shocks meant to revive victims of sudden heart seizures. In the first major study of their use in household settings, the researchers found no evidence that the devices produced significant life-saving benefits.

title: In the World Series Chase, Cashing in on Hope and Nostalgia
description: The Yankees are hoping that this year is the big one, the season when theyll win the World Series to end a seven-year drought.

title: Grand Jury Is Investigating Noose at Columbia University
description: A state grand jury in Manhattan is investigating the appearance of a noose in October on the office door of a black education professor at Columbia University, officials said on Monday.

title: CPR Can Help, Even With No Training
description: Even people without CPR training can save the life of an adult whose heart stops, and the American Heart Association has issued an advisory urging everyone, trained or not, to act immediately in such an emergency.

description: BEIJING  President Hu Jintao of China waved the Olympic torch at a ceremony in Tiananmen Square on Monday, smiling as balloons, streamers and confetti filled a mostly blue sky.

description: The slap shot that Chris Drury fired at Pittsburghs net had almost no margin for error, much like the Rangers playoff hopes. It soared through a maze of legs and found a hole so small that it had completely closed by the time the puck sprang into the back of the net.

description: WASHINGTON  House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday suggested that President Bush should skip the opening ceremonies of the Olympics to be held in August in Beijing to protest Chinas actions in Tibet, its overall human rights record and its trade policies.

title: How I Achieved Inner Peace (Despite the Concussion)
description: I KNOW of travelers who book year-end trips to maintain their premium status on preferred airlines. I never have that problem. I log so many miles that I gain elite status with airlines I dont even like.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an obituary of G. David Low, a space shuttle astronaut, carried an incorrect date in some editions. The photograph of Mr. Low was taken in 1990, not 1989.

title: Canada: Mining Companies in a Merger
description: Peak Gold, owner of the Amapari mine in Brazil, agreed to a $1.6 billion all-stock combination with Metallica Resources and New Gold to diversify and increase production. The combined company, to be called New Gold, is expected to produce 297,000 ounces of gold this year and 335,000 ounces in 2009 from operations in Australia, Brazil and Mexico, Peak said. Shareholders in Peak, which is based in Vancouver, will receive 0.1 New Gold share for each Peak share they own. Investors in Metallica, based in Toronto, will receive 0.9 New Gold share for each share in the company.

title: Supreme Court Rules for Delaware in River Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  New Jerseys hope of profiting from a huge liquefied natural gas processing plant on its Delaware River shore ended in the Supreme Court on Monday when the justices ruled by a vote of 6 to 2 that Delaware has the right to veto the project.

title: Cuba Ends No Cubans Allowed Hotel Policy
description: President Ral Castros new government will begin allowing Cubans to stay at hotels that were previously set aside for foreign tourists, the latest in a string of moves liberalizing internal restrictions on Cubans. In other changes, Cubans will be able to rent cars and buy cellphones, computers, microwaves and DVD players. However, with state salaries of about $20 a month, most Cubans will not be able to afford them.

title: For Yanks and Fans, One More Day to Wait
description: Yankee Stadium has never played host to a regular-season baseball game in March, and now it never will. Judging by the raw and soggy conditions in the Bronx on Monday, it may be just as well.

title: Somali Town Falls to Insurgent Raid
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Islamist insurgents overpowered Somali government troops on Monday, seizing a strategic town and continuing their steady march across the country.

title: Talks Begin on New International Climate Treaty
description: BANGKOK  Representatives of more than 160 countries began formal negotiations here on Monday on a treaty to address climate change, with the secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, urging governments to help in saving the planet.

title: Democrats Hit the Campaign Trail in Pennsylvania
description: FAIRLESS HILLS, Pa.  The Democratic campaign took on the feel of the early voting states on Monday, back when the candidates buses would crisscross paths in a single state. Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama were both in eastern Pennsylvania courting voters, on a day in which Mr. Obama gained a superdelegate.

title: 3 Friends Become Foes in Fight for Final Four
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Nothing comes between Tina, Kaili and Epiphanny. They are like the friends on Sex and the City, only they wear Nikes instead of Manolos, and meet for basketball, not brunch.

title: Chad: French Aid Workers Pardoned
description: Six French aid workers who had been sentenced to eight years of hard labor for the attempted kidnapping of 103 children were pardoned and released. The workers had chartered a plane to fly to Europe children they claimed were orphans of the conflict in the Darfur region of Sudan. Most of the children were neither orphans nor from Sudan. The workers were serving their time in France, but after France pledged to help defend Chads president, Idriss Dby, from rebel attacks in February, he agreed to consider pardoning them.

title: Karen Kain Leaves Canada Arts Council
description: Karen Kain, artistic director of the National Ballet of Canada, resigned on Monday from her post as chairwoman of the Canada Council for the Arts, CBC News reported. In a letter to Jose Verner, minister of Canadian Heritage, Ms. Kain said she wanted to devote more time to the ballet company. The council, charged with promoting the arts in Canada, is that nations largest arts-granting organization. Ms. Kain has been its chairwoman since September 2004 and, since July 2005, artistic director of the National Ballet, where she danced from 1969 to 1997.

description: Fighting in Afghanistan and Pakistan meant that polio eradication did not go well in those countries in 2007, a World Health Organization report said last week.

title: The Ancient Mechanics and How They Thought
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Consider the galley slave, clad in rags, chained to a hardwood bench and clinging to an oar as long as a three-story flagpole. A burly man with a whip walks back and forth shouting encouragement. Youve seen the movie.

title: Regimens: Drug Samples Found to Affect Spending
description: Having doctors distribute free samples of medicines may do exactly what drug companies hope for  encourage patients to spend more money on drugs.

description: Terminal 5 was supposed to be the saving grace for British Airways and London Heathrow, one of the most congested airports in Europe.

title: New Plays Exploring Difficult Relations
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The schisms in American society, both macro and micro, were on vivid display at this years Humana Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville. The divisions between the religious right and the secular left, the tech-fueled widening of the generation gap and the ever-relevant question of what makes a modern marriage function smoothly were among the themes explored by playwrights at the festival.

title: Politics Benefits CNN
description: The political season continues to be very good to CNN, which will officially announce on Tuesday that for the first time since 2001, it managed to beat the Fox News Channel in prime time for one quarter of the year in the category of news viewers most desirable to advertisers, according to Nielsen. Thanks to its debate coverage and heavy focus on the presidential primaries, CNNs ratings in prime time for viewers 25 to 54 were up 90 percent, to an average of 453,000 for the first quarter of 2008. That was enough to edge past the perennial leader, Fox, which had 438,000 viewers, up 12 percent from last year. MSNBC also had a strong quarter in prime time, growing 68 percent to 329,000 viewers. CNN has done especially well on the nights of contested primaries, winning every night in those ratings except one, the Florida primary on Jan. 29. That was the only night when the Republican race was of higher interest than the Democratic one, and Fox won that night. Among total viewers in prime time, Fox maintained its leadership position in the first quarter with an average of 1.8 million viewers, up 14 percent from last year. CNN grew 67 percent to 1.3 million viewers. MSNBC was up 59 percent to 791,000 viewers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pitching With Purpose
description: A few years ago, a former professional baseball player mentioned a book that had made a great impression on him. It was called The Mental ABCs of Pitching, by a sports psychologist named H.A. Dorfman. I read the book one spare evening, though, as you may have noticed, Im not a pitcher  and no major league organization has expressed interest in making me one.

title: Picasso Nude Found in a Bedroom Trove
description: A nude watercolor painted by Picasso when he was about 20 and struggling for recognition has been found stacked against a wall in the bedroom of a house in southwest England, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting, Entreinte (Embrace), from 1901 or 1902, depicts a nude Picasso entwined with his girlfriend Louise Lenoir, known as Odette. He authenticated it in 1969. The watercolor was found with two other paintings, by George Stubbs and Alfred Munnings, both specialists in portraying horses. To find one of these works would have been incredible, but to find three was quite exceptional, said Guy Schwinge of Dukes, the auctioneers that will sell the paintings on April 10. Each is expected to fetch as much as $199,000.

title: Hamas and Fatah Supporters Clash at Gaza University
description: GAZA  Hamas police and supporters on Monday beat a number of professors and students of Al Azhar University, the last bastion of Fatah in Gaza, wounding several, witnesses said. Hamas denied it had acted improperly and said the police restored order.The students and staff were protesting a rally that Hamas insisted on holding inside the university campus in memory of Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, the founder of the militant Islamic group who was killed in an Israeli air strike in March 2004.

title: Insider Trading Cited in EADS Case
description: PARIS  The French financial market regulator filed a formal complaint on Tuesday against European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent company of Airbus, and more than a dozen current and former executives in connection with an inquiry into accusations of insider trading and other market abuses.

title: Carrying Primary Scars Into the General Election
description: President Jimmy Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy had been sharp adversaries with a bad history, and in the 1980 presidential campaign they let it bleed into a bitter nomination fight. The Carter administration challenged Mr. Kennedys patriotism and refused to debate, while Mr. Kennedy dragged out their fight for nine months, all the way to the Democratic convention. A weakened Mr. Carter prevailed and won the nomination, but he went on to lose in November.

title: Professor Puts a Face on the Performance of Baseball Managers
description: The baseball season began in earnest this week, with 750 major league players and 2,430 games ready to collide and create countless millions of data  which the games devotees (who have included Nobel laureates) will assay with the statistical equivalent of an electron microscope.

title: Administration Rebuffed on House Office Search
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration failed on Monday to persuade the Supreme Court to hear its argument that the Federal Bureau of Investigations highly unusual search of a Louisiana congressmans office nearly two years ago was carried out properly.

title: For Entrepreneurs, Its All About Time
description: Everybody gets the same amount of time: 168 hours in a given week; 8,736 in a year. And yet a common complaint among entrepreneurs and small-business owners is that they wish they had more time.

title: City Council Approves Fee to Drive Below 60th
description: The controversial proposal to charge drivers in the busiest parts of Manhattan took a major step forward on Monday, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Speaker Christine C. Quinn wrenching approval from the City Council by an unusually slim margin.

title: Ex-Convict Is Charged After Abduction in Connecticut Leads to a Body
description: NEW HAVEN  The last time anyone recalled seeing MaryEllen Welsh, she was heading toward her friends house in New Britain, about to have coffee on Sunday morning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about vehicles that were struck by gunfire on I-64 in Virginia misspelled the surname of a gunman involved in highway shootings in the Washington area in 2002. He is John A. Muhammad, not Mohammed. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the distance between the recent shootings and the area that was terrorized six years ago. It is about two hours drive, not about an hours drive. (The error was repeated in an article on Saturday about the arrest of two teenagers in the Virginia shootings.)

title: Santanas Start Helps Mets Forget Finish
description: MIAMI  The beauty of opening day lies in its simplicity. Nothing that happened before  not yesterday, not last week, not 182 days ago  mattered Monday afternoon, when the Mets faced the Florida Marlins in their first game since the Collapse.

title: Ecuador Sues Colombia Over Coca Spraying
description: Ecuador filed a lawsuit against Colombia in an international court, seeking to end Colombias fumigation of coca crops along the border. Ecuador says that the aerial herbicide spraying also kills legal crops in Ecuador and that it sickens Ecuadoreans living near the border. Faced with previous complaints, Colombia had recently increased manual eradication of coca plants as part of an antinarcotics program financed by the United States. The lawsuit, filed in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, followed a raid by Colombian forces on March 1 on Colombian guerrillas in Ecuador.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about an apology by the Florida Legislature for the states history of slavery included an incorrect attribution from Gov. Charlie Crist for the quotation All that is necessary for evil to prevail is for good people to do nothing. Although often attributed to the philosopher Edmund Burke, the quotation does not appear in his writings, and its author is unknown.

title: A Push to Stop Swiss Cats From Being Turned Into Coats and Hats
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  Had just one of her cats disappeared last October, Isabelle Nydegger would simply have assumed it had lost its way in the nearby forest or been attacked by a dog or wild animal.

description: The already crazed competition for admission to the nations most prestigious universities and colleges became even more intense this year, with many logging record low acceptance rates.

title: TB Declines, but the Toll Is Still Severe
description: The nation's tuberculosis rate dropped last year to its lowest level since national reporting of the rate began in 1953. "It means we have to have a sustained effort to continue our progress," she said. "There's a perception that TB is a disease of the past, but it continues to exact a severe toll on many U.S. communities."

description: U.S. agricultural giant Monsanto unveiled an agreement Monday to buy the Netherlands De Ruiter Seeds Group for 546 million euros ($800 million) in cash.

description: The Delaware Chancery Court made no immediate ruling Monday on a shareholder lawsuit seeking to delay the sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase. The judge said he plans to issue a written ruling on the matter in the next several days.

title: Talks Between Canover and Towergate Said to Stall

Flowers because it significantly undervalues the firm, Friends said. But Friends executive chairman, Adrian Montague, signaled that the company wasnt entirely unwilling to strike a takeover deal with J.C. Flowers.

title: Northern Rock Reports Loss
description: Northern Rock, the British mortgage lender taken over by the government, on Monday reported a loss of 168 million pounds ($333 million) for 2007, compared with a profit of 627 million pounds in 2006, because of costs related to its funding crisis and higher losses on risky assets and home loans.

title: Pop Goes the Alphabet
description: The recent trend in pop-up books has been watchwork complexity and conspicuous feats of engineering. (See Star Wars: A Pop-Up Guide to the Galaxy, which dominated the childrens best-seller list this holiday season.) There have been no shortage of pop-ups marketed to an older audience, either. (Im thinking here of Sam Itas Moby Dick, which topped my gift list.) But heres one perfect for the tyke that you can display with pride on your Noguchi coffee table too: Marion Batailles ABC3D, a deceptively-simple race through through the alphabet thats full of sly visual winks and typographical fun. The video readthrough above is pure pleasure. So much so, it seems, that the book is selling swiftly  it hit #55 in Amazon sales rank last week  even though it wont be released until October. Pekearo and Yevgeniy Marshalik, who were killed on March 14, 2004.

Todd, an architect of the towering Manhattan Plaza complex who later brought an imperturbable style to the chairmanship of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, died on Monday in Manhattan. title: Leveraged Planet
description: JUST before JPMorgan Chase announced its initial $2-a-share deal to buy Bear Stearns, Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, held an extraordinary impromptu conference call. The participants on the Sunday night call, who got a preview of the deal, were Wall Streets biggest power brokers: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs dialed in from home. John Mack of Morgan Stanley rushed to the office to listen on speakerphone. Richard Fuld of Lehman Brothers, who had been directed to return home from a business trip in New Delhi by none other than Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, was patched in, too, among others.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on March 20 about a decision by Iraqs Presidency Council to withdraw objections to legislation on provincial elections referred incorrectly to the effective date of any Iraqi legislation passed into law. Under Iraqs constitution, if the effective date is not specified in the legislation, then it is the date the legislation is published in the newspaper of the Ministry of Justice  not 15 days after publication.

title: Overpromoted Cholesterol Drugs

These drugs were supposed to offer a valuable alternative to the older cholesterol-lowering agents known as statins, a class that includes Lipitor, Zocor and other drugs that not only reduce cholesterol but also reduce the risk of heart attacks. In clinical trial results released this week, the newer drugs failed to reach their main goal: slowing the growth of artery-clogging plaques  a suggestion that they might not help ward off heart attacks.

After 24 years of working and paying taxes in the U.K., I am heading back to North America, where an individual with involvement in, and charitable contributions to, visual arts and classical music is valued, not punished, she wrote in a letter to Robert McNeil, a humor columnist for the newspaper The Scotsman who mocked rich foreign residents. title: Lukas Award Winners Are Named
description: The Nine: Inside the Secret World of the Supreme Court (Doubleday), a portrait of the Supreme Court since the Reagan administration written by Jeffrey Toobin, below, has won the $10,000 J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize, the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and the Nieman Foundation at Harvard University announced. The other winners of this years J. Anthony Lukas Prize Projects Awards were Peter Silver, recipient of the $10,000 Mark Lynton History Prize for Our Savage Neighbors: How Indian War Transformed Early America (W. W. Norton), and Michelle Goldberg, recipient of the $30,000 J. Anthony Lukas Work-in-Progress Award for The Means of Reproduction, to be published by Penguin Press in 2009. title: Pen Rallies Behind Ousted Author
description: When it comes to publicity, being denied entry into the United States may be the best thing that ever happened to Sebastian Horsley, right, unless you count being hung on a cross in the Philippines. Mr. Horsley, the British author of Dandy in the Underworld (Harper Perennial)  a rollicking memoir of his rampant drug use, abundant encounters with prostitutes and that trip to the Philippines to be crucified for an art exhibition  was turned back at Newark Liberty International Airport last month on the grounds of moral turpitude. He was here for a book party and media tour. Now PEN American Center, the writers organization, has invited Mr. Horsley to speak at its annual festival of international literature at the end of this month and written a letter to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff, asking them to admit Mr. Horsley to the country. Francine Prose, president of PEN American Center, said that Mr. Horsley was not originally invited as a speaker, but that his deportation made him a cause clbre. PEN supports freedom of speech and freedom of expression on the most basic level, she said. Writers should be able to enter our country regardless of what theyve written. Mr. Horsley, in a telephone interview from London, said he would absolutely accept PENs invitation if American authorities would let him into the country. The pen is mightier than the sword, he said. And its considerably easier to write with. So far his book has sold only a thousand copies in the United States, according to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks about 70 percent of retail sales.

title: Art Thief Changes Mind, Returns Paintings
description: Seven historic aboriginal paintings, valued at $460,000, were stolen from a museum in Darwin, Australia, before dawn on Tuesday but recovered undamaged about seven hours later after the thief apparently changed his mind, The Associated Press reported. (One of the recovered works is above.) Six of the paintings taken from the Northern Territory Museum and Gallery exemplified the early work of the Papunya Tula movement. Named for an artists collective in central Australia, it is credited with being the first to paint aboriginal tribal motifs on board or canvas, creating a style in the 1970s that became world-renowned. The police said a blood-spattered broken window, security footage and other clues indicated that the thief had smashed into the museum with a rock and spent 15 minutes inside while alarms sounded. The paintings were found in parkland. A 37-year-old man was detained and questioned.

title: Dancing Draws Monday Night Eyes
description: ABC was the most-watched network on Monday night, as roughly 20.3 million viewers tuned in to an extended 96-minute edition of Dancing With the Stars at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Although ABC averaged more total viewers, CBS, the runner-up, edged ahead among adults 18 to 49, thanks to its popular half-hour sitcoms, including Two and a Half Men at 9 p.m. (14.4 million), which led the night among the 18-to-49 set. CBS also dominated the 10 p.m. time slot with CSI: Miami (15.5 million), easily outpacing both NBCs Medium (9.5 million) and the last hour of ABCs Bachelor, which averaged just over 8 million viewers from 9:36 to 11 p.m. NBC ranked third for the night, delivering its largest audience at 9 with Deal or No Deal (10 million) but struggling at 8 with My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad (4.4 million). Fox, fourth in total viewers, tied NBC for third among adults 18 to 49, broadcasting a repeat of House at 8 (7.5 million) followed by New Amsterdam at 9 (6.6 million). On Saturday night Nickelodeons Kids Choice Awards, with Jack Black as host and a performance by Miley Cyrus, drew 7.4 million viewers, the cable channel said on Tuesday. That audience  an increase of 1.3 million viewers, or more than 20 percent, over last year  was the largest in the shows 21-year history.

title: Actors Set Date for Formal Contract Talks With Studios
description: Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild said on Tuesday evening that they had agreed to open formal contract talks with representatives of Hollywood's movie and television companies on April 15. The actors' current contract with the companies expires June 30, and much of the entertainment industry, hoping to avoid a strike similar to a three-month walkout by writers that began last November, has been eager to see the bargaining begin. The actors guild has about 120,000 members. Last weekend, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, which has bargained jointly with the guild in the past, broke off their alliance and said it, too, expected soon to begin negotiating a new contract on its own.

He is planning to take legal action against News of the World, the British tabloid that started the uproar with an article published on Sunday.

title: Life Without Pedro, Again

We are expected to learn about the severity of Pedro Martinezs hamstring strain later today, after he takes an MRI exam in New York. It is possible that he will only miss a few weeks. Anyone who knows David, or has been reading his posts, wasnt surprised that it was smart, witty and elegant. Indeed, it elicited an enormous response. Yet I was troubled by it. David chose as his overrated books D.H. Lawrences Women in Love and the Bible. Im not about to offer a defense of the Bible, but I do want to speak up for Women in Love.

And this is about as easy as it gets, as long as you have the Szechwan peppercorns. Ms. Liebman notes that you can add Chinese Five Spice powder to the mixture, but the simple mixture of Szechuan pepper and salt lets the true essence of pork shine through. title: The Three Hs
description: I had no idea I was going to turn out to be a songwriter. I would bet my next years royalty checks that when I was getting slapped on the butt and crying out my first melodies as a newborn, my parents were not dreaming of the day that their youngest baby boy would grow up to become a songwriter. The family business was an air freight trucking company. So God bless my parents for knowing by my second year in grade school that music was my first love and it wasnt going to be me driving around in the hot Arizona sun at 18 in an Econoline van full of freight to deliver. So with everything I have in me, I thank my mom and dad for letting me follow my intuition.

title: CURRENTS | Development That is Mindful of the Planet and the Budget
description: The David and Joyce Dinkins Gardens, a new affordable housing project on West 153rd Street in Harlem, was built green on a budget. Paul Freitag, the director of development at Jonathan Rose Companies, which built the project with Harlem Congregations for Community Improvement, said its $19.5 million cost was just a fraction more than a conventional affordable housing project of a similar size. You really can do these things for one or two percent more, he added. The 85-unit building has Energy Star-rated appliances and light fixtures, low-V.O.C. paint and nontoxic materials, as well as more elaborate elements like exterior solar shades, a rainwater harvesting system and a green roof. Residents, who include individuals leaving foster care and families earning less than 60 percent of the areas median income, will begin moving in this week.

title: Winning Combination: Food and Song
description: Fox trounced its competitors Tuesday thanks to the combination of American Idol and a strong showing for the start of Hells Kitchen, with Gordon Ramsay, left. Nielsen estimated that the fourth season premiere of the reality cooking show drew 12.6 million viewers, a considerable improvement over the 8.4 million the series averaged last summer. That 9 p.m. show also delivered the nights second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, outpacing a direct competitor, the results episode of Dancing With the Stars, even though that ABC show delivered more total viewers in the hour (16.9 million). Foxs American Idol, meanwhile, achieved the top ratings over all with 25.2 million viewers at 8 p.m. ABC ranked second in total viewers, but fourth among the 18-to-49 set behind CBS and NBC, which tied for second. CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with CSI: Miami (14.3 million), easily outperforming ABCs Barbara Walters special Live to be 150 ... Can You Do It? (10.2 million).

And the three-week Kirov Ballet season that opened at City Center on Tuesday night looks on paper like a major course in the history of ballet classicism. You could know nothing about dance and learn from this season much about the forms of ballet and how they have changed. Audiences perusing the lineups will assume the seasons focus will be on choreography. It has started with the first of two Petipa anthologies and will include a Fokine, a Balanchine and a Forsythe program.

description: Sodexo, the catering company, said first-half sales rose 3.8 percent, to 7.08 billion euros ($11 billion) in the six months through February from 6.82 billion euros a year earlier. Sodexo said North American sales, which make up two-fifths of overall revenue, climbed 5.8 percent, excluding acquisitions and currency movements. Revenue rose 8 percent in Continental Europe excluding takeovers and exchange rates. British and Irish sales gained 22 percent on that basis. The company said sales were helped by bookings it handled for the rugby World Cup.

title: Louisiana: Lawmakers Brother Indicted
description: The older brother of Representative William J. Jefferson, who is facing trial on bribery and racketeering charges, has been indicted on unrelated corruption charges, the United States attorneys office in New Orleans announced. Mose Jefferson, 65, is accused of bribing a former president of the New Orleans school board, Elleneese Brooks-Sims, in order to obtain a lucrative contract for educational software approved. Some $14 million in contracts for the I Can Learn software of JRL Enterprises Inc. was bought; Mr. Jeffersons firm earned about $913,000 in consulting fees from JRL. Ms. Sims has pleaded guilty to taking $140,000 in bribes.

Mugabe and his party have lost control of the nations Parliament, official election returns showed Wednesday, giving new impetus to the bigger question: Does that foretell a loss of the presidency itself, the job he has held tightly for the past 28 years?

title: Women Against Women, From Anywhere in the World

At www.bridgebase.com there will be four 10-board tournaments each day, two for individuals and two for pairs. You can play in as many competitions as you like and get into the spirit of global B.B.O. by competing in the pair events with a partner from another country. Each tournaments entry fee is $1 per person, and the times are 5 a.m., 10 a.m., 3:40 p.m., and 7 p.m. Eastern. As an added incentive, World Bridge Federation master points will be awarded.
