title: Mariah and Madonna Pass by Elvis Presley
description: This week on the Billboard charts one act from MTVs Making the Band supplants another for the No. 1 album, and Mariah Carey and Madonna both nudged past Elvis Presley for historical standings on the singles chart. In a week busy with new albums, the all-male Day26 reached No. 1 with its self-titled debut, selling 190,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, bumping Danity Kane  the all-female Making the Band group that topped last weeks chart  to No. 4, with 89,000. (Both were released by Bad Boy/Atlantic.) Panic at the Discos Pretty. Odd. (Fueled by Ramen/Atlantic) moved 139,000 to reach No. 2. Counting Crows Saturday Nights & Sunday Mornings (Geffen) is No. 3 with 106,000, and the Raconteurs sold 42,000 copies of Consolers of the Lonely (Third Man/Warner Brothers) for No. 7. ... Ms. Careys Touch My Body becomes her 18th No. 1 single; only the Beatles have more, with 20. Madonnas new 4 Minutes, at No. 3, becomes her 37th single in the Top 10, beating Presleys record for the most Top 10 songs.

title: Investigators in Congo Check Allegations That Peacekeepers Engaged in Torture
description: French and Swedish military officials said they were investigating allegations made in a Swedish television report that French soldiers participating in a European Union peacekeeping operation in Congo in 2003 tortured a civilian who was being held prisoner. Uppdrag Granskning, a Swedish television news magazine, broadcast a report based on interviews with Swedish soldiers who said they witnessed the torture, which was said to include mock drowning.

title: A Featherweight Laptop Wrapped in Leather
description: Apple may be aiming at metalheads with its thin MacBook Air, but Asus is chasing the leather crowd. Asuss ultralight laptop, the U2E, has black pebbled leather on the top and the palm rest. The refined look is meant to evoke the days when travelers wouldnt leave home without their leather valises and trunks.

title: Rage Against the Machine With Artisans and Beauty
description: Romantic artists of the 19th century viewed the Industrial Revolution with wary skepticism, if not fear and loathing. That machines might replace skilled artisans and fill the world with affordable but ugly, poorly made junk was a disheartening prospect. So in late-19th-century England the Arts and Crafts movement developed, and in Vienna the Wiener Werksttte was born. Both promoted the viability of good design and fine craftsmanship in the modern world.

title: China Confirms Protests by Uighur Muslims
description: SHANGHAI  Chinese officials said Wednesday that they were grappling with ethnic unrest on a second front, in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, where Uighur Muslims protested Chinese rule last month even as Tibetans rioted in the southwest.

title: Corrections
description: Obituaries

title: With a New Knicks Chief, the Old One Is in Limbo
description: Thousands of children, all giggles and glee, streamed out of Madison Square Garden and into the bright sunlight early Wednesday afternoon. The circus had just shut down for the day, bowing to more sober proceedings in another part of the building.

title: Car Chase in Miami Results in 5-Hour Lockdown at a Mall
description: MIAMI  A car chase involving four young men in a minivan and the young father they are suspected of trying to rob ended Wednesday with the lockdown of one of Miamis largest malls.

title: In Senate, Agreement on Housing
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats and Republicans reached a tentative deal Wednesday on a package of legislation to help homeowners facing foreclosure, including new tax breaks intended to help stabilize the wider housing market.

title: Rolling the Right Way?
description: The Major League Soccer season opened last Saturday, and the league hopes to build on some of the momentum created by David Beckham's arrival last year. But as Taylor Twellman, a striker for the New England Revolution and U.S. National team, tells Jeffrey Marcus of The Times, a couple of factors continue to hurt the league's credibility: the quality of its television broadcasts, especially the announcers, and the inappropriateness of some of its playing surfaces. "I can't tell you how many times I get phone calls making fun of my sport because of the announcing," says Twellman, who lauded ESPN's decision to have J.P. Dellacamara and former U.S. national team captain John Harkes take over the broadcast from Dave O'Brien and the uber-loquacious Eric Wynalda this season. But Twellman still laments the presence of football hash marks in some stadiums and the artificial turf that can produce a different roll and bounce than natural grass. "If the game is on turf, with football lines, I'll tell you right now, I'm not watching the game," he told Marcus.

title: Racing Groups Deal Broke Law, State Says
description: ALBANY  New Yorks thoroughbred racing association broke state law when it granted a no-bid contract to a Manhattan law firm, the State Commission of Investigation said in a report issued Wednesday.

title: World Bank Calls on Sovereign Funds to Invest in Africa
description: WASHINGTON  The president of the World Bank, Robert B. Zoellick, called Wednesday for the major government-owned sovereign wealth funds of Asia and the Middle East to join with the bank in investing in Africa.

title: One Bullet Can Kill, but Sometimes 20 Dont, Survivors Show
description: A man in North Carolina was shot roughly 20 times in 1995 and lived to tell about it. The rapper 50 Cent was shot nine times in 2000 and has since released three albums. And in 2006, Joseph Guzman survived 19 gunshot wounds during the 50-shot fusillade by police detectives that killed Sean Bell.

title: Inspectors for F.A.A. Say Violations Were Ignored
description: WASHINGTON  Three veteran Federal Aviation Administration inspectors told lawmakers on Thursday that their agency supervisors looked the other way while Southwest Airlines neglected to inspect planes as required, and continued to fly them even after discovering cracks in some of them.

title: CURRENTS | An Instant Hangout, Undeniably Splashy
description: The Joule Hotel in Dallas doesnt officially open until next month, but its unusual design is already attracting a fair amount of attention. The 1927 building, which once housed a bank, remains largely unchanged on the outside, with one exception: a plexiglass extension of the 39-foot pool, left, that cantilevers out from the 10th floor and glows at night, far left.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press article on Wednesday about a judges order that Representative Jim McDermott of Washington pay Representative John Boehner of Ohio about $1 million in legal fees in a dispute over an illegally taped telephone call misstated the nature and timing of a Supreme Court ruling on the case. The court let stand a lower court ruling that Mr. McDermott had acted improperly; it did not rule so itself. Also, the court acted in December, not last month.

title: Irelands Prime Minister to Resign Amid Corruption Inquiry
description: DUBLIN  Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland, one of Europes longest-serving leaders, who was closely involved in the negotiations that brought peace to Northern Ireland, announced Wednesday that he would resign next month.

title: Once the Toast, Now Just Toast
description: Last season the Buffalo Sabres were the toast of the N.H.L., a small-market team that had returned from the brink of bankruptcy to lead the league in merchandise sales, TV ratings and, most significantly, the standings. But then their owner, Tom Golisano, the Rochester payroll-processing tycoon, simply stopped spending money. Result: the Sabres' two captains left over the summer and their top defenseman, Brian Campbell, was dealt away at the February trade deadline and promptly sparked San Jose to win 17 of its first 19 games since his arrival. And the Sabres, whose fans are now thoroughly disaffected? They're one loss from becoming only the eighth team in the 80 years of N.H.L. playoffs to fail to qualify for the post-season after finishing first the year before. Here are the other seven:

title: In Rappers Deal, a New Model for Music Business
description: LOS ANGELES  In a move that reflects the anarchy sweeping the music business, the superstar rapper Jay-Z, who released his latest album to lukewarm sales five months ago, is on the verge of closing a deal with a concert promoter that rivals the biggest music contracts ever awarded.

title: Greeces Flexibility on Macedonia
description: To the Editor:

title: In High Prices, Moribund Mines Find a Silver Bullet
description: WALLACE, Idaho  The strangest thing happened here in the Silver Valley as it began the transformation from historic mining camp to yet another Western confection of ski slopes and condos for newcomers with money. The real estate market slowed, and the price of silver soared.

title: Court Approves Review of Countrywide Practices
description: PHILADELPHIA (Dow Jones/AP)  A federal judge has authorized an examination of the mortgage processing systems of the lending giant Countrywide Financial by bankruptcy investigators seeking evidence that the company systematically abuses borrowers.

title: In Limited Release, a Small-Screen Newcomer With Big Promise and a High Price
description: The Sony XEL-1 is a big idea in a small, expensive package. The first television available in the United States to use organic light-emitting diodes, it provides strong contrast, pure blacks and good detail in a screen that is thinner than the cord that powers it.

title: Faster Background Checks Are Pledged
description: The federal Citizenship and Immigration Services agency announced an agreement with the F.B.I. to speed up security background checks of immigrants applying to become permanent residents and United States citizens. The agencies said they would finish by May all background checks that have been backlogged for more than three years and by July for all cases waiting more than two years. The agencies said they planned to expand staff and streamline procedures. Currently, about 66,000 cases have been waiting longer than six months.

title: Fear of Regulating
description: To understand the White Houses blueprint for regulating the financial markets, start with what the Bush administration did not do. It did not offer America a plan to respond to the ongoing credit crisis or to the Federal Reserves dramatic intervention to prevent the collapse of Bear Stearns. It certainly did not provide a roadmap for avoiding this sort of meltdown in the future.

title: Democrats Campaign in Puerto Rico Becomes Entangled in Statehood Issue
description: At 11 a.m. on March 27, hours after an indictment against Gov. Anbal Acevedo Vil of Puerto Rico was unsealed, his allies met members of the rival party in San Juan. The discussion was not about the charges. It was about Senator Barack Obamas campaign.

title: Coming to New York, a Science Event for the Masses
description: Vowing to make New York City the center of the scientific universe  as it is for commerce, art and expensive dining  a panel of university presidents, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein of New York, the actor Alan Alda, the Columbia physicist Brian Greene and a Muppet announced plans on Wednesday for a World Science Festival to be held here at the end of May.

title: Switzerland: Bank Executive Leaves
description: The Credit Suisse Group said David Blumer quit as chief executive of asset management to join the Swiss Reinsurance Company, where he will succeed Roger Ferguson as head of financial services. Mr. Blumer was succeeded by Rob Shafir, the head of the Americas region,. Mr. Ferguson will take a senior position at a major financial institution, Swiss Re said.

title: Farmers Strike in Argentina Is Suspended for Negotiations
description: BUENOS AIRES  Agricultural groups on Wednesday suspended a nationwide farmers strike that shut down highways across the country for 21 days and caused food shortages, in what has become President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchners biggest test to date.

title: Defense Lawyers Fight DNA Samples Gained on Sly
description: The two Sacramento sheriff detectives tailed their suspect, Rolando Gallego, at a distance. They did not have a court order to compel him to give a DNA sample, but their assignment was to get one anyway  without his knowledge.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,002 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Using the Human Touch to Solve Workplace Problems
description: A SMALL company in Jacksonville, Fla., came up with a novel  and sensitive  solution when two crucial employees had trouble making the commute to its new headquarters across town.

title: At NBC, Supersizing the Season
description: Here are some of NBCs big promises: fewer reruns, 65 weeks of new shows, the return of sentimental favorites like E.R. and Friday Night Lights  and more product placements from advertisers in its programs.

title: Leader Quits at the Mount, Former Home of Wharton
description: Following months of increasing financial troubles for the Mount, Edith Whartons home in Lenox, Mass., the president of the organization that owns and maintains the property has resigned rather than accept a new position in a restructured management, trustees said. Under the president, Stephanie Copeland, the Mount was restored to much the way it was when Wharton built it in 1902, and it won several awards for preservation.

title: Wisconsin Voters Excise Editing From Governors Veto Powers
description: Wisconsin governors have long been allowed to sign off on budget bills but do some tricky erasing first. They could delete words, numbers, sentences, paragraphs or some combination of all of those, to create entirely new meanings never intended by the original authors  a legislative twist on the game of Mad Libs.

title: American Questioned in Killing in Japan
description: A 22-year-old United States Navy seaman was questioned by the Japanese police in connection with the killing of a taxi driver last month in Yokosuka, south of Tokyo. The Japanese media reported that the police might seek an arrest warrant for the serviceman, who was being sought for desertion at the time of the taxi drivers death and is now being held on a United States naval base in Yokosuka.

title: Striking an Unlikely Friendship
description: Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Cold Start Catches Up to Mussina and Yankees
description: There were patches of empty seats in the second and third decks at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night, and catcher Jos Molina wore a ski cap under his helmet and mask. The Yankees second game of the season was 20 degrees colder than their first, and A. J. Burnett was not the kind of pitcher who makes a hitter feel warm.

title: Tom Cruise, in Bit Role, Nips Studios Top Gun
description: LOS ANGELES  Take that, Sumner Redstone.

title: Hamas, Jews and Hate Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tale of the Tape and the Talmud
description: Four days before his first North American Boxing Federation title defense, Yuri Foreman sat in the basement of a Brooklyn brownstone studying Shulchan Aruch, the code of Jewish law. By early afternoon, he would be at Gleasons Gym to train for his approaching bout with Saul Romn, a power puncher from Mexico with 24 knockouts in 28 fights.

title: Pope Benedict Evokes Saintliness of John Paul on Anniversary of Death
description: Pope Benedict XVI celebrated a Mass marking the third anniversary of the death of John Paul II, evoking the possibility of his predecessors sainthood by praising his many human and supernatural qualities. While the Vatican normally waits five years after a persons death, two years ago Benedict placed John Paul on an accelerated schedule for beatification, the first step toward sainthood.

title: Ralph Rapson, Modernist Architect, Is Dead at 93
description: Ralph Rapson, the Modernist architect who designed the original Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and a popular rocking chair that bore his name, died on Saturday. He was 93.

title: Ease Your Way -- Well, Not Exactly -- Into the Season
description: Baseball fans celebrate the onset of spring amid the sunshine of Grapefruit and Cactus League contests in Florida and Arizona, respectively. In golf, the Masters traditionally ushers in the new season for devotees of the pro game, but for those who would rather play than watch, Pinehurst, North Carolina, is the place to go. It's the ideal spot to shake off the winter rust.

title: Behind the Scenes of Secret Surveillance and Its Public Unmasking
description: Eric Lichtblau is used to being cast as a hero or a villain for his reporting about the war on terror. This year Mike McConnell, the director of national intelligence, predicted that some Americans are going to die because of the public debate that resulted when Mr. Lichtblau and his New York Times colleague James Risen disclosed the existence of the Bush administrations secret surveillance program; for the same articles Mr. Lichtblau and Mr. Risen won the 2006 Pulitzer Prize for national reporting.

title: On Stand in Officers Trial, Surgeon Details Injuries to Passenger in Sean Bells Car
description: Among the lingering mysteries of the Sean Bell shooting have been how many times the tall, stocky passenger in his car who sustained 19 gunshot wounds was actually shot, and how he lived to tell about it.

title: No Quick Fixes, but Walsh Has Promise of So Much More
description: Lawyer that he is, Donnie Walsh mumbled habeas corpus as he sat down to meet the print media Wednesday in his first charming minutes as president of the decidedly uncharming Knicks.

title: News Corp. Stung by Post-Soviet Politics
description: MOSCOW  As the raw turmoil of a street protest unfolded last autumn in Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, the television cameras rolled, capturing the billows of tear gas, the stone-strewn streets and the bloodied protesters.

title: Next Stop, Broadway, Showbiz Youngsters
description: ABOARD AMTRAKS VERMONTER, just outside Washington  It was 8:15 a.m., which is half-past dark in the theater world, but James Gardiner and Nick Blaemire were already up and on their way. Though Mr. Gardiner had performed in a production of Kiss of the Spider Woman the night before, and they had both gone out with the cast afterward, neither seemed the least bit tired. Mr. Gardiner and Mr. Blaemire, you see, are quite young.

title: Look Whos Best-Dressed Now
description: THE ballots for the 2008 International Best-Dressed List have gone out. The tension mounts! Will Lapo Elkann, the zany Fiat heir, make the list again and line himself up for a place in the Hall of the Forgotten  oops, the Hall of Fame? Will Nicolas Sarkozy be joined by his bride, the former model Carla Bruni? Shes been looking so fabulous in her new Dior clothes.

title: BlackBerrys Maker Beats Forecasters
description: Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry smartphone, reported a fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday that more than doubled and topped analysts estimates as the company added more than two million subscribers.

title: Google Cutting 300 Jobs at DoubleClick
description: In the first sizable layoffs in its history, Google is cutting about 300 jobs from the American operations of DoubleClick, the advertising technology company that it acquired recently, according to a person with direct knowledge of Googles plans.

title: Tip of the Week: Saving Error Messages
description: If you find yourself facing a Windows alert box with far too much arcane error-message information to write down, you can quickly save the message  and save yourself the trouble of trying to remember what it said when talking to a technical support person. Click on the alert box to select it and press Control-C to copy the contents of the error message. Next, open a working word-processing program or e-mail message and press Control-V to paste and save the information.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about diversity among political pundits who appear on cable television coverage of the presidential campaign misspelled the given name of a Fox News anchor who is the host of a show on which Leslie Sanchez, a Mexican-American Republican strategist, recently appeared. He is Shepard Smith, not Shepherd.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Architecture and Big Ideas

title: Talking Sense on Tobacco
description: With all the campaign talk about health care, there is far too little discussion of one of the nations most preventable agent of deadly disease: smoking.

title: Modify the Plan for St. Vincents Hospital
description: To the Editor:

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Where can I find a good restorer for an original Eames lounge chair and ottoman?

title: The Capeman Revisited, Far From Broadway Lights
description: In 1998 The Capeman disappeared into one of American cultures black holes: it failed on Broadway. The musicals songs  music by Paul Simon, lyrics by Mr. Simon with Derek Walcott  were put on a pair of good albums, one sung by the original cast and the other by Mr. Simon. If anyone ever talks about those records, its usually with the prefix the underrated.

title: Wisconsin: Jailed Alderman Loses Race
description: Michael McGee Jr., a Milwaukee alderman who faces charges of extortion and bribery, lost his bid for re-election. Mr. McGee, left, who had been the top vote-getter in a February primary, received 2,244 votes from his mostly black district on the citys North Side, losing to Milele Coggs, a consultant from a political family, who won 3,098 votes, election officials said. Mr. McGee has been held behind bars for 10 months while he awaits his trials.

title: Ballet Theater Settles Bias Suit
description: American Ballet Theater settled an age-discrimination case brought on behalf of a trumpet player in its orchestra, agreeing to give him $18,277 in back pay, but making no admission of wrongdoing. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued the company after the player, Henry Nowak, was released in 2005 at age 74. The commission said that his playing had never been criticized and that a conductor had been heard to say it was time for the orchestras older players to go, including Mr. Nowak. Ballet Theater agreed not to discriminate on the basis of age or to retaliate against those who make age-discrimination complaints, the commission said in announcing the settlement late Tuesday. It also agreed to provide antidiscrimination training to senior staff members, the commission said.

title: Footnote
description: David Cook, an American Idol finalist, was treated at a Los Angeles hospital after Tuesdays show for heart palpitations and high blood pressure and was released, said Nigel Lythgoe, an executive producer of Idol. Mr. Cook performed as usual, but skipped the rest of the show.

title: Ben Carnevale, 92, Basketball Coach and Administrator, Is Dead
description: Ben Carnevale, a successful mens college basketball coach at North Carolina and Navy and later an athletic director and a national and international basketball administrator, died on March 25 at his home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 92.

title: The Would-Be Revivalist
description: SYRACUSE

title: A Not-So-Fine Romance
description: In the aftermath of the Tibet upheavals, the complicated romance between America and China is degenerating into mutual recriminations, muttering about Olympic boycotts and tensions that are likely to rise through the summer.

title: Souping Up a Cellphone for Maximum Multitasking
description: WHAT is the one item you never leave home without? Sure, the American Express folks have you conditioned to think about their product, but the more likely answer is your cellphone.

title: Three Firefighters Hurt in Brooklyn
description: Three firefighters were seriously injured on Wednesday afternoon at a fire in a residential high rise in Brownsville, Brooklyn, fire officials said.

title: 60-Plus, Ripped, and Natural Competitors
description: UNTIL nine years ago, Dr. Neal Grossman didnt make a habit of parading around his bedroom in his skivvies and admiring his physique in the mirror. Nor did he ever imagine that his oldest son, then a teenager, would take one look at his father midflex and cry out, Dad, put your clothes back on!

title: House Approves Anti-H.I.V. Funds
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The House approved a measure on Wednesday to spend $50 billion over the next five years to combat H.I.V./AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis in Africa and the Caribbean.

title: Adrift in the Middle East
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rices latest trip to Israel and Jordan came at a time when anger and frustration among ordinary Israelis and Palestinians are building to dangerous levels. This was a moment for American leadership and direction. Unfortunately, the moment was once again allowed to slip away.

title: O.K., Is This the Year?
description: We asked this last year -- should Kobe Bryant be the N.B.A.'s most valuable player -- but maybe we were a year ahead of ourselves. Bryant is making his case again, this time with a better supporting cast, and has the Lakers atop the Pacific Division. Will he finally win his first M.V.P. award, and should he?

title: Peabody Award Winners
description: Three news reports about Iraq war casualties were among the winners of the 2007 Peabody Awards. Announced on Wednesday by the Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Georgia, the awards are intended to honor the best in electronic media. CBS received two Peabody awards for war coverage, one for a Scott Pelley report on 60 Minutes about the killings of civilians in the Haditha, Iraq, and another for the report by Kimberly Dozier, above, on CBS News Sunday Morning: The Way Home about two female veterans who lost limbs in Iraq. Ms. Dozier was wounded in Iraq in May 2006. Similarly, the ABC News correspondent Bob Woodruff, injured in Iraq in January 2006, received an award for Wounds of War, a series about wounded veterans. Among entertainment series, awards went to 30 Rock, the NBC sitcom inspired by Saturday Night Live; Mad Men, the AMC drama about a 1960s advertising agency; The Colbert Report, the cable news satire on Comedy Central; Project Runway, the fashion reality show on Bravo; and Nimrod Nation, a d Sundance Channel documentary series. The Discovery series Planet Earth and PBSs Nature: Silence of the Bees also received awards.

title: In Rarefied Air, Calipari Reaches for His Pot of Gold
description: One of these things is not like the other. Three of this year's Final Four teams are legendary programs from major state universities, each of them the latest float in a long parade of national title contenders launched from America's power conferences. The other one is Memphis - a somewhat less renowned hotbed of athletics that until fairly recently was known as Memphis State.

title: McCain and Clinton Ads Spar Over Mortgage Crisis
description: PENSACOLA, Fla.  Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton released dueling advertisements Wednesday that highlighted how the housing crisis has come to dominate the presidential race, with Mrs. Clinton using a version of her red-phone commercial to question Mr. McCains ability to handle the souring economy.

title: A Stormy Decade for Citi Since Travelers Merger
description: Ten years ago this Sunday, on April 6, 1998, Sanford I. Weill rewrote the rules of Wall Street.

title: With Orchestral Offering, Festival Passes a Milestone
description: The MATA Festival is celebrating its 10th season, partly by showing off how far it has come since its early days as Music at the Anthology, a new-music series resident at the Anthology Film Archives. Since the Anthology days the festival has traveled a circuit of churches and small halls, but for the last couple of years it has been ensconced at the Brooklyn Lyceum, an old public bath converted into a concert hall. And having presented chamber groups and soloists in its first decade, the five-day festival passed a milestone on Tuesday night, when it imported the energetic Boston Modern Orchestra Project and its conductor, Gil Rose, for its first orchestral offering.

title: France: Concrete Maker Sells Assets
description: Ciments Franais, the international unit of Italcementi of Italy, agreed to sell its Turkish assets to Sibirsky Cement of Russia for 600 million euros ($940 million) in cash and stock. Ciments Franais, based in Paris, will receive 400 million euros and a 5.4 percent stake of Sibirsky, one of Russias largest producers of concrete. The stake was valued at 200 million euros, Ciment Franais said.

title: Bill to Regulate Tobacco Moves Forward
description: The House Commerce Committee approved a bill Wednesday that would give the Food and Drug Administration sweeping regulatory authority over the tobacco industry, clearing the way for a floor vote on the legislation, which has long been sought by antitobacco activists.

title: Maine to Act on ID Law
description: Gov. John Baldacci of Maine reached an agreement with federal officials on Wednesday to insure that the states drivers licenses would remain valid as identification at airports and federal buildings.

title: U.S. Cites Planning Gaps in Iraqi Assault on Basra
description: This article was reported by Michael R. Gordon, Eric Schmitt and Stephen Farrell and written by Mr. Gordon.

title: Perjury Case Goes to Jury
description: The perjury trial of the former cyclist Tammy Thomas went to the jury Wednesday after the government and the defense presented their closing arguments in San Francisco.

title: Thomas Says He Can Share Burden With Walsh
description: MEMPHIS  On the day he was replaced as the Knicks team president, Isiah Thomas said all the right things.

title: Group Seeks E.P.A. Rules on Emissions From Vehicles
description: In a new push to get the federal government to act on global warming, a coalition of states, cities and environmental groups took its fight to federal court on Wednesday.

title: CURRENTS | Paul Evanss Works, From One Who Helped Make Them
description: Dorsey Reading went to work for Paul Evans, the master craftsman, sculptor and furniture designer, two weeks out of high school and stayed for 23 years, until 1982, five years before Evans died at the age of 56. It was an adventure every day, said Mr. Reading, 66, who is now a general contractor living in Erwinna, Pa., surrounded by Evanss bronze, steel, slate and verdigris copper pieces.

title: Israel Slow to Admit Gaza Patients, U.N. Says
description: JERUSALEM  A new report by the World Health Organization says that 32 Palestinians from Gaza have died in recent months largely because of Israeli restrictions that delayed their access to urgent medical treatment in Israel.

title: Hiding Your Face on Facebook
description: Q. Is there a way to share certain pictures in my Photos area on Facebook only with specific friends and not everybody on my Friends list?

title: In Economic Drama, Bush Is Largely Offstage
description: WASHINGTON  The first hint that President Bush might be detached from the nations economic woes was in February, when he conceded that he had not heard about predictions of $4-a-gallon gasoline.

title: A Hit Is Heading for Manhattan
description: Following its critically praised run at the Humana Festival of New American Plays, This Beautiful City, the latest work from the theater troupe the Civilians, has a premiere scheduled for New York. The Vineyard Theater at 108 East 15th Street in Manhattan announced that it would put on the show, a musical docudrama about the megachurch movement in Colorado Springs, Colo., sometime in early 2009, as part of a production with the Center Theater Group of Los Angeles.

title: Iraqs Sunni Time Bomb
description: Washington

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A music review on Wednesday about Norah Jones, at the Living Room, misidentified the Fender guitar she played. It was a Mustang, not a Stratocaster.

title: Fed Chief Sees Possible Contraction in First Half
description: WASHINGTON  In his bleakest economic assessment to date, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Wednesday that the American economy could contract in the first half of 2008, meeting the strict definition of a recession, and he called on Congress to strengthen the nations distressed housing industries.

title: A Reprise of the 3 A.M. Call
description: This 30-second television commercial for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, began running statewide in Pennsylvania on Wednesday. Within hours, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, released a similar advertisement as a rebuttal.

title: Unsold Homes Tie Down Would-Be Transplants
description: Dr. Michele Morgan migrated last fall from Detroit to Phoenix, taking a job as a psychiatrist. She expected her husband, Sam Kirkland, to soon join her, since he was accepting an early retirement package from his employer, General Motors. But he cannot move, he says, because he has not been able to sell the four-bedroom family home.

title: Pope Plans to Visit Manhattan Synagogue
description: At 80, Pope Benedict XVI has limited his coming trip to the United States to 13 public events, but the Roman Catholic Church made a surprise announcement on Thursday that he has added two brief meetings  both with Jewish leaders.

title: A Phone With TV, Radio, Music, G.P.S. and Camcorder
description: The Apple iPhone may have raised the ante for smartphone design last year, but the competition is not just sitting around. Although it has a similar slablike form and touch screen function, the new Samsung Instinct has a few special features of its own, as well as a monogamous marriage with Sprint as its wireless carrier.

title: Paulson Urges China to Move on Market Overhaul
description: BEIJING  Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. ended a two-day visit Thursday by calling for China to move ahead with financial market changes, despite growing concerns about the economic downturn in the United States.

title: The Mets Bounce Back in a Big Way Behind Prez
description: MIAMI  The Mets would not have been struck down by lightning or swarmed by locusts or, even worse, sent plummeting to last place if they lost to the Florida Marlins on Wednesday night. But it is telling, even this early in a season, that the team has responded to the adversity of losing its second ace and mascot, Pedro Martnez, for perhaps the next six weeks.

title: An Impossible Contract, Except That It Wasnt
description: The White House Junior Championship, so called because it is played in the Witte Huis in Amsterdam, was held from March 10 to 15. The diagramed deal was drawn to my attention by Roland Wald from Denmark, who is the commentator coordinator for Bridge Base Online (www.bridgebase.com). It occurred during the round-robin qualifying match between Norway and Poland U25.

title: Secrets From the Temple of Scent
description: AEDES DE VENUSTAS, the quirky fragrance shop on Christopher Street at the corner of Gay Street, is just a few doors down from the site of the historic riots in 1969 that marked the first battle for gay rights. When you walk by on the sunlit sidewalk, 40 proud years of midnight camaraderie and spilled drinks spring to life.

title: European Union to Review Britains Rescue of Bank
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission opened a formal investigation on Wednesday into the bailout of Northern Rock, a process expected to set a precedent on government aid within the 27-nation European Union.

title: Girl Meets Boy, Then Kinetic Melodrama Ensues
description: Dance fans remember Stephen Petronio for the bare bottoms and men in tightly laced corsets, for the pounding rock scores and Baudelairean bad-boy theatricality, and for the cream-of-the-crop cutting-edge composers and fashion designers that he likes to involve in his work.

title: An Ensemble Finds Unity With a Seasoned Soprano
description: If there is such a thing as a typical French composer, it might be Ernest Chausson, whose Poem of Love and of the Sea was sung by Felicity Lott at Tuesdays concert of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. In Chaussons songs there is the ambiguity of souls in need of privacy and solitude and yet filled with the need to be felt by others. Passion subdued by reticence was as necessary to Couperin in the 18th century as to Poulenc in the 20th.

title: Author Clarifies Source of Financing for Cancer Study
description: A 2006 study claiming 80 percent of lung cancer deaths may be prevented with CT scans was paid for by a tobacco company, The New England Journal of Medicine said in corrections and an editorial. Vector Group, parent of Liggett Tobacco, contributed $3.6 million, or virtually all of the financing for the Foundation for Lung Cancer, which backed the study, the author Claudia Henschke said in a clarification published online by the journal. The source of the financing was reported by The New York Times on March 26.

title: New Job for Patrick McEnroe
description: Patrick McEnroe, the Davis Cup captain and a former top-30 player, has been hired to oversee player development for the United States Tennis Association.

title: Is Photo Old or Oldest?
description: Sothebys said on Wednesday that it would postpone the sale of an early photographic print known as a photogenic drawing because some scholars now believe that the print  an image of a leaf  may have been produced much earlier than previously thought, making it the earliest existing photographic image. For many years the image was attributed to William Henry Fox Talbot, one of the fathers of photography, and was thought to have been made in 1839. But Larry J. Schaaf, an expert on Talbots work, questioned that attribution in an essay in the catalog for the photography auction, which will still be held on Monday but without the leaf image, above. Mr. Schaaf wrote that there is evidence to suggest that the work titled Leaf  made by placing a leaf on photosensitive paper exposed to light  could have been created by the early photographic experimenters Thomas Wedgwood, James Watt or Humphry Davy. They are known to have produced photogenic drawings, also called photograms, as early as the 1790s, though no examples have ever been found. Denise Bethel, director of Sothebys photograph department, said the auction house and the images owner, an investment firm called the Quillan Company, had decided to postpone the sale of the print indefinitely until more research could be done.

title: CURRENTS | A Chance to Bend Glass Into a Work of Art
description: Flickinger Glassworks, a company in Red Hook, Brooklyn, bends sheets of glass to create curved windows, display cases, light fixtures and various other items. (The glass faces on the Grand Central Terminal information booth clock were made by Flickinger.)

title: Playing a Sport With Balls and Bats, but No Pitcher
description: Cricket, which its fans say is the worlds second most popular sport, is played by millions of people around the globe. But it is pursued seriously by probably fewer than 1,000 people in New York City, where the game is played in relative obscurity, its matches confined to the corners of the city.

title: Senate Rejects Proposal for More Leeway in Bankruptcies
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday afternoon rejected a proposal to let bankruptcy judges change the terms of subprime mortgages to help financially struggling homeowners.

title: Composing on the Spot, With Help From a Master
description: Jazz improvisation is often misconstrued as merely a blank-slate scrawl, its basic substance involving something clever made up on the fly. The reality has more to do with shorthand strategies, half-tested hypotheses, a resourcefulness in the realm of what-if. Only in rare instances does a group manage coherence without prescriptions, speaking freely and spontaneously but in whole paragraphs, with proper syntax and a persuasive argument.

title: Correction: A Place to Hang Her Hats
description: An article last Thursday about Mimi Weddell, a 93-year-old model and the subject of the documentary film Hats Off, misspelled the name of the designer of one of the hats in her large collection. It is Adolfo, not Adolpho.

title: When a House Is (or Is Not) Where the Heart Is
description: To the Editor:

title: Dilbert the Inquisitor
description: ONE afternoon last week I found myself sitting at a desk that was not mine, answering to a name that was not mine, and fielding phone calls and e-mail messages from colleagues who dont exist. I held a meeting with an actor pretending to be a passive-aggressive employee who was sabotaging a new sales plan with his vocal disapproval. I had a conference call with an actress who was convincingly frosty as she refused to share key research and manpower that her department had and mine needed. In other words, I spent that day doing what a growing number of employees will do if they are to reach a position of power or potential: I was being assessed.

title: Actors Set Talks
description: Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild said on Tuesday evening that they had agreed to open formal contract talks on April 15 with representatives of Hollywoods movie and television companies. The current contract for the 120,000-member actors union expires on June 30, and much of the entertainment industry, hoping to avoid a strike similar to a three-month walkout by writers that began in November, has been eager for bargaining to begin. Last weekend the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, which has bargained jointly with the guild in the past, broke off its alliance and said it, too, expected to begin negotiating a new contract on its own soon.

title: Knicks Try New Tack: Better Ties to Media
description: The hiring of a team president is rarely accompanied by the announcement that he will alter the restrictive ways that the franchise deals with the news media. Most teams view a good relationship with the press as important, especially when they are losing.

description: Q. Im still using Outlook 2003, which only allows me to add holidays to my calendar through 2007. Is there a way to get updated holiday information for the program?

title: CURRENTS | Discounts of Up to 70 Percent at Conrans Sample Sale
description: Discounts of up to 70 percent will be taken on furniture, accessories and textiles at Conrans annual sample sale on April 11 and 12, from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Merchandise will be sold as is, in limited quantities. Among the pieces that will go on sale are a modern sleeper sofa ($1,995, marked down from $2,850); stacking chairs for children by Robin Day ($34 each, reduced from $48); the Domino Extending Table, which seats eight people ($2,075, marked down from $3,195); and wood-frame Manilla side chairs and armchairs, left, with sea-grass seats ($162 to $185, from $325 to $375). The Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street, (212) 755-9079.

title: Book Unit to Skip Advances and Share Profits
description: HarperCollins Publishers, in an effort to address one of the more vexing issues of the book industry, is forming a publishing group that will substitute profit-sharing for cash advances and attempt to eliminate the costly practice of allowing booksellers to return unsold copies.

title: Proof That Spring Can Keep a Promise
description: WINTERTHUR, Del.

description: Yahoo, the second-most-popular Internet search engine, upgraded its mobile phone software, OneSearch, to allow voice queries and provide more information in results.

title: Redskins Are the New Adventure for Zorn
description: ASHBURN, Va.  Inside an office the size of a large bedroom, opposite the giant flat-screen television, behind the oak desk and next to the unpacked boxes, Jim Zorn sat in a leather chair. Two laptops hummed behind him.

description: Raucous and bawdy, Repertorio Espaols production of Doa Flor and Her Two Husbands begins with a bang: carnival in Bahia, with exuberant music and dancing, revelers in colorful costumes (lots and lots of feathers) and a man in a dress, sporting a stuffed phallus. This adaptation of Jorge Amados Brazilian novel (in Spanish with simultaneous English translation via headsets) is a sex farce with the clarity and logic of a folk tale.

title: Weak Economy Sours Publics View of Future, New Poll Finds
description: Americans are more dissatisfied with the countrys direction than at any time since the New York Times/CBS News poll began asking about the subject in the early 1990s, according to the latest poll.

title: Mother and Unborn Child Pursue Dad on a Dusty Trail
description: Its not hard to find people who will tell you how strange a trip parenthood can be, and with Silver Bullet Trailer, the actress-playwright Julie Shavers gives pregnancy and childbirth the most surreal, acerbic scrutiny.

title: 3 Ranger Scorers Try to Adjust to a Defensive Strategy
description: The Rangers three lions do not need the captain and assistant captain letters on their uniforms to signify their importance. Jaromir Jagr, Brendan Shanahan and Martin Straka are the teams three oldest players and among the most decorated, with two of them carrying multiple Stanley Cups on their rsums.

description: The citys Department of Housing Preservation and Development failed to properly supervise a major subsidized housing program, raising concerns about unqualified applicants being awarded apartments, according to an audit by the New York City comptrollers office.

title: Mayor Presses for $8 Fee for Drivers to Enter Parts of Manhattan
description: ALBANY  The plan to charge drivers $8 to enter Manhattan below 60th Street met with stiff resistance from Democrats in the State Assembly on Wednesday night, suggesting that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a difficult path ahead of him to persuade lawmakers to pass the initiative.

title: Gladiators of the Dance in the Arena of Reality TV
description: If reality television can be said to have an auteur at the moment, it is surely the Bravo channel itself, purveyor of the idea that creativity is born neither in solitude nor in serendipity but in the bloody spirit of vigorous contest. Having made incalculable cultural contributions with Project Runway, Top Chef and even Shear Genius, Bravo has now come up with Step It Up & Dance, a competition that makes literal the cuts and bruises of the career-building genre. Calves swell and hopes cave by the end of the first episode on Thursday, when the parting words take ominous form: The shows over. Its time for your last dance. Step It Up penetrates the freakishly curious world of the aspiring theatrical dancer.

description: In the latest sign of troubles in the airline business, ATA Airlines shut down on Thursday, canceling all flights after filing for bankruptcy.

description: PIKIN SARON, Suriname  The Netherlands may have relinquished control of this South American country in 1975, but one day last month it seemed as if it had never left as Sergeant Major Bart Cobussen expounded on killing techniques in the Surinamese jungle for two Dutch platoons at their camp here.

description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi security forces fanned out into the suburbs and ports of Basra on Wednesday, as life in that southern city slowly began to return to normal, with government offices reopening and residents venturing more confidently into the streets.

description: TRENTON  Disrupting the highly choreographed world of New Jersey politics, a veteran United States representative from South Jersey said Wednesday night that he would challenge Senator Frank R. Lautenberg for the Democratic nomination.

title: Report Faults States Approval of Crane Operator Licenses
description: A longtime state employee approved crane operator licenses for 210 people who had failed a licensing exam, according to a report issued on Wednesday by the state inspector generals office. The report did not identify a motive and said there was no evidence of bribery.

description: A chart with an article on Wednesday about United States auto sales for February carried a number of outdated figures and misidentified the vehicles that were pictured.

He is Geoffrey Davis, not Jeffrey.

title: In Nepal, Long-Lived Monarchy Fades From View
description: GORKHA, Nepal  This is the cradle of the kingdom, from where, more than 250 years ago, a shrewd and ambitious king named Prithvi Narayan Shah set off to conquer faraway lands and create the nation now known as Nepal. Here today stands a gleaming white marble memorial in his honor, except that on the pedestal where his likeness once stood, His Majestys name inscribed below, there is now something decidedly less majestic: a pot of pink geraniums.

title: Alitalias Board Seeks Options After Deal Collapses

Yet at a recent education conference in Nashville, there was a fellow from the conservative Hoover Institute, Eric A. Hanushek, gushing with praise for Ms. Weingarten, and promising to do all he could to support her bid to become the president of the American Federation of Teachers, the national union.

But it also includes the T-Mobile Hotspot@Home technology that lets you make calls from anywhere in the world over Wi-Fi networks.

title: Suit on Light Cigarettes Is Thrown Out

description: BUCHAREST, Romania  President Bush threw the NATO summit meeting here off-script on Wednesday by lobbying hard to extend membership to Ukraine and Georgia, but he failed to rally support for the move among key allies.

description: Mime, rap, dance and song. Elephants, surly tigers, Frisbee-crazy dogs, horseback-riding goats, parading llamas and a trained porcupine.

title: Caught Between a Crackdown and a Tibetan Welcome
description: THE ride in the Chinese minivan had taken 11 hours. After enduring multiple delays, the crossing of a treacherous 16,000-foot mountain pass and a seatmate who chain-smoked the entire way, casually flicking the ashes into his lap, I had arrived in Dege. I was in the culturally Tibetan area of western Sichuan Province, practically on the border of the Tibetan Autonomous Region. I had come to Dege to visit the sacred Bakong monastery, which is both the worlds largest library of ancient Tibetan Buddhist texts and a printing house where monks hand-ink thousands of pieces of religious paraphernalia every day.

description: Sherry Britton, whose hour-glass figure, jet-black hair and rambunctious presence made her one of the queens of the burlesque stage in the 1930s and 40s, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

description: About one-third of Americas eighth-grade students, and about one in four high school seniors, are proficient writers, according to results of a nationwide test released on Thursday.

The 451 Group reports that tech-related deal volume fell only modestly in the first quarter of 2008, declining 8 percent to $92 billion from $100 billion in the comparable period a year earlier. title: Scent Notes | Daisy by Marc Jacobs
description: What in the world is the point of Daisy? I have rarely smelled a perfume with a personality so impossible to pin down. Chimerical. Start with the most basic question: Is it good or bad? Hard to say. What do you consider good? A perfume with a clear character? Then no. Daisy, a 2007 launch that the perfumer Alberto Morillas crafted under the creative direction of Marc Jacobs and Cotys vice president of marketing, Michael DArminio, is almost mesmerizing in its violent resistance to being mesmerizing. A perfume built to play a specific role? Then emphatically yes. Floral without flowers, sweet without sugar, somehow a pretty face without allowing a single feature of that face ever to come into distinct focus. (The only distinct aspect here is its demographic appeal: the perfume skews young.) It seems to have a peculiar engineering that allows it to melt into any background, to speak with a female voice emanating from invisible speakers somewhere over your head, to travel under any door like smoke and occupy, comfortably if spectrally, any space.

title: Ligurian Fish Dishes
description: Eating at the decent fish joints in Liguria, youre virtually guaranteed of one thing: local fish, caught that day. At La Prua, a seaside restaurant in Alassio, I had a plate of raw seafood, just brought in by a boat, that had on it tuna; gamberi (shrimp); langoustine; rascasse (the classic bouillabaisse fish); and clams and an oyster. All of which was fine, and all drizzled with good oil, of course. The most delicious  and unusual  of the lot were the raw shrimp, where were unbelievably creamy in texture. Couldve eaten a dozen, easily.

title: A Non-Executive Decision
description: Even John McCain isnt old enough to remember the presidential race of 1908, which featured two highly distinguished nominees: William Howard Taft, the appointed governor-general of the Philippines, and William Jennings Bryan, the famed Nebraska populist, who was making what would be his third and final doomed run at the White House. For all their accomplishments, though, what neither of these men could claim was any service as an elected executive  that is, as mayor or governor or vice president or president. I mention this only because in the 100 years since, at least as far as I can tell (though perhaps one of you history buffs can prove me wrong), America has never faced a choice between two candidates who lacked any previous executive experience. (Some might argue, of course, that the vice presidency shouldnt really count as an executive office, given the limited roles accorded many running mates, but most vice presidents do have to deal with Congress as representatives of the executive branch at one time or another.)

title: Pope Plans Visit to a New York Synagogue
description: Updated, 6:30 p.m. |Pope Benedict XVI has added a new stop to his New York itinerary this month, the first papal visit to a synagogue in the United States and only the third such visit by a pope to any synagogue. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops announced today that the pope will visit Park East Synagogue at 164 East 68th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues on the afternoon of April 18, the day he arrives in the city. (Laurie Goodstein of The Times has more details in this article for Friday editions.)Pope Benedict was invited by Rabbi Arthur Schneier, the leader of Park East Synagogue. This would be only the third papal visit to a synagogue anywhere. The pope visited the Cologne Synagogue in his native Germany in April 2005, and Pope John Paul II visited the Rome Synagogue in Italy in April 1986.

title: No Justice, No Mani-Pedi!
description: Susan Kim has sparked a nail salon rebellion of sorts in the New York metro region. Ever since word of her victorious labor lawsuit against her former employer in October (which awarded her more money than she asked for) spread in the immigrant press, nail salon workers have been approaching advocacy groups and speaking up about their working conditions.Among those who were motivated by her case were three Latino manicurists in Connecticut, including Irma Karina Vivar, who said she heard Ms. Kim speak at a meeting organized by the National Mobilization Against Sweatshops.

title: Corporate Espionage?
More Trouble at Heathrow? Naomi Campbell Enters Fray
description: In February, Naomi Campbell said that her court-ordered sanitation vacation and anger-management training changed her ways. But an issue involving her baggage at Heathrow Airport has reportedly sent the supermodel with a temper over the edge once more.

title: Harassment at Obamas Church Is Detailed
description: After mostly avoiding the media and declining interview requests, officials at Trinity United Church of Christ, home church to Senator Barack Obama and Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr, changed tactics Thursday, and described how the church has faced threats and other forms of harassment in recent weeks.

title: Four Marquee Coaches
description: Much has been made of the powerhouse teams in the Final Four, but each of them is also led by a big-name coach.

title: Joba Steps Carefully in the Clubhouse
description: My children sometimes pretend that parts of our carpet are hot lava, and Im absolutely not allowed to step there. I can tiptoe around them or jump over them, but I must not touch the hot lava. Its a variation on the old sidewalk-stepping game of step on a crack, break your mothers back. And its alive and well in the Yankees clubhouse.

title: M.L.S. By the Numbers, $$$ Numbers That Is
description: The Los Angeles Galaxy went to Asia and Australia during their Major League Soccer preseason, reaping hefty appearance fees and showing off their so-called talisman, David Beckham, to some adoring fans. Then the club returned home to start its league season and fell flat, a feeble 4-0 flat in the high-altitude of Colorado last week.

title: Frosty Freeze, B-Boy
description: An excerpt from the 1983 documentary "Style Wars" featuring the late Wayne Frost, a k a Frosty Freeze, the breakdancing icon.

description: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

title: Calm  and Hope  in Indianapolis
description: Ron Klain was a member of Bill Clintons 1992 campaign policy and debate preparation staff. (Full biography.)

title: Poll Shows Economic Woes
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that Americans are unsure about their economic future.

title: Hamptons Return With Braves Is Delayed
description: ATLANTA  Twenty thousand people had their fingers crossed for Mike Hampton here Thursday night. It did not do any good.

title: Blue Blood Final Four
description: North Carolina, Kansas and U.C.L.A. may be college basketball blue bloods, but in the past 25 years, they have only four titles between them.

title: Clinton Jokes About Her Tuzla Tale
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has clearly learned Rule 1 of show business - never upstage the star. She appeared on Jay Lenos The Tonight Show on Thursday night and pretty much stuck to her standard campaign fare - education, the woes of the middle class, the errors of the Bush administration, the dispute over the Florida and Michigan delegations.

title: Play It Again, Sam (Re-enactments, Part One)
description: So, how is it that you managed to be on the roadway that night? The question was posed by a reporter from the Dallas Morning News. This was in 1988, during an interview about my recently released film, The Thin Blue Line. I had decided for the first time as a documentary filmmaker to use slow-motion re-enactments in my account of the wrongful conviction of Randall Dale Adams for the murder of Dallas Police Officer Robert Wood.

title: Play It Again, Sam (Re-enactments, Part One)
description: O body swayed to music, O brightening glance,How can we know the dancer from the dance? -W.B. Yeats, "Among School Children"

title: Battle for Hearts & Minds
description: A top terrorism expert believes Abu Yahya Al-Libi has revealed the secret to bringing down the global Jihadist movement.

title: The Chronicles of Ovechkin
description: Luc Robitaille scored 63 goals for the LA Kings in the 1992-93 season. It used to be the record for left wings.

title: Spanish builder looking to grow presence in New York City
description: With the Spanish market struggling, a Barcelona-based developer is finding success with its first U.S. project.

title: Jagr Nets 2 as Rangers Clinch Playoff Spot
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Rangers have carried different emotions off the ice at Nassau Coliseum  frustration, anger, relief among them  but they found a new one (joy) Thursday night when they clinched their third consecutive playoff berth with a 3-0 victory over the Islanders.

title: Singing Conductor Averts Opera Disaster
description: At the Pittsburgh Opera a performance of Aida on Tuesday became a night to remember, ending with the conductor singing the tenor role of Radames from the pit in the fourth act while continuing to lead the orchestra. The sequence that led to the grand finale concluded with cheers and applause for the singing conductor, Antony Walker, above, who is also the music director of the Pittsburgh Opera. Vladimir Kuzmenko, who was supposed to sing the leading role of Radames, began to feel ill before the curtain went up. The company arranged to borrow Eduardo Villa from the Metropolitan Opera, but his plane was delayed. By Act IV Mr. Kuzmenko could no longer sing, and Mr. Villa had not arrived, The Pittsburgh Tribune-Review reported. So Christopher Hahn, the artistic director, asked Mr. Walker to step in. With the silent Mr. Kuzmenko acting the role onstage, Mr. Walker, who studied voice at the University of Sydney in Australia, sang Radames while he led the orchestra. It was quite a nerve-racking thing to do, but I realized there wasnt much choice, Mr. Walker said. Mr. Hahn said, This could be one for the history books, I think.

title: Council Considers Testing Water for Traces of Drugs
description: New York Citys vast drinking water supply system provides 1.1 billion gallons a day of water containing minute amounts of pain relievers and other medications. The city does not test for the presence of such drugs, and members of the City Council want to know why.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline on a report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about a posthumous Medal of Honor for Michael A. Monsoor, a member of the Navy Seals who threw himself on a grenade in Iraq to save his colleagues, misstated his rank. He was a petty officer second class; he was not a commissioned Navy Officer. Because of an editing error, the report also misstated the number of people who have received the honor since the beginning of the Afghanistan and Iraq wars. Petty Officer Monsoor became the fourth, not the fifth.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 28 through April 2 with 1,368 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,196 said they were registered to vote.
