description: Vineyard Estates at Kluge Estate Winery

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: A Birds-Eye Perspective and a Seamans Sensitivity to the Sky
description: The folk artist Earl Cunningham (1893-1977) romanticized the American landscape without hyperbole. Cunningham didnt suffuse his paintings with divine light or invoke manifest destiny, like the Hudson River School artists; he simply showed the many small interactions of the Atlantic coastal ecosystem  a delicate balance of dock workers, harbor pilots, fishermen, farmers, waterfowl and American Indian tribes. His landscapes are as sustainable as they are beautiful.

title: In California, a Lawsuit Is Allowed Against Web Site
description: A Web site that matches roommates can be sued for violating fair housing laws by helping users describe their preferences, an expanded panel of the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled. Chief Judge Alex Kozinski, joined by seven judges, ruled that the site, Roommates.com, was not protected by a 1996 federal law that gave immunity to Internet service providers that transmit unlawful materials supplied by others, because the site may have participated in unlawful conduct by asking users for information through a series of menus. Judge M. Margaret McKeown, dissenting with two other judges, said the decision threatens to chill the robust development of the Internet.

title: What Did You Sing in the War, Daddy? A 1940s Revue
description: When the Lights Go On Again may call itself a new 1940s musical, but this flimsy potpourri of World War II songs enjoying an extended run of Friday and Saturday performances at the Triad Theater trots out every clich of so-called wartime nostalgia. Its four cheery singers  Bill Daugherty, Eli Schneider, Christina Morrell and Connie Pachl  play the Moonlighters, a vaguely Modernaires-like vocal group, whose live broadcast from the Roosevelt Hotel in New York is interrupted by an announcement of the bombing of Pearl Harbor.

title: Voodoo Health Economics
description: Elizabeth Edwards has cancer. John McCain has had cancer in the past. Last weekend, Mrs. Edwards bluntly pointed out that neither of them would be able to get insurance under Mr. McCains health care plan.

title: Unemployment Rate Rises After 80,000 Jobs Cut
description: The economy shed 80,000 jobs in March, the third consecutive month of rising unemployment, presenting a stark sign that the country may already be in a recession.

title: Space Opera Returns: One Last Step for Mankind
description: Earth, not space, is the final frontier of Battlestar Galactica.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A dance review on March 18 about the Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater, at the Merce Cunningham Studio, omitted the designer of the projections seen during Guernica and referred incorrectly to the program. She is June Kosloff, and she was in fact credited on the program.

title: In Plainfield, N.J., 27 Are Arrested in Raid Aimed at Gangs
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J.  It is not uncommon for shots to ring out at night in the West End housing projects, where public surveillance cameras rise over parking lots. Across town, private cameras guard historic homes in the exclusive Sleepy Hollow section where the former governor, James E. McGreevey, lives.

title: Listen Up, Boys: Break Fizzy and Fake Insouciance
description: In the good old days, around 1925, according to Leatherheads, professional football was a lot more fun, a rough, ragged enterprise, untrammeled by corporate influence and unconstrained by rules and regulations. And in the slightly more recent old days  the 30s and 40s, more or less  movies were also more fun. They had zip, pep, moxie, trains, hats and double-entendres.

title: Pitfalls of the First Purchase
description: A SECOND home  its a dream come true, right? Unfortunately, some first-time buyers make rookie mistakes that can turn owning a vacation house into a nightmare. Here are a few tips to avoid them.

title: This Year, Buckeyes Take Home a Trophy
description: For the second year in a row, Ohio State was finishing the season in a championship game. And while the prestige of playing in the National Invitation Tournament final can hardly match that of the N.C.A.A. tournament decider, the Buckeyes appeared grateful that the result was different.

title: Chinese Rights Activist Is Jailed
description: BEIJING  A Chinese court sentenced an outspoken human rights advocate on Thursday to three and a half years in prison after ruling that his critical essays and comments about Communist Party rule amounted to inciting subversion, his lawyer said.

title: On the Road, With Melancholia and a Hankering for Pie and Ice Cream
description: Anyone who has been to Las Vegas, Memphis or New York  or who has received postcards from friends in those cities  is likely to find My Blueberry Nights, Wong Kar-wais first English-language feature, wildly unrealistic, even though much of it was shot on location in the real-deal U.S.A. The smoky Tennessee juke joint and the cute little Manhattan bakery-cafe look like theme restaurants catering to the tourist trade, and even the highways snaking through the mountains and deserts have the inauthentic glow of rental-car advertisements. Mr. Wong and his cinematographer, Darius Khondji, make America look so pretty that you may have trouble recognizing it.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 28 through April 2 with 1,368 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,196 said they were registered to vote.

title: Judges Push to Wrap Up French Trader Inquiry
description: PARIS  The judges leading the investigation of Jrme Kerviel, the Socit Gnrale employee blamed for trading losses of nearly 4.9 billion euros ($7.2 billion), are expected to conclude their work by summer, with a trial likely to begin in early 2009, lawyers said Friday.

title: Wayne Frost, Pioneering Break Dancer, Dies at 44
description: Wayne Frost, a hip-hop pioneer known as Frosty Freeze who helped inspire a worldwide break-dancing craze in the early 1980s as a member of the influential group Rock Steady Crew, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 44.

title: In the Battle for the Democratic Nomination, a Ray of Hope for House Republicans
description: WASHINGTON - Representative John A. Boehner, having fought his way back from exile to be elected leader of House Republicans, is no stranger to political intrigue and calculation. With his ever-ready pack of Camels, he is a virtual one-man smoke-filled room.

title: Optimist Awash in the Tropics
description: Love blossoms fast and early in Bartlett Shers rapturous revival of Rodgers and Hammersteins South Pacific, which opened Thursday at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center. And while you may think, But this is so sudden, you dont doubt for a second that its the real thing.

title: Coal Company Verdict in West Virginia Is Thrown Out
description: The State Supreme Court for a second time threw out a $50 million verdict against the coal company Massey Energy. The court decided to rehear the case after the publication of photographs of its chief justice on vacation in Monte Carlo with the companys chief executive, Don L. Blankenship. The chief justice, Elliott E. Maynard, and a second justice disqualified themselves from the rehearing and were replaced by appeals court judges, but the vote was again 3-to-2 in favor of Massey. A third justice, Brent D. Benjamin, who was elected to the court with the help of more than $3 million from Mr. Blankenship, refused to recuse himself.

title: Air America Host Suspended for Clinton Slur
description: Randi Rhodes, left, an afternoon host for the Air America radio network, was suspended on Thursday after repeatedly insulting Hillary Rodham Clinton at an event last month. On March 22 Ms. Rhodes used vulgar language that likened Ms. Clinton to a prostitute at an event sponsored by KKGN-AM, the Air America affiliate in the San Francisco area. A video of Ms. Rhodess remarks was posted on Tuesday on YouTube. Charlie Kireker, the chairman of Air America, said in a statement that the radio network encourages strong opinions about public affairs but does not condone such abusive, ad hominem language by our hosts. The network called Ms. Rhodess suspension indefinite and did not elaborate on the fate of her daily three-hour radio show. Sam Seder, another Air America host, was scheduled to fill in for Ms. Rhodes on Thursday. On the video Ms. Rhodes is also shown using derogatory language to describe Geraldine Ferraro, a former congresswoman and Democratic nominee for vice president. Ms. Ferraro resigned from a committee of Ms. Clintons campaign last month after making controversial remarks about Barack Obama.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Starbucks Sued in New York Over Tip Issue
description: A former barista sued Starbucks on Thursday, accusing the company of cheating thousands of baristas in New York State by giving a share of their tips to shift supervisors.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Art With Baggage in Tow
description: Who knew that the first Louis Vuitton boutique in Brooklyn would touch down smack in the middle of an exhibition in one of the boroughs most venerable art institutions?

title: Appeals Court Panel Throws Out Class Action Over Light Cigarettes
description: In a victory for the tobacco industry, a federal appeals court threw out on Thursday an $800 billion class-action lawsuit on behalf of smokers who said they had been misled that light cigarettes were safer than regular ones.

title: At Hearing, Pointed Questions About What Led to a Bailout
description: I love the ritual, growled Robert S. Bennett, the influential Washington lawyer as he sucked on a lozenge. He eyed the clutch of photographers swarming around Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke, the clicking of shutters rising up like a storm of insects in the committee room.

title: Correction: The United Plates of New Jersey
description: An article last Friday about the diverse eating spots that can be found off the New Jersey Turnpike misstated the location of the pizzeria Palmermos and the given name of the founder of Carvel. The pizzeria is at 674 Route 206 south, not 260 south, and the founder of Carvel is Tom Carvel, not Frank.

title: Needing Room to Grow, Jets Build Dream Home
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  From a terrace at the Jets under-construction palace of a practice facility and headquarters, Woody Johnson fixed his gaze on an old tree between two fields. The tree has a split trunk, forcing its branches upward into a shape Johnson hopes will signal a new era for the football team he owns.

title: Navigating a Zigzag Course in a Sea of Relationships
description: Jellyfish is the kind of movie  not quite ubiquitous, but not exactly rare either  in which the accidental connections between lonely city dwellers are given a magical glow of serendipity. Like Miranda Julys Me and You and Everyone We Know and Jill Sprechers Thirteen Conversations About One Thing  Los Angeles and New York variations on this conceit  Jellyfish, which takes place mainly in Tel Aviv, seeks out mystical patterns in the drab fabric of modern existence. Its characters are, for the most part, lost, glum and confused, but their crisscrossing stories nonetheless seem charmed.

title: Rabbi Herbert A. Friedman, Israel Backer, Dies at 89
description: Rabbi Herbert A. Friedman, who as chief executive of the United Jewish Appeal raised more than $3 billion to support the fledgling state of Israel and led efforts to close the educational gap there between European Jews and those from other lands, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Little Show, Big Break
description: In what could be Broadways most profound exercise in postmodernism, [title of show], the scrappy little musical about trying to put on a scrappy little musical, is heading to Broadway. The show, written by Jeff Bowen and Hunter Bell and directed by Michael Berresse, is scheduled to begin previews at the Lyceum Theater on July 5 with an opening date of July 17. Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller lead the producing team, which includes the Vineyard Theater, where [title of show] made its Off Broadway debut in 2006. The full cast  the two writers; Susan Blackwell; Heidi Blickenstaff; and the musical director, Larry Pressgrove  has been busy over the last few months with their online series, The [title of show] Show at titleofshow.com, about trying to get the musical to Broadway. They are all signed on for the Broadway run.

title: Like Old Times for the New Kids
description: No longer new, no longer kids, the boy band New Kids on the Block has reunited and is planning a new album and a tour, The Associated Press reported. After selling 70 million albums in the 1980s and early 90s, the group disbanded in 1994. Donnie Wahlberg, who went on to act on television and in films, said he was persuaded to rejoin his former band mates  Joey McIntyre, Danny Wood and the brothers Jordan and Jonathan Knight  when they decided to record new music. Mr. Wahlberg, 38, said he wrote 80 percent of the new material with Mr. McIntyre and Jordan Knight. I had no interest in going out on a nostalgia tour and singing the same material, he said. But he promised, We will absolutely do the old songs for sure.

title: For L.P.G.A. Amateur, a Major Is a Family Tradition
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Myra Blackwelder was walking outside the ropes of the Mission Hills Country Club course that she played many times in her professional golf career. She wore a sleeveless University of Kentucky golf shirt and a blue baseball cap that identified her as Coach B.

title: UBS Chairman Rejects Calls to Shift Investment Banking Unit
description: LONDON  As investors stepped up pressure on UBS to consider a breakup in the wake of more write-downs this week, the chairman, Marcel Ospel, said Friday that dividing the Swiss banks investment arm from its booming wealth management business would be a mistake.

title: The Last Run
description: I WAS somewhere below the knob on Horizon Ridge, midway through a long solo slog from the Ostrander Ski Hut in Yosemite last spring, dogged by deep slush, mud, a too-heavy pack and a hopelessly broken binding. It was late in the afternoon, with at least five miles yet to go, when I finally realized: the end of ski season was no longer merely nigh, but hard upon me.

title: Train Skip Your Stop? Its No Mistake, Its Just the Weekend
description: Human affliction is a steady travel companion of subway riders.

title: Robert Brown, Chief of Editor & Publisher, Dies at 95
description: Robert U. Brown, who spent four decades heading a leading newspaper industry trade publication, Editor & Publisher, died on March 20 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 95.

title: Footnotes
description: The Grammy-nominated rapper Remy Ma, facing sentencing on April 22 after her conviction in New York last month for shooting another woman in a dispute over missing cash, plans a jailhouse wedding to her boyfriend, the rapper Papoose. Ivan Fisher, the lawyer for Remy Ma, whose real name is Remy Smith, said the couple hoped to marry at Rikers Island jail before her sentencing. She faces a maximum of 25 years in prison. A jail spokesman could not immediately confirm the details. ... The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has set April 28 for the start of negotiations on a new prime-time television contract, the union announced on its Web site, aftra.org. Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild said earlier that they would begin formal contract talks on April 15.

title: Senate Rejects a Proposal to Allow Bankruptcy Judges to Alter Home Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday rejected a proposal to let bankruptcy judges modify mortgages on primary residences to help financially distressed homeowners, but lawmakers continued to work on a bipartisan bill that includes other foreclosure assistance as well as tax breaks intended to stabilize the housing market.

title: Chiles Salmon Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma on the Rise, Along With Prospects for a Cure
description: When bad news comes along, its only human nature to wonder why. When the diagnosis is cancer, research increasingly provides an answer. Smoking lurks behind lung cancer. The hepatitis virus can turn liver cells malignant. Genes play a role in a whole host of tumors.

title: Roger P. Lang, an Architect Who Supported Preservation, Dies at 64
description: Roger P. Lang, an architect who often served as the public voice of the historical preservation movement in New York City, died Monday in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in the Yorkville section.

title: After Backing Father in Murder Trial, Sons Now Blame Him
description: Just a year ago, the testimony of Marcus and Stephan Odierno helped spare their father, Ben, an Upper East Side landlord, from spending the rest of his life in prison for killing their mother.

title: The Deals Made to Go on in a So-Called Simple Life
description: Who, if given a choice, would want to grow up on the cold, arid steppe of Inner Mongolia, the setting of Wang Quan Ans absorbing film Tuyas Marriage? The climate is so inhospitable that life is a grinding struggle for subsistence. Water is scarce and must be lugged by hand from distant wells. Yet the movie finds an austere beauty in this landscape of scrub and grassland ringed by forbidding slate-blue mountains. The camera frequently draws back to take in the spectacle of people dwarfed by nature in a harsher Asian answer to the North American plains.

title: Many Options, but Little Consensus, for Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma
description: Dr. John P. Leonard is the Richard T. Silver Distinguished Professor of Hematology and Medical Oncology at Weill Cornell Medical College/New York-Presbyterian Hospital and clinical director of the New York-Cornell Center for Lymphoma and Myeloma in New York City.

title: What You Need to Know About an Enlarged Prostate
description: Once a man passes the half-century mark, its not uncommon to experience such bothersome lower-urinary-tract symptoms as frequent urination throughout the day, getting up at night multiple times to urinate or a weak urinary stream. These symptoms are often caused by an enlarged prostate, a condition known as B.P.H., for benign prostatic hyperplasia. As the prostate grows in size, pressure is placed on the urethra, the tube transporting urine from the bladder through the prostate, and this can lead to a host of urinary complaints. Here are five things Dr. Franklin C. Lowe, a professor of urology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, believes that every man with B.P.H. should know.

title: New Jersey Courts Ruling Ends 12-Year Fight Among Johnson & Johnson Heirs
description: The better half, the old man, the breadwinner, the spouse.

title: Yuri Foreman Stays Unbeaten
description: Yuri Foreman, the North American Boxing Federation light middleweight champion who is also studying to become an Orthodox rabbi, remained undefeated by unanimously outpointing Saul Romn of Mexico in a dazzling 10-round title defense at Aviator Sports Complex in Brooklyn. Foreman (25-0) outboxed the plodding Romn (24-5, 20 knockouts). The judges scored the bout in favor of Foreman, 98-92, 98-92, 97-93.

title: Cargo Ship From Europe Joins Station in Space
description: Europes new Jules Verne cargo ship made a nearly flawless first docking at the International Space Station on Thursday, carrying tons of needed supplies and expanding Europes role in space.

title: Lawsuit Challenges Immigration Raids in New Jersey
description: Immigration agents systematically entered homes and made arrests without proper warrants during raids to round up immigration fugitives in New Jersey, according to a federal lawsuit filed Thursday.

title: Legislators $500,000 Rainy-Day Fund Swells Into $4.5 Million Headache
description: It began as a way of managing the fringes of a gigantic and complex city budget: filling little pots with extra money to cover miscalculations, oversights and politically popular programs that might arise throughout the year.

title: Former Leader in Kosovo Acquitted of War Crimes
description: PARIS  The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague on Thursday acquitted a former commander of the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army of all charges of war crimes in a decision that could inflame anti-Kosovo sentiment in Serbia just weeks after Kosovo unilaterally declared independence.

title: New Therapies in the B.P.H. Pipeline
description: Dr. Kevin T. McVary is a professor of urology at Northwestern Universitys Feinberg School of Medicine and a specialist in prostate diseases and erectile dysfunction. He has been the lead investigator of many drug and therapy device studies for B.P.H.

title: Tibet Will Reopen to Tourism After Protests
description: BEIJING  Tibet will be reopened to tourists on May 1, a decision announced Thursday even as authorities showed no sign of lifting restrictions preventing foreign journalists from freely visiting Tibet and other Tibetan regions in western China to report on episodes of ethnic unrest.

title: Arkansas Fixes Error on Who Can Say, I Do
description: An Arkansas contest between not and knot ended in a no this week.

title: Thomas Jury Deliberations to Continue
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal jury completed its first day of deliberations Thursday without reaching a verdict in the case of the former cyclist Tammy Thomas, who is on trial charged with making false statements under oath about her use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Ben Carnevale, 92, Former Coach at Navy, Is Dead
description: Ben Carnevale, a successful mens basketball coach at North Carolina and Navy and later an athletic director and a national and international basketball administrator, died March 25 at his home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 92.

title: Mandate Is Sore Spot for Sisters
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.

title: Europe to Approve Guidelines on Bank Failures
description: BRUSSELS  Europes finance ministers are expected to agree on Friday to guidelines for handling cross-border banking failures, their first steps to address potential threats brought on by the tight credit markets.

title: Abreu and Yanks Rally and Win Opening Series
description: It was not a giveaway night at Yankee Stadium, except in the home clubhouse. After batting practice Thursday, every Yankees player found a navy blue T-shirt on the chair by his locker, in honor of Bobby Abreu.

title: A Teaspoon of Melancholy Before a Cup of Good Cheer
description: The violinist Gil Shaham has been a constant presence in New York over the last two seasons, appearing as a chamber musician and as an orchestral soloist. Given his formidable technique as well as a big, singing tone and a sunny disposition, he is hardly in danger of wearing out his welcome. When he played in the Rose Theater on Wednesday night as part of the Great Performers series of Lincoln Center, his program included works seldom encountered.

title: A Colossal Private Sale by the Heirs of a Dealer
description: In what experts described as the largest private sale of art ever, the heirs of the legendary dealer Ileana Sonnabend have parted with some $600 million worth of paintings and sculptures in two transactions to cover their estate taxes.

title: A Craft Polished to the Lofty Heights of Art
description: In Japan, before there was plastic, there was lacquer. Shiny and waterproof, it made an excellent coating for wooden cups, bowls, utensils and food storage containers. Unlike plastic, an industrial material, lacquer was a natural product  the sticky sap of the lacquer tree  and working with it was a demanding craft. In the hands of a skilled, ingenious artisan like Shibata Zeshin (1807-91), the greatest of all Japanese lacquer artists, it was a high art.

title: The View From Room 306
description: On Wednesday morning I was in Memphis, and I walked over to the Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated 40 years ago today. I toured the National Civil Rights Museum and then went up to the room by the balcony where King was shot.

title: British Prosecutors Open Case in Airline Bombing Plot
description: LONDON  British prosecutors laid out charges on Thursday at the trial of eight men accused of planning suicide attacks on trans-Atlantic airliners in the name of Islam, using explosives made of household liquids mixed into a deadly cocktail, as the planes flew from London to the United States and Canada.

title: Wonder Bread and Curry: Mingling Cultures, Conflicted Hearts
description: Jhumpa Lahiris characters tend to be immigrants from India and their American-reared children, exiles who straddle two countries, two cultures, and belong to neither: too used to freedom to accept the rituals and conventions of home, and yet too steeped in tradition to embrace American mores fully. These Indian-born parents want the American Dream for their children  name-brand schools, a prestigious job, a roomy house in the suburbs  but they are cautious about the pitfalls of life in this alien land, and isolated by their difficulties with language and customs. Their children too are often emotional outsiders: having grown up translating the mysteries of the United States for their relatives, they are fluent navigators of both Bengali and American culture but completely at home in neither; they always experience themselves as standing slightly apart, given more to melancholy observation than wholehearted participation.

title: For Obama, a 2-to-1 Edge Over Clinton in Donations
description: Senator Barack Obama raised $40 million for his campaign in March, roughly double the amount collected by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the same period as both campaigns saw their fund-raising drop from their record levels.

title: Mythic Figures, Living Large and in Love in Egypt
description: Antony and Cleopatra is a big play to squeeze onto a small stage. The same could be said for most of Shakespeare, in theory, but the mythic title characters of this one may require even more theatrical space than most of their brothers and sisters in the tragic canon. And the play is as much a sweeping historical drama as it is the story of a passionate union brought to ruin. Antony and Cleopatra do not just make history as they make love  they embody it, in all its grandeur, its confusion and its folly.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film review last Friday about Chapter 27, a portrait of John Lennons killer, Mark David Chapman, referred incorrectly to the movies depiction of an encounter between Mr. Chapman and Lennons son Sean and the character who introduces them. The encounter did in fact happen; it was not one of the films silly flights of fancy. And the character, a Beatles fan named Jude played by Lindsay Lohan, is based on a real person; the character is not fictional.

title: Out of Africa, Whatever Africa May Be
description: Afropolitanism is the modish tag for new work made by young African artists both in and outside Africa. What unites the artists is a shared view of Africa, less as a place than as a concept; a cultural force, one that runs through the world the way a gulf stream runs through an ocean: part of the whole, but with its own tides and temperatures.

title: There Were Orders to Follow
description: You can often tell if someone understands how wrong their actions are by the lengths to which they go to rationalize them. It took 81 pages of twisted legal reasoning to justify President Bushs decision to ignore federal law and international treaties and authorize the abuse and torture of prisoners.

title: Born in New York, Established in Indiana
description: Donnie Walshs N.B.A. coaching career was brief and unspectacular, but it involved one poignant stroll through Madison Square Garden nearly three decades ago.

title: Safeguarding Electronic Voting
description: After the bungled voting and vote-counting in Florida in 2000, Americans agreed that the nations voting systems had to be upgraded. With a presidential election fast approaching, there is a real danger of another meltdown  this time because of the flaws in electronic voting.

title: Louisianas Creole Country, Colorfully Preserved
description: COME April, the streams and sloughs, bogs and bayous of central Louisiana bloat from rejuvenating spring rains, watering a landscape in full flower. Deep in the Kisatchie National Forest, wild azaleas blaze trails with pinkish-white clusters, sassafras trees glow brilliant green and hikers stride through glades dotted with the lavender blossoms of blazing star. Kayakers rouse turtles that belly-flop off sunny logs with splashy kerplunks. Pileated woodpeckers wail out their shrill, laughlike calls.

title: Rethinking an Old Ailment: Enlarged Prostate
description: Men, the old joke goes, spend the first half of their lives making money, and the second half making water. Thats because past age 50, many men face an embarrassing problem called B.P.H., for benign prostatic hyperplasia. This slowly progressive enlargement of the prostate can make urination difficult or painful and send men trudging off to the bathroom many times during the day and night.

description: POP

title: Surf and Quiet Amid the Pines of the Central Coast
description: TO many of its visitors, Cambria, Calif., is a find  like some unexpected treasure stumbled upon at a yard sale  a coastal shock tucked between the waves of the Pacific and the Monterey pine forests of northern San Luis Obispo County.

title: Suriname: 19 Dead in Plane Crash
description: A plane carrying 19 people crashed near Benzdorp, a mining village along the border with French Guiana, killing everyone on board. Civil aviation authorities said on Surinamese radio that the twin-engine Antonov-AN28 operated by a local carrier, Blue Wing Airlines, descended to land at Benzdorp but veered upward to avoid a plane on the landing strip and crashed after hitting a tree.

title: Mississippi Towns Brace for Floods
description: Cities and towns along the Mississippi River braced for rising water levels and possible flooding on Friday as recent rains in the nations lower midsection ran off saturated ground toward its eventual destination in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Theater Listings
description: BASIL TWIST In most cases its safe to say that actual people outrank puppets as performers. If, however, the strings are being pulled by the third-generation master puppeteer Basil Twist, all bets are off. His Dogugaeshi, seen several years ago at Japan Society, ranks among the most magically charged experiences Ive ever had in a theater. For others, Mr. Twists version of the ballet Petrushka fits this bill; luckily for those of us who missed it at its Lincoln Center premiere seven years ago, the institution has brought it back for another limited run, as part of the Stravinsky Onstage series.

title: Another Balloon Over Paris, With Lives Adrift Below
description: If the luscious red orb that sails through Flight of the Red Balloon like an airborne cherry looks as if it flew in from another movie, in some ways it did. The film, the latest wonderment from the Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-hsien, takes as one of its inspirations Albert Lamorisses 1956 classic, The Red Balloon, about a young boy and the talismanic sphere that follows him through the gray streets of Paris like a dog, a lover, a ghost  as much a reminder of the precariousness of life as an emblem of innocence.

title: Crossing Into the Deep End, Where Desire Is Fathomed
description: The flowers that bloom in the French film Water Lilies belong to a familiar cinematic species, the newly sexualized teenage girl. Being French, these teenage girls exhibit some notably different characteristics from their Hollywood counterparts; among other things they dont text, snap their gum or deliver snappy dialogue like some peewee-league Rosalind Russell. But like most movie teenagers, they also weigh in closer to carefully fabricated adult conceits than to fleshed-out real girls.

title: An Ex-Mayor Holds Hope 2 Witnesses Are Enough
description: NEWARK  The federal case against Sharpe James was built on the testimony of 33 witnesses. His rebuttal comprised of two. And now the public corruption trial against Mr. James, the former mayor of Newark, is poised to move to the only pool of people that matters: the 12-member jury.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Robert F. Goheen, a former president of Princeton, misspelled the name of his birthplace in India. It is Vengurla, not Venguria. Because of an editing error, the obituary misstated the timing of the answer he gave  Fire the football coach  when the Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, then the president of Notre Dame, asked how his university could get the reputation for scholarship that Princeton had. The remark was made early in Father Hesburghs 35-year tenure as president, which began in 1952; it was not made in 1987 (The Times reported the remark in an article that year). And the obituary misstated the year that Mr. Goheen became director of the Woodrow Wilson Fellowships. It was 1953, not 1963.

title: An Unlikely Friendship
description: A spoonful of fashion helps the feminism go down in Nana, a delightful pop fairy tale that speaks to young women in the language of sisterhood and self-direction.

description: WASHINGTONA new National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq cites significant security improvements and progress toward healing sectarian political rifts, but concludes that security remains fragile and terrorist groups remain capable of initiating large attacks, several American government officials said this week.

title: Maximum Term for Stepfather in Death of Girl
description: As he faced the judge about to sentence him for causing his 7-year-old stepdaughters death, Cesar Rodriguez said he was sorry. He said he loved his stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown. He said he would serve his time. Still, Mr. Rodriguez said Thursday before a packed courtroom in Brooklyn, I can honestly say that Im being accused of something I did not do.

title: India Tiptoes in Chinas Footsteps to Compete but Not Offend
description: NEW DELHI  Since protests against China broke out among the Tibetans who make their home in exile here, India has urged the Dalai Lama to refrain from talking politics and assured Beijing that the Olympic torch will pass unmolested when it arrives here this month.

title: Fox Idols Beat CBS Dramas
description: The return of CBSs dramas gave that network a boost in the ratings on Wednesday, but Fox dominated the night over all, thanks to the weekly results episode of American Idol, which led the night with 24.3 million viewers at 9, Nielsen reported. Ramiele Malubay was eliminated from the competition; eight contestants remain. Fox also finished first during the 8 oclock hour with the season finale of The Moment of Truth (10 million), which has averaged the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 for any new show this season. CBSs new episodes of Criminal Minds at 9 and CSI: NY at 10, which each averaged 12.8 million viewers, lifted the network into second place on the night, but it fared less well at 8 with Big Brother (6 million). NBC was third over all, with repeats following Deal or No Deal at 8 (9.3 million). ABC finished fourth but ahead of NBC, in third, among the 18-to-49 set.

title: McCain Sees King Speech as Chance to Mend Ties

As the article noted, he pleaded guilty last October to a charge of conspiring to provide firearms and ammunition to illegal aliens. Peek into the dim, shivery insides of a decommissioned firehouse reborn as Shamrock Stables, one of five home bases to New York Citys historic but endangered horse-and-carriage trade. The danger faced by these 220 urban beasts of burden and the 293 drivers licensed to pilot their carriages? Pink slips from the city.

title: High School Musical Seeks Student Body
description: A lot of teenagers are going to be fighting to get into this summer school. ABC announced on Thursday that it would conduct open casting calls for participants in a new summer reality series based on Disneys popular High School Musical franchise. High School Musical: Summer Session will follow a group of 16- to 22-year-olds through casting and a seven-week music and dance program, in which they will compete to become a part of the High School Musical family, according to ABC. The network would not say, however, exactly what that means and whether the winner would get a part in the forthcoming third High School Musical film, scheduled for theatrical release in October. Open auditions for Summer Session will begin on May 7 in Orlando and on a date to be determined in Southern California. Details on eligibility and how early eager participants can begin lining up for the auditions are on the Web site abc.com/hsmsummersession. The reality television series is scheduled to have its premiere on July 20.

title: Cyprus: Symbolic Crossing Opened
description: Greek and Turkish Cypriots tore down the Ledra Street crossing, which has kept the islands communities divided for decades. Hundreds of people watched the event; Cypriots also lined up (left) to cross once the checkpoint was opened. Although Turkish Cypriots have opened five other checkpoints in recent years, the Ledra Street crossing was considered especially symbolic because it sat in the heart of the islands divided capital, Nicosia. Both sides agreed last month to restart talks on uniting the island, the first serious effort in two years to erase the 1974 division.

title: Welcome to Up To The Moment
description: By Armand Limnander Its hard to bring a fresh perspective to photographic portraiture, but Paul Mpagi Sepuya proves that sometimes the simplest approach yields the most rewarding results. His book, Beloved Object & Amorous Subject, Revisited (Envoy), is straightforward enough: a series of shirtless young men  Sepuyas friends, boyfriends and collaborators  pose deadpan against a plain white wall in his bedroom. These images are technically impeccable, almost ritualistic in their repetition, and they offer a voyeuristic frisson. But it is the subtle changes in mood and expression that draw us in: who exactly are these guys, and why do we care? The books title was inspired by Roland Barthes A Lovers Discourse: Fragments, his 1977 impressionistic treatise on desire. Sepuyas work allows him to explore the subject while categorizing special relationships that have affected him through the years. The viewer is left to imagine what exactly transpired between the characters. Only Sepuya has the answers, but hes not interested in revealing them  for him, this is just the beginning of a story that can be developed indefinitely.

You may also see stands selling paper replicas of everything from yachts and cars to mobiles and MP3 players. In modern, materialistic Hong Kong, these can be burned as offerings, too, in case your ancestor would like having a new Mercedes or Motorola in the afterlife. A traditionalist would warn you against buying one as a kitsch souvenir, though.

title: Reclaiming Sudan's Abandoned Children
description: A shift in attitudes and practices at the Maygoma Orphanage in Khartoum, Sudan, has rescued many infants from a grim fate.

title: Flowers in Moscow: Take Two
description: Unseasonably warm, gloriously sunny weather in Moscow recently has highlighted the abundance of flowers on sale in this sun-starved city.

title: London Pubs, with Thanks to Madonna and Prince Charles
description: What do Prince Charles and Madonna have in common? Apart from the fact that they are both rich, you probably cant imagine. But they are both fans of the traditional English pub  where you can go for a pint of un-chilled, flat beer and a packet of pork scratchings (a snack made from fried pork skin).

title: T. Boone Looms
description: SAN ANTONIO  Even though Oklahoma State has been essentially irrelevant this basketball season, the deep pockets of the billionaire booster T. Boone Pickens are still looming at the Final Four.

title: Battlestar, A Signature Brand For NBC Universal
description: Think about NBC Universals signature shows, and Saturday Night Live, NBC Nightly News and Law & Order may come to mind. But Battlestar Galactica?

title: Bloggingheads: Hillary the Partisan
description:
Jonathan Chait of The New Republic, left, and David Greenberg of Slate debate whether Hillary Clinton's stance as a partisan figure bolsters her case.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Moving On but Still Playing Hard
description: Of all things to be on television in the Rays clubhouse, a show called Cheaters was consuming the attention of the players on the couch. And, three weeks since Shelley Duncans spikes-high slide into second base against the Rays in a spring training game, the debate over what constitutes cheating, unsportsmanlike conduct or just playing hard is alive and well.

title: Thats What I Like About Me
description: At the start of his run for the presidency, Barack Obama would explain the positive reaction he was getting from admirers by saying this is more about you than about me. Now that Mr. Obama is the front-running Democratic candidate, an in-depth look at how voters are reacting to him  and the reasons for those reactions  lends considerable credence to his characterization of public opinion. It turns out, however, that the its about you phenomenon is a little broader than the Mr. Obama might have imagined. It pertains not only to reasons for liking and supporting him, but is also relevant to reasons for disliking him and for supporting Hillary Clinton.

title: Better Off Than They Were Eight Years Ago
description: One take-away from the Clinton tax returns may be that the path to financial security may be found by writing books.

title: Why There Arent More Flips
description: The feedback continues to roll in about my review of the ultra-simple, ultra-successful Flip Video camcorder two weeks ago. I think almost everyone can relate to this story, sent to me by e-mail:

title: Vows: Francesca and Eric
description: Francesca Harper and Eric Cohen tell about how doubts about the future led to a separation that was followed by a rousing encore.

title: Bruins Have a Fan on the Charts
description: SAN ANTONIO  Last month, when U.C.L.A. went to overtime against Stanford, the Linkin Park guitarist Brad Delson convinced his bandmates to not take the stage for a concert in Las Vegas until the game ended.

title: Murakami at the Brooklyn Museum
description: A retrospective exhibit of the work of Japanese pop artist Takashi Murakami opens at the Brooklyn Museum.  Melena Ryzik reports.

title: Is Hansbrough Like Mike?
description: SAN ANTONIO  Its not too often that Michael Jordan comparisons are thrown around. Actually, theyre about as rare as a San Antonio meal that doesnt include chips and salsa.

title: Bush, Putin and What Russian Bloggers Think
description: MOSCOW  President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia  two old war horses, as Mr. Bush put it on Friday at the NATO summit  are meeting for talks this weekend in Russia. How can the two reach compromises, given the many tensions that have arisen in their relationship?

title: Cheektowaga's Middle School Experiment
description: A school district outside Buffalo has enacted rigid disciplinary measures to instill responsibility in students.

title: The Rangers Playoff Calculus
description: If your head does not currently hurt, it might after considering all the playoff permutations possible in the Eastern Conference with two days to play.

title: Official Put on Leave After Latest Report on Trooper Inquiry
description: ALBANY  Daniel Wiese, the inspector general of the State Power Authority, was placed on indefinite administrative leave on Friday.

title: In a Modern Gold Rush, Can Memories Beat $913 an Ounce?
description: Gold rushes should be simple money-making schemes.

title: Test for War Pass at  Wood Memorial
description: His road to the Kentucky Derby having veered wildly off course, War Pass will return Saturday in the $750,000 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, where he will either redeem himself or confirm that he is not Derby material.

title: Iraqi Premier Suspends Government Raids on Militias
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki sought to defuse recent tensions among Iraqs Shiites on Friday by suspending raids by government forces on militias, less than 24 hours after he threatened further raids.

title: The Guitar Gods
description: Deep Purples 1973 hit Smoke on the Water features the greatest guitar riff of all time, according to a poll by a London music school that has taught members of bands like Radiohead, the Kinks and the Cure, Reuters reported. The majority of the 25 songs selected by current students of the London Tech Music School were recorded in the 1960s, 70s and 80s. Only seven were recorded in the last 20 years. The most recent was 7 Nation Army, recorded by the White Stripes in 2003; the oldest was Johnny B. Goode, recorded by Chuck Berry, above, in 1958. Other songs include Purple Haze by Jimi Hendrix (1967), Walk This Way by Aerosmith (1975) and Money for Nothing by Dire Straits (1984).

title: Past Catches Up With the Queen of Roads
description: ROME  In ancient times the Appian Way, which links Rome to the southern city of Brindisi, was known as the regina viarum, the queen of the roads. But these days its crown appears to be tarnished by chronic traffic congestion, vandalism and, some of its guardians grumble, illegal development.

title: Congressional Maneuvers Ahead of Iraq Hearings
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Republican officials have met at the White House to synchronize strategies. House Democrats issue daily countdowns as the moment approaches. Both sides are planning major operations next week to try to gain the high ground.

title: A Legal Fandango
description: Gary Brooker, right, the lead singer of Procol Harum, has regained sole royalty rights to the bands 1967 hit A Whiter Shade of Pale at the Court of Appeal in London, the BBC reported. The decision on Friday overturned a 2006 ruling that the organist Matthew Fisher, who argued he had written the songs organ melody, was entitled to 40 percent of the royalties. The court agreed that Mr. Fisher had contributed the organ theme but ruled that he had waited too long to make his claim. In October, Mr. Brookers lawyer told the court that Mr. Fisher had failed to take the case to the court earlier because he knew it would end his career in the group. He wanted to stay in the band and live the life of a pop star, the lawyer said. In his ruling, Lord Justice Mummery said he would consider Mr Fishers request for final appeal to the House of Lords.

title: 2 Incomes, at What Price?
description: THE United States is often referred to as a dual-income society, but there are plenty of families who struggle with just one.

title: U.S. Charges Contractor at Iraq Post in Stabbing
description: BAGHDAD  The American military has charged a contractor with assault in a case that may emerge as a major test of the militarys legal jurisdiction over civilians who accompany the armed forces into the field, military officials and legal experts said Friday.

title: Work Every Bit as Wild as It Is Woolly
description: NORRIS, Mont.  It sounds like something a Zen master might ask: How does the wool come off a sheep?

title: Making It to the Major League of Fantasy Sports
description: Christopher J. Russo lives a life of fantasy in the real world.

title: Stringer Concedes Error in Bio
description: The story of how she became her high schools first black cheerleader has become a popular narrative in C. Vivian Stringers life story ever since she recounted the anecdote at a news conference last April that followed derogatory comments made by the radio host Don Imus about her Rutgers womens basketball team.

title: A U.S.-Trained Entrepreneur Becomes Voodoos Pope
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

title: Newspaper Chain Hires Adviser as It Weighs Restructuring
description: In a magazine article seven years ago, the chief executive of the Journal Register Company, the publicly traded newspaper company, bragged about being such a skinflint that he checked the odometers in reporters vehicles to verify expense reports.

title: Footnotes
description: Celebrate Brooklyn will open its 30th season on June 12 with a performance by Isaac Hayes. This summers lineup for the free concert series at the Prospect Park band shell includes Miriam Makeba; Beth Orton; a screening of the Bruce Lee movie Enter the Dragon, with live accompaniment by Karsh Kale; a tribute to the R&B singer Bill Withers; and a benefit by Feist. Information: briconline.org/celebrate. ... Tony Hoagland, a poetry professor at the University of Houston, has been named the second annual winner of the $50,000 Jackson Poetry Prize, given to underrecognized writers, The Associated Press reported. ... Roger Ebert, the film critic who has undergone a series of cancer operations, says he planned to resume writing reviews for The Chicago Sun-Times this month but will not rejoin his syndicated television show, Ebert & Roeper because he has not regained the ability to speak, The Associated Press reported. ... Robert Falls, the director who won a Tony Award in 1999 for Death of a Salesman, will be reunited with its star, Brian Dennehy, in Eugene ONeills Hughie, opening in previews on June 18 and continuing through Aug. 31 at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada. On a double bill, Jennifer Tarver will direct Mr. Dennehy in Samuel Becketts Krapps Last Tape.

title: Clinton Strategist Lobbied for Trade Pact She Opposes
description: MEMPHIS  Mark Penn, the pollster and chief strategist for Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign, apologized on Friday for meeting with Colombian officials to discuss a free-trade agreement that Mrs. Clinton opposes.

title: Jury Rules Against Gypsy-Cab Driver in Rights Case
description: A gypsy-cab drivers claim that two New York City police officers violated his constitutional rights by reporting him to immigration authorities was rejected on Friday by a federal jury in Manhattan.

title: Two Yankees Have Suspensions Reduced
description: Shelley Duncan had wanted a chance to explain what he was doing on March 12, when he slid with his spikes high and incited a brawl with the Tampa Bay Rays during spring training. But while Duncan was looking forward to the hearing on his appeal of a suspension, he and his teammate Melky Cabrera faced reality Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times listing on Friday about Staten Island Historical Society events at Historic Richmond Town gave information for an event that was not described. The prices of $15, and $12 for members, are for the Tavern Concerts held on Saturday evenings; the telephone number is (718) 351-1611, extension 280.

title: Overcoming Customs and Stigma, Sudan Gives Orphans a Lifeline
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Like so many babies at the Maygoma Orphanage, Nariman Siddiq Ahmed Ali was brought here the day after he was born, sickly and barely alive, weighing less than four pounds.

title: Dance in Review
description: CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATER OF TAIWAN

title: U.S. Renews Blackwater Deal
description: The State Department renewed a contract for one year with Blackwater to guard American diplomats in Baghdad, where the company has come under scrutiny for incidents in which civilians died.

title: After 50 Witnesses in Trial Over Police Killing, Still No Clear View of 50 Shots
description: The prosecution called 50 witnesses in the Sean Bell trial, each telling some part of the case of the 50 shots, their accounts as earnest or exaggerated or feverish as those of 50 kids watching a ballgame through 50 tiny holes in a tall fence. One kid sees the swing, another the bobble of the ball in the outfield, and a third the runners slide over home plate, and everything seems clear, until a fourth kid says wait, youre wrong, the outfielder caught the ball. Didnt you see?

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Friday about prisoner abuse misidentified the job held by John C. Yoo when he wrote a recently declassified memo on the subject. He was working for the Justice Department, not the Pentagon.

title: McCain Ends Resistance to Secret Service Protection
description: Senator John McCain said Friday that he would meet with officials next week to discuss receiving Secret Service protection, even though he has resisted it in the past.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Saturday about New York Democrats resolve to pursue control of the State Senate despite the resignation of the Democratic governor, Eliot Spitzer, gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader. The spokesman is John McArdle, not McCardle. A correction in this space on Wednesday misstated his given name as Joseph in some editions.

title: New Agreement Is Reached in Hartford Desegregation
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Schools in Hartford and 22 of its suburbs would be encouraged to open more classroom seats to children from outside their neighborhoods in order to increase racial diversity, under a tentative settlement reached Friday in a decades-old desegregation case.

title: Performance Art for Sale, Like Elections
description: About a decade ago two Russian artists, Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid, conducted a poll to find out what would make the most popular painting. They discovered that people mostly wanted the same thing: a landscape primarily in blue.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 4, 2008

title: Day on Campaign Trail to Remember Dr. King
description: MEMPHIS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called for a cabinet-level poverty czar and Senator John McCain said he was wrong to have voted a quarter century ago against a federal holiday in memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as both presidential candidates converged here on Friday to appeal to black voters on the 40th anniversary of Dr. Kings assassination.

title: Latest Reality TV: Dancing (Along) With the Stars of Nickelodeon
description: LOS ANGELES  For all of the reality programming on television today, few shows actually encourage viewers  particularly children  to get up and do something real.

title: Corzine Aide Testifies Against a Former Friend
description: NEWARK  Javier Incln, a deputy chief of staff to Gov. Jon S. Corzine, came to Federal District Court here on Friday to testify against a former friend and ally, Mayor David Delle Donna of Guttenberg, N.J., who is charged with extorting money from a bar owner accused of trafficking in illegal immigrant girls.

title: For Seattle Shoppers, Paper or Plastic Could Come with a Green Fee
description: SEATTLE  The cashiers chorus has long fallen on deaf ears among the sustainability set here. Paper or plastic? Neither is of course the greenest answer.

title: More Training for Foreign Students
description: Immigration officials said they were extending the duration of on-the-job training for immigrant students who are recent graduates with advanced degrees in science, technology and engineering. The training period will be extended to 29 months from 12 months for immigrants on student visas employed in jobs related to their field of study. Training will also be automatically extended for students who are waiting to shift to temporary work visas known as H-1B. The measure, which officials said would benefit about 25,000 students, is designed to close visa gaps that had forced some highly skilled graduates to leave the country.

title: 52 Girls Are Taken From Polygamist Sects Ranch in Texas
description: HOUSTON  Responding to an accusation of sexual abuse of a 16-year-old girl, Texas enforcement officers and child welfare investigators raided a West Texas ranch founded by the convicted polygamist sect leader Warren Jeffs and removed 52 children, officials said Friday.

title: Bush Champions Expansive Mission for NATO
description: ZAGREB, Croatia  Addressing new NATO allies in a medieval town square here, President Bush on Saturday championed the alliances expansion across all of Europe and compared the liberation of Eastern European nations from communism to the American-led wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: UBS to End Its Support of Orchestra for Students
description: Whats in three little letters? Millions of dollars.

title: Latest Hitch for Delphi, New Worry for G.M.
description: DETROIT  The Delphi Corporations tortuous path out of bankruptcy went awry Friday when a private equity group backed out of a deal to invest $2.55 billion in the troubled auto-parts maker.

title: Thomas Is Found Guilty in First Trial Linked to Balco Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A former elite cyclist, whose trial was the first in the five-and-a-half-year investigation of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative, was found guilty Friday of making false statements under oath to a federal grand jury about using performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Whoever Wins in Final Four, Brown Cant Lose
description: There are only three boxes left on thousands of photocopied bracket sheets strewn across office cubicles from coast to coast. So, who had Larry Brown in the Final Four?

title: Years After 9/11, Items Returned Underscore a Loss
description: It was the $2 bill that told Myrta Gschaar what she did not really want to know with such certainty: that her husband had been killed at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Ping-Pong as Mind Game (Although a Good Topspin Helps)
description: I DUCKED into the New York International Table Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens, puzzling over the peculiar sound echoing in my ears. With preposterously high odds against me, I was going to play a challenge game of what is commonly known as Ping-Pong. But the echoing I heard did not match that supposedly onomatopoeic name. Instead, it sounded more like a dozen clocks synchronized to the staccato beat of tock-tock-tock-tock.

title: Turner Apologizes
description: Kathleen Turner apologized to Nicolas Cage, her co-star in the film Peggy Sue Got Married, for saying he had been arrested twice for drunken driving and once for stealing a Chihuahua, Bloomberg reported. Ms. Turner, 53, sincerely apologized to Mr. Cage, 44, in a statement read by her lawyer on Friday in a London courtroom. Ms. Turners assertion, which led Mr. Cage to sue for libel, was made in Ms. Turners book Send Yourself Roses and was published in a London newspaper in February. Ms. Turner agreed to reimburse Mr. Cage for court costs and to make a donation to a charity benefiting victims of elder abuse. Ms. Turners British publisher will place an apology or correction in the book , and Associated Newspapers agreed to remove the article from its Web site and to publish an apology.

title: The Social Security Backlog
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary and a headline on March 28 about the screenwriter Abby Mann misstated his age in some editions. He was 83, not 80.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Op-Ed page yesterday, about Hillary Clintons presidential campaign, misstated the date of the Democratic caucus in Nebraska. It took place on Feb. 9; it will not be held on May 13.

title: Morgan Board Loses Support
description: The California State Teachers Retirement System has withheld votes for eight Morgan Stanley directors, including the chairman, John J. Mack, because the company has underperformed both the market and peers.

title: A Confidant to the Big and the Small, Woven Into All Levels
description: SAN ANTONIO  Under the moonlight here, the Riverwalk bustles with coaches, administrators and players in town for the mens college basketball Final Four.

title: Britain: Prince Philip Hospitalized
description: Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeths 86-year-old husband, was admitted to a hospital in London, where he was to be treated for a chest infection. Philip, a generally robust, outdoor-activity-loving man, canceled a public engagement on Wednesday, saying he was suffering from a bad cold. The BBCs royal correspondent, Daniela Relph, reported that he was up and about and dealing with his correspondence.

title: Crime Is Tops
description: The return of CSI to CBS at 9 p.m. on Thursday lifted the network into first place on the night, leading the ratings with 20.4 million viewers, Nielsen reported. Survivor: Micronesia (12.9 million) and Without a Trace (15.4 million) won the 8 and 10 p.m. time slots, respectively. Fox ranked second over all, with installments of Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? at 8 (9.7 million) and 9 p.m. (10.3 million). NBC was third, with four repeats of The Office following an hourlong episode of My Name Is Earl at 8 (7.5 million). ABC finished fourth, earning its lowest ratings at 9 with a rerun of Lost (4.1 million) and two episodes in the 8 p.m. hour of Miss Guided, which averaged 4.6 million viewers.

title: Home Depot Job Cuts
description: HOME DEPOT JOB CUTS Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, may cut as many as 1,000 jobs as it reduces human-resources departments in stores by half to shift more workers to the sales floor. About 2,200 workers were notified of possible changes, and affected full-time employees, less than 1 percent of its work force, can apply for other jobs at the Atlanta-based company, a spokesman said Friday. The job cuts are effective May 1.

title: A Trio Winds Down, a Circle Closes, and Musicians Plan to Go On
description: Retiring? No, Menahem Pressler doesnt know the meanings of the word. Warm and gregarious as a person and as a musician, he is certainly not shy. And irrepressibly energetic at 84, he shows no intention of giving up his career as a concert pianist and an esteemed teacher at the Indiana University School of Music.

title: When Protection Vanishes
description: At midnight on March 28, the gray wolves in Wyoming slipped out of the protection of the Endangered Species Act and became other kinds of creatures: trophy game animals to be hunted in the states northwest corner and predators to be shot on sight elsewhere.

title: Woman Accused of Beating Infant Son
description: A 22-year-old Queens woman was arrested and charged with attempted murder on Friday after she was accused of brutally beating her 7-week-old son, leaving him on life support, the Queens district attorney said.

title: Editors Note
description: A front-page article on March 19 about why many medical students find lucrative specialty fields like dermatology more attractive than general medicine paraphrased comments by several people but put the paraphrases between quotation marks, a violation of The Timess rule that every word between quotation marks be what a speaker or a writer actually said.

title: White Guys Are Back
description: It was probably inevitable. The historic contest between a woman and an African-American for the presidential nomination is now all about white men.

title: Unemployment Rising
description: Fridays awful news of 80,000 lost jobs in March surprised economic forecasters, who had not expected such a severe contraction. But its safe to say that it did not surprise most Americans. Just days before the report, a poll taken by this paper and CBS News showed that a stunning 81 percent of Americans believe the nation is on the wrong track. Thats the highest percentage since the poll began asking about the countrys direction in the early 1990s. Two in three respondents said they believed the economy was in a recession.

title: Texans Beat Big Coal, and a Film Shows How
description: HOUSTON  David had only a slingshot. Texans fighting big coal have Robert Redford.

title: Attic-Like Museums New Annex of Ideas
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass.  Among the many visionaries celebrated in the Feigenbaum Hall of Innovation, which opened here last weekend at the Berkshire Museum, one figure, Zenas Crane Jr., is not fully given his due.

title: A Town Under Fire Becomes a Symbol for Israel
description: SDEROT, Israel  This long neglected immigrant town a mile from Gaza, pounded by Palestinian rockets for the past seven years, is taking on a new identity, edging into the center of Zionist consciousness as a symbol of the nations unofficial motto: Never Again.

title: Russian Romances, Lovelorn Variety
description: Love was the theme of the evening at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, when the remarkable Siberian-born baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky performed romances by Tchaikovsky, Medtner and Rachmaninoff. These being Russian songs, there were no apple-cheeked lovers frolicking in springtime, but instead a torrent of gloom and heartache. Mr. Hvorostovsky used the infinite shadings of his luxuriously dark and dusky voice to illuminate the yearning nuances of bitterness and regret.

title: Time Is the Last Hazard Standing in Neumanns Way
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  For some golfers, the hardest hazard to escape is the space between their ears. Liselotte Neumann came into this weeks Kraft Nabisco Championship trying to forget that her competitive clock is ticking.

title: Degrees of Matriculation
description: The already crazed competition for admission to the nations most prestigious universities and colleges became even more intense this year, with many logging record low acceptance rates.

title: Pataki Slow to Release Documents to Archives
description: As governor, George E. Pataki was sometimes criticized for practicing government by press release. Inadvertently, perhaps, he may be perpetuating that image for history.

title: Times Journalist Still in Zimbabwe Jail
description: A journalist for The New York Times detained by the police in Zimbabwe spent a second night in a jail cell on Friday, after government authorities overruled the attorney generals decision to set him free.

title: Leaders of Ruling Party Say Mugabe Will Fight On
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Dampening speculation that Zimbabwes strongman, President Robert Mugabe, would step down after 28 years in power, the senior leadership of the countrys ruling party decided Friday that he should participate in a runoff with the opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, if neither won a majority in last weeks election.

title: Rainout Pushes Back Pelfreys First Start
description: ATLANTA  Shortly after learning that Fridays game was rained out, the Mets pitching coach, Rick Peterson, delivered the news to Mike Pelfrey.

title: For Kaun, a Lesson of Responsibility Learned at an Early Age
description: SAN ANTONIO  Sasha Kaun, the 6-foot-11 center for Kansas, will share in a great responsibility Saturday when his Jayhawks try to stop North Carolina forward Tyler Hansbrough, college basketballs player of the year.

title: Building a Skyline, Safely
description: To the Editor:

title: A Policy of Detachment
description: To the Editor:

title: UBS Rejects Call to Split Off Ailing Investment Unit
description: LONDON  As investors stepped up pressure on UBS to consider a breakup after more write-downs this week, the departing chairman, Marcel Ospel, said Friday that dividing the Swiss banks investment arm from its booming wealth management business would be a mistake.

title: While Alluring, Foreign Currencies Can Be Elusive
description: Interest rates on savings accounts are falling. The dollar is weak. And the stock market is up one day and down the next. It is no wonder that even normally timid investors are hearing the siren song of foreign currencies.

title: At Last, Buffetts Key to Success
description: TO be safe, a column or blog post bearing the headline Warren Buffett Invests Like a Girl needs two things: it has to be written by a woman, and it has to be backed up with plenty of details.

title: Ethnic Unrest Continues in China
description: SHANGHAI  Fresh ethnic violence has erupted in a Tibetan region of southwestern China, with disputed reports of eight people shot dead by the police, and the Chinese government on Friday vowed swift and severe punishment of Tibetans accused of rioting and taking part in last months antigovernment protests.

title: Big Sky Slugfest
description: Heres some advice for Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama as they prepare for Montanas annual Democratic dinner Saturday night in Butte  where the ragged-edged town on the crest of the Continental Divide will be the center of the political universe.

title: Across the Globe, Hints of More Perils in Housing
description: AS a weakening housing market appears to be dragging the American economy into recession, the International Monetary Fund warned this week that home prices in other industrial countries were even more overvalued.

title: In Massachusetts, Universal Coverage Strains Care
description: AMHERST, Mass.  Once they discover that she is Dr. Kate, the supplicants line up to approach at dinner parties and ballet recitals. Surely, they suggest to Dr. Katherine J. Atkinson, a family physician here, she might find a way to move them up her lengthy waiting list for new patients.

title: Putin, at NATO Meeting, Curbs Combative Rhetoric
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia complained Friday that NATO was not taking Russias legitimate security concerns into account, but he also said that President Bush was listening to Moscows criticisms of a planned missile defense system for Europe, which is to be based in the Czech Republic and Poland.

title: Trojan Horse on a Chip
description: SECURITY experts warn that as supply chains become more global and more opaque, no one can be sure what parts are going into the computers that run, well, everything from air traffic control towers to banks to weapon systems, Popular Mechanics says.

title: Lessons of War, Past and Present
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Spoil the Rangers Home Finale
description: The Rangers tried to handle the traditions that come with their final home game at Madison Square Garden with requisite enthusiasm, but as they peeled off their sweaters to give to eager season-ticket holders, disappointment hung heavily on their shoulders.

title: Passport Official to Leave Post
description: A State Department official in charge of passport services is stepping down two weeks after the agency said files of the three presidential candidates had been improperly accessed. A department spokesman said Ann Barrett, the deputy assistant secretary of state for passport services, was stepping down and being replaced by Lawrence Baer, a senior management official. Ms. Barrett will leave the post effective April 7 but will remain employed in the departments consular affairs bureau. The department is investigating the improper breach of confidential passport files of Senators Barack Obama, Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain.

title: Vaccines, Autism and Our Daughter, Hannah
description: To the Editor:

title: Indecency Appeal Rejected
description: INDECENCY APPEAL REJECTED  The News Corporations appeal of $91,000 in indecency fines for a 2003 broadcast featuring strippers at bachelor and bachelorette parties has been rejected by the Federal Communications Commission on technical grounds. The appeal from the Fox Television unit exceeded a 25-page limit for responses, the agency said Friday in an order posted on its Web site. The F.C.C. said in the three-paragraph order that the fines would stand because Fox neither complied with the rule nor sought a waiver. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: New Choir Director
description: Mack Wilberg will replace Craig Jessop, who abruptly resigned last month, as music director of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Wilberg, the associate director, served as interim director after Mr. Jessop stepped down after eight years in the position, saying he wanted to teach and spend more time with his family. As music director, Mr. Wilberg will oversee musical and creative aspects of the choir, the Orchestra at Temple Square, the Temple Square Chorale and the Bells on Temple Square, including selecting the repertory for concerts, recordings and tours. He will also oversee the weekly Music and the Spoken Word broadcast.

title: Hard-Hearted Dancers as Stravinskys Puppets
description: Basil Twist understands a thing or two about the uses of enchantment. Puppets are magic, he says in the notes to Petrushka, his wondrous, visually opulent puppet version of the Stravinsky-Fokine ballet at the Clark Studio Theater at Lincoln Center. And he proceeds to show us why: puppets can fly or dance on their hands or float in midair, effortlessly ignoring the laws of gravity governing our too solid flesh.

title: The Already Big Thing on the Internet: Spying on Users
description: In 1993, the dawn of the Internet age, the liberating anonymity of the online world was captured in a well-known New Yorker cartoon. One dog, sitting at a computer, tells another: On the Internet, nobody knows youre a dog. Fifteen years later, that anonymity is gone.

title: In Albany, Secrecy Surrounds Budget Talks
description: ALBANY  Around the Capitol this week, the top political leaders have been particularly cagey about answering questions.

title: Soaring Gold Prices Lure New Breed of Diggers
description: COLFAX, Calif.  On a recent Saturday afternoon, in the freezing shallows of the American River, Gene Zuspan looked into a pile of wet sand and swore he saw something glint.

title: Housing Bill to Get Vote in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, moved Friday to end debate on a bipartisan housing bill intended to aid homeowners in danger of foreclosure and help stabilize the wider real estate market. Mr. Reids action set the stage for final action on the bill next Tuesday.

The three-masted 288-foot yacht had no passengers on board. The officials said that French and American naval forces were in the area and were following the situation. Acts of piracy are frequent off Somalias coast, and commercial craft are usually advised to avoid it.

title: Comedian, All Serious, Takes Stand
description: LOS ANGELES  Chris Rock, the actor and comedian, headlined the Hollywood wiretapping trial on Friday, fully inhabiting the role of a witness who found absolutely nothing funny in being called to testify.

title: David Newsom, 90, Diplomat in Iran Crisis, Dies
description: WASHINGTON  David D. Newsom, a career diplomat who was a go-between in unsuccessful efforts to keep the deposed shah of Iran from entering the United States in 1979, then tried to win the release of Americans held hostage at the embassy in Tehran, died on Sunday in Charlottesville, Va., where he had lived in recent years. He was 90.

title: Health Database Was Set Up to Ignore Abortion

The dean of the Public Health School lifted the restrictions after learning of them.

The aide was shot as the minister was briefing a group of Canadian Jews at an observation point on the Israeli side of the border.

title: Clooney Trims Ties to Writers Guild
description: George Clooney, below, a staunch supporter of the Writers Guild of America during its recent strike, quietly withdrew from the union last fall after it rejected his request for a writing credit on his film Leatherheads, Reuters reported, citing Variety. Mr. Clooney switched to financial core status, which means that he is still covered by the basic guild contract but loses his voting rights and cannot run for office or attend union meetings. Mr. Clooney, who directed, produced and stars in Leatherheads, a comedy about football in the 1920s, said he had sought a writing credit on the film alongside Duncan Brantley and Rick Reilly because he had overhauled their 17-year-old script. His request was denied by a 2-to-1 vote at an arbitration hearing. When your own union doesnt back what youve done, the only honorable thing to do is not participate, Mr. Clooney said, according to Variety.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 30 about C. Vivian Stringer, the womens basketball coach at Rutgers, attributed an erroneous distinction to her from her days as a pioneering black cheerleader at her high school in Pennsylvania during the 1960s. Dolores Dantzler preceded Ms. Stringer as a member of the squad in the 1950s; Ms. Stringer was not her schools first black cheerleader. (The error also appeared in an article on April 11, 2007.) After Ms. Dantzler pointed out the error to The Times in a telephone call this week, Ms. Stringer acknowledged that she had been mistaken when she made the claim publicly several times and included it in her recent book, Standing Tall. (A corrective article appears today on Page D2.)

title: Dieters Portion of a Hearty French Meal
description: Pretty much anyone with a passion for early music looks forward to William Christies visits to New York with Les Arts Florissants, his Paris vocal and period-instrument ensemble. But Mr. Christies group comes in various forms, and its configuration makes a huge difference. When he brings a full-scale opera production  with a chamber orchestra, his front-line singers and staging  his performances are usually thrilling and memorable. But when he comes on the cheap, with a few singers and instrumentalists, they can be both interpretively soporific and technically spotty.

title: Herbert Alexander, 80, Scholar of Money in Politics, Is Dead

title: Vacant Shopping Centers
description: VACANT SHOPPING CENTERS Vacancies at community and neighborhood shopping centers in the United States rose in the first quarter to the highest level in more than a decade, and rent growth was the lowest since the last recession, the research firm Reis reported on Friday. The average vacancy rate rose to 7.7 percent from 7.1 percent a year earlier. It was the highest since 1996, the real-estate researcher said. Demand for retail space is being hurt by a drop in home prices and sales, rising food and gasoline costs, and job cuts, Reis said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: Unconscious Attitudes on Race and Gender
description: My Sunday column is on the impact in this election cycle of our unconscious minds, particularly toward race and gender. I would strongly encourage you to take some tests that measure your own attitudes. Joshua Correll at University of Chicago has created an on-line test called the police officers dilemma, in which you encounter 100 pictures of black and white men, some armed and some unarmed. The idea is to shoot those who are armed and holster your gun when you see someone unarmed  and the program measures how fast you do these things. Try it  if youre like most whites and many blacks, youre quicker to shoot blacks than whites.
