title: Bad Habit
description: By the time Lucy Clark, the protagonist of Fiona Maazels first novel, Last Last Chance, enters drug rehabilitation midway through the book, she has been through a lot. At 29, Lucy is in rehab for the seventh time, and less than a year earlier her father, an official at the Centers for Disease Control, had vials of superplague stolen from his lab and committed suicide. Lucys mother, the chief executive of a multimillion-dollar hat company, is a drug addict herself. (Shes first seen crawling around the floor, looking for anything white and crumbly. ... Shed smoke talcum powder if it was there.) Lucys half sister, born of an extramarital affair, is, at 12, obsessed with disease (she appears to know more about superplague than the C.D.C. itself), and Lucys 84-year-old grandmother has taken to wearing surgical masks (she buys them in bulk) when shes not channeling her past lives (shes teaching herself Japanese, in the belief that it will help her when she comes back).

title: Drive Carts, Not Cars
description: There are very few car thefts in Peachtree City, Ga. There are, however, more than a few cart thefts. This planned town 25 miles south of Atlanta has 90 miles of golf-cart paths and 9,000 registered carts, one for every four of its 36,000 residents. About two-thirds of the households own at least one. Kids drive them to school (no drivers license is required for a cart). Seniors whove given up their cars drive their carts to the doctor and to go shopping. And of the 80 motor vehicles reported stolen last year, 72 were golf carts, which sell new from about $5,000 at the three Peachtree City cart-sales shops; used carts run about $2,000.

title: The Tightwads Legacy
description: THE KELLER HOTEL, an old seamans inn, has seen a few tides come and go. An Irish coal merchant constructed it in the late 1890s along a salty stretch of the Greenwich Village waterfront, at a time when the docks there were some of the busiest in the world. During the Depression, the Keller served as a flophouse for out-of-work sailors, who boozed and brawled in its ground-floor saloon. As the decades passed and economic forces pushed ships toward other ports, the West Side docks rotted, the Village deteriorated and a new clientele moved into the Keller. By the 1980s, the city was housing indigents upstairs, while the downstairs tenant was a gay leather bar, reputedly New Yorks oldest. Then, in 1985, a real estate investor named William Gottlieb purchased the property for $1 million. Thats when things started to get weird.

title: A Newfangled Way to Count the Trees in the Park
description: On a frigid morning in January on the east side of the Central Park Reservoir, Eric George, 28, was mystifying joggers and dog walkers alike. He wore a backpack with a G.P.S. receiver and carried, in one hand, a data collection unit resembling a portable credit card machine, and in the other, a strip of wood known as a Biltmore stick.

title: Could King Be the Next Governor?
description: PETER T. KING, a well-known congressman from Long Island with considerable political assets, must be providing some measure of comfort to his fellow New York Republicans now that he is exploring the possibility of running for governor.

title: Italian Classics and Adventures
description: IT was a dark and stormy night. What were we doing in Rocky Point at Carusos, a very ordinary-looking Italian restaurant with a casual pizza parlor up front and a more upscale dining room behind? Surely there were scores of similar places closer to where we live in western Suffolk County. But they would not have Wayne Wadington in the kitchen.

title: Indecisive Moments
description: Everyone loves an election  right? Americans parochial love of the hustings (whatever they are) has been evident in Iraq almost from the beginning, urged along by the drama of the raised purple fingers and the Bush administrations recurring need to show tangible markers of progress. The latest electoral venture  provincial contests scheduled for the fall of 2008  was recently approved by Iraqs government under the usual American pressure.

title: Your True Calling Could Suit a Nonprofit
description: Q. Youve spent your career in a profit-making business but want your work to be more in line with your personal values. The idea of working for a nonprofit is appealing, but is this the right reason to make a switch?

title: American Children
description: Quaint and antique, the cry for love of country that Sir Walter Scott made in his poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel is something schoolchildren quit memorizing a century ago. Its stirring theme rouses a patriots yearning: Breathes there the man, with soul so dead, / Who never to himself hath said, / This is my own, my native land!

title: Anne Stone, Matthew Harad
description: Anne Elizabeth Stone, the daughter of Susan Stone and Dr. Alex Stone of Great Neck, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Matthew Corde Harad, the son of Beverly Harad and George Harad of Boise, Idaho. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York.

title: Correction: Practicing Patients
description: An article on March 23 about PatientsLikeMe, a medical-information Web site, misstated the given name of a woman with multiple sclerosis who has used the site. She is Laurie Fournier, not Leslie.

title: Putting a Price on Luxury
description: Complaining about taxes is an American tradition, but thats particularly true when it comes to property taxes. The two other primary forms of individual taxation  sales taxes and income taxes  involve far less estimation. If you buy a sweater in a state with a 5 percent sales tax, theres no mystery to what you owe. Thats not true with property taxes, which are based directly on the local governments estimate of the property value. As anyone knows who has ever agonized over what to bid on a co-op apartment or scoffed at an overpriced listing, estimating the value of a piece of real estate can be quite a challenge.

title: Creature Feature
description: When deciding the worst era in American cinema, its tempting to look closely at the 1950s. Equidistant from Citizen Kane and 2001: A Space Odyssey, the decade saw countless reels of sexless love, bloodless war and humorless comedy, stories with all the romance of a Ken and Barbie set and the poetry of an I Like Ike button. Every period has bad art, but only one has Bedtime for Bonzo. In the horror genre, however, the 1950s were a golden age. Inspired by the twin terrors of nuclear holocaust and Communist infiltration, filmmakers produced unnerving allegories in which body snatchers and id-born Things gave sensational form to our fears about the downside of scientific progress and the threat of the Other, like Technicolor signs flashing brightly in the Age of Anxiety.

description: Seattle

The building is just to the east of a new tower at 40 Bond Street, not across the street from it; its facade is constructed primarily from black granite and zinc, not limestone and steel.

title: A Chateau of Ones Own

In fact, the whole wine game is enough to give the casual investor a raging headache, and not just from the occasional hangover. People dont understand the complexities, says Gilles de Boissson, a Paris lawyer specializing in vineyard deals. There are a lot of points where you can fail.

description: SOMEWHERE along the line, having $1 million  like the ability to diagram sentences, do math in your head, and the dollar itself  became devalued.

title: Searching for the Dalai Lama
description: Do you get the impression that the Dalai Lama is not exactly the brightest bulb in the room? a journalist asked Pico Iyer after both men left a speaking event by His Holiness. We know what hes getting at. At a certain angle, the chirpy aphorisms, the generous stream of book forewords, the Hollywood entourage, all conspire to cast a hue of superficiality that few global pop icons escape.

title: Robert A. Dentler, Who Helped Shape Desegregation in Boston, Is Dead at 79
description: Robert A. Dentler, one of two court-appointed education experts who helped design and administer the groundbreaking desegregation plan that led to mob violence in Boston in the mid-1970s, died on March 27 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 79 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: New Looks for Small Cars
description: NEW looks at the small car are coming from unexpected sources. Gordon Murray, renowned for creating winning Formula One cars and for the McLaren F1 and Mercedes SLR supercars, is creating a new city car that he promises will cost around $10,000 and pay for itself in fuel savings in four years. Mr. Murray is working with a small group at his firm, Gordon Murray Design.

title: A Grown-Up Caribbean Getaway
description: I am interested in a quiet, warm getaway for my husband and me, and thinking about the Virgin Islands. Our interests include a pool, a clean beach, modern spa and fitness facilities, fine dining (not tuxedo, not fast food)  a place thats more adult, less family-oriented, mainly to read and relax for about a week. Price range: moderate or above.  Cheryl Shea, Montclair, N.J.

title: An Elaborate Stable Fit for a Vanderbilt

Is there a photo of the stable entranceway showing Mr. Kemeyss work, which included a bulldog, Tom Cribb; a bloodhound, Brutus; and what was apparently a Scotch collie, Laddie? ... Robert McGann, Manhattan

title: Regime Change

You know, a fiction.

title: Mr. Normals Dysfunctional Irish Families

title: The Last Wish of Martin Luther King
description: FORTY years ago on March 31, at the National Cathedral, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered what would be his last Sunday sermon, on his way back to Memphis. That same night in 1968, President Johnson shocked the world by announcing that he would not seek re-election.

Thirty-eight years ago, Mr. Taub and his wife, Simone, were among the first occupants of what has become the largest cooperative housing project in the United States, with 15,372 units in 35 towers, as well as 7 town-house clusters varying in size, with an average of 33 units in each.

The site strives to provide unbiased information on luxury restaurants, including video tours of restaurant kitchens and cooking demonstrations and interviews with various chefs. There is also a restaurant compare function, in which users may pull up side-by-side information on up to four different restaurants in the same city.

description: To the Editor:

title: Babylon on a Budget: A Weekend Challenge
description: THERES a very fine line between tackiness and glamour, and in Miami Beach  itself a very fine strip of sand  that line sometimes vanishes. Is that maximum blondes minimal swimsuit cringe-making or heart-racing? Is the hotel pool scene high-class or crass? Is the cityscape, which veers from boxy condo towers to candy-colored Art Deco, an architecture buffs dream or nightmare?

Though the broader market, as measured by the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, was down more than 9 percent during the last quarter, Mr. Rodriguezs fund was up 0.4 percent, according to Morningstar. FPA Capital has also performed well over the last five years, returning 15.7 percent, annualized.

title: Change Can Be Painful, but This One Shouldnt Hurt

On Page 3, where he was used to finding an international article  he has a special interest in news from France  was an airy-looking index to the paper, expanded from its usual spot on Page 2. On Page 4 was a new guide to content on nytimes.com, and two full-page ads followed that. title: You May See a Stranger
description: ANYONE who has ever fallen in love with a foreigner  or with the opening scene of Rodgers and Hammersteins South Pacific  knows how tellingly a language is spoken by someone just shy of fluency. Call it fragrancy: when unexpected, latent meanings frequently peek out and bloom. As Oscar Hammerstein knew, the effect is charming; its one of the ways he draws the audience (and Nellie Forbush, the young Navy nurse whos the heroine of the show) so quickly to Emile de Becque, a Frenchman living in the New Hebrides during World War II. Its also one of the ways he sketches the vast differences between them. When the worldly Emile refers to Nellies Arkansas hometown as Small Rock, its not so much a mistake as an insight.

Erik is recalling the way he and his sister, Inga, used to play at their grandparents dilapidated Minnesota farmhouse when they were children, innocent of the gloomy associations the place held for their father and grandparents, whose livelihood had failed during the Depression. Its odd that were all compelled to repeat pain, Erik notes, but Ive come to regard this as a truth.

title: The Boomtown Mirage
description: Halfway through our second bowl of tortilla chips, Daryl Fox got a call from the bank, which was threatening to begin foreclosure proceedings on his house. It was happy hour, and we were at Penascos, a strip-mall Mexican restaurant in Maricopa, Ariz., that serves flavored margaritas and a decent soft chicken taco. When Fox moved to Maricopa in the spring of 2006, he was recently divorced, almost 40, sitting on his half of the proceeds from the house that he and his ex-wife had just sold in Chandler, a suburb of Phoenix. It was a moment when home prices were shooting up all over Arizona, and Fox was determined to find something to buy. He wasnt interested in renting; after his parents marriage ended, Fox had watched his fathers savings slowly slip away, and he didnt want to make the same mistake. He wanted equity.

title: The Wasted Land
description: For 30 years Jorie Graham has engaged the whole human contraption  intellectual, global, domestic, apocalyptic  rather than the narrow emotional slice of it most often reserved for poems. She thinks of the poet not as a recorder but as a constructor of experience. Like Rilke or Yeats, she imagines the hermetic poet as a public figure, someone who addresses the most urgent philosophical and political issues of the time simply by writing poems.

title: Why Shouldnt I Accept the Lowest Bid for a Construction Job?
description: REETZ: The issue is the spread. If you have bids within at most 15 percent of each other, theres probably no reason not to go with the lowest bid. On the other hand, if one bid is 25 percent lower than the rest, there is a problem. It should set off alarms. PASTER: Generally, the low bid will come from someone who hasnt thought through the job properly, or doesnt have enough experience to understand what the job entails, or might be looking to get the job and make up some money with add-ons once you get started, or is looking to cut corners on materials and insurance and things you dont want him to cut corners on. FANUKA: I wont tell you never to accept the lowest bid. You might get lucky and find a contractor who is really good but desperately needs a job to fill in a space in his calendar and keep his guys working. Ask for at least three references. Check to see there are no complaints against him and that hes fully licensed and insured.

There were no hotel rooms available; the National Restaurant Association (the good N.R.A., two different cabbies said) was holding its annual convention. But Michael was able to arrange a room for me in his dorm, a crumbling former hotel from the golden age. Al Capone stayed there, and Elvis Presley. Jimmy Hoffa used it as his base of operations when in town, and rumor has one of his attachs strangling a hotel employee who had the nerve to inquire about the bill.

title: Bhutto and the Future of Islam
description: Picture the moment. It is Dec. 2, 1988. A beautiful woman, 35 years old, walks into the presidential palace in Islamabad, Pakistans capital, flanked by liveried and turbaned honor guards. She is wearing a green silk tunic and a white gauzy shawl that barely covers her hair. She speaks flawless Urdu and English, her English perfected as an undergraduate at Radcliffe and then as a student at Oxford, where she was president of the Oxford Union. She is intelligent, erudite and intensely charismatic. And she is about to take the oath of office to become the first woman in history to lead a modern Muslim country.

title: Inside the List
description: THE FUTURE, DARKLY: Joel C. Rosenberg isnt the most polished writer on the shelf; his prose throws exhaust like a 68 Greyhound bus. An act of terrorism on the readers brain  thats how a Washington Post critic described the writing in Rosenbergs first novel, The Last Jihad (2002). But there is no doubting Rosenbergs sense of timing. The Last Jihad was written before 9/11 (though published after); it opened with a hijacked jet crashing into a presidential motorcade and ended with American planes dropping nuclear bombs on Iraq. Rosenberg is an evangelical Christian with ties to conservative politicians, and hes a favorite with the right-wing commentariat. (If you only read one novel this year, this is it! Rush Limbaugh said of The Ezekiel Option. About that same book, Sean Hannity declared: Joel Rosenberg is one of my favorite novelists of all time.) Rosenbergs new novel, Dead Heat, ripped from tomorrows would-be headlines, crackles darkly with news of a new dictator rising in Iraq and trouble in China and North Korea. It enters the fiction list this week at No. 4.

title: Letters: Mixed Messenger
description: Peggy Orenstein (March 23) proposes that Senator Obamas dual identity, as both African-American and biracial, is the source of his crossover appeal, which has helped him to both embrace and transcend race. Orensteins comment should and, I expect, will strike no one as offensive, but let us consider what it implies  namely, that without this complex racial identity, the senator would not have the unique kind of appeal that he does. How is that so different from the proposition, albeit less felicitously expressed, for which Geraldine Ferraro was pilloried? Why should what is acceptable opinion when voiced in sympathy with Senator Obama be unacceptable racial politics when voiced by someone who supports Senator Clinton?

My mother, a child of the Depression, held her tongue while I pored over the stores list of must-buy products that she had somehow managed to do without while raising three children. We had spent 20 minutes trying to discern the difference between models of Diaper Genies when I came upon the Boppy Tummy Time pillow  which you apparently need in addition to the Boppy breast-feeding pillow, even though both are half-moon-shaped pieces of foam virtually indistinguishable from each other  and my mother began to giggle. We left without registering.

title: The Contextualizer
description: EVERY JEAN NOUVEL BUILDING tells a story. Typically, architects begin the design process with a sketch pad or scale models, but Nouvel starts with an idea he can express in words. Everyone is a product of his epoch, he told me recently. For me, I was born in France after the war; I was in the milieu of Structuralist thinkers. If I dont have a good analysis of something, I am lost. Once Nouvel examines his given conditions and decides that the best architectural solution is, say, a skyscraper without visible base and summit, or a mechanized geometric facade that casts filigreed shadows, he can get going. But to this cerebral process he appends a counterweight: the sensuous love of the material components of a building. What I like is the potique of the situation, he said, in Gallically accented English. I am a hedonist, and I want to give pleasure to other people. That avowal of hedonism gained credibility from the surroundings in which it was made: Le Duc, arguably the best seafood restaurant in Paris, where the waiter knew without instruction to bring Nouvels standard order of marinated raw fish followed by poached lobster dressed with olive oil.

title: Letter: Neal Cassadys Mexico
description: To the Editor: In reading "On the Lam with Kesey" (March 23) about Lawrence Downes's mostly fruitless search for signs of Kesey in Manzanillo from more than 40 years ago, I found myself wondering if he had thought of taking his quest to San Miguel de Allende. True, Kesey had returned to the United States by the time I dropped out in '67, but Neal Cassady and friends were well established in this town of expatriate artists and potheads. Neal was the featured guest at most parties, entertaining us all with his perpetual-motion silver hammer act and dazzling us with his washboard abs. (He was always bare-chested, regardless of the temperature!) We'd all read Kerouac and Burroughs, but few of us knew that Cassady, too, was something of a poet. By the time I met him, drugs and booze had taken their toll. In 1968, he was found dead on the railroad tracks outside of town. At least, that was the story that made the rounds of our hippie community. Thanks for the memories.

title: Letter: Wheres Heidi?
description: To the Editor: The Explorer column "Zermatt, Switzerland: A famed Alps Resort Schusses Into the Future" (March 16) does not describe the place I visited in 1956. My travel diary entry brought back vivid memories of the one main street lined with chalet-style architecture. A horse-drawn carriage took us to the Breithorn Hotel, third class but comfortable, where we had a dinner that included boiled tongue. A walk took us up into a meadow where we watched elderly women, wearing heavy boots and, on their heads, kerchiefs, pitching hay in the fields. My diary entry ended with the words "so quiet, peaceful." Were I to be there once more, I suspect I might not recognize what I referred to then as a very quaint Heidi-land.

title: Sunday Mornings at Yankee Stadium
description: For six days and 23 hours, the auxiliary locker room at Yankee Stadium is exactly that. It is on the lowest level of the Stadium, between the home and the visiting clubhouse. It is the place where the Yankees stage some press conferences, like Manager Joe Girardis pregame and postgame sessions.But when the Yankees play at home, a Catholic Mass is held in the locker room from 10 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. on Sundays. The first Mass of the season was held on Sunday. The service is attended by stadium employees, police officers, reporters and, sometimes, visiting players and team executives. I have seen Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, there.Bob Sheppard, the Yankees public address announcer since 1951, often does the Scripture readings, which, on its own, is a reason to attend the Mass. Sheppard is still recuperating, but there was an announcement made during the service about how he hopes to return by June.The Mass is quick because most attendees are working, but, for those whose Sundays feel vacant without a spiritual experience, it is enjoyable. A half hour after the Mass was over, the makeshift altar was gone and Girardi was doing his pregame news conference.The next Mass at the Stadium will be much different. It will be celebrated by Pope Benedict XVI in two weeks and will attract more than 50,000 worshipers.

title: Girardi Is On for Sunday, But Joe Girardi Show Is Not
description: A scratchy-voiced Joe Girardi said he would return to the dugout on Sunday and manage the Yankees. Girardi did not manage the Yankees in the last two games because he had an upper respiratory infection.Its the worst Ive ever felt for a two-day period, Girardi said.While Girardi felt strong enough to manage, he cancelled the first Joe Girardi Show. Girardi was supposed to tape the show on Sunday morning for airing on the YES Network after the game, but he decided against doing it.I didnt think it was in my healths best interest to try and do a half hour show and be coughing all the time, Girardi said.As Girardi quarantined himself off in his office at Yankee Stadium, Rob Thomson, the bench coach, managed the Yankees to two losses. Girardi said that he communicated with Thomson during games, but hated sitting in the dugout and managing.It was hard, Girardi said. You feel bored. You feel somewhat worthless.

title: Bay City to Madonna: Come Home
description: Thomas Wolfe wrote, You cant go home again. But Madonna will, if Mayor Charles M. Brunner of Bay City, Mich., has his way, The Associated Press reported. The mayor wants to give the key to the city to Madonna, below right, who grew up there and in the Detroit suburb of Rochester Hills. The problem is that in 1985, according to The Bay City Times, Madonna was considered for the honor but some people thought then that her entertainment was too risqu. To make matters worse, the newspaper reported, the city refused to accept a sculpture of Madonna from an Italian artist in the late 1980s on the grounds that her popularity would fade. Now Mayor Brunner has written to Madonna to offer her the key, saying, We have always been proud of your accomplishments, but recently your induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame reminded us that we need to honor you with the highest honor that Bay City can offer. Whats more Guy Greve, president of the Bay Arts Council, wants to commission a sculpture of Madonna, and City Commissioner Christopher J. Shannon, who fronts a rock band, plans a Madonna tribute album, using local musicians to cover her hits, including Like a Virgin and Express Yourself.

title: Another Test for Habeas Corpus
description: One of the dismal hallmarks of the Bush administrations conduct of the war on terror has been its obsession with avoiding outside scrutiny of its actions, including by the federal courts. In particular, it has attacked habeas corpus, the guarantee that prisoners can challenge their confinement before a judge. The administration is doing so again in an important Supreme Court case concerning the habeas rights of American citizens held abroad. The justices should rule that the detainees have a right to review by a United States court.

title: Violinist Takes a Break
description: Maxim Vengerov, right,  has called a time out from his career as an violinist, The Times of London reported. After suffering a recurrence of a shoulder injury, he has played no concerts since June. But now that the shoulder has mended, Mr. Vengerov, 33, said, From this point on, I have decided to leave my violin to rest for some time, in order to give my undivided attention to conducting. He added: I will play again. But I cant tell you when that will be. He will judge the Yehudi Menuhin violin competition in Cardiff, Wales, beginning Friday; will conduct a performance there by another violin luminary, Joshua Bell; will devote time to his school for gifted musicians in Migdal, Israel, where he has a home; and will spend time with his girlfriend, the trumpeter Alison Balsom.

It was said to be Diaghilevs favorite ballet, and for decades it was the epitome of what many dancegoers wanted from ballet: atmosphere, romanticism, poetry.

title: Court Rebuffs Estate on Monroe Rights
description: Marilyn Monroe has been labeled many things. Some have been flattering and some derogatory, but none have been as potentially costly as what her own estate has called her: a New Yorker. Judge Margaret Morrow of Federal District Court in Los Angeles has ruled that because Marilyn Monroe LLC had argued to California tax authorities that the actress was a New York resident, Monroe could not have been a Californian when she died. As so Monroe becomes subject to legislation in New York, where her rights of publicity ended with her death in 1962, rather than in California, where her rights of publicity continue after death and can be bequeathed. The decision makes it possible to reproduce Monroes image without having to pay licensing fees worth millions of dollars to her estate. Marilyn Monroe LLC lacks standing to assert any right of publicity in Marilyn Monroe, said  Surjit Soni, a lawyer representing families of photographers who own images of Monroe. For nearly 25 years they have been unlawfully extracting license fees from content providers and legitimate businesses that have wanted to use her photograph or name in connection with profits. According to a statement, Monroes estate plans to appeal the ruling. The suit was brought in March 2005 and, as a result, California clarified its legislation regarding dead celebrities publicity rights in October 2007.

title: How Pennsylvania Gains From Nafta
description: The 1993 North American Free Trade Agreement, and free trade in general, have somehow emerged as hot campaign issues in the Democratic primary race. This is particularly odd in Pennsylvania because the state economy has done very well in exporting manufactured goods  something that would have been quite difficult if Canada and Mexico had not agreed to reduce their tariffs on U.S. goods.  Pennsylvania shipped $9.2 billion worth of export merchandise to Canada in 2007  32 percent of the state total  and $2.2 billion of goods to Mexico, according to the International Trade Administration. Pennsylvanias exports to Mexico rose 81 percent from 1993 to 2003 and exports to Canada rose 61 percent. The trade association notes that export-supported jobs linked to manufacturing account for an estimated 4.3 percent of Pennsylvania's total private-sector employment. Nearly one-sixth (16.5 percent) of all manufacturing workers in Pennsylvania depend on exports for their jobs.  At the national level, Canada accounted for nearly 16 percent of all U.S. imports of merchandise last year, but also 22 percent of American exports. Mexico accounted for 11 percent of U.S. imports, but 14 percent of U.S. exports. Oil and gas accounts for over 16 percent of American imports from Mexico and (including electricity) nearly 26 percent of our imports from Canada. The dollars we spend on Canadian and Mexican imports are mainly used to buy U.S. exports  mostly goods, but also investments and services provided by such Pennsylvania giants as Vanguard, Cigna, Mellon and PNC Bank.  For all the talk about lost jobs, theyre hard to find in the data. The unemployment rate in Pennsylvania was 6.9 percent in September 1993 when Nafta was enacted, and it is 4.9 percent today. Nonfarm payrolls have grown by 682,500 since then, or 13.3 percent.   Technology (computers and robots) has long been shrinking assembly-line manufacturing jobs in virtually every nation. If we exported manufacturing jobs, it must have been to the moon. A 2006 Banco de Mexico study worries that in recent years employment in (Mexican) industry has been decreasing whereas the employment in the service sector has been increasing. Even China eliminated 10 million manufacturing jobs from 1991 to 2003, according to the Asian Development Bank.   Some U.S. jobs are lost every year, even as more jobs are added, because some businesses shrink or fail. Critics of Nafta toss out anecdotal examples of job losses, which they loosely blame on import competition, rather than on competition from other states. For example, U.S. Steel (now USX) has its headquarters in Pittsburgh, but many of the companys 49,000 employees are now in Indiana, Alabama, Minnesota, Illinois and Texas.   One of the biggest things Nafta accomplished was to cut steep Mexican tariffs on U.S. goods. Half of all American imports from Mexico were already duty-free before Nafta because of the 1976 Generalized System of Preferences. Mexico, on the other hand, imposed brutal tariffs on American goods. The U.S. tariff on Mexican cars was 2.5 percent; the Mexican tariff on U.S. cars was 21.5 percent.   Nafta slashed the Mexican tariff on Heinz Ketchup from 20 percent in 1993 to zero since 1998. In exchange for such dramatic reductions of Mexican tariffs, the U.S. agreed to cut an 8 percent tariff on tomatoes and cut flowers, a 26 percent tariff on frozen orange juice, and a 35 percent tariff on canned tuna. As a result, U.S. consumers saved a lot of money at the grocery store.  Tariffs dont protect jobs. They protect monopoly profits. Tariffs just raise the cost of living and the cost of production, making consumers and producers poorer. Nasty U.S. tariffs on sugar, nuts and milk, for example, impose huge costs on Hershey.   The mutual reduction of trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the U.S. made all three economies more efficient and more affluent. And, yes, Nafta was unquestionably good for Pennsylvania.   Alan Reynolds, a senior fellow with the Cato Institute, is the author of Income and Wealth.

description: WASHINGTON  The war in Iraq collided with White House ambitions in hearing rooms on Capitol Hill on Tuesday as three would-be commanders in chief  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John McCain  came off the campaign trail to question the top American commander in Baghdad, General David H. Petraeus.

title: A Plan on Iran
description: Few informed people doubt the tactical success of General Petraeuss operations since the surge. Uncertainty focuses squarely where it always did: on whether, as an American officer once put it to me, there is anything to join up to politically. The prospect of military action against Iran by the Bush administration appears to have receded. But however great the difficulties of diplomatic engagement with Iran and Syria, some of us question whether American policy in Iraq will ever work unless it is within the framework of very different regional policies for the Middle East.

title: Small Meetings, Big Pluses
description: Small corporate meetings have a virtue  theyre small. That means they usually cost less than big meetings. They can be held at smaller hotels. Their agenda can be better attuned to the particular needs and interests of participants. And they are all the more valuable in a tough business climate.

title: Two Minutes to a Title: Kansas Prevails
description: SAN ANTONIO  The sign on the scoreboard looming above the court at the Alamodome reads: The Road Ends Here.

title: Mr. Silver Does It Again
description: Rarely does one man have a chance to do so much harm to so many.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about Larry Browns ties to the N.C.A.A. mens basketball Final Four teams misstated one of his career moves. He left U.C.L.A. in 1981 to coach the Nets in the N.B.A.  not to coach Kansas, where he went in 1983 after leaving New Jersey.

title: Views Differ on Boy Suspected in Columbia Students Death
description: His aunt says he has cried himself to sleep the last few nights, and has struggled with moving away from a broken home and a depressed mother.

title: The Saturday Night Stay Is Making a Comeback
description: REMEMBER the much-hated, ostensibly long-gone rule that required a Saturday night stay for cheap fares on the major airlines? Well, its back  at least on some routes.

title: Lottery Numbers: April 7, 2008
description: April 7, 2008

title: More Time for More of the Same?
description: Americans this week get another chance to take stock of President Bushs war-without-end in Iraq. Gen. David Petraeus, the military commander in Baghdad, has already signaled his bottom line: there should be a pause in the withdrawal of American troops.

title: The Claim: IPods Can Interfere With Pacemakers
description: THE FACTS

title: Bravos Parent Sues for Runway Rights
description: NBC Universal has gone to court to try to prevent the owners of Project Runway, one of the biggest hits in cable television, from relocating the show next fall from NBC Universals Bravo network to a competitor, Lifetime.

title: Footnotes
description: The Venice Biennale has announced the appointment of Daniel Birnbaum as director of visual arts. He will be the curator of its 53rd International Art Exhibition, opening in June 2009. Since 2001 Mr. Birnbaum, born in Stockholm in 1963, has been rector of the Staedelschule, an international academy in Frankfurt. ... The Roundabout Theater Companys Broadway production of Sunday in the Park With George, above, has been extended for a third time, to continue through June 29 at Studio 54. ...The 1986 film Short Circuit will be remade by Dimension Films from a script by S. S. Wilson and Brent Maddock, who created the characters and wrote the scripts for Short Circuit and its sequel, Short Circuit 2 (1988).

title: Honor for Shea at Shea: He Brought Mets Here
description: William A. Shea, known as the blarney to his law partner Milton S. Goulds chutzpah, liked to poke humor at having his name adorn the home of the Mets.

title: 48 Hours Gets Religion
description: 48 Hours, the CBS newsmagazine usually known for investigating murder mysteries, is about to tackle a very different subject: teenagers who are training to be Christian missionaries. On Tuesday the network is expected to announce a collaboration with two Oscar-nominated filmmakers for a one-hour report titled The Lords Boot Camp. Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, the producers of the acclaimed 2006 documentary Jesus Camp, gained access to an evangelical camp in Florida last year and followed three teenage girls. The resulting report will be shown on Saturday at 8 p.m., Eastern and Pacific times, on CBS. Susan Zirinsky, the executive producer of 48 Hours, said she hoped the project would open the door to future collaborations with filmmakers. We love the crime genre, but this is another interesting way to expand our base, she said.

title: Researchers Find Bacteria That Devour Antibiotics
description: Antibiotic resistance is a simple idea: Bacteria that might be expected to be wiped out by a drug are instead unaffected by it.

title: Disability Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review on Friday about The Genius of Japanese Lacquer: Masterworks by Shibata Zeshin, at Japan Society, referred incorrectly to inro, the small, nested boxes displayed in the exhibition that substituted for pockets in traditional Japanese clothing. They were made to be hung from a waist sash, not around the neck.

title: Congos Horror, as Seen Through a Personal Filter
description: The shrinking of budgets at news outlets across the country means that many atrocities in far corners of the globe receive diminished attention. That documentary filmmakers have persisted in filling the information void is something for which we should all be grateful. And we should be doubly thankful that The Greatest Silence: Rape in the Congo is the second television documentary in recent months to deal with this particular misery. Beggars should not be choosers, and yet still there is something about this film that grates.

title: Play the Feud? Summitt Wants to Play the Game
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Ouster Opens Opportunity for Obama
description: The resignation of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons chief strategist, who came under fire for advising Colombia on a free trade pact, gives Senator Barack Obama an opportunity he has awaited since Mrs. Clinton walloped him on trade issues in Ohio.

title: The Last Open Tract in a Township in Need of Revenue
description: MINE HILL, N.J.  More rust than rustic, parts of John Paschals suburban farm are strewn with cars and their parts, remnants of the farmers former life running a body shop and junkyard: a bus, a shelf full of axles, a camper.

title: Return of the Buffalo
description: While talk of several possible David Mamet revivals has been percolating around Broadway, one has come together for next year: a new production of American Buffalo, Mr. Mamets 1976 profane tale of three low-rent crooks and a really valuable nickel. The play, scheduled to open in the fall at a theater to be named, is being presented on Broadway by Elliot Martin, along with Ben Sprecher and Louise Forlenza. Robert Falls, an old friend of Mr. Mamet from Chicago, will direct and John Leguizamo is in talks to star.

title: Memo Pad
description: FUEL PRICES SHUT 5 AIRLINES Four low-cost airlines ceased passenger operations last week. A fifth, a charter operator, said it would shut at the end of May. All blamed high fuel costs. The four were Aloha Airlines, based in Honolulu; ATA Airlines, based in Indianapolis; Skyway Airlines, of Milwaukee; and Skybus Airlines, of Columbus, Ohio. Champion Air, which operates charter flights for sports teams and corporate incentive trips, said it would close May 31.

title: Injury and Danger No Match for Record-Seeking Freeskier
description: The inspiration for setting a new standard for soaring into the air came to Simon Dumont in January, some six stories above the snow.

title: That Ringing in Your Ear (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Case Involves 2 N.F.L. Players
description: When David Jacobs, a personal trainer and supplement-store owner from Plano, Tex., pleaded guilty to steroid-distribution charges in November and agreed to cooperate with federal authorities, he told a local television station that he would offer evidence linking football players to performance-enhancing drugs.

title: With Laughter and Toughness, Stanford Forges a Path
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As her nickname, Bam Bam, suggests, center Jayne Appel is not much for subtlety on the Stanford womens basketball team. The first week of practice, Coach Tara VanDerveer looked up and saw that Appel had something locked in the crook of her arm. It was not the ball. It was the freshman forward Kayla Pedersens head.

title: Simon Michael Bessie, a Publisher of Major Literary Figures, Dies at 92
description: Simon Michael Bessie, who in 1959 left a top editorial position at what was then called Harper & Brothers to help found Atheneum Publishers, perhaps the last major literary house to be started from scratch in the 20th century, died on Monday at his home in Lyme, Conn. He was 92.

title: Vision: Study Sees Value in Older Cornea Donors
description: In transplanting corneas, the current practice is to reject any donor older than 65. But a new study finds that corneas of people up to 75 years old appear to work just as well.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Friday, about the potential impact of changes to the womens tennis calendar on Serena and Venus Williams, misspelled the given name of a player Serena Williams defeated at the Sony Ericsson Open and misstated the day of their match. She is Justine Henin, not Justin; the match was last Tuesday  not Monday, March 31.

title: Badges Worn by French Athletes Might Violate Olympic Rules
description: The International Olympic Committee may review whether French athletes broke rules prohibiting political protests at Olympic sites after several members of the national team wore badges with the words for a better world at the torch relay in Paris on Monday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about HarperCollinss formation of a new publishing group that will substitute profit-sharing with authors for cash advances and try to eliminate the practice of allowing booksellers to return unsold books misstated the usual basis of royalty payments. After authors have paid off their advances, their royalties are typically 15 percent of the hardcover price for each book sold, not 15 percent of the profits.

title: Cholesterol-Fighting Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: New Path for Kings of Buyouts
description: Private equity bigwigs like David Bonderman used to sneer at the idea of investing in public companies. You know, companies that are traded on stock exchanges  the kind ordinary folks buy. Instead, they espoused the virtues, or at least the big rewards, of taking public companies private.

title: Better Options for Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC and CBS in a Tie
description: On the lowest-rated Sunday for the five broadcast television networks since Christmas Eve 2006, ABC and CBS finished in a tie for first place over all. According to Nielsens estimates, ABC got a lift as usual from Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Oprahs Big Give, which drew 9.9 million and 9.4 million viewers, respectively, at 8 and 9 p.m. The two shows, along with ABCs Here Come the Newlyweds at 10 (7.7 million), delivered the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49; but they trailed CBSs 9 p.m. drama Cold Case for the largest audience over all (11.8 million). CBS, despite matching ABC in total viewers, finished third in the 18-to-49 set behind both ABC and Fox, which broadcast mostly repeats. NBC ranked a distant fourth for the night in that demographic, attracting just 5.7 million and 4 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. with back-to-back debuts of two USA Network cable series, Monk and Psych.

title: Gomezs Playoff Experience With Devils Is Plus for Rangers
description: As Rangers center Scott Gomez skated little circles around the ice at Prudential Center on Sunday, preparing for his shootout attempt against the Devils while fans filled the arena with boos, he could not keep the smile off his face.

title: Children: Heredity May Figure Into Breech Deliveries
description: The tendency to have a breech delivery is inherited, a new study reports, and it is apparently inherited equally through the father and the mother.

title: Cruise Film Delayed
description: "Valkyrie," in which Tom Cruise plays a German officer who tried to assassinate Hitler, will have its release delayed until early next year, MGM and United Artists said on Monday. The film was originally scheduled for release in July 2008, then was bumped to an October date, which would have dropped it into the thick of Hollywoods awards race. The new date is Feb. 13, 2009.

title: Kashmir Says Come On In, the Tee Times Are Safe
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  Naeem Akhtar has an improbable task in the Indian governments drive to revitalize Kashmir after 18 years of militant violence: rebranding this heavily militarized Himalayan region as a global golfing destination.

title: Senate Moves Forward on Housing Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday afternoon to proceed with legislation aimed at easing problems in the housing market, meaning that the senators could vote on final passage of a bill before the end of the week.

title: Motorola and Icahn Reach Compromise on Directors
description: Motorola put an end to a costly and distracting battle with the activist investor Carl C. Icahn on Monday, giving the company a chance to focus on turning around its declining cellphone business.

title: A Dominant Half by Rose Falls Short by One Shot
description: SAN ANTONIO  When Memphis took the floor before Mondays national championship game, the Tigers ran out in single file behind Derrick Rose.

title: A Man Is Locked in Jail, but His Mind Roams Free
description: The Negro Ensemble Company, hoping to sink roots in Harlem, is announcing itself with a distinctive show called Webeime that racks up plenty of style points, though not so many in the substance department.

title: Hard Hits and Hard Work Motivate Giants Fullback
description: WALLBURG, N.C.  Hours after dumping a cooler on Coach Tom Coughlin in the closing moments of the Giants Super Bowl victory, Madison Hedgecock hit the road. Not to the beach, a Vegas casino or Disneyland. Rather, he took his celebration to the National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Ky.

title: As Price of Lead Soars, British Churches Find Holes in Roof
description: EDMONDTHORPE, England  Thieves peeled long strips of lead from the roof of St. Michael and All Angels, until a barking dog sent them fleeing from this tiny Leicestershire village. But by then, they had left a hole of about 100 square feet in the top of the 800-year-old church.

title: California Feuding
description: Two couples are neighbors in Sunnyvale, Calif. One couple plants redwoods and drives a Prius. The other one installs solar panels and drives an electric car. The solar-panel couple sues the redwood couple because the trees block the sun, making the panels less effective.

title: Brigadoon to Return (Doesnt It Always?)
description: A new production of Brigadoon, by Frederick Loewe and Alan Jay Lerner, will materialize out of the mist on Broadway sometime in spring 2009, producers announced Monday. Well, not out of the mist, exactly; out of Boston, where the revival will try out at a theater to be determined.

title: Nielsens Latest Purchase Is Audience Research Firm
description: The Nielsen Company is making another acquisition in a deal that underlines the growing interest in gauging how well advertising works  or fails to work.

title: Advocating Fetal Autopsies (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fears That the Market Watchdog Is Losing Its Bite
description: Not long ago the market police at the Securities and Exchange Commission gave JPMorgan Chase the Wall Street equivalent of a traffic ticket. The penalty: $25 million.

title: Fears of Iraq Becoming a Terrorist Incubator Seem Overblown, French Say
description: PARIS  After the Paris police smashed a cell suspected of sending insurgents to Iraq early in 2005, French authorities predicted a new and dangerous threat: young Muslims lured to the Iraqi battlefields who would return, radicalized, to use their newfound battlefield skills in terrorist acts inside France.

title: Suit Accuses Pediatrician of Abuse
description: BOSTON  A prominent pediatrician and best-selling author put his medical license on inactive status in North Carolina last week after a civil lawsuit accused him of sexually abusing young patients here years ago.

title: Novartis and Nestl in a Deal for Alcon
description: PARIS  The Swiss drug maker Novartis said on Monday that it would pay Nestl $11 billion for a 25 percent stake in Alcon, the worlds biggest eye care company, in the first step of a deal that could become a full acquisition.

title: Just Practice, but Masters Rookie Says Its the Best
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  With a cool breeze blowing down in Amen Corner, the throng sitting on the hillside behind the 12th tee rose in unison to wrap Gary Player, 72, in one of those warm blankets of Masters applause  for his 51st appearance here, for his three Masters titles, for his boundless enthusiasm.

title: For the Giants, Bondss Presence Is in the Past
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barry Bondss larger-than-life presence with the San Francisco Giants has been essentially replaced by a small plaque in right-center field that marks the record-setting 756th career home run he hit in August.

title: Charity Hospital, on Brink, Gets a $200 Million Gift
description: ATLANTA  Grady Memorial Hospital, one of the countrys largest charity hospitals, will receive $200 million from a private foundation with ties to Coca-Cola, hospital officials said Monday.

title: An All-Brahms Program, Both Passionate and Poised
description: Brahms, an intensely self-critical composer who destroyed many of his works before publication, described his Clarinet Trio in A minor and Clarinet Quintet in B minor as twin pieces of foolishness. The many Brahms bashers in the late 19th and early 20th centuries perhaps agreed.

title: Designing the Future by the Seat of Our Pants
description: New Yorks wallow in baseball nostalgia shifts to Queens on Tuesday with the Mets last opening day at Shea Stadium. Next year the team will move into a new playground, Citi Field, named for a bank whose vanity seems as deep as its pockets.

title: Sailing Off With Heroes of Irelands Ancient Times
description: Does anyone in contemporary dance have a stranger and more fantastical imagination than Christopher Williams? In The Voyage of the Hui Corra, his new piece for the Second Avenue Dance Company of the Tisch School of the Arts, the costumes are relatively restrained, and there is more dancing than he often includes in his tableaux-

title: Citigroup Director Expected to Quit Key Committee
description: The chairman of Citigroups audit and risk committee, C. Michael Armstrong, who has overseen more than $22 billion in write-offs, is poised to resign from that post under pressure from shareholders, people briefed on the situation said Monday.

title: For McCain, Little Talk of a Controversial Endorsement
description: When Senator John McCain won the endorsement of the Rev. John C. Hagee in February, his campaign hoped it would shore up his conservative credentials among evangelicals and build enthusiasm among a voting bloc that would be critical for him in November.

title: Broken Soldiers, and a Broken System
description: To the Editor:

title: Facebook Reportedly Near Accord Over Origin
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook may soon close an uncomfortable chapter in its brief history: a legal dispute over its origins.

title: Power to Build Border Fence Is Above U.S. Law
description: Securing the nations borders is so important, Congress says, that Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary, must have the power to ignore any laws that stand in the way of building a border fence. Any laws at all.

title: Wide Net Cast by Lobby for Colombia Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON  There have been all-expense paid trips to Colombia for more than 50 members of Congress, featuring coffee tastings and dinner at a posh restaurant inside an old Spanish fort. The Colombian president has visited Washington to make personal appeals. Major corporations like WalMart and Citigroup are taking up the cause. And former Clinton administration officials have landed lucrative lobbying contracts.

title: High Court in Zimbabwe Delays Ruling on Vote
description: JOHANNESBURG  The High Court of Zimbabwe on Monday delayed a decision on whether to force the government to release the results of the March 29 presidential election, prolonging an impasse that seemed to be growing increasingly acrimonious at each turn.

title: Flying Glass Fragments May Have Tricked Officers
description: The police bullets that shattered the passenger window of Sean Bells car would have sent glass shards flying outward, toward the officers firing their guns, and could have made it appear to the officers that someone in the car was shooting at them, a crime scene analyst testified on Monday.

title: Washington Post Wins Six Pulitzers
description: The Washington Post won six Pulitzer Prizes on Monday, the second most any newspaper has won in a year, including awards for reporting that helped define much of the national political dialogue in 2007.

title: At 60, Not Ready to Punch Out
description: Saoul Mamby is 60, fewer than 15 months from eligibility for Social Security checks, but he is not ready to retire. He is keeping the job he has held for 39 years: professional boxer.

title: Searching Debris of Katrina for Memories
description: NEW ORLEANS  Kierstyn Cyrus cracked open the front door of her ruined home, a single goal in mind, just one precious thing she wanted to rescue. It was October 2005, the first time since Hurricane Katrina that she had stepped inside the brick ranch at 2455 Deslonde Street in the Lower Ninth Ward. The morning before a levee burst four blocks away, Kierstyn, her mother and grandmother had fled 250 miles inland.

title: Teachers at Catholic Schools Suspend Strike
description: Striking teachers at Catholic schools announced on Monday night that they had temporarily suspended their job action against the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Potential for Harm in Dietary Supplements
description: A form of substance abuse rampant in this country is rarely discussed publicly or privately. It involves abusing legally sold dietary supplements  vitamins, minerals, herbals and homeopathic remedies  all of which can be sold over the counter without prior approval for safety and effectiveness.

title: Familiar Face in a Different Morning Spot
description: The fourth hour of Today badly needed some pizazz.

title: Bush Says Economy Is Poised to Rebound
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush urged Congress on Monday to resist efforts by Democrats to pass a second economic stimulus package, saying that while the economy is in a rough time right now, he is confident it will begin to rebound by the end of the year.

title: Captured but Living Long Enough to Sing About It
description: Can I ask what a woman like you is doing in a dive like this? That cornball pickup line takes on gruesome comic undertones in the new rock musical Hostage Song. It is spoken by a man who is blindfolded and bound. The object of his apparent interest is the only woman in the room, who is similarly incapacitated. They share a dingy cell, a few moments of tender communion and occasionally a microphone in this ragged but adventurous show at the Kraine Theater in the East Village.

title: N.B.A. and N.C.A.A. to Run Youth System
description: SAN ANTONIO  The basketball luminaries from all levels wore crisp suits, gathered for pictures and spoke with boundless optimism about the future of the game. In all, 13 executives and leaders from high school, college and the N.B.A. lined up for an announcement they billed as something that could change the face of basketball in America. They just did not say quite how.

title: A.M.D., Citing a Slowdown, to Cut 1,650 Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Advanced Micro Devices said it would cut about 1,650 workers  about 10 percent of its work force  because of deteriorating business conditions across its units around the globe.

title: Hermaphrodite Frogs Found in Suburban Ponds
description: Just as frogs mating season arrives, a study by a Yale professor raises a troubling issue. How many frogs will be clear on their role in the annual springtime ritual?

title: Ewing to Join His Coach and a Rival in the Hall
description: Patrick Ewing, who rescued the Knicks from their malaise in the 1980s and made them an Eastern Conference power in the 1990s, has been elected to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame. He will be inducted this fall, along with one of his most beloved coaches, Pat Riley, and one of his greatest rivals, Hakeem Olajuwon.

title: Yahoo Answers Microsoft With Yet Another No
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After their top executives traded recriminations in an exchange of letters, Microsoft and Yahoo continued their stalemate, with Yahoo shareholders expected to play an increasingly large role in the takeover battle.

title: Bar Code Sales Tool Is Failing Campus Test
description: IN parts of Asia and Europe, marketers have been using bar code technology to help sell things to people on their cellphones. A consumer can point a phone at something intriguing that bears a signature black-and-white square, then get information about a product or service or an offer to purchase it.

title: Keeping Priorities Straight, Even at the End
description: As a professor of computer sciences at Carnegie Mellon University, Randy F. Pausch expected students to pay attention to his lectures. He never expected that the rest of the world would listen, too.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the pianist who helped found the Beaux Arts Trio, which gave its final New York performance on Sunday evening, misspelled his given name. He is Menahem Pressler, not Menachem. (The error also appeared in two picture captions and in capsule summaries about the article and about related information at nytimes.com/music.)

title: As the General Briefs Congress on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Upper West Side Couple Settles Suit Over a Neighbors Smoke
description: The war over secondhand smoke at the Ansonia has ended.

title: Times Reporter Is Released on Bail in Zimbabwe
description: A reporter for The New York Times who was jailed for covering the elections in Zimbabwe without government permission was arraigned and released on bail on Monday, according to Harrison Nkomo, one of his lawyers.

title: Vanished: A Pueblo Mystery
description: Perched on a lonesome bluff above the dusty San Pedro River, about 30 miles east of Tucson, the ancient stone ruin archaeologists call the Davis Ranch Site doesnt seem to fit in. Staring back from the opposite bank, the tumbled walls of Reeve Ruin are just as surprising.

title: Focus of a Raid in Texas Was Living Out of State
description: ELDORADO, Tex.  A 50-year-old man sought for arrest on a sexual abuse complaint that Texas authorities said had led them to raid a polygamist compound here is not in hiding but living in Arizona with three women and their 22 children and disavows any role in the case, his probation officer said Monday.

title: Queens Man Is Charged in the Killing of His Wife
description: A man has been charged with fatally stabbing his wife and wounding his daughter, who was trying to help her mother in the attack at their home in northern Queens, the police said on Monday.

title: A Network of Truces
description: The U.S. brought no shortage of misconceptions into Iraq, but surely the longest lasting has been what you might call: Founding Fatherism. This is the belief that peace will come to the country when the nations political elites gather at a convention hall and make a series of grand compromises involving power-sharing and a new constitution.

title: Tony Award in Mystery Sale
description: Heres some good news for producers hard up for cash: The 1991 Tony Award for best musical revival, honoring the producers Barry and Fran Weissler for Fiddler on the Roof, below, was sold at auction in Dallas on Saturday night for $5,676.25.

title: In U.S., Metal Theft Plagues Troubled Neighborhoods
description: CLEVELAND  Metal scrappers have attacked churches and ransacked homes in this Midwestern city, leaving entire neighborhoods uninhabitable.

title: Concern for a Stranger (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Suicide Bigger Threat for Police Than Criminals
description: NORWALK, Conn.  When Matthew Morelli, a 38-year-old police officer, was found slumped in a secluded parking lot with an AK-47 rifle on March 21, state and local authorities spent two days looking for a suspect, with helicopters and police dogs scouring the neighborhood, where witnesses reported hearing multiple shots. The culprit turned out to be a stealthy if surprisingly familiar cop killer: suicide.

title: Testimony by General Will Test Candidates for President
description: WASHINGTON  Three presidential candidates and two very different views of Iraq will be on full display on Tuesday as Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Baghdad, testifies before the Senate in a marathon session of war and White House ambitions.

title: Theres Gas in Those Hills
description: HUGHESVILLE, Pa.  At first, Raymond Gregoire did not want to listen to the raspy voice on his answering machine offering him money for rights to drill on his land. They want to ruin my land, he thought. But he called back anyway a week later to hear more.

title: Whats Making That Awful Racket? Surprisingly, It May Be Fish
description: Eerie Thumps Haunt Some Cape Residents, a headline in The News-Press of Cape Coral, Fla., said. Noise May Cost City Big Bucks.

title: Crackdown on Militias Raises Stability Concerns
description: BAGHDAD  A crackdown on the Mahdi Army militia is creating potentially destabilizing political and military tensions in Iraq, pitting a stronger government alliance against the force that has won past showdowns: the street power wielded by the radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr.

title: CBS Said to Consider Use of CNN in Reporting
description: CBS, the home of the most celebrated news division in broadcasting, has been in discussions with Time Warner about a deal to outsource some of its news-gathering operations to CNN, two executives briefed on the matter said Monday.

title: Increasing Obesity Requires New Ambulance Equipment
description: CONCORD, N.H.  Calls from obese patients had increased nearly 25 percent in recent years, and the Fire Department could no longer handle them.

title: California Hospital Faces Sanctions After Workers Wrongly Looked at Patient Records
description: LOS ANGELES  The head of Californias health department said Monday that the agency planned to sanction the University of California, Los Angeles, Medical Center after hospital workers improperly viewed the records of more than 60 patients, including the actress Farrah Fawcett and the states first lady, Maria Shriver.

title: Accident Changed Corzine, Not His Political Agenda
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Gov. Jon S. Corzine swears that he wears his seat belt now, and reminds others to do the same. He says he feels so blessed to be alive that he takes far better care of himself now. And he says he is touched when people wish him well, even if they do not care for his policies.

title: And Behind Door No. 1, a Fatal Flaw
description: The Monty Hall Problem has struck again, and this time its not merely embarrassing mathematicians. If the calculations of a Yale economist are correct, theres a sneaky logical fallacy in some of the most famous experiments in psychology.

title: Recession Worries Drove Rate Cut, Minutes Show
description: Federal Reserve policy makers now believe the economy will probably contract in the first half of the year, and they said a prolonged and severe economic downturn could not be ruled out, according to minutes of the Feds meeting on March 18.

title: State Oil Industrys Future Sets Off Tussle in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  A bitter debate over what to do about Mexicos ailing state oil monopoly has dominated national politics here in recent weeks, tapping strong emotions on both sides and resurrecting the political fortunes of the leftist leader who narrowly lost the 2006 presidential election.

title: A Group Says Goodbye to Its New York Fans
description: In the early part of the 20th century piano trios were glamorous for all the wrong reasons. Mostly, they were occasional collaborations of star soloists: Cortot, Thibaud and Casals, for example, or Rubinstein, Heifetz and Piatigorsky. As chamber groups in the best sense, these trios had nothing on the great string quartets, groups that rehearsed intensively and performed almost as a single organism.

title: Rothko Kin Sue to Transfer His Remains
description: For 38 years the body of the artist Mark Rothko has rested in an unassuming cemetery on the North Fork of Long Island, a quiet reminder of both the Abstract Expressionist legacy and one of the harshest legal battles ever to rock the art world.

title: Traveling With a Moody Old Friend Thats Tightly Strung
description: FLYING is never simple for me. Its not really a simple process for anyone these days, but I have a permanent challenge. I travel with a cello. Depending on my energy level and the actual amount of support or resistance I encounter from security or fellow passengers, my cello brings about moments of connection, amusement, anxiety or intense frustration. Often all in the same trip.

title: Obama Gets Help in Pennsylvania

title: Brooklyn Storefronts as Metaphor for a Changing Borough

Now he does freelance page layout for publishers of science and technical books. But Mr. Lacys real passion  like that of so many New Yorkers who are defined as much by their hobbies as their day jobs  is street photography. He has just published his first book, Brooklyn Storefronts, a collection of 75 color photographs of small, independently owned stores throughout the borough.

title: Brooklyns Changing Storefronts
description: Slide Show: Brooklyn StorefrontsPaul Lacy, 50, has lived in Brooklyn for all but two years since 1983. He has worked as a factory night watchman and an apprentice furniture maker. Now he does freelance page layout for publishers of science and technical books. But Mr. Lacy's real passion -- like that of so many New Yorkers who are defined as much by their hobbies as their day jobs -- is street photography. He has just published his first book, "Brooklyn Storefronts," a collection of 75 color photographs of small, independently owned stores throughout the borough.   City Room first noticed the book, which W. W. Norton published as a paperback last month, during a visit to the Whitney Biennial; it was on sale in the gift shop. More than merely documenting the great variety of small businesses in Brooklyn, it provides a glimpse of the often rapid social and economic change that many residents fear is transforming Brooklyn neighborhoods and threatening the unique enterprises that have long made them distinctive.   In a phone interview, Mr. Lacy said he began photographing the storefronts a few years ago, often encountering subjects while riding his bicycle, whether to get some exercise, take a break from work or check out new restaurants.  "I knew northern Brooklyn and coastal Brooklyn, but I didn't know the central Brooklyn area where I was to move," he said. "In a way, I was exploring all the places that I would then patronize. If I saw a place that repaired vacuum cleaners, I would think, 'Hey, I should remember that.' "  The images, taken since 2001, certainly reflect the eclectic nature of Brooklyn commerce -- and of Mr. Lacy's tastes. The images invite all sorts of questions. Who would have guessed that there was a taxidermist shop at 964 Jamaica Avenue in Cypress Hills, on the Brooklyn-Queens border? What is shown or performed at the Impact Theater at 190 Underhill Avenue in Prospect Heights? What kinds of "statuettes" and "variety items" are sold at Fraille Botanica at 616 Flatbush Avenue, in Flatbush? Are there other sins besides alcohol at the Sin City Lounge, at 59 Montrose Street in Williamsburg? What does the Egyptian iconography signify outside the Smai Tawi Afrakan Kultural Wellness and Martial Art Center, at 106 Kingston Avenue in Crown Heights -- and what explains the unusual spelling?  In the foreword to the book, Mr. Lacy admits that his visual record of Brooklyn's storefronts might seem "a bit odd," and indeed, some store owners would pop outside to ask why he was taking snapshots. Mr. Lacy writes:   Granted, "you can't judge a book by its cover," but a small, independently owned store is singular and so is a handpainted sign. When you see one, you have to wonder whether there will be something inside not found in the other stores, let alone the chains and franchises. Very often there is: a lovingly made dish made from a family recipe, a display of photographs or posters, a funny story, catchy tunes from another land: there are so many surprises.   Mr. Lacy moved to Brooklyn in 1982, a year after graduating from the Rhode Island School of Design, where he studied painting. He has lived in a wide variety of Brooklyn neighborhoods: Greenpoint, Williamsburg, East Williamsburg (or is it Bushwick?), Boerum Hill, Gowanus, Fort Greene and now Crown Heights.   Mr. Lacy said the book "came about somewhat by chance" when the owner of a garage with a 12-foot-high Trinidadian flag painted on the door asked to see some of Mr. Lacy's other pictures. Mr. Lacy made those prints to show to the store owner; Mr. Lacy also showed the prints to a friend, who passed them on to James L. Mairs, an editor at Norton and the publisher of Quantuck Lane Press, which publishes photography books.  Virtually all the 75 businesses in the book have hand-made signs, a feature that Mr. Lacy considers particularly distinctive. There is not a Starbucks, a bank branch or a chain store among the 160 pages.  "For me, this is an exploration I have not finished," Mr. Lacy said in the interview. But even as he continues his photography journey, the stores themselves are changing.   Indeed, by the time Mr. Lacy wrote the foreword to his book in September 2007, he estimated that one-fifth of the storefronts had already changed during the previous five years. "Their signs have been painted over, or replaced by a new sign, or the business has changed altogether," he wrote. "And there are new stores with new signs. In this sense, the book could never be complete."   Asked what criteria were used to select images, Mr. Lacy reflected a bit and wrote in an e-mail message, "It was never stated outright while Jim and I were selecting the pictures, because we were proceeding intuitively, but one way to think about it is warmth. Warmth -- the way people talk about vinyl records as having a warmer sound than do CDs. ... So yes, there is nostalgia, but also there is a timeless value, a preference, if you will, for that which is warm and friendly."   The images are crisply focused and artfully composed, but Mr. Lacy's technology is rather simple. He used a Canon digital point-and-shoot camera to take the photographs, although he has worked in the past with single-lens reflex cameras, which more advanced photographers generally prefer.   "I'd go back and visit the same place until I felt it was the right time to take the picture," Mr. Lacy said, explaining that he often waited for a time of day with more compelling light, or even for a day when different alternate-side parking rules were in effect so that cars would not obstruct his view of the storefronts. Even as the stores change, the parking rules, it seems, remain constant.

title: 11 High Schools Are Identified as Failing
description: Eleven New York City high schools have been newly identified as failing under the federal No Child Left Behind law, the State Education Department said today. Fourteen city high schools have improved enough to be removed from the list, which is released each year.In December, the state added 60 city elementary and middle schools to the list of those failing under the federal law. Of the more than 1,400 schools in New York City, 374 are now deemed failing under the federal law, including 81 high schools  up from 335 last year. (An additional 69 city schools have similarly failed to meet standards, but they were not placed on the failing schools list because they do not receive federal Title I antipoverty money.)

title: Ving, Vang, Vong. Or, the Pleasures of a New Vocabulary.
description: Lately Ive been thinking about the word vang. It is a sailing term, and if you look it up in the glossary of Royces Sailing Illustrated, you find that it refers to a line to prevent the peak of a gaff from falling off leeward. That is how it goes when youre learning a new technical vocabulary. The language seems self-enclosed at first, each new definition an opaque cluster of words that themselves need defining. I was taught, during vocabulary in grade school, to try using a new word in a sentence. There is a vang. Can someone show me the vang? Those are my best efforts so far.
