title: Stone Temple Pilots to Rock Again
description: The Grammy Award-winning Stone Temple Pilots, after a five-year breakup and a nearly eight-year absence from concerts, plan to reunite for a 65-city North American tour that will begin on May 17 in Columbus, Ohio, The Associated Press reported. The storys not finished, the singer Scott Weiland said. Theres more to be revealed and more to be told. Founded in 1992, the rock band, including the brothers Dean DeLeo (guitarist) and Robert DeLeo (bass) and the drummer Eric Kretz, has sold more than 35 million albums worldwide.

title: U.S. Says It Will Increase Efforts Against Tax Defiers
description: If you think paying taxes is unfair, illegal or unconstitutional, then watch out  the Justice Department is after you.

title: Iran Says Its Installing New Centrifuges
description: TEHRAN  Iran announced on Tuesday a significant expansion of its plans to enrich uranium despite the United Nations Security Councils demand that it halt the program. President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said during a visit to Irans main enrichment complex at Natanz that the country had started installing 6,000 centrifuges at the site, in addition to the existing 3,000 centrifuges.

title: Rising Rents Force Older Businesses to New Sites
description: Is there a second act for the mom-and-pop shop in New York?

title: Take Alternate Route
description: WITH congestion pricing dead (for now), New York City is left with drivers still stuck in traffic and transit riders packed like sardines. How else can we ease traffic jams and provide decent and affordable bus and subway service? Both the state and the city have work to do.

title: Official Had Controversial Photos Deleted, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top immigration enforcement official ordered the destruction of photographs of an office Halloween party that showed a white agency employee dressed as a black detainee, according to a Congressional investigation whose report was released on Tuesday.

title: At Hearings, a Chance to Explain Iraq Views and Audition as Commander in Chief
description: WASHINGTON  The war in Iraq collided with White House ambitions in hearing rooms on Capitol Hill on Tuesday as three would-be commanders in chief  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John McCain  swooped in from the campaign trail to question the top American commander in Baghdad, Gen. David H. Petraeus.

title: Quota Limit for High-Skill Visas Is Reached
description: Federal immigration officials said they had received enough applications for three-year visas for high-skilled immigrants, known as H-1B, to meet the quota of 65,000 for the year beginning Oct. 1. Officials at Citizenship and Immigration Services said they closed the application period, which started April 1, after the pre-set minimum of five days. The agency also received enough applications to surpass an annual quota of 20,000 work visas for immigrants with a masters degree or higher from an American college or university. The agency has not finished counting the applications, but they are expected to greatly exceed the quotas. In coming days, officials said, the agency will run an electronic lottery to select immigrants who will receive visas, in a process that prompted calls from technology businesses to raise the visa limits.

title: Mexico: Bees Attack Police
description: African honeybees, also known as killer bees for their aggressive behavior, attacked about 20 state police officers in southern Tapachula on Monday morning as they practiced shooting at a firing range. Several officers were treated at a hospital. The officers apparently shot one of several hives near the range, provoking the easily agitated strain of bees. Some of us hit the ground, but that didnt help, Officer Miguel Serrano told The Associated Press.

title: Legislators Balk at Tying Teacher Tenure to Student Tests
description: ALBANY  In the latest rebuke to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs agenda, state lawmakers have decided to bar student test scores from being considered when teacher tenure determinations are made.

title: City Blames Weak Rock for Fallen Wall
description: A temporary retaining wall at a building site on the Upper West Side collapsed last summer because it was erected on rock that was too weak to hold it, according to a report from the citys Department of Buildings.

title: At Age 17, Ski Resort Has a Troubled Past (and Present)
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  Ever since it sprouted in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado 17 years ago, the Peaks Resort has loomed large over this tiny ski town. With about 170 rooms, the Peaks is the regions largest hotel, a major employer and a crucial asset in luring the conventions and wealthy tourists who fuel the economy.

title: Quickly and Easily, a Touch of Elegance
description: MOSTLY I play down elegance  its too complicated and fussy for most home cooks to bother with  but occasionally Im surprised at how easily it can be achieved. That was the case a couple of weeks ago when I decided to try to mimic a restaurant-style dish that resembles stuffed cabbage but contains far fewer ingredients and can be put together in less than half an hour.

title: Where the Lights Are Never Low
description: A FRIEND from Spain was in town, and I needed to take him to dinner. On the promising list of new restaurants I was checking out, which would send him home with the most vivid memories of the city? With the right ones?

title: Court Files Detail Claims of Sects Pattern of Abuse
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  Texas authorities released court documents on Tuesday detailing accusations of a widespread pattern of physical and sexual abuse of children by a polygamous sect.

title: Economy Has Become a Drag on Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Housing prices in Silicon Valley remain defiantly high. New BMWs and Saabs cruise Highway 101. But for the first time there are signs that the current economic downturn is taking its toll on the countrys cradle of technology and innovation.

title: Hung Jury in Case of Noted Coroner, but Hell Be Retried
description: PITTSBURGH  A federal judge declared a mistrial Tuesday in the criminal case against Dr. Cyril H. Wecht, one of the nations best-known forensic pathologists, after jurors failed to agree on a verdict on any of 41 charges that he had used his public position as county coroner here to benefit his private pathology practice.

title: Iceland: A Retailer Plans to Shed Units
description: The Baugur Group, the Icelandic owner of the House of Fraser department stores in Britain, will sell its media, technology and financial units for 430 million ($852 million) and use the funds to expand in retail. Assets including a property investor, the FL Group; and Saga Film and EFG, a cinema producer, will be sold to two independent companies led by Baugur directors, the company said. Baugur investments including Saga, the media company 365 and Teymi, which offers information-technology services, will be sold to Stodir Invest, while financial assets like FL will go to Styrkur Invest. Baugur is based in Reykjavik.

title: Job Losses Bolster Calls for Extension of Benefits
description: Job losses in the national economy combined with a surge in new claims for unemployment insurance are giving a boost to proposals  pushed for months by Democratic leaders and labor groups  to extend unemployment benefits beyond their usual limit of 26 weeks.

title: Footnotes
description: The world premiere engagement of Betrayed has been extended for a second time, through June 28 at the Culture Project in SoHo. This well-received play by George Packer, top, deals with the suffering of Iraqis who risked everything to help the American government and military in Iraq and often received insufficient protection in return. ... The reunited boy band New Kids on the Block will play its first engagement in 14 years on May 17 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., during the annual Zootopia concert of the New York radio station Z100 (WHTZ, 100.3 FM), Reuters reported. Also featured will be Miley Cyrus, Jordin Sparks, the Jonas Brothers, OneRepublic, Simple Plan, Sara Bareilles, Gavin DeGraw and Ferras. ... Emmylou Harris, above, who will be inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame on April 27, will release her new album, All I Intended to Be, on the Nonesuch label on June 10. Its her first recording of new material in nearly five years. ... A new Neil Diamond album, Home Before Dark (Columbia), will be released on May 6, Reuters reported. Mr. Diamond begins a monthlong European tour in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, on May 24 and is expected to tour North America in the summer.

title: As Torch Reaches San Francisco, It Runs for Cover Before Its Run
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Olympic torch arrived at the airport here from Paris in the wee hours Tuesday morning, exited out a side door and was escorted by motorcade to a downtown hotel. There it took a well-deserved break in a room complete with cable TV, room service and views of the citys popular Union Square shopping district.

title: Woods Favored, but Others Like Their Chances
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods, contrary to popular perception, is not unbeatable on a golf course. He is not indomitable even at Augusta National Golf Club, where he has won 4 times in 13 appearances and where he is the even-money favorite to win the 72nd Masters, which begins Thursday.

title: West Virginia Senator Apologizes for Comments on McCain
description: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV personally apologized to Senator John McCain of Arizona on Tuesday after remarking in an interview that Mr. McCains years as a Navy pilot would not have given him an understanding of everyday issues faced by Americans.

title: Progress Cited in Korea Nuclear Talks Impasse
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea and the United States made significant progress on Tuesday toward ending an impasse in talks aimed at revealing the full scale of the Norths nuclear weapons programs and dismantling them, top negotiators from both countries said.

title: Lawmaker Found Guilty of Corruption
description: State Assemblywoman Diane M. Gordon of Brooklyn was convicted on Tuesday of receiving a bribe for offering to help a developer acquire a parcel of city-owned land in her district if he would build her a free house in a gated community in Queens.

title: In Justice Shift, Corporate Deals Replace Trials
description: WASHINGTON  In 2005, federal authorities concluded that a Monsanto consultant had visited the home of an Indonesian official and, with the approval of a senior company executive, handed over an envelope stuffed with hundred-dollar bills. The money was meant as a bribe to win looser environmental regulations for Monsantos cotton crops, according to a court document. Monsanto was also caught concealing the bribe with fake invoices.

title: Accounts of Violence Spread in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  Ten days after Zimbabwe voted and by most accounts rejected its long-serving, autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, the mood of the country grew more ominous on Tuesday. The opposition reported widespread attacks on its supporters, black youths drove white farmers off their land and election officials were accused of vote tampering and arrested.

title: Marketers Find a Sound That Draws a Crowd
description: IN cartoons, the Road Runner goes Beep, beep. On Madison Avenue, the popular onomatopoeia is pronounced Bleep, bleep.

title: Summitt and Tennessee Roll to Another Title
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Thirty-four seasons ago, after Pat Summitt had coached her first game at Tennessee, she phoned home.

title: Bank Hit by Rogue Trader Tries to Reassure Lawmakers
description: PARIS  The chairman and chief executive of Socit Gnrale said Wednesday that the bank expected to spend as much as 100 million euros or $157 million this year to improve its risk-management systems after a trading scandal led to losses of nearly 5 billion euros.

title: Chances of Homeowner Relief Losing Momentum in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan effort in the Senate on tax breaks to stabilize the housing market and other aid for homeowners at risk of foreclosure began to crumble on Tuesday, as the White House threatened a veto, saying the bill would only make things worse.

title: Judge Jails Pete Doherty
description: The trouble-prone British rocker Pete Doherty, right, was sentenced on Tuesday to 14 weeks in jail for violating the terms of his probation, Reuters reported. The punishment cost Mr. Doherty, the 29-year-old Babyshambles frontman, a major solo engagement at the Royal Albert Hall on April 26 and an appearance the next day at the Love Music Hate Racism concert in London. He is also scheduled to perform at the Glastonbury Festival, June 27 to 29. In a statement about the Royal Albert Hall postponement, his record label, Parlophone, said, Peter was very much looking forward to the show and would like to offer his sincerest apologies to all his fans and all those concerned. At a hearing in West London Magistrates Court Mr. Doherty was jailed for violating probation and using drugs, the BBC reported. In earlier proceedings he was given a suspended jail sentence for drug possession and driving illegally last October. His supervision order required him to visit court regularly to make progress reports and to take part in a rehabilitation program. The BBC reported that he had missed one appointment with his probation officer and was late for another.

title: An Architect of the CVS Deal Will Start a Turnaround Firm
description: The former chief of Caremark Rx who orchestrated its $26.5 billion sale last year to the drugstore chain CVS is getting into the deal business full time.

title: The Torch and Freedom
description: After facing major protests in London and Paris as the Olympic torch made stops on its journey to Beijing, the Chinese government is said to be looking for a public relations firm to patch up Chinas image before the 2008 Games in August. In the spirit of the Olympic ideals, we are prepared to help China  free of charge.

title: Beat the Devils? The Rangers Join Them
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The rivalry between the Rangers and the Devils has undergone a drastic transformation since the teams last met in the playoffs two years ago.

title: 7 Are Charged in Illegal Trading Inquiry at Nymex
description: Seven men have been charged after a joint investigation by New York prosecutors and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission into accusations of front-running, evidence tampering and bribery at the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: With Words or His Bat, Rollins Shakes Up Mets
description: Jimmy Rollins smiled, which he does quite easily. His Phillies had just beaten the Mets, which he is making seem easier still.

title: Petraeus Urges Halt in Weighing New Cut in Force
description: WASHINGTON  Telling Congress that progress in Iraq was fragile and reversible, the top American commander recommended Tuesday that consideration of any new withdrawals of American troops be delayed until the fall, making it likely that little would change before Election Day.

title: In Northern Iraq, the Kurds Find Success Amid Struggle
description: The script for Iraq was supposed to go like this: The dictator topples; the oppressed masses celebrate; democracy takes root; and the United States, showered with gratitude, embraces a new, pro-Western ally in the hostile Middle East.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a shortage of primary care physicians in Massachusetts misstated a word in a quotation by Katherine J. Atkinson, a doctor who said that her insurance reimbursements often do not cover her costs. She said, I calculated that every time I have a Medicaid patient, its like handing them a $20 bill when they leave; she did not say Medicare patient.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions last Wednesday about a Justice Department legal memorandum on interrogation methods misstated the day the memo was released in 2003 and referred incorrectly to the resignation of Jay S. Bybee, who signed the memo, in relationship to the memos release. It was issued on March 14, a Friday, not a Saturday; and that was two weeks before Mr. Bybee resigned as the head of the Office of Legal Counsel, not the day after he left.

title: Strawberry Joins SNY as Part-Time Analyst
description: Darryl Strawberry is a part-time Mets analyst for SportsNet New York, announcing a deal Tuesday that will have him in the networks Manhattan studio for 15 pre- and postgame shows this season when his former teammate Lee Mazzilli has a day off.

description: Adapted from Benoit

description: Looking Ahead

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some editions on Sunday and in some copies on Monday about the actor Charlton Heston misstated his given name at birth. It was John Charles Carter, not Charlton Carter. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the character played by Orson Welles in the film Touch of Evil, in which Mr. Heston had a starring role. The character, Quinlan, is a police captain, not a sheriff. And a list of Mr. Hestons films accompanying the obituary on Monday misstated the relationship between two characters in the film Midway, in which Mr. Heston played a Naval officer. The characters, the officers son and a woman of Japanese descent, are hoping to marry; they are not already married.

title: Asian Carrier Shuts Down, Stranding Thousands
description: HONG KONG  Oasis Hong Kong Airlines, a long-haul budget carrier that tried to offer premium service and spacious seats at low prices, suddenly went into liquidation on Wednesday and canceled all flights, the fourth budget carrier worldwide to halt operations in the last week and a half.

title: New Entertainment President at HBO
description: HBO said Wednesday afternoon that it had selected Sue Naegle, a Hollywood talent agent, as the president of its entertainment division, and charged her with helping the cable channel finds its next Sopranos and Sex and the City.

title: 9 Officers Sentenced in Philippine Coup Plot
description: MANILA  A Philippine court on Tuesday sentenced nine military officers to prison terms ranging from 6 years to up to 40 years for participating in a 2003 coup attempt against President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

title: The Outlaw Glamour of a Long-Banned Fruit
description: The mangosteen, a Southeast Asian fruit, is stepping into the spotlight this year, its second in markets in the United States. It is available at more stores and the price is down, though perhaps only connoisseurs will eagerly part with $6 a fruit at Dean & DeLuca stores and Agata & Valentina, or $4 at Kings supermarkets in New Jersey.

title: Former Israeli President Drops Plea Deal
description: JERUSALEM  In a dramatic courtroom twist, Moshe Katsav, the former president of Israel, backed out of a plea agreement on Tuesday that required him to admit to having committed sexual offenses against female employees.

description: How has the United States economy gotten to this point?

description: So, the best advice if you are planning to travel on Thursday?

description: Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Citi Is Said to Be Near Deal to Sell $12.5 Billion of Loans
description: Private equity moguls are doubling down  on their own takeovers.

title: William D. Eberle, Trade Representative for Nixon, Is Dead at 84
description: William D. Eberle, who pushed Europe and Japan to lower trade barriers as President Richard M. Nixons chief trade negotiator in the 1970s, died Thursday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 84.

title: Equestrians Deaths Spread Unease in Sport
description: A failed jump by one of the worlds finest riders and a spate of deaths have unnerved the equestrian community.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the Penn Center, a school for freed slaves on St. Helena Island, S.C., that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King used as a retreat center misstated the age of Joseph McDomick, a former staff member. He is 69, not 72.

title: A.B.T. Plans Tudor Tribute
description: American Ballet Theater will salute the centennial of the birth of the choreographer Antony Tudor (1908-1987) in its fall season at City Center, from Oct. 21 through Nov. 2. His works will be presented at each performance, and the Oct. 31 program  the Tudor Centennial Tribute, with special guest appearances and films of Tudor at work  will be devoted entirely to his dances. The evening will include Continuo (1971), Jardin aux Lilas (1936) and pas de deux from Romeo and Juliet (1943) and The Leaves are Fading (1975), as well as Judgment of Paris (1938) and Pillar of Fire (1942).

title: Harnessing Biology, and Avoiding Oil, for Chemical Goods
description: THE next time you stop at a gas station, wincing at the $3.50-a-gallon price and bemoaning societys dependence on petroleum, take a step back and look inside your car.

title: Final Defense Witnesses Testify in Sean Bell Case
description: Testimony concluded in the Sean Bell case with the last of the six defense witnesses taking the stand on Tuesday, the 26th day of the trial, and both sides preparing to deliver closing arguments next week, lawyers said.

title: Hearing Intrudes in Sadr City, if Power Lasts
description: BAGHDAD  When the electricity came on in the ramshackle district of Sadr City, the soldiers from the Second Stryker Cavalry Regiment flicked on the television to watch Tuesdays Congressional hearings with Gen. David H. Petraeus.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The byline for the E-Commerce Report column on Monday, about fishing as an online fantasy sport, was omitted. It was by Bob Tedeschi.

description: SHANGHAI  Sothebys Hong Kong auction of Chinese contemporary art brought in nearly $18 million on Wednesday afternoon, with aggressive bidding countering concerns that global economic uncertainties would weaken prices.

description: BARRA MANSA, Brazil

title: Group of Players Plans Removal of Upshaw
description: Baltimore Ravens kicker Matt Stover has proposed a plan to replace the N.F.L. union chief Gene Upshaw by next spring, when the union will most likely be engaged in critical negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement.

description: Time: 30 minutes

title: More Skepticism Voiced at House Hearing on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  General David H. Petraeus, the commander of American forces in Iraq, and Ryan C. Crocker, the American Ambassador to Iraq, faced a new round of deep congressional skepticism today, not only about progress in the war and the prospects for eventual withdrawal, but also about whether the nations involvement in Iraq had made it more vulnerable on other fronts.

title: Toil and Trouble Are Still Bubbling Over
description: The Chichester Festival Theaters Macbeth, starring Patrick Stewart and Kate Fleetwood, which opened in February at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has moved to Broadway. It opened on Tuesday night at the Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street; (212) 239-6200. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantleys review, which appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 15.

title: Mets Nostalgia Brings Up Bad Memories
description: If there is one team that cannot afford to wallow in nostalgia, it is the Mets. It may be tempting for Mets fans to get sentimental about old ballparks and old days, but any trip down memory lane immediately invokes September of 2007, when many of these same chaps blew a seven-game lead over the Phillies with 17 games to go.

title: Lebanon: U.N. Investigator Seeks More Time in Hariri Inquiry
description: Daniel Bellemare, left, the head of the United Nations investigation into the 2005 car-bomb assassination of Rafik Hariri, a former prime minister of Lebanon, told the Security Council that he had collected credible evidence of a network of people behind the act and that the assassination of Mr. Hariri and the killings of other anti-Syrian Lebanese political figures his commission is studying were politically motivated. Mr. Bellemare asked the Council to grant him an extension beyond the June 15 deadline, and Dumisani Kumalo, the ambassador of South Africa who is this months president of the Council, said it would probably give him six more months. Mr. Bellemare said he expected that indictments would emerge to be presented to a new special tribunal being set up in The Hague but declined to predict when. This investigation is a huge puzzle he said, and it takes time.

description: Front Page

title: African Heat, Bottled in New Jersey
description: Tiny African birds-eye chilies pack a fiery wallop. The chilies, called piri-piri in some parts of the world, are made into a sauce in South Africa, West Africa, Portugal and two of its former colonies: Mozambique and Brazil.

title: Ex-Fed Chairman Chides Current One
description: The biggest financial crisis in a generation  a downturn that officials at the Federal Reserve acknowledged in minutes released Tuesday might be prolonged and severe  is turning the traditionally reserved and omniscient central bank into an institution that seems to be in the throes of family therapy.

title: Planned Tower Near MoMA Widely Criticized at Hearing
description: Neighbors, public officials and preservationists were among the people who spoke out on Tuesday night against a proposal to build a skyscraper in Midtown that, at 1,155 feet, would be about 100 feet taller than the Chrysler Building.

title: From Clinton, Evocation of Nostalgia in a Crucial State
description: This 30-second television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, is one of five that the campaign began running Tuesday in Pennsylvania. (The other four advertisements include one with the states governor, Edward G. Rendell, one with Mayor Michael Nutter of Philadelphia, a third about the economy, and the last, a general message commercial in Spanish.)

title: Philharmonic to Give Summer Concert on Governors Island
description: The New York Philharmonic will give a free concert on Governors Island on July 5, officials said Tuesday, a possible step toward the orchestras cherished hope of finding a permanent summer home in the New York area.

title: American Canceling More Flights for Inspection
description: American Airlines, the airline owned by the AMR Corporation, said late Tuesday that it expected to cancel as many as 500 flights  more than a fifth of its daily total  to reinspect its fleet of 300 MD-80 jetliners to make sure a wiring bundle in the wheel wells was stowed properly.

title: In Storing 1s and 0s, the Question Is $
description: LISTEN. Do you hear it? The bits are dying.

title: 2 Oil Firms Plan Alaska Gas Pipeline
description: Two of the worlds biggest oil companies, BP and ConocoPhillips, joined forces Tuesday to try to break a longstanding deadlock over Alaskas vast reserves of natural gas. They said they would spend billions to build a pipeline from the North Slope to feed energy-hungry markets in the United States and Canada.

title: A Wounded Soldier Turns His Fire on the War
description: Drenched in emotion and suffused with good intentions, Body of War is impossible not to like, but difficult to admire. Produced and directed by Ellen Spiro and Phil Donahue (yes, that Phil Donahue), the movie uses the wrenching story of one American soldier to mount an angry if unfocused jeremiad against the war in Iraq.

title: Closing the Doors That Virtual Sprawl Leaves Open
description: THE advent of virtualization software has made it possible for companies to use virtual computers to run various critical tasks, wringing more work from their computers. The software enables a single computer to run several different operating systems, or several copies of the same system..

title: MySpace Mind-Set Finally Shows Up at the Office
description: AS online social networking weaves itself more extensively into the fabric of everyday life, a new class of technology vendors has set out to make the social Web relevant in the workplace, too.

title: An Inspiration to Serve America, and Regret for Having Done It in Iraq
description: His first visit to New York was during the transit strike of December 2005, when the city was in the grip of a traffic snarl for the ages, but there was one spot in Lower Manhattan that Tomas Young, of Kansas City, Mo., had to see. It was the place where George W. Bush, standing atop a pile of broken concrete on Sept. 14, 2001, vowed into a bullhorn to get the people who had brought down the World Trade Center.

title: Democrats See Economic Fault Lines in War and Trade
description: WASHINGTON  It is not easy to draw a straight line from the slumping economy to the war in Iraq and a trade deal with Colombia, but Democrats are trying to connect those dots.

title: Devices That Track Every Precious Need
description: ITS 10 p.m. Do you know where your children are? How about your pets? And your car?

title: Solid State Steps Out of the Shadows
description: SOLID-STATE technology has long performed many electrical tasks. But with lighting, Thomas Edisons bulb still largely rules. Solid-state lighting, for the most part, has been relegated to niches like automobile taillights, Christmas decorations, patio lanterns and the humble flashlight.

title: Familiar Bullpen Job Ends in Familiar Way
description: Citi Field looms as a hulking presence behind the outfield walls of Shea Stadium, peeking in like an overprotective sibling. It beckons fans to dream of next season and beyond, which may become an increasingly attractive option if the Mets continue in a time warp that makes this year seem like last year, which it certainly did Tuesday when a blur of hapless relievers again came up short against a familiar nemesis.

title: Day of Rejoicing for Red Sox; Emotional Return by Buckner
description: BOSTON  For one glorious afternoon, everything seemed brighter, happier and more hopeful in this passionate baseball city because everything was right with the Red Sox. Remembering the beloved Red Sox second championship in the last 90 years can have that soothing an impact.

title: For French Bank Chief, Questions From Lawmakers
description: PARIS  If experience, as Oscar Wilde once wrote, is simply the name we give our mistakes, then the expertise that Daniel Bouton has gleaned over the last two-and-a-half months ought to place him among the leading authorities on detecting fraud and managing financial risk.

title: Immigration, Outsourced
description: Not content to botch immigration policy all by itself, Congress has handed large parts of the job to others to mishandle. It gave the homeland security czar the czarist powers to overturn any law and ignore any court to seal the border. Now Michael Chertoff is clear-cutting a forest of regulations to wall out Mexico by the end of the year. And through the program known as 287(g), his agency is parceling out duties to a growing number of local police and sheriffs departments, raising an army of junior deputies in the war on illegal immigrants.

title: Russia Close to Privatizing Huge Electricity Producer
description: MOSCOW  A plan to privatize the worlds largest electricity company is entering the home stretch, successfully it seems, in spite of its complexity and the general hostility toward privatization in todays Russia.

title: A Noisy Train, a Fed-Up Rider and a Day in Court
description: All John Clifford wanted was a peaceful ride to work on the 7:39 to Pennsylvania Station. He would get to the Long Island Rail Road station at Long Beach early every weekday morning, board the train, stake out a five-seat section to rest his bad back, and prepare to read his newspaper and eat his breakfast.

title: Therell Always Be a France, Especially in New York
description: IT turns out that the obituaries for duck  lorange were premature. With the closing, in 2004, of Lutce, La Cte Basque and La Caravelle, conventional wisdom had it that high-end French food in New York was finished.

title: 60 Years After Israels Founding, Many Are Not in the Mood for a Party
description: JERUSALEM  When the government of Israel budgeted about $28 million to observe the 60th anniversary of the founding of the state, it was probably hoping that its fractious citizens would set aside their troubles and come together in an outpouring of national pride.

title: Income Gap in Connecticut Is Growing Fastest, Study Finds
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Marie Wendorff knows better than most about Connecticuts economic contradictions.

title: Amid Protests, Torch Run Takes Detour
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The nations only chance to see the Olympic flame up close became an elaborate game of hide-and-seek here on Wednesday, as city officials secretly re-routed the planned torch relay, swarmed its runners with blankets of security, and then quickly evacuated the torch to the airport under an heavily guarded motorcade.

description: His red card in the second half of the Red Bulls season opener last Saturday will cost defender Jeff Parke $250. Hardly a princely sum.

description: Last year when George Wein sold Festival Productions Inc., jazz fans worried about what might happen to the programming of his JVC Jazz Festival New York, the citys biggest and longest-running such event.

title: Venezuelan Channel Banishes Simpsons
description: Viewer complaints prompted a Venezuelan television channel to banish the satirical animated sitcom The Simpsons and replace it with Baywatch Hawaii, The Associated Press reported. Elba Guillen, a spokeswomen for the station, Televen, said on Monday that the decision to change offerings in its 11 a.m. time slot followed viewer protests to the National Telecommunications Commission. Referring to The Simpsons, she said, They consider it to be a series that isnt appropriate for that time because it isnt appropriate for children. The commission did not specify what was deemed offensive but said that broadcasting the series at 11 a.m. could violate national regulations barring messages that go against the whole education of boys, girls and adolescents. Baywatch Hawaii, with its lifeguarding bikini-wearing beauties and muscle-bound hunks, took over the time slot on Friday.

title: Equus Schedules Its Run

Previews are a tricky time for shows; you have to fill seats to ignite the word of mouth, but the reviews have not come out, and few may know about your show. So The Womens Project theater company is taking the straightforward approach: giving away tickets. One thousand tickets will be made available free during the preview period  April 11 through 19  of the Catherine Trieschmann comedy crooked, directed by Liz Diamond and playing at the Julia Miles Theater on West 55th Street in Clinton. Information: WomensProject.org.

title: April Madness Favors CBS

Nielsens overnight estimates suggested that CBSs live broadcast attracted slightly fewer viewers than the championship game a year ago, which drew 19.6 million. Even so, the basketball game, which followed repeats of CBSs Big Bang Theory at 8 p.m. (10.2 million) and Two and a Half Men at 8:30 (12.2 million), still dominated its time-slot competitors. ABC earned its highest ratings early in the night thanks to Dancing With the Stars, which averaged 19.5 million viewers from 8 to 9:30. The rest of ABCs lineup, Samantha Who? at 9:30 (11 million) and The Bachelor at 10 (7.2 million), struggled to attract comparable ratings. NBC ranked third over all, drawing its largest audience for Medium at 10 oclock since May 2006 (10.7 million). Fox finished fourth for the night.

South Africa will seek to extradite Mr. Goodwin, whose arrest was confirmed by prosecutors in the United States, and charge him with theft, fraud and corruption, the National Prosecuting Authority in Pretoria said. Fidentia was placed under administration last February, accused of stealing client funds, with losses estimated at as much as 1 billion rand ($130 million). An investigation found that the company had invested in private equity ventures outside the mandate given by investors and its license conditions, and that client funds had been used to pay for the personal expenses of its chairman, Arthur Brown. Mr. Brown, who has denied wrongdoing, is to face trial by Oct. 3, the South African Press Association reported last month. The companys accountant, Graham Maddock, was sentenced to a seven-year term under a plea deal, the news agency said.

description: Nelson Mandela needs a special waiver to visit the United States. In 2008.

title: Putting a Price Tag on Apollo
description: Leon Black generally avoids the public eye  so why did his buyout firm, Apollo Management, just file to go public? And why now, when private equity deals are in a credit-crunch-induced coma? Well, it had to: As part of its debut last August on Goldman Sachss private market, GSTrUE, Apollo agreed to register for a public offering in 240 days. The deadline was just about now. Like it or not, its showtime.

title: Fox Prepares a Second Round Of Pilot Pickups
description: The Hollywood Reporter: Fox is taking another step toward year-round series development with a new strategy that could redefine the upfronts. The networks entertainment president Kevin Reilly is starting a second round of pilot pickups this month to get a jump on next years presentation to advertisers.

title: Jasper Johns
description: Two outstanding gallery exhibitions (through Saturday) are timed to coincide with the lavishly engaging Jasper Johns: Gray at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Chinese Contemporary  Art Auction
description: Sothebys sold $51.77 million worth of Chinese contemporary art in three auctions in Hong Kong on Wednesday, allaying concerns that the global economic slowdown would depress the prices.

title: Measuring Ratings on the Run
description: Television executives know that many people have their eyes fixed on the tube at work, at the gym, at the sports bar, and elsewhere outside the home. Now, for the first time, Nielsen Media Research is attempting to measure just how many out-of-home viewers are watching.

title: American Cancels Third of Flights
description: CNBC reports from New York's LaGuardia Airport on the huge cancellation of flights by American Airlines because of inspections on its MD-80 planes.

title: Monty Halls Other Problems
description: Now that so many Lab readers have brilliantly mastered the Monty Hall Problem discussed in my Findings column, Ive got several new problems for you. (If youre not yet clear on the original one, you can still play the Monty Hall game.)

title: George Soros on Credit Crisis
description: CNBC interviews George Soros, a billionaire investor and philanthropist, about why the current credit crisis is the worst since the 1930s.

description: CNBC interviews George Soros, billionaire investor and philanthropist, about why the current credit crisis is the worst since the 1930s.

title: The Microwaves Not Just For Food . . .
description: Reader Sarah Beam spent hours (she even enlisted her younger brother) perfecting her technique for microwave CD melting. Not quite as dramatic as Peeps, but her blog is worth a look.

title: Clinton Uses 100-Year Remark to Fault McCain
description: Senator Barack Obama has come under some criticism for suggesting that his colleague in the Senate, John McCain, wants to stay in Iraq for 100 years, even though Mr. McCain was speaking hypothetically. Today in Pennsylvania, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton did not shy away from using that line of attack either.

title: Tensions Rising in Sadr City
description: This mostly Shiite district in Baghdad has been encircled by troops since heavy fighting in Basra spilled over into the capital last month.

title: What We Think We Think
description: The Book Reviews special issue on Islam (Jan. 6) ran an essay by the controversial scholar Tariq Ramadan called Reading the Koran. Many were puzzled by it, but then how often do readers of the Book Review come upon a piece on Islams holy book by a believing Muslim? The essay led in many directions, one of them being this: How do we happen to hold the particular religious beliefs we have? For sure, not through a process of reasoned thought and careful comparison. How many Christians and Jews have bothered to read the Koran, not to mention the Book of Mormon or the writings of L. Ron Hubbard before deciding what to believe? How many Muslims have read the Bible?

title: Tenants and N.Y.U. Battle Over Paint Removal
description: What was supposed to have been a fairly simple job of cleaning up a row of buildings on East Eighth Street owned by New York University has turned the neighborhood into an environmental hot zone and further contaminated relations between the university and its neighbors.

title: Colberts Philadelphia Lineup
description: When Stephen Colbert takes his Colbert Report on the road to Philadelphia for four days beginning April 14, hell be joined by John Legend (who plans to serenade him with the Star Spangled Banner), Chris Matthews, Gov. Edward G. Rendell, Mayor Michael Nutter of Philadelphia and Representative Patrick J. Murphy (a Pennsylvania Democrat who is also an Iraqi war veteran.)

title: It Takes a Lot To Laugh; It Takes These Dylan Jokes To Groan
description: Vanity Fair has put together a portrait of Bob Dylan  a Pulitzer honoree this week  based entirely on his weekly XM Radio show, Theme Time Radio Hour. Heres a sampler of Dylan mots compiled under Bad Jokes:

title: Bleeping The Fun Out Of Commercials
description: Advertisers are winking at the contentious issue of content regulation by using bleeping sounds in commercials and video clips, Stuart Elliott reports.

title: Will Dr. Oz Become the Next Dr. Phil?
description: Maybe the doctors are taking over daytime TV.

title: Insider | Julie Trotta
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Julie Trotta, owner of Fake Estate gallery, shares a few of her stylish essentials with The Moment. Trotta is gearing up for spring with new works from the artist (and granddaughter of Jimmy Carter) Sarah Chuldenko and a group show organized by the photographer Glynnis McDaris. But come fall, Trotta is keeping things closer to home with an upcoming show curated by her grandmother, the feminist art historian Linda Nochlin.Name: Julie TrottaAge: 25Occupation: Director and owner of Fake Estate Retail standbys: Albertine in the West Village, John McWhinnie at Glenn Horowitz Bookseller and Art Gallery for books, John Derian and Moon River Chattel for home.Music: Priestbird, Free Blood, Helene Smith.Provisions: Max Delivery, Roccos, Nuts About Nuts.For gifts: Vintage perfume bottles from Bond No. 9, white cotton nightgowns from Laina Jane.Restaurant:  Blaue Gans, Bacaro, Banjara in the East Vilalge for delicious Indian. LEpicerie in Brooklyn does great private dinners.Cocktail: Dirty martiniMomentary style obsessions: Right now Im into mixing menswear with silky florals. I also always love Rachel Comey shoes, Acne jeans, Epice scarves and Kelly Bergin skirts and cocktail dresses. Kelly is a dear friend and I absolutely love her line.Reading material: The New Yorker. Im currently reading a biography of Aby Warburg.Art picks:  I love this show at Lisa Cooley called Gut of the Quantifier. Also Corbet at the Met, Peter Coffin at Andrew Kreps Gallery, Megan Pflug at the V&A gallery, and theres a good self portrait show at James Fuentes.Museums: Tate Modern and the Met.Movie: 3 Women, La Cienega, and the upcoming Silent Light by Carlos Reygadas.Vacation destination: I like to head upstate for a quick getaway, but hoping to make a big trip to Buenos Aires soon.Something you are looking forward to this spring: My upcoming shows! New paintings by Sarah Chuldenko and a group show curated by Glynnis McDaris.

title: Bad Contracts Haunt the Lions
description: Knicks fans think theyve had it bad since Isiah Thomas took over the team in December 2003, but it could be worse. Just ask the folks in Detroit.

title: Would You Eat at This Restaurant?
description: Looks normal, doesnt it? Well, read on . . .

title: In the Raw
description: No doubt everyone has seen Victoria Beckham in the Marc Jacobs ads, and some of you may have caught Juergen Tellers show at the Lehmann Maupin Gallery. I went to the openingit was during Fashion Week, a nice diversionand I saw Juergen at the back of the gallery. He seemed constantly surrounded by young Asian girls waiting to take his picture with their cell phone cameras. I was struck by the portrait of Beckham, the half-nude (and maybe fully nude) picture of Marc sitting at a desk, and Juergens photos from Kiev and other places, many of them of Lara Stone. I was struck by how much Marcs ideas, the personality of Marc, seemed to feed Juergens workand vice versaand I thought it would be interesting, I told Juergen, to write about their collaboration, already a decade on. There isnt another like it in fashion at the moment.

title: Best in Show | Baselworld
description: (From left,winston, concord, chanel, maccanico)Bruce Pask, Ts mens fashion director, is in Switzerland at Baselworld, the top trade show for the watch industry, to report on the styles and technological breakthroughs that will be worn on stylish wrists in the months ahead. He calls it a luxe trade show on steroids.

title: Legislature Approves State Budget
description: Updated, 5 p.m. | The New York State Senate and Assembly have approved the bills making up the states new $122 billion budget. The budget, which relies on an array of taxes and fees for smokers, banks, hair salon patrons and others to keep the states 200,000-person government running, comes as New York faces one of the most uncertain economic outlooks in recent years.Gov. David A. Paterson and lawmakers struck a deal on the spending plan late Tuesday night.

title: The Playoff Bunker Is Ready
description: An extended illness forced the bunker to look at hockey a new way.

title: Jim Leylands Bucket List
description: Jim Leyland, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, watched Kansas rally in the final two minutes to defeat Memphis in the N.C.A.A. basketball championship on Monday night. For a few hours, Leyland said the game allowed him to forget about how dismal the Tigers have been this season. Detroit is 0-7.

title: The Beleaguered Torch, Now With Nazi Origins
description: For the Olympic torch relay, every day just seems to bring bad news. What began last Tuesday in Beijing as a Journey of Harmony had by Sunday become a public relations nightmare in London, and worse on Monday in Paris, when the torch was extinguished several times. On Tuesday, international Olympics officials mulled the prospect of canceling the rest of the relay.

title: Money for Indias Ultra Mega Coal Plants Approved
description: The troubling tension between propelling prosperity and limiting climate risks in a world still wedded to fossil fuels is on full display this week. Indias Tata Power group just gained important financial backing from the International Finance Corporation, a branch of the World Bank, for its planned $4 billion, 4-billion watt Ultra Mega coal-burning power plant complex in Gujarat state.

title: The Advance of Civilization
description: From Reuters:

title: On a Clear Day, You Can See Connecticut
description: With the Freedom Tower headed steadily skyward (though not yet in view of sidewalk superintendents), the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is looking ahead to the moment when the public will want a slice of that sky.It said Wednesday that it has begun searching for a private operator for the observation area planned on the 102nd floor of the tower, also known as 1 World Trade Center. Early next month, the authority will ask prospective candidates for their qualifications. Qualified bidders will be asked to submit proposals at the end of 2008. A firm will be chosen in early 2009. The observation area is expected to open in 2012.

title: Scent Notes | Gucci Envy
description: Gucci Envy is not only categorically brilliant as a perfume, it is a masterpiece of olfactory art that deserves to be exhibited at the Modern.

title: Tuesday Ratings: Foxs Idol, NBCs Loser Are Winners
description: The Biggest Loser proved to be a big asset for NBC on Tuesday, as the reality weight loss competition lifted the network to a second place finish  behind Fox  for the night among adults 18 to 49.

title: Confirmed: Sue Naegle Becomes Entertainment President at HBO
description: Jacques Steinberg reports: HBO said Wednesday afternoon that it had selected Sue Naegle, a Hollywood talent agent, as the president of its entertainment division, and charged her with helping the cable channel finds its next Sopranos and Sex and the City. Read more

title: Yahoo to Announce Test Partnership With Google
description: Another shot has been fired in the increasingly bitter battle between Microsoft and Yahoo.

title: Study Finds Third of Citys Income on the Top Rung
description: The top 1 percent of New York City tax filers now receive more than a third of the citys adjusted gross income, according to an analysis released today that looked in part at tax returns.This reflects an overarching trend that income inequality in New York State continues to be the worst in the country, echoing previously released census figures, according to a new edition of the report by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the Economic Policy Institute, Pulling Apart: A State-by-State Analysis of Income Trends [pdf].

title: Obama, Clinton, McCain On Idol Tonight
description: The Associated Press: The three leading candidates in the presidential race, Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and John McCain, were to appear Wednesday on the uber-popular reality show American Idol.' They will deliver videotaped appeals for viewers to donate to worthy charity organizations.

title: Summers: Recession Is On
description: The recession is on, and the government will need to pass a further economic stimulus package. From the perspective of Main Street and the real economy, there is a very large amount of pain left to be felt.

title: Promoting (And Profiting From) a Poignant Story
description: Randy Pausch, a Carnegie Mellon University professor who is dying of pancreatic cancer, used to dream of becoming a Disney Imagineer, or creative developer. This week he can be certain that he is a part of the Walt Disney Co. family.

title: How Should I.S.P.s Tell You if They Want to Track Your Surfing?
description: The term unavoidable notice has been bandied about by a group of Internet advertising executives recently as they explored whether to endorse proposals for Internet service providers to keep track of where their customers surfed and what they searched for.

title: Change at the Top for Red Bulls
description: Marc de Grandpre got his man  Juan Carlos Osorio, the Red Bulls new coach. And now the Major League Soccer clubs managing director has got another job.

title: An (Almost) Pure Travel Post
description: It happened, after a few days of nearly nonstop eating, that Fred and I decided to sightsee. First we hiked to the understated, 900-year-old abbey of Sant Antimo, not far from where we were staying near Montalcino. We walked for a couple of hours before coming upon the striking and by then familiar view (its widely publicized) of the Norman-style abbey with its distinctively tall, slender cedar tree alongside. We hung out for a while  the weather was gorgeous  ate some fruit, and went inside in time to hear the monks chant a bit.

title: Next Up: Housekeeping, by Marilynne Robinson
description: From the canyons of New York City we travel now to the canyons of Fingerbone, Idaho: next up in Reading Room will be Housekeeping, the first novel by Marilynne Robinson. Its the story of Ruth and Lucille, sisters who grow up in the care of various female relatives after their mother commits suicide (by driving into the same lake where her father died in a train derailment).

title: Pool Party
description: (Rendering of Gansevoort South courtesy of Nancy J. Friedman, Public Relations)

title: Advertisement for Himself
description: Is John McCain a Real Man of Genius? Slate blogger Mickey Kaus says the presumptive Republican nominees first general-election TV ad is reminiscent of a certain Bud Light campaign. Repeat playing would be an excellent enhanced interrogation technique, Kaus writes.

title: $350 Million Raised to Date for 9/11 Memorial
description: With a $10 million contribution from Cantor Fitzgerald, the institution that suffered the greatest loss of human life on 9/11, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center has reached the $350 million construction fundraising goal, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Wednesday. Mr. Bloomberg is the chairman of the memorial and has personally donated at least $15 million to the project.To honor our colleagues and all those who lost their lives on that tragic day, we are privileged to provide this gift to help realize the dream of building our countrys national 9/11 memorial, said Howard W. Lutnick, chairman and chief executive of Cantor, where 658 employees  including Mr. Lutnicks brother, Gary  died in the terrorist attack.

title: The Open Way Yahoo Could Do a Search Deal With Google
description: Yahoo said Wednesday that it would test Googles search ads for the next two weeks as part of its consideration of potential ways it could fend off Microsofts hostile takeover offer.

title: Final Word On Seinfelds Fiat
description: Mystery solved: Jerry Seinfeld was driving a 1967 Fiat 500 when he got into a single-car accident two weekends ago, according to Sam Cabiglio, Mr. Seinfelds fleet manager. It was more affectionately known as the Cinquecento.

title: Is Mumps Making a Comeback?
description: An alarming outbreak of the mumps two years ago has raised questions about whether an additional vaccination is needed.

title: At SIMA, analyst predicts reality check for Eastern Europe markets
description: While most of Europe is already experiencing a slowdown, fast-growing markets in Eastern Europe are due for a fall, Deutsche Bank analyst Dr. Tobias Just said during opening sessions for SIMA (Saln Inmobiliario Internacional de Madrid), the Madrid property show.

title: Prerequisite for Congress: Escaping Death?
description: The 12th Congressional District of California seems to have a preference for representatives who have faced death and lived to tell about it. From 1980 until early this year, the district was represented by Tom Lantos, who survived the Holocaust by escaping from forced-labor camps in Nazi occupied Hungary not once, but twice.

title: Rangers Kick Off Playoff Quest
description: Rangers Coach Tom Renney started his playoff season before Game 1 with the Devils with a bit of gamesmanship about his lineup, perhaps as a way to conjure up a tiny bit of mystery between two teams that know each other all too well.

title: Chinese-Americans Divided Over Olympic Protests
description: As the most-high profile Olympics in a generation approaches, just four months away, the world has simultaneously cast one eye toward the violent Tibetan clashes in China and the other toward the roving (and lately also violent) path of the Olympic torch, which has drawn the ire of protesters.In New York City, home to a broad range of Chinese immigrants and their children, the attitudes of Chinese-Americans toward the conflicts are as diverse as the people themselves, depending upon how they feel about the government of China, the sense of an uber-Chinese identity, and the mixing of politics and sports. Attitudes range from indifference to patriotism to harsh criticism of the Chinese government.

title: City to Ease Admissions for Gifted and Talented Classes
description: Faced with a deluge of children vying for coveted slots in gifted-and-talented programs and a shortage of top-scoring applicants,  Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said that he intended to change the citys new, standardized policy for admitting children to the programs.The chancellor proposed today that students scoring in the top 10th percentile on admissions tests would be guaranteed a slot in kindergarten or first-grade gifted and talented programs; last fall, he announced that only those scoring in the top 5th percentile would be admitted.

title: Europes Final Four
description: The semifinals of the UEFA Champions League is set. Manchester United eliminated Roma on Wednesday and Barcelona dispatched Schalke 04. There are three English teams among the final four. Who will win?

title: On Low Cost Airlines, Pay for First Class
description: With low cost airlines proliferating across Europe and prices often less than one third of regular carriers, their offers are often just too tempting to pass up.

title: Bloggingheads: Hillary's Sexism
description:
Bloggers Jeralyn Merritt, left, and Ann Althouse debate whether Hillary Clinton uses her gender or is abused for it.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Sharing an Office, With a Puppy
description: On Monday morning, as usual, I sat down with my morning latte and the New York Times home page on the screen. But nothing in my office was as usual because I had a new office mate: my 5-month-old puppy, Sinatra. By Tuesday, I had already seen that Sinatras presence would change the way I work and the way I live, and mostly for the better. Here are some of the categories where my new puppy has already been helping me.

title: Obama on Boycott: Wait, Then Decide
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been pushing in recent days for President Bush to boycott the Olympics, and now Senator Barack Obama is suggesting a more cautious approach.

title: A Website to Bookmark
description: Want to know what the media knows during the Second Season? The NHL communications department has launched www.stanleycupplayoffs2008.com to assist media members covering the Stanley Cup Playoffs. Billed as a one-stop shopping website that provides storylines for each series, statistical previews, all the NHL press releases, a downloadable full version of Total Stanley Cup (the NHL playoff media guide) as well as team playoff media guides (as they become available), the site will be updated regularly.

title: In San Francisco Torch Relay, Couch Potatoes Were Winners
description: As the Olympic torch hopscotched across San Francisco Wednesday afternoon, the best view may have been on television.

title: Asked About the Deficit, McCain Cites Reagans Example
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  When Senator John McCain was asked here this afternoon how he plans to balance the budget, he said that he hoped to do so by stimulating economic growth  and approvingly cited the example of President Ronald Reagan.

title: Banks Seek to Dismiss Clear Channels Texas Suit
description: The six banks led by Citigroup that are being sued by Clear Channel Communications and its buyers argued in a court filing Wednesday that a lawsuit against them should be dismissed and a temporary restraining order lifted. (Read the filings as a PDF here.)

title: Another Setback for El Duque
description: The Mets best-case scenario was that Orlando Hernandez would return to the rotation in about a week to 10 days. Hernandez, who was evaluated in New York on Wednesday after complaining of discomfort in his right foot, has been shut down for the next two weeks, and I would bet a bag of Blow Pops that we do not see him again until the middle of May. Hell need time to recuperate, to rebuild arm strength, to make rehab starts in the minors  add all that together and were talking at least another month, folks. Just saying.

description: Before the playoffs began, we polled the Slap Shot staff and their Hockey Night in Blogdom unpaid interns on who would win the Eastern and Western Conferences and, of course, the Stanley Cup. The results of that poll, with teams and number of votes received:

title: For Yanks, Pregame Is a Land of Confusion
description: The capper to a wacky pregame Wednesday night came when Brian Bruney was named the surprise starter in place of Ian Kennedy. Was Kennedy hurt? Nobody seemed to know, because the Yankees said nothing.

title: Beekeepers Journal
description: I must admit to a somewhat laissez faire attitude when it comes to my beehives. I can see them from the kitchen window, and my naive hope is that all is well inside those dark caves of activity.

title: Readers Respond to China/Tibet
description: Nick has put up three China-related posts recently: an invitation to Chinese readers to critique Western coverage of China; a comparison of Xinjiang and Tibet, both home to sizable ethnic minorities with anti-Beijing sentiments; and a lead-in for his column about Sino-U.S. relations after the upheavals in Tibet. In response, readers have posted about a thousand comments. Here is a small sampling:

title: The Ghosts of Casa Grande
description: COOLIDGE, Ariz.  A pair of Brits, a Vietnam vet, a sullen teen and a dozen or so retirees gathered under the Sonoran Desert sun to try to decipher some of the clues left behind by people who lived here nearly 1,000 years ago.

title: Practical Steps for Darfur
description: In my Thursday column, I outline some steps that President Bush and other world leaders could take that I believe would dramatically increase the prospect of peace in Darfur, and elsewhere in Sudan.

title: The 33-Year-Old Rookie
description: Before the game, I caught up with the Phillies backup catcher Chris Coste, who, regardless of whether youre a fan of the Mets, Phillies or Vermont Lake Monsters, has a pretty cool story. In a nutshell, Coste reached the major leagues at age 33 after bucking the odds the whole way to get there. He went to a little-known Division III college, Concordia College; played in the independent Northern League; and spent nearly seven years in the minors before making his debut for the Phillies in 2006.

title: Elizabeth Edwards Is Back in the Spotlight
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Elizabeth Edwards has pretty well established by now that shes not afraid to express her views, take on institutional figureheads whether they work in the media or in the political maelstrom.

title: And We Have  Prudential Square Garden?
description: The most bizarre part of Wednesday nights playoff opener between the Devils and Rangers was trying to figure out what percentage of the Prudential Center crowd was made up of Rangers fans. My guess is 35 percent and it was a loud 35 percent, creating competing chants and all kinds of strange moments in the Rangers 4-1 victory.

description: WASHINGTON  The recommendation by the top American commander in Iraq to suspend troop reductions reflects a bleak assessment that Iraqi forces remain unprepared to take over the mission of securing their own nation, senior administration and military officials said Wednesday.

title: Japan Approves New Bank Chief
description: TOKYO  Japans Parliament chose a new chief for the nations central bank on Wednesday, ending a long political standoff that had left the bank leaderless at a time of global financial turmoil.

title: For Pilots, Dreams Run Into Reality
description: IRVING, Tex.  Among the jobs little boys dream of  policeman, fireman, bulldozer driver  airline pilot long held the added virtue of satisfying grown-up dreams: pay that reached $300,000 a year, 20 days a month off work, the prestige of one day commanding a $200 million airplane, and a lush retirement at 60.

title: Sir Elton and Democratic Friends
description: The glitter. The stars. The flow of campaign dollars.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft on Thursday plans to introduce a Web-based service for driving directions that incorporates complex software models to help users avoid traffic jams.

title: For Lady Vols, Anosike Keeps Things Together
description: TAMPA, Fla.  This was her final game in a Tennessee uniform, the end of a splendid career in which center Nicky Anosike became the first from Staten Island, male or female, to play in the Final Four. She had one national title already and was determined not to go home without another.

title: Another Heck of a Job
description: Any remaining hope for a modern, efficient and precise census in 2010 has cratered, brought low by managerial incompetence and the administrations relentless antipathy for effective government.

description: Well, this ought to be good.

title: Public Financing? Obama and McCain Appear Split
description: MALVERN, Pa.  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain are beginning to lay the groundwork for divergent ways of financing fall campaigns for the presidency.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about anti-Chinese protests that disrupted a ceremonial relay of the Olympic torch through Paris en route to China, host of the Summer Games, referred incorrectly in some copies to the head of the Norwegian Olympic Committee, who said the torch relay tradition should be reconsidered. The Norwegian, Tove Paule, is a woman.

title: F.A.A. Auditing of Airlines Criticized at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administrations troubles seemed to deepen on Thursday as a Senate subcommittee chairman compared its handling of its lapses to the Pentagons handling of the abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib, and suggested that punishments should reach higher into the ranks.

title: The Tiger Imperative
description: I have played golf a total of five times in my life. The first was when I was about 13 years old, and my Uncle Lotsi informed me that I was a perfectly fine player, "other than your putting, chipping and driving." The other four times were at bachelor parties.

title: Suggested Read: The Big Sandy
description: Twenty years ago, Sandy Lyle stood in a fairway bunker on Augusta National's 18th hole, 145 yards from the pin, just a bogey away from handing the Masters to Mark Calcavecchia. The result was more grand. Lyle hit an approach shot that finished 10 feet from the hole, and a single putt to win the green jacket, for one of the most dramatic finishes in the tournament's history. Dave Anderson summed it up in The Times the next day: "In their betting games, duffers define a 'sandy' as getting up and down in two shots from a bunker for a par. But now there's a new term. Call it a Big Sandy, as in Sandy Lyle himself: getting up and down in two shots from a fairway bunker for a birdie."

title: New Roadblocks Delay Tribunals at Guantnamo
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  When military officials announced war crimes charges against six detainees for the Sept. 11 attacks two months ago, the move was part of an effort to accelerate the Bush administrations sluggish military commission system, which has yet to hold a single trial.

title: As Woods Chases History, History Appears
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Pairing sheets listing the official 2008 Groupings and Starting Times for the first round of the 72nd Masters tournament for Thursday, April 10, were a hot item Wednesday. The most oft-scanned line on the sheet was about halfway down the page.

title: Mayhem and Monsters: 2 Games Splatter Your Screen With Gore
description: The role-playing game Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII for the hand-held PSP seems to almost wink every time it introduces a new character. Look, it seems to say, its Aerith! Gee whiz, it shouts, theres Cloud! Wow, its Sephiroth!

title: Unexpected Conductor and Soloist; Expected Results
description: The concert that the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night was not the one it originally planned. Murray Perahia, the ensembles principal guest conductor, withdrew from its American tour because of illness. Neville Marriner, who founded the Academy in 1958, took up the reins for the tour, and in New York the pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin was added to the bill. The program stuck to presumably safe territory: a piano concerto and a symphony apiece from Haydn and Mozart.

title: Police Department to Start Routinely Testing Officers for Steroid Use
description: For many New York City police officers, a trip to the gym or the station house weight room is as much a part of the day as roll call or making notes in a memo book.

title: Currents | The Fabrics May Not Stretch, but a Dollar Bill Will
description: Brunschwig & Fils, the high-end fabrics house, will hold a fabric and wallpaper sale starting Tuesday. Merchandise will include silk and linen damasks for $20 to $50 a yard (marked down from $76 to $150), and silk woven patterns for $50 a yard (reduced from around $290).

title: Tax Preparer Is Charged With Theft on L.I.
description: A certified tax preparer on Long Island has been charged with filing false tax returns using the names of former clients and others to try to collect at least $19 million, law enforcement authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Covering Up a Slender Strip
description: Q. The strip of soil between the side of my house and a walkway is about 15 inches wide and 20 feet long and gets sun all day. Please recommend a ground cover.
