description: An entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday imprecisely described a piece in an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art that David Hammons created by rebinding a catalogue raisonnn of works by Marcel Duchamp. On the outside it appears to be a large version of the Old Testament, not the New Testament.

title: Art for All Ages
description: To the Editor:

title: The Barber of Warm Feelings
description: FOR once, in this city of cranes and money, its not about real estate. This is more a story of devotion  not to a usual suspect like a wife, not to the secondarily acceptable, like a mangy pet, and not to something embarrassing like a blanket. What Im talking about is someone Ive seen regularly for more than 10 years, someone who became a part of my life shortly after I moved to New York.

title: Where Irish Eyes Hope to Smile Again
description: FEW people have suffered more as a result of the monumental failures of the New York Knicks than the Irish. For years, the blocks surrounding Madison Square Garden have been strewn with Irish pubs  West Side joints, the old-timers might say  and when the Knicks are doing well, these Blarney Stones and Blarney Rocks do a brisk business.

title: Long Road Leads Back to the Outfield for Kapler
description: On a cold night in October 2004, Gabe Kapler etched his name in baseball trivia. He had been merely a pinch-runner, but when Red Sox Manager Terry Francona left him in the game to play right field in the ninth, Kapler joined an exclusive club.

title: Instant Digital Prints (and Polaroid Nostalgia)
description: MILLIONS of families once snapped Polaroid photographs and enjoyed passing around the newly minted prints on the spot, instead of waiting a week for them to be developed.

title: Scouts Honor
description: 1. England may be a nation of shopkeepers, but it probably doesnt have many as savvy as Nicky Kinnaird, the founder of Space NK Apothecary. Fifteen years  and 52 stores  after first opening in Covent Garden, she still has an uncanny knack for making even the most au naturel women covet the cult beauty products that line her shelves. Its not about newness for the sake of newness, she says. Innovation is what does it for me. Kinnaird recently opened Space NK Soho, at 99 Greene Street. Go to spacenk.com.

title: Tamara Smith, Albert Sonon IV
description: Lt. Tamara T. Smith and Lt. Albert T. Sonon IV, both Navy supply corps officers, are to be married Sunday at the Spring Valley Church of God in Temple, Pa. The Rev. Robert E. Hinson, a Pentecostal minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Witness in Track Doping Case Is Ready to Name Big Names
description: LAREDO, Tex.  When one of the most successful coaches in the history of track and field goes on trial next month in the long-running federal investigation into doping in sports, lawyers for both sides are prepared to reveal that cheating in track is far more widespread than previously known.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Green Jeans
description: Growing organic cotton helps keep additional chemical pesticides out of the ground, which protects aquifers, communities, health (especially farmers) and biodiversity. Buying organic jeans is the equivalent of buying a hybrid car, says Earth Pledges Leslie Hoffman. Test-drive one of these models.

title: In the Projects, Hope and Hard Knocks
description: IN 1991, the high crime rate at the Cypress Hills Houses in East New York, Brooklyn, made it the perfect setting for Mayor David Dinkins to announce a crackdown on illegal guns. It was a little too perfect, in fact. As the mayor spoke, shots rang out a block and a half away. People in the crowd screamed, some started to run and others ducked for cover. No one was injured, but the story added another chapter to the rough reputation of Cypress Hills.

title: A Lender Failed. Did Its Auditor?
description: ALTHOUGH he had been with the mortgage lender New Century Financial for only two months, Tajvinder S. Bindra had spent a good part of late 2006 and early 2007 pelting the companys controller and a member of its auditing firm, KPMG, with questions about the companys accounting.

title: Florence, Italy: Cammillo Trattoria
description: Back in Florence after a 15-year absence, I began with dinner at the Cammillo Trattoria, a ritual I have followed on every visit to that city since my first in 1953. Then eight years old, Cammillos was on the must-see list of every serious food buff, touted as a new find with a mostly Tuscan home-style kitchen, and, wonder of wonders, moderate prices.

title: For the West, Many Tough Calls on China
description: PARIS  As the Dalai Lama begins a contentious two-week visit to the United States and the Olympic torch continues its tortuous journey across six continents toward Beijing, the 2008 Games, already tarnished, have become a political as well as an athletic spectacle, with vying theories of human rights and how best to promote them.

title: Michigan Has Vacant Buildings Waiting for the Right Film Role
description: DETROIT  A film crew may soon find itself in a mothballed Michigan prison, where it is likely to be treated more graciously than most people who spent time there.

title: To Restore a Historic Site, a Treasure Hunt
description: Oakdale

title: Too Far Behind to Defend His Title, Johnson Still Proves He Belongs
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The defending Masters champion, Zach Johnson, got off to a torrid start Saturday, birdieing four holes on the front nine for an outward 32, but he was unable to sustain the pace and finished with a four-under-par 68.

title: Southern African Leaders Press Zimbabwe
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  After a marathon session to address Zimbabwes political impasse, southern Africas political leaders on Sunday urged the government of President Robert Mugabe to permit representatives of the opposition to be present when vote tabulations are verified, handing the opposition a substantial victory.

title: Skeletons, Earthenware and SpongeBob Piatas
description: AVENIDA Independencia runs west from the central square in Tlaquepaque, Mexico. For several blocks it is a pedestrian street, cobbled and lined with ornate mansions that, more than a century ago, served as weekend homes for the elite of Guadalajara. Today, they are shops featuring high-end wares for other weekend homes throughout the continent.

title: Woods Refuses to Fade Away
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  For the past five years, the golf world has been wondering if there are any worthy young players who can challenge Tiger Woods. On a wet, gray day on Saturday, in the third round of the Masters at the Augusta National Golf Club, some new leading men volunteered for the job.

title: What She Really Wants to Do Is ...
description: WHAT has the Oscar-winning actress Helen Hunt, 44, been doing since her 2000 hit What Women Want? Raising a daughter (Mkena lei, now 3) with her partner, the screenwriter-producer Matthew Carnahan, appearing in a couple of big-screen misfires (The Curse of the Jade Scorpion, A Good Woman) and wondering what was missing in the screenplay she was rewriting (credited to her, Alice Arlen and Victor Levin), based on Elinor Lipmans novel Then She Found Me. Ms. Hunt said it was the Jungian psychologist James Hillmans essay on betrayal, of all things, that suddenly made everything click.

title: Color Wheel | Fading Fast
description: From Diane von Furstenbergs color-washed shifts to Alexander McQueens purple-and-red saturated kimono, ombr  the chic version of tie-dye  was awash on the spring runways. Not to be outdone, the beauty establishment is offering its own versions of gradient makeup shades: Guerlain Ombre clat Eyeshadow ($57 at sephora.com) comes in six pastel-to-bold combinations; Chanel Ombre dEau Fluid Iridescent Eyeshadow ($30 at chanel.com) comes in a new gold shade with multiple pigments; and Darphin Blush Sensation ($40 at Bergdorf Goodman) comes in four colors  Rose Amour fades from hot pink to just a hint of rose. CELIA ELLENBERG

title: Catholic Schools Face Changing Fortunes
description: BREWSTER, N.Y.

title: On the Retail Frontier, Another Shop in SoHo for the Person Who Has Everything
description: Michael Hall said he was in SoHo on Saturday to do what people do in SoHo: meet friends, have a meal, browse the galleries and boutiques. But along the way, he stumbled upon something completely different  a storefront offering to analyze his genes.

title: For Philadelphias Rollins, a Game of Maternal Instinct
description: Reason would suggest that Jimmy Rollinss greatest baseball triumph came last season, when his extraordinary play and passion led the Philadelphia Phillies into October and won him a Most Valuable Player award. And as a performer who delights in the spotlight, his becoming the antagonist for whom New York fans unleash their heartiest boos leaves him feeling only more accomplished.

title: In Bed With Runway: A Lifetime Story
description: THE guys from Project Rungay are worried.

title: Of Witches and the Wait for Justice
description: In 1662, the colonists of Hartford accused 39-year-old Mary Sanford of witchcraft. Based on evidence  drinking wine and dancing around a bonfire  the court pronounced her guilty for not having the feare of God before thyne eyes. Sanford was hanged, leaving behind five children and a shaken husband who was later acquitted of similar charges.

title: Rat Pack Playground Revived
description: SUNNY ISLES BEACH, a two-mile stretch of white sand five miles north of Miami Beach, was once the Vegas of Florida. In the 1950s, Frank Sinatra and his cronies wintered at glamorous party palaces like the Gold Strand Hotel, occasionally ducking out to bet on jai alai and dog races. title: 36 Hours in Chiang Mai, Thailand
description: BLESSED with a cooler climate than Bangkok and buffered by lush mountains, Chiang Mai has long served as a backpackers gateway to Thailands northern reaches. But an influx of Thai artists and Western expatriates has turned this quiet city into a vibrant destination in its own right. Design studios have sprung up in town, fusing traditional Thai with modern twists. Age-old curries are now paired with Australian red wines and croissants. The area around Nimanhaemin Road now looks like South Beach, packed with BMWs and Art Deco homes, alongside contemporary art galleries run by young Thais with purple hair and nose rings. But traditional Chiang Mai is still there. Walk away from Nimanhaemin into the old city and youll see shaved monks meditating and backpackers chowing down on banana pancakes.

title: Extreme Makeover
description: The actress Tilda Swinton does not wear makeup. At the Oscar ceremony, she appeared brazenly pasty, unstained by rouge and bronzer, a white waif in an ocean of spray-tanned limbs and bobbing plastic torsos. Her asymmetrical black dress exposed an ivory arm. The virginity of her unpainted flesh made everyone around her look like a crowd of aging, insecure hookers. I admired her for going without a double deck of fake eyelashes, for braving the television lights without a whisper of powder or blush  for being what passes for naked in Hollywood in front of millions, if not billions, of people. On television, she looked like a fabulous alien. In person, people must have stopped and stared. Dont you think the other actresses must have gossiped to one another in the bathroom?

title: All the Time He Needs
description: President Bush said last week that he told his Iraq war commander, Gen. David Petraeus, that hell have all the time he needs. We know what that means. It means that the general, like the Iraqi government, should feel no pressure to figure a way out of this disastrous war. It means that even after 20,000 troops come home there will be nearly 140,000 American troops still fighting there  with no plan for further withdrawals and no plan for leading them to victory.

title: The Aria of Chris Matthews
description: Whenever Chris Matthews says something he likes, which happens a lot, he repeats it often and at volumes suggesting a speaker who feels insufficiently listened to at times. Tim Russert finally reeled the big marlin into the boat tonight, Matthews yelled  nine times, on and off the air, after a Democratic debate that Russert moderated with Brian Williams in late February at Cleveland State University. Matthews believed that Russert (the fisherman) had finally succeeded in getting Hillary Clinton (the marlin) to admit that she was wrong to vote in favor of the Iraq war resolution in 2002. Weve been trolling for that marlin for what, a year now? Matthews said to Russert.

title: The Cure
description: For a year I worried that I might die having had sexual intercourse with only one person. Like many college students, I thought intercourse was the greatest thing in life. And it just about killed me to hear of everyones rambunctious affairs while I was in the hospital.

title: Damage Control
description: Michael Paul Mason is the anti-Oliver Sacks. As a brain injury case manager, he deals not with neurological exotica, but with workaday broken brains: the neck-up aftermath of crashes, accidents and kicks in the head. No one is mistaking his wife for a hat. The people in this book are having seizures, running after their loved ones with kitchen knives, waking up in unfamiliar towns with no idea how they got there. Rather than spotlighting the rococo workings of the human brain, the author highlights its bald frailty: the ease with which a tap on the head, as Mason puts it, can blow apart a life.

title: After Protests, Haitian Leader Announces Rice Subsidies
description: MEXICO CITY  Responding to violent street protests against rising food prices that ground Haiti to a halt over the last week, President Ren Prval announced subsidies on Saturday that he said would cut the cost of rice by more than 15 percent.

title: But Is It Art?
description: A suspense story has to take over your mind, leaving you disoriented (and feeling a little foolish) when you look up at the end. Jesse Kellerman makes this act of self-hypnosis easy, mainly because he understands the mechanics of obsessive thought. In his first novel, Sunstroke, a woman fixated on her boss becomes unhinged during a long road trip to recover his body. In Trouble, a repressed medical student enslaves himself to a sexually sadistic lover.

title: Nicaragua Credited With Shrewd Tactics in Bid for General Assembly Presidency
description: UNITED NATIONS  Nicaragua, a vigorous critic of the United States and a vocal ally of Hugo Chvez, the Washington-baiting president of Venezuela, stirred alarm in many Western and Latin American capitals a year ago when it proposed its candidacy for the presidency of the General Assembly.

title: Video Link Plucks Afghan Detainees From Black Hole of Isolation
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Early this year, a 10-year-old Afghan named Esrarullah got his first chance in months to see his father, who had been held since last May at Bagram Air Base outside Kabul. It was not in person, but in a video conference call, and the boy was so overcome, he clutched the phone to his ear and stared mutely at the screen.

Fox writes soul-searching adult and childrens novels, including the 1974 Newbery Medal-winning Slave Dancer. title: Trauma
description: My mother's first depressive illness occurred when I was seven years old, and I felt it was my fault. I felt I should have prevented it. This was about a year before my father left us. His name was Fred Weir. In those days he could be generous, amusing, an expansive man  my brother, Walt, plays the role at times  but there were signs, perceptible to me if not to others, when an explosion was imminent. Then the sudden loss of temper, the storming from the room, the slamming door at the end of the hall and the appalled silence afterward. But I could deflect all this. I would play the fool, or be the baby, distract him from the mounting wave of boredom and frustration he must have felt at being trapped within the suffocating domestic atmosphere my mother liked to foster. Later, when she began writing books, she fostered no atmosphere at all other than genteel squalor and heavy drinking and gloom. But by then my father was long gone.

title: Shrinking Portals to the Past
description: WITH its taped advertisements and garbage-laden ledges, the pay phone in New York, that familiar feature of the streetscape, is becoming a grimy museum relic. Just last December, for example, AT&T announced that it would get out of the pay phone business by the end of this year, and the companies that maintain pay phone lines and the accompanying street enclosures are struggling to profit from a dwindling, once-lucrative part of the industry.

The rapid economic rise of China (and India) suggests to many that the geopolitical center of gravity no longer lies somewhere between Washington and London. title: N + 2
description: Literary editors who write novels are like princesses who get involved in the manufacture of tiaras: they want a piece of the action, sure, but also they must want to play a more invigorating part in creating the dazzle that defines them. Some editors, like William Maxwell, are novelists no matter how they earn their living, while others, like Cyril Connolly, appear to be utterly brutalized by their own high standards. In The Rock Pool, Connollys 1936 novel of snobbery and ambition in the South of France, the great editor and critic wished to capture the hedonism of his artistic generation. Yet he couldnt do it. Despite all he knew about elegance and all he knew about polish, his material was ill sourced and his story as lifeless as pebbles.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE ECHOING GREEN: The Untold Story of Bobby Thomson, Ralph Branca and the Shot Heard Round the World, by Joshua Prager. (Vintage, $15.95.) The story broke in The Wall Street Journal in 2001: The New York Giants historic comeback at the end of the 1951 season, capped by Bobby Thomsons famous home run in Game 3 of the playoffs, was powered by their theft of the signals of opposing catchers. Here Prager expands his original research into the mechanics of the scheme  a telescope hidden behind the mesh grid of a clubhouse window in the Polo Grounds  but he focuses on the lifelong effects of the secret on Thomson and the Dodgers pitcher Ralph Branca. The book is a revelation and a page turner, John Thorn wrote in the Book Review.

I was so inexperienced that even my parents suggested I loosen up when I got to college, which would have been easy, what with co-ed dorms, freshman pamphlets on birth control and sex practices and well-established codes to announce activities requiring privacy. (In our dorm, it was a sock on the door handle.) I put off sex, not because of morality but because it just never felt right. So it was a relief to read about college students making similar secular-based choices.

title: Can the Cellphone Help End Global Poverty?
description: If you need to reach Jan Chipchase, the best, and sometimes only, way to get him is on his cellphone. The first time I spoke to him last fall, he was at home in his apartment in Tokyo. The next time, he was in Accra, the capital of Ghana, in West Africa. Several weeks after that, he was in Uzbekistan, by way of Tajikistan and China, and in short order he and his phone visited Helsinki, London and Los Angeles. If you decide not to call Jan Chipchase but rather to send e-mail, the odds are fairly good that youll get an out of office reply redirecting you back to his cellphone, with a notation about his current time zone  GMT +9 or GMT -8  so that when you do call, you may do so at a courteous hour.

title: Caught on Tape
description: Ah, the perils of the rhetorical device. Three-quarters of the way through Jonathan Coes eighth novel, the narrator, Rosamond, breaks off her story. She is talking not to us but to Imogen, the young, blind relative she tried  and failed  to care for many years before. Now Rosamond is 73 and near death, and she decides to speak the tale of that failure into a tape recorder so Imogen can have some knowledge of her own familys history. She does this by selecting 20 photographs, then describing them and the circumstances in which they were taken. But by the time she reaches No. 16, the strain is beginning to tell: Five more to go, then. Thank goodness! I am growing tired of this story, and you must be exhausted, listening to me chatter on for hours on end. Can you bear with me for just a little longer, Imogen? It will be over now, all over, very soon. A relief all round, I am sure.

title: Bad Bet
description: In March, the Massachusetts House of Representatives rejected a measure that looked unstoppable when it was proposed by Gov. Deval Patrick last September: the authorization of destination casinos across the commonwealth. The plan was for Massachusetts to sell three 10-year licenses for at least $200 million apiece and then tax the casinos takings at 27 percent, raking in $400 million a year. That, went the reckoning, would cover a $1.3 billion budget shortfall. Patrick was backed by The Boston Globe, big casino corporations and some trade unions. His opponent, the House speaker, Salvatore DiMasi, warned of human devastation and suggested that Massachusetts could aim higher. We are the Athens of America, DiMasi said at a St. Patricks Day breakfast. Do we really want this? Do we need this casino culture?

title: In Search of the Skeptical, Hopeful, Mystical Jew That Could Be Me
description: What brought me to the small, neat office in the Kabbalah Center in Los Angeles  at the tacky southern edge of Beverly Hills where the upscale ambience of Doheny Drive turns into a decrepit stretch that includes two gas stations and multiple Korean nail salons  was Madonna, who doesnt believe in death. And then there was my mother, who had recently died. Somehow, in an effort to reconcile divergent realities, I must have been looking for a resolution of the irresolvable, a way of navigating a path between the absoluteness of mortality and the lingering hope of something beyond it, between the immutable reality of personal loss and the promise of spiritual consolation.

title: Adventures of a Deliveryman
description: JOAQUN BOTERO is not your average food service worker. A 35-year-old with thick, expressive eyebrows and a habit of talking with his hands, he grew up and went to college in Medelln, Colombia, where he studied journalism. He came to the United States on a tourist visa and worked as an editor and feature reporter for three years at Hoy, the Spanish-language newspaper. Since then, he has worked as a deliveryman, bakery employee and cheesemonger in a succession of restaurants and grocery stores, including Mr. Broadway, a kosher restaurant in the theater district; Citarella on Third Avenue; and the West 23rd Street branch of Garden of Eden. He has written a book about being a deliveryman, which is unpublished. His book about life at Garden of Eden, titled El Jardn en Chelsea, was published last July in Colombia. title: Religious Intent
description: Nothing about the founders seems as interesting or as timely to us, 200 years and more farther on, as their religious views  who, if Anyone, they worshiped, how they marked the boundaries of church and state. As a Washington biographer, I have been assured, during the Q. and A. periods after talks, that George Washington saw the Virgin Mary at Valley Forge and converted to Roman Catholicism on his deathbed (why wait, if he had seen the Virgin 21 years earlier?). I was also once asked if he was an illuminated Freemason; I sped away from that question as fast as possible. Whether in legal briefs or op-ed articles, we are as passionate about religion as the founders were. Unfortunately, our passions make for a lot of sloppy and willful historical thinking and writing. In Founding Faith, Steven Waldman, a veteran journalist and co-founder of Beliefnet.com, a religious Web site, surveys the convictions and legacy of the founders clearly and fairly, with a light touch but a careful eye.

title: Pure Science

A few, like the science writer George Johnson, also see beauty in the act of research. Johnsons new book, The Ten Most Beautiful Experiments, is an appealing account of important scientific discoveries to which a variation of Keats applies: occasionally, beauty yields truth.

This season, he explored a new kind of sexiness with purposely disheveled, lingerie-inspired looks  the kind of balance between innovation and sophistication that a cool French actress like lodie Bouchez (four months pregnant at the time of this shoot, and with no patience for maternity duds) can appreciate. title: Reference for an Ex?

Only those which wont hurt his chances? Refuse to participate?  NAME WITHHELD, SEATTLE

description: PLENTY of people have come this close to buying the sprightly, nano-scale Mini Cooper. And then they got a load of that back seat.

title: Inside the List
description: THE COP NOVELIST: Joseph Wambaughs 13th novel, Hollywood Crows, slips onto the fiction list this week at No. 5. Its been nearly four decades since Wambaugh  then Sgt. Joseph Wambaugh of the Los Angeles Police Department, Hollenbeck Division  emerged with a first novel called The New Centurions (1971). That book collected its share of favorable reviews (Thomas Flemings assessment in this publication began: Do you like cops? Read The New Centurions. Do you hate cops? Read The New Centurions), and profile writers served him up as a blue-collar hero. Wambaugh, raised in East Pittsburgh, told a Times writer in 1971: Nobody in my family had ever been to college, and damn few had graduated from high school. I held the middle class in awe. I thought they were the upper class. The New Centurions remained on the Times hardcover list for more than six months.

title: Intriguing Assemblages
description: If collage seems all but ubiquitous in the art world lately, spare a thought for John Evans and the late May Wilson (1905-1986), both of whom have shows at the Morris Museum. It is a thoughtful pairing, for each contributed significantly to the history of collage and assemblage in 20th-century American art.

title: Where Many Ended Their Search for Paradise
description: FROM the lofty deck of the Hiva Oa Hanakee Pearl Lodge, the only hotel on the remote South Pacific island of Hiva Oa, the view is of lush forest, crashing cobalt sea and, if it is morning, a very misty Mount Temetiu. Below and for miles beyond, nature runs wild: steep cliffs and deep valleys covered with luxuriant tropical vegetation. No reefs surround the island, allowing the sea to pile wildly onto the sandy, rocky shoreline. The only thing missing is ... people. Which is a good thing when youre contemplating the idea of paradise, which I happened to be doing on a recent morning, my legs dangling in an infinity pool that seemed to spill into Hanakee Bay.

description: LONDON

title: Hes Living Masters History: Viewing 18 Holes for 72 Years
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Dr. Ed Bailey peered intently from under his floppy hat Friday, eyes focused on the golfer who was hitting high, arcing draws toward Washington Road. He was seated in the first row of the bleachers behind the practice tee at Augusta National Golf Club, taking it all in, pretty much as he has, at various spots around these impossibly manicured grounds, since long before the grooming began.

title: Pace Law School to Get $1 Million Gift
description: IN 70-plus years of practicing law, Theodore W. Kheel has negotiated with some of New Yorks most intractable parties, brokering deals between labor and management representing the air, rail and newspaper industries, among others. As head of the National War Labor Board, he oversaw more than 100 disputes a week; as a mediator for New York Citys Labor Relations Division, he settled a contentious newspaper strike and several transit strikes.

title: My Life in Pictures
description: 1913: At age 2, posing at my childhood home in Choisy-le-Roi, outside Paris.for close to a century, the sculptor Louise bourgeois has been a beautiful provocateur. 1926: Wearing a dress designed by Paul Poiret. My parents competed over who could outfit me in better fashions. 1934: My student card from the University of Paris, where I studied art history. 1980: I wrote my name in the back of my town house in Chelsea, where Ive run a Sunday salon for more than 30 years. 2007: Still working, at 96, and exhibiting around the world. 1996: Posing in front of one of my spider sculptures in Brooklyn. 1975: In an amoebalike latex suit that I designed and made.

title: My Bad
description: In several of his previous novels, the Scottish poet John Burnside chronicled the interior states of a child murderer and a rapist; in a memoir, he revisited the bizarre and violent life of his father. His latest novel, The Devils Footprints, begins with the brutal self-immolation of a mother and two young children, then travels back through time to an episode of coldblooded murder and forward to an act of criminal psychosis. Burnsides account of this harrowing journey is written in plain language, but when were finished theres some doubt as to where, precisely, we have been.

title: Steady Hand for the G.O.P. Guides McCain on a New Path
description: When Senator John McCains campaign was collapsing last summer, it was Charlie Black who set the comeback strategy: Mr. McCain had to win New Hampshire.

title: Better Home and Garden
description: Now and then fate hands you a do-over, even if you didnt ask for one. When the architect Ron Radziner, his wife, the graphic designer Robin Cottle, and their two children, Asher and Lexi, moved into the house that Radziner designed for them in Venice, Calif., more than five years ago, they thought they were there to stay. Their spare, light-filled house wasnt big, but its interiors were expansive, and it had an outdoor dining area with a big fireplace  a perfectly contemporary update of the mid-20th-century California Modernist ideal of indoor-outdoor living. But then Radziner, who is a partner in Marmol Radziner & Associates (whose work is the subject of a book that will be published by Princeton Architectural Press in August), spotted a house for sale nearby on a rare double lot. And since the house was in tear-down condition, Radziner and Cottle pounced. We had always wanted more outdoor space, Radziner says.

title: A Hip Shaker in His Prime, Among Hip Friends
description: PART Anthony Newley but even more Otis Redding, the Welsh singer Tom Jones was a musical shape-shifter long before American Idol turned versatility into karaoke posturing. With a voice as husky as it was pretty, Mr. Jones at the peak of his popularity in the late 1960s could slide from soulful rasp to pop croon with a credibility todays would-be Idols could barely imagine.

Considering how terrible the real estate market is these days, you could have knocked me over with a feather, said Ms. Carberry, who  like other fortunate sellers receiving multiple bids on their homes  had the enviable job of choosing among the good offers.

title: Personal Property in Common Areas
description: Q Our co-op board recently requested, in writing, that all owners remove any personal property in common areas like the basement or roof within 60 days and threatened to discard anything that remains after that time. title: A Lack of Intelligence
description: Americas intelligence services may try to work in secret, but they are increasingly being exposed to public scrutiny. After the 9/11 Commission chronicled their shortcomings in its best-selling 2004 report, the Bush administration and Congress backed sweeping reforms. But as accounts appear about fresh lapses, it doesnt seem that much has changed. The surprising thing doesnt seem to be when things go wrong, but when they go right.

title: The Cream Merchants
description: There are empires, and then there are empires  dynasties that reign because of inherited wealth or royalty, and dynasties that emerge by way of a family business of some sort, fueled by an entrepreneurial or artistic vision and sustained by a will toward perpetuity. These latter phenomena include cars (Ford), shoes (Ferragamo), fashion (Fendi), cosmetics (Este Lauder), architecture (I. M. Pei and sons), art (Wyeth pre and fils), literature (Waugh and Amis), acting (Redgrave and Barrymore), and political office (Adams and Bush). When we think of these dynasties, we think of a specific bequest, a passing on of lineage from father to son (and, more rarely, to daughter) of skill, expertise, commercial acumen or, as it may be, sheer staying power in a competitive marketplace.

title: Cash-Short Cities Want New Slice of Taxes
description: AS the economy sinks, Connecticuts big-city mayors are growing increasingly desperate for new revenue sources to cope with soaring costs, the housing crisis and an overburdened property tax system.

title: Green Goddess

A few days after the work was started, he stopped the work and suggested that we use his contractor. My contractor has the required license to do the work. Are we compelled to use the managers contractor?

title: Off the Mound but in the Game
description: On April 4, a strained pectoral muscle kept Mike Hampton from making his first start since 2005 and left the Braves bullpen short-handed before the game even began. By the time the Pirates and Braves went into the 10th inning, Atlanta Manager Bobby Coxs options were limited. He had reliever Chris Resop on the mound but wanted Royce Ring to face the lefty Adam LaRoche. The problem was that Cox wanted Resop to pitch however many innings remained after that.

title: Even Renters Arent Safe

title: Paper Trail
description: The opening chapter of this intelligent New York thriller is vivid, ominous and disgusting. Just before dawn, two young Mexican women occupy the front seat of a 15-year-old Toyota, hurtling along the Belt Parkway toward the warm darkness of the beach. They have finished a long night of cleaning business offices in Manhattan, bagging paper, arranging for it to be taken to shredders. It is now time for some laughs, a little reefer too. Alone in the back seat is the woman who is their boss. Her name is Jin Li, and she is older than the two Mexicans, better educated, speaks good English and is a legal immigrant from China. Todays China, booming through its stage of savage capitalism.

title: Ms. Smith Goes to Paris
description: The musician, poet, artist and dreamer Patti Smith brings all facets of her persona to Land 250, her solo exhibition at the Fondation Cartier in Paris, through June 22. Using drawings, Polaroids, films and favorite objects, Smith chronicles her relationships in one way or another. The idea of friendship is really valuable to Patti, says Grazia Quaroni, the foundations curator, whether its real people shes shared her life with, like Robert Mapplethorpe, or the references she has in her literature and other things, such as Arthur Rimbaud. Smiths world is also captured in the documentary Patti Smith: Dream of Life, currently making the film-festival circuit. The photographer Steven Sebring spent 11 years traveling with Smith to create a collage-like tribute. For information, go to dreamoflifethemovie.com. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

But the answer is Tim Horton. His name is mentioned countless times every day.

Paul Wolfowitz may fail miserably, twice; but theres a chair waiting for him at AEI. Rick Santorum may talk about man on dog, and lose in a landslide; but theres a job waiting for him as head of the Americas Enemies program at a movement conservative think tank.

title: Larger Than Life: Charlton Heston
description: One day more than 35 years ago, I pulled into the parking lot of the massive Del Coronado hotel in San Diego when an equally massive figure walked in front of my car, blocking my view because his body filled the entire windshield. It was Charlton Heston, and he strode toward the tennis courts with a purposive authority that brought to mind Moses and Ben Hur, albeit dressed this time in shorts. This was the closest I ever got to Heston in the flesh, although, like hundred of millions of other moviegoers, I saw a great deal of him, sometimes barely clothed (Planet of the Apes), on the big screen.

title: Uneasy Transition
description: It has become common to talk of the improvement a pitcher should see in his numbers by moving from the American League to the weaker National League, but Barry Zito, the Giants $126 million pitcher, is single-handedly doing his best to change that way of thinking. After a rocky first season with San Francisco, Zitos first three starts this year have been even worse. He is 0-3 and has allowed 13 runs  8 earned  for a 4.50 earned run average. Through 37 games in the N.L., Zitos E.R.A. is 4.53. In 222 games over seven seasons for the Athletics in the A.L., it was 3.54.

title: The Watch List

LaRoche had a poor first month last season, hitting .133 and striking out 30 times in 83 at-bats. He still finished 2007 with a .272 average, 21 home runs and 88 runs batted in  all near his career averages.

description: It is hard to imagine a more solemn responsibility than confirming the nomination of a Supreme Court justice. And we have worried, especially in recent years, that nominees are far too carefully packaged and coached on how to duck all of the hard questions.

description: WASHINGTON  A top White House official on Sunday criticized foreign leaders who plan to skip the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Beijing following Chinas crackdown in Tibet, calling such actions a cop out far less effective than the quiet diplomacy the United States is pursuing.

title: The Big Dig: The Yanks Uncover a Red Sox Jersey
description: With dust swirling around them on Sunday afternoon, Frank Gramarossa and Rich Corrado extracted a Red Sox jersey that a construction worker had buried at the site of the new Yankee Stadium. After workers used jackhammers to break through about two and a half feet of concrete, Gramarossa and Corrado pulled out a dusty, torn David Ortiz jersey.

title: The Mask Slips
description: I havent read much Karl Marx since the early 1980s, when I taught political philosophy at the University of Pennsylvania. Still, it didnt take me long this weekend to find my copy of The Marx-Engels Reader, edited by Robert C. Tucker  a book that was assigned in thousands of college courses in the 1970s and 80s, and that now must lie, unopened and un-remarked upon, on an awful lot of rec-room bookshelves.

description: An article and a headline in some editions last Monday about the arrest of a young boy on charges of manslaughter in the death of a Columbia University graduate student gave an incorrect age from the police for the suspect. He is 14, not 13.

title: Housing Woes in U.S. Spread Around Globe
description: DUBLIN  The collapse of the housing bubble in the United States is mutating into a global phenomenon, with real estate prices swooning from the Irish countryside and the Spanish coast to Baltic seaports and even parts of northern India.

title: Flora and Fauna of Spring Hockey
description: Coming in on the train, I could not help noticing the colors of this new and hopeful season  the bright yellow forsythia, the purple dogwood, the red azalea, to say nothing of the red-and-blue bushy-headed Rangers fan sitting in front of me.

title: Firing Barbs, but Looking Like a Saint
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton showed no mercy at the compassion forum.

title: Polytrack Blamed for Pyros Struggles
description: The trainer Steve Asmussen is not worried. He shook off Pyros poor performance in Saturdays Blue Grass Stakes, saying that his colt had an aversion to Keenelands synthetic surface. Before the Blue Grass, Pyro had been among the most consistent horses around, finishing in the top three in six career starts. Trying a synthetic track for the first time, he finished 10th in the Blue Grass.

title: U.S. Marathoner Has Impressive Showing in London
description: LONDON  Ryan Hall was flying through the London streets Sunday, alongside six of the worlds fastest marathoners.

title: Her Pounds Could Make Millions
description: Her name is Sue Tilley. People call her Big Sue. In 1995, for a fee of 20, now worth about $40, she posed naked for the British artist Lucian Freud. Next month, the resulting painting, Benefits Supervisor Sleeping, above, will be offered at auction by Christies in New York. Art experts expect the work, depicting a fleshy woman reclining on a sofa, to fetch as much as $33.5 million, which would make it the most expensive painting by a living artist, Agence France-Presse reported. Now the manager of an employment agency in London, Ms. Tilley, who said she was introduced to Mr. Freud by a friend, joked that she was the first nude pinup to appear on the front page of The Financial Times, which printed a photograph of the painting on Saturday. I cant quite believe it, to be honest, she told the BBC.

title: Crisis of Confidence
description: The Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan has been tracking American economic perceptions since the 1950s. On Friday the center released its latest estimate of the consumer sentiment index  and it was a stunner. Americans are more pessimistic about their situation than they have been for more than a quarter century.

title: Dirty Job, but Someone Has to Do It
description: Go to a nondescript office building on the East side of Manhattan, down the hall to a door already in the clutches of a fake dismembered hand, and you will find the newsroom of The Smoking Gun. The take-no-prisoners Web site at thesmokinggun.com is in the midst of spilling affidavits in a Texas polygamy case and recently pushed The Los Angeles Times to retract a major article about the shooting of Tupac Shakur by pointing out that it was based on fake documents.

title: In Europe, a Push to Take Away Piracy Suspects Internet Access

Scruffy and slightly rumpled despite his suit and tie, Mr. Ritter didnt try to disguise a sense of wonder at his surroundings. This is like storming the gates of irony, he said.

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A National Opera House Opens in Norway
description: More than 120 years after an optimistic Oslo newspaper predicted its advent, a national opera house finally opened in Norway on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. Calling it a new and monumental landmark, King Harald V formally inaugurated the $840 million white marble structure, above, on the shore of the Oslo Fjord in the heart of the capital. On hand for the two-and-a-half-hour performance at the new home for the Norwegian Opera and Ballet was an invited audience that included Queen Sonja of Norway, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Queen Margrethe II of Denmark. With a 1,350-seat and a 400-seat auditorium, the house is decorated with about $12 million worth of art.

title: Beaming Online Services Toward Blacks
description: CHEAP computers and Internet connections have helped people get online in greater numbers in recent years. Now Barry Dillers IAC/InteractiveCorp wants to make money by helping minority groups connect more easily to specific sites.

title: Finance Ministers Emphasize Food Crisis Over Credit Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The worlds economic ministers declared on Sunday that shortages and skyrocketing prices for food posed a potentially greater threat to economic and political stability than the turmoil in capital markets.

title: Justices Decline Zoloft Defense Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court declined on Monday to hear an appeal from a South Carolina teenager who was sentenced to 30 years in prison for killing his grandparents with a shotgun when he was 12 years old.

description: JAKARTA, Indonesia

description: CAIRO  Egyptians in this capital city say it is harder and harder to be heard and to have a voice, but they are not talking politics. Well, not only politics.

title: Off New York Streets, Film Piracy Is Online
description: When Shari C. Hyman tried to buy some pirated DVDs of first-run movies last February, she and her friends went to Canal Street, New York Citys knockoff marketplace. What surprised them was not the racks of phony brand-name handbags, the briefcases of counterfeit watches and other bootlegged merchandise, but rather that illegal DVDs were virtually nowhere to be found.

description: SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn.

title: Dalai Lama Says His Aides Are Talking to China
description: SEATTLE  The Dalai Lama said Sunday that some efforts at diplomacy were under way between his representatives and those of the Chinese government even as officials in Beijing continue to portray him as having orchestrated protests in Tibet that have led to a crackdown and violence there.

title: Germany Nears Deal to Sell Stake in Railroad
description: BERLIN  After months of disagreement, Germanys coalition of conservative and Social Democrats appeared close to a deal Monday to sell to private investors 25 percent of Deutsche Bahn, one of Europes largest rail networks in Europe.

title: Still More Faces of the Kirov in Fokines Dramatic Poetry and Landers tudes
description: The Kirov Ballets current three-week season at New York City Center comprises six different programs of repertory. Since five of these are more or less devoted to individual choreographers, the advance impression is that the Kirov is a great custodian company, devoted to choreography above all else.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Faces Crucial Court Rulings
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  Zimbabwes political opposition is facing crucial court decisions this week that could reshape its electoral stalemate with the governing party of Robert Mugabe, who has been president since the country won its independence 28 years ago.

title: Even Credit Card Offers Are Ebbing
description: Since last November, credit card companies have slashed the amount of direct mail they send out, according to figures released by Mintel, a market research firm. Mintel found that fewer pieces had gone out in February, the last month for which figures were available, than in any month since April 2004. Mintel extrapolated the figures from a panel of 9,700 households, recruited afresh every month.

title: Look! In the Sky. Its a Rocket Racer.
description: The racers may finally be reaching the starting line.

title: Constructive Tips for the Everyday Golfer
description: The Masters tournament helps identify the worlds best golfers. The rest of us already know who we are. We are the Everyday Golfer, and if we are wearing a green jacket today, it is because there was a sale on them somewhere  right next to the dozen Noodle or Lady Precept balls for $19.95.

title: A Funeral for Charlton Heston
description: Hollywood luminaries turned out on Saturday for the funeral of Charlton Heston, The Associated Press reported. Among some 300 people who attended the service at the Parish of St. Matthew, an Episcopal church in a wooded canyon above Pacific Palisades in Los Angeles, were Tom Selleck, escorting Nancy Reagan; Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger; Olivia de Havilland; Keith Carradine; Pat Boone; Oliver Stone; and Rob Reiner. Mr. Heston, who starred in Ben-Hur, The Ten Commandments, The Agony and the Ecstasy and Planet of the Apes, among many other films, died at 84 on April 5.

title: Foreclosure Politics
description: With foreclosures running at about 20,000 per week, at least 100,000 more families are likely to lose their homes before Congress passes a relief bill. And even then, the measure may fail to stanch the problem unless Congress comes up with something that is significantly better than proposals currently in either chamber.

title: In Varitek, the Red Sox Have a Studious and Gritty Leader
description: BOSTON  Jason Varitek of the Red Sox offered a thin smile when he was told that Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, wanted to pull a Ralph Kramden and send him to the moon. Or at least in that direction.

title: Iran Says Blast at Mosque Could Be Accidental
description: TEHRAN, April 13  The death toll from a powerful explosion at a mosque in the southern Iranian city of Shiraz on Saturday evening rose to 12, the state news media reported Sunday. The number of those wounded had reached 202. A terrorist attack has not been ruled out, but officials said the blast could have been an accident.

title: Pettitte Admires Girardis Approach
description: BOSTON  When Andy Pettitte watched Saturdays meeting at the mound between Manager Joe Girardi and Mike Mussina, he liked what he saw. It was not so much the decision Girardi made that resonated with Pettitte  pitching to Manny Ramrez turned out to be a mistake  but the idea of consulting the veteran Mussina before making it.

title: WNEW Returns, Online and in HD
description: WNEW-FM, the New York station that pioneered free-form rock radio, is coming back  sort of. CBS Radio, which owns WNEW and its former frequency in the New York region, 102.7, will begin broadcasting a high-definition signal and Internet stream on Monday based on the stations rock format, the company announced. The HD signal (102.7 HD 2)  high-quality, digital audio broadcast alongside the regular radio signal  and the streaming audio version, on wnew.com, will play a mix of classic 1960s and 70s music and current rock songs, as well as historic concerts and interviews from its archives, but will not have disc jockeys. Instead, CBS says, listeners will be able to contribute through wnew.com and last.fm, a social-networking Web site owned by the CBS Corporation. WNEW-FM became a rock station in 1967 and switched to a talk format in 1999; the 102.7 FM signal in New York is currently an adult contemporary station, WWFS.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about the potential for harm in taking dietary supplements, misidentified the main component of the supplement Cold-fX. It is ginseng, not zinc.

title: Correction: 13 Iraqis Killed by Shells Fired at the Green Zone
description: A reporting credit on March 24 with an article about a mortar attack on the fortified Green Zone in Baghdad and other violence in Iraq misspelled the given name of a contributor. He is Hosham Hussein, not Hoshan Hussein.

description: Q: (Reader)

title: British Voices: Fresh, Lean and Worldly
description: The Choir of Kings College, Cambridge, at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue on Friday, confirmed what many listeners think they know about the British choral tradition, but then gave listeners other things to think about too. The 30 men and boys led by Stephen Cleobury were scrupulously prepared, well tuned and musically alert. That, everyone could expect.

title: Wachovia Is Said to Raise Billions Amid Losses
description: The Wachovia Corporation, the countrys fourth largest bank, is raising several billion dollars from outside investors because of mounting housing losses and an ill-timed acquisition of a big California mortgage lender, people briefed on the matter said Sunday night.

title: A Day at the Opera, a Snack for the Soul
description: Even amid the slurps of giant Pepsis and the rattling tubs of buttered popcorn, Mimis lyrical death scene was, as ever, to die for. Angela Gheorghiu sang Mimis final breaths to a fare-thee-well of heartbreak as another La Bohme  live in HD telecast from the Metropolitan Opera  drew an ecstasy of bravos and applause from aficionados gathered in the darkness of the College Point Multiplex Cinema.

title: Hefty Bill for Popes Visit Looms for Archdioceses
description: WASHINGTON  From printing tickets for the papal Masses to organizing street closures and security, a hefty bill looms for the hosts of Pope Benedict XVIs visit.

title: He Wrote 200,000 Books (but Computers Did Some of the Work)
description: Its not easy to write a book. First you have to pick a title. And then there is the table of contents. If you want the book to be categorized, either by a bookseller or a library, it has to be assigned a unique numerical code, like an ISBN, for International Standard Book Number. There have to be proper margins. Finally, theres the back cover.

description: With Jim Hardy

title: The Making of a Teenage Editorzilla
description: If The Hills is an indictment of 20-something women behaving as if they were not yet old enough for bat mitzvahs, The Paper, a new reality series following it on Monday nights on MTV, is a different kind of exercise in ageism. It plays into stereotypes of overscheduled teenagers who run around with goals of world domination, who believe that an advanced-placement class is license to act as though they were 42. Its Election all over again.

title: Delta to Join Northwest to Form Worlds Largest Airline
description: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines agreed to merge late Monday, in a $3.1 billion deal that would create the worlds biggest carrier and could trigger other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.

title: The Relay of Fire Ignited by the Nazis
description: If you want to know how the Olympic torch really began its Journey of Harmony, as the Chinese call its current relay, if you want to see why the torch has had to pass through a human obstacle course composed of protesters, SWAT teams and police in San Francisco, Paris and London, then do not look to Tibets grievances against China. Look to the opening of Leni Riefenstahls 1938 film, Olympia.

title: Change Brews at Bayreuth
description: After 57 years as chief of the Wagner festival in Bayreuth, Germany, Wolfgang Wagner, 88, plans to step down, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Wagner, right, grandson of the composer Richard Wagner, wrote to donors on April 8 to express his support for his daughters Katharina Wagner, from his second marriage, and Eva Wagner-Pasquier, from his first, as part of a group to succeed him. He had previously rejected the appointment of Ms. Wagner-Pasquier, who is supported by the Richard Wagner Foundation, which supervises the annual Bayreuth Festival. And he had insisted that he would step aside only if Katharina were allowed to succeed him. The German-language television network 3sat reported that Mr. Wagner had suggested that the half-sisters could be part of a team that included the German conductor Christian Thielemann and Peter Ruzicka, the former director of the Salzburg Festival. Mr. Wagner has led the festival since 1951, first with his brother, Wieland, and then by himself after Wielands death in 1966.

title: Happy Days for Prom Night
description: The slasher remake Prom Night, distributed by Sony/Screen Gems and starring Brittany Snow, piled up an estimated gross of $22.7 million in its debut to capture the N0. 1 ranking North American box office over the weekend. After two weeks at the top, 21 (Columbia Pictures) tumbled into third place with $11 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers, just behind another newcomer, the cops-gone-wrong drama Street Kings (Fox Searchlight), which drew $12 million. The comedy-adventure Nims Island (Fox) rang up $9 million to take fourth place, followed by the George Clooney football film, Leatherheads (Universal), with $6.2 million.

title: From Texas to East Coast, Pilgrimage to See the Pope
description: SPRING, Tex.  The Texas sky was still dark and studded with stars Sunday when Ricky Pequeo Jr., rubbing sleep from his eyes, stumbled downstairs to add his bag to a pile of backpacks, sleeping bags, food cooler, baseball glove and ball, football, drum and guitar  everything a family of ardent Roman Catholics might need for a 1,600-mile pilgrimage to see the pope.

title: Uncertain Church Awaits Pope in U.S.
description: Less than two weeks ago, as final preparations were being made for the visit of Pope Benedict XVI to the United States, the bishop of Camden, N.J., announced plans to close or merge nearly half the parishes in his diocese. Meanwhile, Catholics in New Orleans, Boston, New York, Toledo, Ohio, and nearly three dozen other dioceses are mourning the loss of parishes and parochial schools they grew up in.

title: Unity Cabinet Formed in Kenya, Ending Deadlock
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Mwai Kibaki announced a new  and enormous  national unity cabinet here on Sunday, ending weeks of anxious deadlock that had threatened to plunge Kenya back into violence.

title: At the Intersection of Sacred and Secular
description: The gospel singer Edwin Hawkins, famous for the song Oh Happy Day, which put an R&B arrangement on an old hymn and became a hit in 1969, grew up with jazz in his house, through his parents record collection. He said he has been interested in singing secular standards ever since, though hes not known for it.

title: Correction: Olympic Official Calls Protests a Crisis
description: An article on Friday about pressure on China over the Olympic Games misstated part of the name of the group that issued a rare criticism of Chinas human rights record. It is the International Olympic Committee, not the International Olympics Committee.

title: Skepticism and Apathy as Italy Votes
description: ROME  In a mood of national pessimism, Italians began voting Sunday in a race between the conservative billionaire Silvio Berlusconi, seeking a third term as prime minister, and Walter Veltroni, a former mayor of Rome.

title: Delta-Northwest Merger Talks Pick Up Pace Again
description: Merger talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines picked up pace again on Sunday, and people briefed on the negotiations said an announcement of a deal could come as soon as Tuesday.

description: Q: Why do the pants that PGA golfers wear on television look so nice and stylish, and my golf pants look frumpy and tattered?

description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  A maddening melodrama played out within the French Davis Cup team leading into Sundays critical singles matches against the United States as the captain Guy Forget tried to find a warm and willing body to face Andy Roddick.

description: John McCain says the McCain Girls, a trio of singing and dancing campaign supporters, are wonderful and entertaining.

description: The Devils winning goal bounced around like an air hockey puck, traveling its fateful path seemingly on its own. It was nothing anyone would have drawn up, but from center John Maddens perspective, it was the prettiest shot he could imagine.

description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government has dismissed 1,300 soldiers and policemen who deserted or refused to fight during last months Shiite-on-Shiite battles in Basra, it said Sunday.

description: Free tickets to the Metropolitan Operas final dress rehearsal of its new production of Donizettis Fille du Rgiment, at 11 a.m. Friday, are available on its Web site, metopera.org, or by calling (212) 362-6000. The rehearsal is part of the Mets final open house of the season, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., which includes exhibits and a question-and-answer session with members of the cast and the production team. Tickets are limited to two a person.

title: Despite Silicon Valley Optimism, a Disease Resists Cure
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In Silicon Valley, an unshakable optimism holds that the right combination of money, brains and computing power can solve any problem.

title: Slumping Ortiz Is Given a Day Off
description: BOSTON  David Ortiz of the Red Sox has looked lost, managing three hits in 43 at-bats this season. Manager Terry Francona decided that Ortiz, the Red Sox designated hitter, needed a rest and did not start him against the Yankees on Sunday night.

title: Bail in Canada for 2 From Protest Ship
description: OTTAWA  A court in Nova Scotia granted bail on Sunday to two crew members of a seal hunt protest ship that was stormed and seized by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: John A. Wheeler, Physicist Who Coined the Term Black Hole, Is Dead at 96
description: John A. Wheeler, a visionary physicist and teacher who helped invent the theory of nuclear fission, gave black holes their name and argued about the nature of reality with Albert Einstein and Niels Bohr, died Sunday morning at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 96.

title: A Bumper Crop of Bureaucracy
description: ESSEX, N.Y.  When Salim B. Lewis and his wife, Barbara, began building three suburban-style homes in 2006 for the workers on their 1,200-acre organic farm here, they didnt realize they were wading into a regulatory brawl with the state that apparently set off an interagency dispute.

title: Co-Payments Soar for Drugs With High Prices
description: Health insurance companies are rapidly adopting a new pricing system for very expensive drugs, asking patients to pay hundreds and even thousands of dollars for prescriptions for medications that may save their lives or slow the progress of serious diseases.

title: Retired Champion Sprinter Denies Claims of Drug Use
description: The retired world champion sprinter Maurice Greene on Sunday denied claims by a self-confessed former drug adviser and supplier that he had used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Malaysia Opposition Chief Rallies to Seek Top Post
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  When he emerged from prison four years ago, the opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was a weakened and gaunt figure, all but written off by the Malaysian political elite.

description: The members of the New York Baseball Giants Nostalgia Society know this: Their teams history is just as rich as that of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

description: The first thing Irwin Corey ordered when he sat down to lunch recently at the Friars Club was a tube of denture cream. Unfazed, the waiter returned five minutes later and placed it in front of him like an appetizer.

description: An 18-year-old woman was killed and a 32-year-old man was wounded when they were shot on Sunday afternoon in a car parked on a street in the Bronx, the police said.

description: Who said anything about a recession? Sometime between the government bailout of Bear Stearns and the Bureau of Labor Statistics report that America lost 80,000 jobs in March, Lee Tachman spent roughly $50,000 last month on a four-day jaunt to Miami for himself and three close friends.

description: Katie Couric may be the least of Leslie Moonvess worries.

description: Soon after China was awarded the Olympic Games seven years ago, a series of public relations strategy sessions were held. But it wasnt the Chinese government holding the sessions: it was grass-roots Tibet support groups in the United States and abroad.

title: Prez Falters, and Mets Go Along for the Slide
description: Mets starter Oliver Prez was pulled from the game Sunday after his 99 pitches resulted in only 13 outs. His messy pitching line included a little bit of everything: eight hits, six earned runs, three walks, a wild pitch, a hit batsman, one home run allowed.

title: A Case Study of the Mysteries of the Robot Thought Process
description: When you play at Bridge Base Online (www.bridgebase.com), you can compete with or against the GIB computer program. These robots, as such programs are sometimes called, are quirky. Occasionally they bid and play well, but often they make strange decisions.

title: Intervention Scuttles a Dr. Phil Show
description: The television psychologist known as Dr. Phil pulled the plug on plans for a story on the Florida teenagers jailed for participating in a videotaped beating after learning that members of his staff helped one of the eight suspects post bond, The Associated Press reported. Terri Corigliano, a spokeswoman for Dr. Phil McGraw, wrote in an e-mail message that although the production had helped in the past when guests needed financial assistance to come on the show, in this case, certain staff members went beyond our guidelines (re the bail being paid). She continued: These staff members have been spoken to and our policies reiterated. In addition, we have decided not to go forward with the story as our guidelines have been compromised. Ranging in age from 14 to 18, the suspects face kidnapping and misdemeanor battery charges, as well as a felony charge of witness tampering, in connection with the beating of another teenager, which was videotaped and then widely viewed on television and the Internet.

title: Views on Money for Iraq War, and What Else Could Be Done With It

title: Remembering John Paul II in New York
description: Pope John Paul II waved as he arrived at Newark International Airport on Oct. 4, 1995. (Photo: Monica Almeida/The New York Times)  Slide Show: The Last Papal Visit to New YorkIn a gray drizzle, John Paul II came down the jetliner steps with care, limping but still iron-willed at 75, and stood on a red carpet on the tarmac at Newark International Airport. He did not bend to kiss the ground, a gesture he reserved for his first visits to a country -- and this was his fourth to America.  The burdens of 17 years as pope were obvious. The mountaineer's shoulders were bent, and the big Slavic face was lined with the years. A hand trembled with Parkinson's disease. But the man who had cried out for humanity at Auschwitz and Hiroshima, who had begged for peace in Ireland and roared for justice in Poland, still had miles to go.  He beamed and made the Sign of the Cross with the fluid gestures of a parish priest. He shook hands with President Clinton and waded into a throng of senators, governors, cardinals, bishops and 800 other dignitaries sheltering under clumps of black umbrellas.  It was Oct. 4, 1995, the start of his final four-day visit to the New York area, and a heavy schedule of Masses, conferences and appearances lay ahead. But he seemed in no hurry. Along a fence on his way to the car, he stopped to greet Sister Miriam Anne Evanoff and her schoolchildren from Jersey City. He reached across to touch them.  "Praised be Jesus Christ," the nun said, her eyes glistening with tears as she offered the traditional Polish greeting.  "Forever, Amen," the pope responded in his native tongue.  Myron Maslowyca, 13, tried his family's Ukrainian: "Glory be to Jesus Christ."  "Glory, forever," the pope said softly, in Ukrainian.  It was one of those touching, spontaneous moments of human contact that, even after all these years, people remember when they think of John Paul.  (Photo: The pope was welcomed by President Clinton in Newark. (Photo: Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)) Security agents and advance planners try to arrange papal trips down to the last detail, fixing routes, timing events, limiting potentially dangerous contacts with the public, trying to prevent the kind of violence in which John Paul was shot in St. Peter's Square in 1981.  But the truth is that elaborate plans are often flawed, and that the pope's spontaneous moments -- the small asides and intuitive reactions to strangers -- often leave the most lasting impressions, those glimpses into the personality behind the public face and the studied pronouncements.  On John Paul's last visit to the city 13 years ago, what most people saw was just a tiny gold-and-white figure on a distant altar during the Masses he celebrated for biblical multitudes on the Great Lawn in Central Park, at Aqueduct Race Track in Queens and at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands.  But a more revealing episode, for thousands who witnessed it, was the pope's moment of impulse outside St. Patrick's Cathedral on his last day in town, when he emerged after reciting the Rosary and, instead of stepping into his Popemobile and riding away, he decided to take a stroll around the block.  "He's walking! He's walking!" someone cried.  And the crowd of more than 6,000, which had hoped for no more than a fleeting glimpse from behind the barricades, suddenly roared and surged after him. A few people actually touched the pontiff before scrambling police officers and Secret Service agents caught up and formed a protective ring around him. John Paul was unruffled and it was all harmless.  But it was not unusual for John Paul. People everywhere found his presence intensely physical. In his visits to 129 nations on 104 trips abroad, he often made protocol chiefs wince and horrified security officers. Not content to wave from a passing limousine, he would jump out and plunge into the crowds, hugging strangers, kissing babies, singing, smiling, winking, reaching out to touch and bless people.  On his first papal trip to his Polish homeland -- a journey that defied the Communist government -- his presence dominated life for nine days, drawing workers away from jobs to outdoor Masses attended by throngs that stretched across hillsides. He sang hymns and folk songs with his people, clasped old friends in headlocks and talked to coal miners, housewives, college students and teenagers in blue jeans.  John Paul leaving St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue after offering Mass on Oct. 7, 1995. Enlarge this image. (Photo: Keith Meyers/The New York Times) Throughout his 26-year papal reign, John Paul was theologically conservative -- many would say intransigent -- but almost from the start it was clear that he was not to be a traditional pope, ascetic and remote behind the high walls and elaborate ceremonies of the Vatican.  Here was a different kind of pope: deftly politic, schooled in confrontation, a physically expressive man of wit, daring and energy who had seen war and sweeping political changes in the world, a showman of the television-and-jet age who would captivate much of humanity by sheer force of personality.  He had been a poet and playwright, an author of books and articles, a philosopher, a debater, an actor, a factory worker, a professor of social ethics and a linguist skilled in a dozen languages. He had been an athlete and outdoorsman most of his life -- a soccer player, backpacker, camper and boater who loved to ski, swim and climb mountains. And he looked it: a rugged, ruddy-faced man with a bullish neck, pastry-maker hands and the legs of a long-distance runner. He moved gracefully until age began to interfere.  Ultimately, John Paul, who died in April 2005, helped end the cold war, contributed to the defeat of European Communism, made ecumenical gestures to Jews, Orthodox Christians and other faiths and reshaped his church with a vision of combative, disciplined Catholicism.  His successor, Pope Benedict XVI, despite almost three years on the Throne of St. Peter, is largely unknown to New Yorkers and even to many American Catholics. He turns 81 on Wednesday, has been abroad six times as pope and has made no deep impression on people around the world. Experts who know him as the German-born former Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, John Paul's arch-conservative Vatican defender of the faith, say he is scholarly and tough beneath a mild exterior.  This week, as Benedict visits America for five days, including three in the New York area, crowds are expected to line his routes, attend his Masses, follow his movements on television and hear him address the United Nations. He is to meet President Bush at the White House, visit ground zero and St. Patrick's Cathedral and celebrate Mass at Yankee Stadium. He is also to meet with Jews, Muslims, Buddhists, Hindus and members of other faiths, as well as Catholic leaders, seminarians and parishioners.  Impressions of Benedict may come primarily from what he has to say -- much of which he has said before -- opposition to the war in Iraq, regrets over the priest sexual-abuse scandals, praise for American religious toleration and rejection of secularism and changes in church teaching on birth control, priestly celibacy, the ordination of women, homosexuality and other issues that trouble American Catholics.  Security will be the tightest ever, the authorities say, with backpacks banned, spectators searched and audiences vetted at every venue. And Benedict will travel in an enclosed Popemobile, limiting chance encounters with people. His visit thus may be a sequel, but in the cautious age of terrorism, impressions of the pope -- especially the emotional connections many felt toward John Paul -- may be limited.  (Photo: About 130,000 people gathered on the Great Lawn in Central Park for a papal Mass. (Photo by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times))
