Then he needs to come up with themes for Passover services on Sunday and Monday.

title: The Verge of Expulsion, the Fringe of Justice
description: Federal appeals are not usually a volume business. Even fancy Manhattan firms with hundreds of lawyers seldom have more than a handful of cases pending in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which is known for its august history, superior judicial craftsmanship and special expertise in commercial and securities case.

title: France: Le Monde Strike Stops Presses
description: Journalists at Le Monde, one of Frances most authoritative newspapers, went on strike for only the second time in its 64-year history to protest planned cuts in newsroom staff. Like other papers, Le Monde is struggling with losses. Management announced this month that the paper would let go a quarter of its 340 journalists.

title: Intels Income Meets Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel, the biggest semiconductor maker, reported solid global demand for its chips, soothing investor concerns that economic softness would rattle the technology industry.

title: L.I. Boy Is Hurt by a Stray Bullet
description: A Long Island boy was seriously injured Monday afternoon when a stray bullet passed through a wall of his house in North Bellport and struck him in the face, the police said.

title: Vonn Finds Herself at the Top
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Lindsey Vonn really did not want to be interviewed at her house, the new one that she had hardly seen in six months while she was off being the worlds best female skier. The Starbucks down the road would be better, she said, because her place was messy, all clutter and heaps. Until recently, the wedding dress she wore on Sept. 29, when her surname changed from Kildow to Vonn, was draped over the back of a couch.

title: Rumsfeld to Write His Memoirs
description: Donald H. Rumsfeld, who resigned as secretary of defense in late 2006, will write his memoirs for the Sentinel imprint of Penguin Group USA. Mr. Rumsfeld, 75, will cover not only his years in the Bush administration but also his experiences with Presidents Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford and Ronald Reagan; his work in the private sector; and his early life. In contrast to other recent political figures who have produced memoirs, Mr. Rumsfeld is forgoing an advance and will donate profits to a nonprofit foundation he recently established to make educational grants to young people interested in public service and establishing links between the United States and Central Asia.

title: Averys Strategy Draws Ire of Devils
description: NEWARK  Rangers left wing Sean Avery, a notorious agitator, did something Sunday that one of his old nemeses, Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur, had never seen before  and probably never will again.

title: Edging Closer to Another Title in Manchester
description: Manchester United is committed to clinching its second consecutive English Premier League title in the next two weeks, perhaps sooner, the clubs manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, said Monday.

title: State Steps Up Efforts to Collect a Sales Tax Owed by More in a Digital Age
description: Line 59 is among the more disregarded blank boxes on New York States income tax form. It is buried on the next-to-last page of form IT-201, inconspicuously near a line for charitable donations to a wildlife fund and one for a surcharge on part-time residents of Yonkers.

title: McCain Joins Fray on Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain threw himself into the culture war between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday. He said at a gathering of news executives that comments by Mr. Obama about working-class voters were elitist and a fundamental contradiction of what I believe Americas all about.

title: In Angry Closings, Trial of 3 Queens Detectives Goes to Judge for Verdict
description: The trial of three police detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell ended on Monday with one of the most fractious days in seven weeks in the courtroom, with one defense lawyer delivering a summation that played up a victims use of a racial slur, and prosecutors countering in equally blistering tones that the police officers were lying on the stand.

title: Rowling Testifies Against Lexicon Author
description: It was her first time testifying in a courtroom, J. K. Rowling said on Monday, and she was a bit nervous.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an exhibition review of Creating the United States, a show at the Library of Congress that uses technology to illuminate history, misidentified the document a visitor was examining at a touch-screen kiosk. It was the Declaration of Independence, not the Constitution.

title: For New Jersey Democrats, Senate Race Turns Divisive
description: TRENTON  One by one, the members of New Jerseys Democratic Congressional delegation who were seated around the dining room table explicitly pledged support to their senior United States senator, Frank R. Lautenberg  and implicitly agreed to keep their ambitions for his seat in check as he seeks his fifth term this fall.

title: The Monty Hall Problem (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, a Sports of The Times column on Sunday about efforts to renovate Fenway Park without damaging its traditional charm misstated, in some editions, the source of the phrase do no harm. It is from Hippocrates work Epidemics, not from the Hippocratic oath.

title: Zingers Hurtling (Duck if You Can)
description: The one-liners fly like rockets in The New Century, the rollicking bill of short plays by Paul Rudnick that opened on Monday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. And more often than not, they hit their targets smoking. If Leno and Letterman regularly scored this ratio of hits to quips, much of America would be hospitalized with late-night laughter burn.

title: What Else Is There for Deion Sanders to Do? Reality TV
description: The former football and baseball player Deion Sanders is blessed with a charm that leaks through the armor of his arrogance. Back in the early 1990s, when he was proving himself one of the greatest athletes in living memory, playing cornerback for the Atlanta Falcons and outfield for the Braves, Mr. Sanders responded to the critical comments of the baseball announcer Tim McCarver by dousing him with ice water. Still, the athletes status as a dazzler, a fun lover, a guy with whom youd love to share a Coors Light or six, suffered no lasting fracture.

title: Fresh, Inventive Partnering, Spinning Full Throttle
description: Ballet Builders was established in 1990 by Ruth Chester and Michael Kraus to present dances by choreographers interested in working with the classical ballet canon. Of the six choreographers presented by Ballet Builders on Saturday night at Kaye Playhouse, Emery LeCrone was the only one to make something fresh of that idiom.

title: M.T.A. to Tap Solar Power for Electricity at Some Buildings
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Monday that it would install solar panels on about a dozen bus depots, warehouses and other facilities with large roofs as part of a push to make its operations more environmentally friendly.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Monday about a large increase in insurance co-payments for high-priced drugs misstated the way the multiple sclerosis drug Copaxone is administered. It is injected, not taken in pill form.

title: Shifting Focus From Boxing Arena to Political Arena
description: The former heavyweight champion Vitali Klitschko is a contender for another title  mayor of Kiev, Ukraine.

title: Tesla Motors Files Suit Against Competitor Over Design Ideas
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley maker of electric sports cars, filed suit in San Mateo Superior Court on Monday against a competing company and two of its employees, saying they stole some of Teslas design ideas and trade secrets.

title: The Vigor of the S.E.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Film Honors
description: Jet Li, above, was named best actor when the Hong Kong film awards were handed out late Sunday in a glittering ceremony, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Li won for his performance in The Warlords, an action drama set in 19th-century China that also carried off the prizes for best film and best director (Peter Chan) among its eight awards. Andy Lau, a co-star of The Warlords, won the prize for best supporting actor for the crime thriller Protg, and Siqin Gaowa of the quirky tragicomedy The Postmodern Life of My Aunt was chosen best actress. The award for best Asian film went to Ang Lee for Lust, Caution, and a lifetime achievement award was given to Raymond Chow, whose Golden Harvest studios fostered the careers of Jackie Chan and Bruce Lee.

title: Supplements and Remedies (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Hard-Drive Maker Files Suit Against Rival
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Seagate Technology, the largest maker of computer hard drives, made a pre-emptive strike against an emerging competitor on Monday when it filed a lawsuit in federal court accusing STEC Inc. of patent infringement.

title: Who Are We? Coming of Age on Antidepressants
description: Ive grown up on medication, my patient Julie told me recently. I dont have a sense of who I really am without it.

title: Styrons Essays Give Glimpses Into a Life Spent in Good Company
description: The United States Marine Corps, William Styron writes in one of the essays in this posthumous collection, introduced him to the glories of the library. Having enlisted at 17 during World War II, he was deemed too young to be sent right away into Pacific combat and was sent first, instead, to a military-sponsored college program at Duke University, which then, as now, possessed one of the great college libraries of America. Possessed of a prevision of himself as being among the fallen martyrs in the Pacific theater, he began to read voraciously, regarding the books in the Duke library as the rocks and boulders he could cling to against his onrushing sense of doom and mortality.

title: On the Edge of Impropriety, Ryanair Builds Its Image
description: LONDON

title: Ex-Director of Smithsonian Latino Center Solicited Gifts and Tickets, Report Says
description: The former director of the Smithsonian Latino Center charged the office for personal expenses like salon, spa and gift shop purchases, solicited free tickets for the Latin Grammy Awards and stayed in four- and five-star hotels while traveling for business  often in upgraded rooms with ocean views and Jacuzzi suites, a report from the Smithsonians inspector general says.

title: 'Housewives' Invigorates ABC
description: The return of Desperate Housewives lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday, as 16 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m., Eastern and Pacific times, for the first new episode of the series since early January, Nielsen reported. Despite delivering the seriess lowest ratings to date among adults 18 to 49, Desperate Housewives still easily led the night in that demographic. Rounding out ABCs schedule were Oprahs Big Give at 8 (8.9 million) and Eli Stone at 10 (9.2 million). CBS, runner-up to ABC in the 18-to-49 set, tied for first in total viewers thanks to an overrun of its afternoon Masters golf coverage well into the 7 oclock hour, followed by 60 Minutes, which attracted roughly 11 million viewers. NBC and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third, although Fox fared better in the 18-to-49 age group, as new episodes of The Simpsons at 8 (6.9 million) and King of the Hill at 8:30 (6 million) drew particularly strong ratings in that demographic.

title: Economy Ailing, Frustrated Italy Picks Berlusconi
description: ROME  Silvio Berlusconi, the idiosyncratic billionaire who already dominates much of Italys public life, snatched back political power in elections that ended Monday, heading a center-right coalition certain to make him prime minister for a third term.

title: At Clintons Side in Pennsylvania, a Dedicated and Often Blunt Promoter
description: KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa.  Edward G. Rendell, the governor of Pennsylvania, demonstrated his value to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton last weekend, helping her quickly devise a strategy to counter and exploit remarks by Senator Barack Obama.

title: Less Drama Is Linked to Changes at Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Among the questions to emerge in the wake of the Masters  right behind where has Trevor Immelman been hiding all that game?  is the annual argument about whether changes to the course at Augusta National have succeeded only in taking the drama out of the event.

title: Tax Data of 3 Officials Show More Than Income
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson and his wife earned $269,815 in income in 2007 but gave only one charitable donation, worth $150, for the year, according to tax returns he will file on Tuesday.

title: Life After Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Lower Insurance Premiums and Better Care: Un-American Health Delivery
description: If your latest battle with your H.M.O. has you pounding your head with frustration, Sick Around the World on PBS may spur you to more drastic action, like leaving the United States altogether.

title: U.N. Inquiry Urged for Bhutto Death
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The new Parliament here passed a unanimous resolution on Monday urging the government to allow the United Nations to investigate the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

title: Open Wide: Pioneer Dentist Gets His Due
description: When, as a child, I heard grandiose tales of my great-grandfather the dentist, I could have been forgiven for thinking that before he came along, dentistry was like something out of a sepia-toned comic skit, with mallet as sedative and crude pliers for extraction. And his arrival, in my imagination, instantly brought the modern dental office.

title: Net Neutrality Regulations
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Journalists Are Released in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Two journalists, one the victim of a kidnapping, the other held in jail by American forces, won their liberty on Monday.

title: Bridging the Gap, the Sequel
description: A story that Daniel Scheinman, a senior vice president at Cisco Systems in San Jose, Calif., likes to tell illustrates the cultural divide between Hollywood and his Silicon Valley.

title: Justices Accept Question of Prosecutors as Lawyers or Managers
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court accepted an appeal on Monday that could help define the boundaries of prosecutorial immunity in an era when the officials who head big prosecutors offices function as managers as much as they act as hands-on lawyers.

title: Choreographers Cross Over, and Gymnasts Take Flight
description: Athlete-performers executing gasp-inducing feats. Pulsing music and roving spotlights. Tight, flesh-exposing outfits. At times it seems that there isnt much daylight between skilled acrobatic troupes like Aeros, featuring members of the Romanian Gymnastics Federation, and many of todays commercially minded contemporary-dance companies (not to mention those of classical ballet, if the Kirovs season wrapping up at City Center this week is any indication).

title: As the Music Swells, Treacle Unlike Any Other
description: I have never thought of the Masters as a bloody battlefield, but the loud martial music CBS Sports used so relentlessly was meant to evoke heraldry  or at least testy jousting. But the Masters is not Braveheart and Trevor Immelman is not William Wallace. And I have got a really bad earworm.

title: Some Perspective on Bitter
description: Maybe Barack Obama felt he couldnt afford to give the correct answer.

title: Tracks Governing Body Is Standing By Greene
description: The world governing body for track and field raced Monday to support Maurice Greene, a four-time Olympic medal winner, after he disputed a report from a federal informant that he had used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Desperate to Cry, Desperate Not To
description: I knelt down in front of the elderly womans wheelchair so she could see me. She wore a baby-blue sweatsuit and smelled of cigarettes and hair spray.

title: Liu to Race at Grand Prix
description: Liu Xiang, the world champion hurdler who is expected to be the face of the Beijing Olympics for the host country, is scheduled to compete at the Reebok Grand Prix on May 31 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island. Liu is the Olympic champion and the world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles. He won the event at last years Reebok Grand Prix in 12.92 seconds. Also scheduled to compete are the sprinters Veronica Campbell-Brown and Lauryn Williams. Campbell-Brown edged Williams in the 100 meters at the world championships last year.

title: The Claim: Being Left-Handed Adds to the Risk of Migraines
description: THE FACTS As if left-handers did not have it hard enough.

title: Germany: Marijuana Smokers Were Poisoned With Lead in Leipzig
description: They had stomach cramps, nausea, anemia and fatigue, and some even had a telltale bluish line along their gums  classic signs of lead poisoning. But the cases, last year in Leipzig, Germany, puzzled doctors. Lead poisoning is rare in Germany, and yet here were 29 cases in just a few months. The doctors noticed a pattern: the patients were young, from 16 to 33; they were students or unemployed; and they had body piercings and a history of smoking.

title: Chinese Entity Buys a Stake in British Oil Giant
description: SHANGHAI  A Chinese government entity has acquired a sizable stake in BP, one of the worlds biggest oil and energy companies, for about $2 billion.

title: Memo From Surgeon: Office Hours Dont Include Midflight
description: IN my years as a cosmetic surgeon I have found that people will go to great lengths to achieve a certain ideal of beauty or masculinity.

title: Delta and Northwest in $3 Billion Deal
description: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines agreed to merge late Monday, in a $3.1 billion deal that would create the worlds biggest airline and could prompt other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.

title: Pope T-Shirt, Anyone? Turning to Big Donors, and Souvenirs, for a Costly Visit
description: WASHINGTON  From printing tickets for the papal Masses to organizing street closings and security, a hefty bill looms for the hosts of Pope Benedict XVIs visit to the United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 14, 2008

title: America in Iraq: Setting Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Sharp, Vehement Gestures to Produce Expansive Sounds
description: Osmo Vanskas recordings of Sibelius and Beethoven symphonies have made him a hot property in the orchestral world, and in visits to New York these last few seasons he has shown that those recordings were not flukes. The Minnesota Orchestra wisely snapped him up, appointing him music director in 2003, and although it has always been a fine ensemble, it sounded more brightly polished and supercharged than ever when it played under Mr. Vanskas baton at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: Country Musical Has Eyes on Broadway
description: Pure Country, you may remember, was a 1992 movie starring George Strait and Lesley Ann Warren and telling the tale of a country star who would, as the tag line went, trade it all to find the kind of love hed only sung about. Now its a new musical in the works with a planned Broadway opening sometime in the 2008-9 season and a rather intriguing creative team. Peter Masterson, the co-writer and co-director of the musical The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas is on board to direct and to write the book along with Rex McGee, the writer of the Pure Country film. Steve Dorff, who wrote the song Every Which Way but Loose, among others, is composing the music, and John Bettis, who wrote Madonnas Crazy for You, among others, is writing the lyrics.

title: Mayors and Wal-Mart Back Gun Sales Plan
description: A coalition of mayors in favor of gun control, led by Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston, said on Monday that it had reached a 10-point agreement with Wal-Mart, the countrys largest seller of guns, to track the sale of firearms more closely.

title: Global Markets and U.S. Dollar Down
description: PARIS  Major stock markets fell in Europe and Asia on Monday, and the dollar lost value against other major currencies, after a weekend meeting of the Group of 7 finance ministers and central bankers ended with no announcement of significant action.

title: Rising Oil and Food Prices Stoke Inflation Fears
description: Businesses continued to grapple with steep inflation last month as oil and food costs hit record highs, leaving Federal Reserve policy makers in a difficult spot ahead of their meeting later this month.

title: Memo Pad
description: AMERICAN JOINS FARE INCREASE  Ending a week in which it abruptly canceled more than 3,000 flights for maintenance inspections, American Airlines became the last of the major network carriers to join in a new across-the-board fare increase. The latest round of increases, the seventh involving fares or fuel surcharges this year, was started by United Airlines last week and then matched by the other five network carriers, said Tom Parsons of BestFares.com. The successive fare increases and fuel charges have added a total of up to $170 round-trip to many tickets, Mr. Parsons said. Rick Seaney, of FareCompare.com, said that fuel surcharges alone now average $50 a ticket for domestic travel, $215 for European travel and $280 for travel to Asia. Jet fuel on the spot market was $3.56 a gallon last week, compared with $1.39 a gallon in January 2005, he said.

title: Let the Sunshine in
description: Q. Am I still getting vitamin D when Im outside on a gray, cloudy day?

title: Europe Steps Around Tibet as Trade Issue
description: The European Commission said Tuesday that legitimate European worries about human rights and Tibet should not be walled off from the Continents trade relationship with China but that it did not support the idea of boycotts.

title: Retailing Chains Caught in a Wave of Bankruptcies
description: The consumer spending slump and tightening credit markets are unleashing a widening wave of bankruptcies in American retailing, prompting thousands of store closings that are expected to remake suburban malls and downtown shopping districts across the country.

title: Footnotes
description: From 2004 until her death at 96 in 2007, the actress, singer and arts advocate Kitty Carlisle Hart celebrated her birthday by performing at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. On Monday at 8:30 p.m., with Michael Feinstein as the host, a benefit performance for New Dramatists will salute Miss Carlisle, with tributes by Mario and Matilda Cuomo and Anne Kaufman and performances by Jane Powell, Dina Merrill, George S. Irvin, Christine Andreas, K T Sullivan, Anna Bergman and others. New Dramatists is a nonprofit center for the development of playwrights. ... Plcido Domingo is to deliver the commencement address at the Juilliard Schools 103rd commencement ceremony on May 23 in Avery Fisher Hall, where honorary doctorates will be awarded to the jazz pianist Hank Jones; the dancer and choreographer Carmen de Lavallade; the philanthropist Charles Simonyi; the actress, playwright and author Anna Deavere Smith; and the pianist Mitsuko Uchida.

title: Construction Worker Falls to His Death on East Side of Manhattan
description: A construction worker fell to his death from an East Side building on Monday when a safety strap system intended to secure him to the building failed, the authorities said.

title: Pakistan: Parliament Seeks U.N. Inquiry for Bhutto
description: Parliament passed a resolution urging the government to allow the United Nations to investigate the death of Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister who was killed Dec. 27, after addressing a political rally. Officials of her party, which now leads the government, have expressed dissatisfaction with the inquiry conducted by the previous government of allies of President Pervez Musharraf.

title: Gravity, Drollery and Even Economy
description: What exactly makes a dance feel too long? A program of seven new dances called pocketworks, presented at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Saturday night, raised this question in the form of Plenitude, one of its more intriguing and ambitious offerings, by Kimberly Young and the Extra-Sensory Pedestrians.

title: Lottery for Temporary Work Visas
description: Federal authorities said they ran an electronic lottery to select 85,000 highly skilled immigrants to receive temporary work visas, known as H-1Bs, for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The federal Citizenship and Immigration Services agency received 163,000 petitions for the visas, which are limited to annual quotas of 65,000 for immigrants with skills in technology, science and engineering, and 20,000 for immigrants with advanced degrees from American universities. The agency said it would notify by June 2 the employers whose petitions for immigrant workers were selected in the lottery, and the visas would be fully processed by July 1. A waiting list was created in case some of the selected petitions do not meet the requirements.

title: Bond Insurer Ponders Its Options
description: FGIC, a money-losing bond insurer owned by the Blackstone Group and the PMI Group, is seeking investors and may consider selling the company as it approaches a deadline to shore up its capital.

title: Kenya: Gang Fights Police in Several Towns
description: Riots erupted when members of a shadowy sect blockaded roads to protest the killing of their leaders wife. Members of the notorious Mungiki gang, a cultlike organization that runs extortion rings across Kenya, attacked commuters and fought the police in several towns. Local news reports indicated that as many as 12 people might have been killed, but Kenyan police officials said they had no confirmation of any deaths. Virginia Nyakio, the Mungiki leaders wife, was found dead last week with her throat slit in a forest outside Nairobi.

title: Breathtaking Frescoes, for Those Willing to Search
description: Its easy to see 2,000-year-old buildings in Rome  they literally line the streets, in various states of graceful decay. But 2,000-year-old art in good enough shape to be viewed, now that is a much tougher find. So heres your chance:

title: How Epidemics Helped Shape the Modern Metropolis
description: On a Sunday in July 1832, a fearful and somber crowd of New Yorkers gathered in City Hall Park for more bad news. The epidemic of cholera, cause unknown and prognosis dire, had reached its peak.

title: Oil Prices Surge to a New High
description: Oil prices surged to a new high on Tuesday, rising to nearly $114 a barrel, as scattered pipeline interruptions and a weak dollar pressured a tight global market.

title: Citing Ethics, Some Doctors Are Rejecting Industry Pay
description: With little fanfare, a small number of prominent academic scientists have made a decision that was until recently all but unheard of. They decided to stop accepting payments from food, drug and medical device companies.

title: Eugene Ehrlich, 85, Word Connoisseur, Dies
description: Eugene Ehrlich, a self-educated lexicographer who wrote 40 dictionaries, thesauruses and phrase books for the extraordinarily literate, not to mention people just hoping to sound that way, died on April 5 at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Detroit City Council Snubs Mayor as Impasse Persists
description: DETROIT  The standoff between Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick, who refuses to resign as he battles charges of perjury and obstruction of justice, and the City Council, which wants him to leave, grows more bitter by the day.

title: France: Le Monde Strike Stops Presses
description: Journalists at Le Monde, one of Frances most authoritative newspapers, went on strike for only the second time in its 64-year history to protest planned cuts in newsroom staff. Like other papers, Le Monde is struggling with losses. Management announced this month that the paper would let go a quarter of its 340 journalists.

title: Drug Fails to Slow Nerve Damage
description: Genentech and Biogen Idecs cancer drug Rituxan failed to slow the disabling effects of the most difficult form of multiple sclerosis in a large clinical trial, the companies said Monday.

title: Frogs in Borneo Added to Ranks of the Lungless
description: Scientists working in the Indonesian part of Borneo have rediscovered a rare species of aquatic frog, known only from two specimens described 30 years ago.

title: Victims in Boston Criticize Popes Comments
description: BOSTON  Pope Benedict XVI may have expressed his regrets on Tuesday for the child sexual-abuse scandal in the Catholic Church, saying he was deeply ashamed, but several abuse victims here, where the crisis erupted in 2002, said his comments rang hollow.

title: Chrysler and Nissan Agree to a Vehicle-Building Pact
description: DETROIT  Chrysler and Nissan Motor of Japan said Monday that they had agreed to build vehicles for each other in a deal that could signal closer cooperation in the future.

title: Tommy Holmes, 91, Who Set N.L. Hitting Mark, Is Dead
description: Tommy Holmes, the Boston Braves outfielder who hit in 37 consecutive games in 1945, setting a modern National League record that endured for 33 years, died Monday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 91.

title: Wall Streeter Converts to a Fan of Regulation
description: Robert K. Steel leans forward, speaking in a rapid, excitable burst about the powers that a superregulator might wield over Wall Street one day.

title: Indias Game, U.S. Spice
description: IN the blink of an eye, India has gone from faith, prudence and chastity to ... Brittany, Courtney and Tiffani. On Sunday, a team of Washington Redskins cheerleaders landed in Bangalore to help create Indias first cheerleading squad.

title: Philharmonic Schedules Free Concerts
description: Preparing for unofficial and official summer, the New York Philharmonic has announced its annual schedule of free concerts, beginning with its 17th Memorial Day concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Led by David Robertson, music director of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra and principal guest conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the performance, at 8 p.m. on May 26, will include Schuberts Symphony in B minor (Unfinished) and Mendelssohns Symphony No. 4 (Italian). The 2008 Concerts in the Parks series, with all performances at 8 p.m., opens on the Great Lawn of Central Park on June 24, with a program including works by Shostakovich, Mendelssohn, Tchaikovsky and Sousa. A program of Mozart, Bach and Elgar will be heard on July 8 at the Richmond County Bank Ballpark on Staten Island; on July 9 at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J.; on July 10 at Cunningham Park, Queens; on July 11 in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx; and on July 12 at Heckscher State Park in East Islip, N.Y. Bach, Beethoven and Sibelius will be heard on July 14 in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, and the series will conclude on July 15 with works by Tchaikovsky, Beethoven and Sibelius on the Great Lawn in Central Park. All New York concerts will be followed by fireworks.

title: Court Sets Fall Debate on Standards of Water Act
description: WASHINGTON  In accepting an appeal on the role of cost-benefit analysis in establishing standards under the Clean Water Act, the Supreme Court on Monday set the stage for what could be an important post-Election Day debate over environmental policy.

title: Coping With a Close Call (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimbabwe Court Refuses to Release Vote Results
description: JOHANNESBURG  The High Court of Zimbabwe on Monday dismissed an opposition demand for the immediate release of the results of a presidential election held 16 days before. Independent monitors say that the countrys autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, trailed badly in the vote and that he may have lost outright.

title: Fuel Choices, Food Crises and Finger-Pointing
description: The idea of turning farms into fuel plants seemed, for a time, like one of the answers to high global oil prices and supply worries. That strategy seemed to reach a high point last year when Congress mandated a fivefold increase in the use of biofuels.

title: Alternatives for the Final Disposition
description: Not once in the collective 76 years since our parents died have my brother and I visited their graves. Though we loved and admired them both much, neither of us can relate to a plot of ground and a carved stone. We prefer to remember them in more tangible ways. The plants our father nurtured and the sports he taught us, our mothers down-home cooking and beautiful handicraft.

title: Tenement Museum Leadership Changes
description: After 20 years as the founding president of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Ruth J. Abram is stepping down on June 1. She will be replaced by Morris Vogel, a history professor at Temple University, where he has been on the faculty since 1973, serving as department chairman and acting dean of the College of Liberal Arts. From 2004 to 2006 he was an official at the Rockefeller Foundation. Under Ms. Abram the museum, which opened in 1988, has grown to about 80 staff members, 130,000 visitors a year and an annual budget of $4.5 million from 23 volunteer staff members and a budget of $75,000. The museum interprets the history of immigrant families who lived at 97 Orchard Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, using their stories to encourage discussion of contemporary immigration. Mr. Vogel is a first-generation American, born in Kazakhstan to a German-Jewish family who escaped during World War II. After living in a displaced-persons camp in Poland, his family immigrated to the United States.

title: The Trouble With Salmon
description: The federal governments decision to shut down commercial salmon fishing from the California coast to north-central Oregon is a blow to local fishermen and the coastal economy.

title: Faith in Spotlight, Candidates Battle for Catholic Votes
description: WASHINGTON  Many years have passed since the Democratic Party was as much a part of American Catholic identity as weekly Mass and parochial school. But it still came as a shock to many Democrats to lose the Catholic vote, a key group in must-win states like Ohio, in the 2004 presidential election.

title: A Recluse Lifts the Veil a Little
description: Stephen A. Feinberg, the money man some hope will save Detroit, seemed almost apologetic. I dont blame anyone who doesnt know me from thinking a lot of things, said Mr. Feinberg, the reclusive founder of Cerberus Capital Management, the big buyout firm.

title: At Developers Trial, Witness Recalls Seeing Obamas at 2004 Party for Investor
description: A government witness testified on Monday at the trial of the Chicago businessman Antoin Rezko that Senator Barack Obama attended a party in 2004 that Mr. Rezko held to court a controversial Iraqi-born investor for a large real estate project.

title: A Lowbrow in High Office Ruffles France
description: PARIS  Nearly a year into his term President Nicolas Sarkozy of France has hardly mentioned the arts or culture. In late February he said that French cuisine should be added to the Unesco World Heritage list.

title: A Speech About Nothing
description: Were in the middle of a series of historic economic transformations.

title: Delta and Northwest Promote Benefits of Merger
description: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines on Tuesday began the business of talking up the benefits of their plan to merge.

title: New Home-Buying Plan May Bolster Abbas
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian West Bank, besieged by Israeli occupation, political division and weak leadership, got a boost on Monday: the announcement of a plan, led by the American government, to help tens of thousands of people buy homes.

title: Recycling That Harms the Environment and People
description: Recycling is supposed to be good for the environment. But if its not carried out properly, certain kinds of recycling  notably the dismantling of electronic circuit boards, which contain lead, zinc, copper and other metals  can cause environmental harm.

title: Kenya: Gang Fights Police in Several Towns
description: Riots erupted when members of a shadowy sect blockaded roads to protest the killing of their leaders wife. Members of the notorious Mungiki gang, a cultlike organization that runs extortion rings across Kenya, attacked commuters and fought the police in several towns. Local news reports indicated that as many as 12 people might have been killed, but Kenyan police officials said they had no confirmation of any deaths. Virginia Nyakio, the Mungiki leaders wife, was found dead last week with her throat slit in a forest outside Nairobi.

title: Olympic Hopes Are Rooted in Tale of Escape
description: Chicago

title: Fans Have Not Forgotten, or Forgiven, the Mets
description: No employee in the Mets organization is safe anymore. Whether it is Johan Santana, their $137.5 million off-season acquisition, or an usher popping a beach ball in the stands, or the left-handed reliever Scott Schoeneweis, the frustrated fans at Shea Stadium are prepared to boo.

title: Grocer Is Charged With Assault on Teenager
description: A Brooklyn grocery store owner was charged with assault on Monday for hitting a 15-year-old boy in the head with a hammer during a confrontation at his store, the police said.

title: The Guitarist Brian May Becomes a Chancellor
description: Brian May, above, already a rock star and astrophysics scholar, has added a new title: university chancellor. Taking up his position as chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University in England, Mr. May, 60, the guitarist of Queen, accepted the largely honorary post and told an audience of about 500 people, including Cherie Blair, wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair, that British science needed more support, Agence France-Presse reported. It is a rather sorry state of affairs, Mr. May said. He also spoke about Queens forthcoming album, its first in 13 years, and a European tour from September to November. The long arm of Queen has pulled me back in at the moment, Mr. May said. It is a beast.

title: An Off Broadway Institution Lets Its Production Staff Go
description: All six employees on the production staff of the New York Theater Workshop have been told that they will be laid off as of May 30, and that their jobs will be performed in the future by temporary workers in a bid to cut costs.

title: Raves (Yes, Its True) for New Hearing Aid
description: Few products are hated as much as hearing aids.

title: Hunting for Answers in Fatal Bronx Shooting
description: The detectives investigating the puzzling killing of a Massachusetts woman in the Bronx on Sunday are working to zero in on the gunman who shot her and her boyfriend as they pulled over on a quiet street with their infant son, the police said on Monday.

title: Nepals Maoists Lead in Early Election Results
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Barely two years out of the jungle, former Maoist guerrillas were poised on Monday to lead Nepals new government, as initial election results signaled that voters had chosen to remove most of their veteran politicians from office and sought a radical break with the past.

title: Measuring a Hurricane by Sound Underwater
description: There are a couple of ways to forecast the destructive potential of a hurricane so that people in harms way can take adequate precautions. Satellite images of cloud patterns can be analyzed to estimate peak wind speeds, but the estimates are often way off the mark. Specialized aircraft can fly into a storm to measure the winds directly, but the flights are costly.

title: Songs in Which Relative Quiet Ruled
description: I remember the American soprano Kathleen Battle as having one of the purest voices I have ever heard. Most New Yorkers have not had much chance to hear it firsthand since her famous run-in with Joseph Volpe and the Metropolitan Opera in 1994.

title: Fans Eat Free and Chew Out Thomas
description: The Knicks thanked their fans  their irrationally loyal, perpetually tormented fans  with free hot dogs, popcorn, pizza and pretzels Monday at Madison Square Garden. They called it fan appreciation night, although the fans surely would have traded the food for a higher-ticket item, namely the termination of Isiah Thomas.

title: Boomers, Lets Talk About ...What Was It Again?
description: To the Editor:

title: Adored, Deplored and Ubiquitous
description: Come next Tuesday, in a move flagrantly timed to coincide with Earth Day, the Whole Foods supermarket chain will no longer offer its customers the plastic bag option. Seeing that it can take more than 1,000 years for a plastic bag to break down in a landfill and that in the U.S. alone, about 100 billion plastic bags are thrown away each year, the company said it could not in good conscience contribute to the crisis.

title: New DVDs: Blast of Silence and Inside
description: BLAST OF SILENCE

title: Final-Act Cameo Saves Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees flight landed here at 5 a.m. on Monday, and an hour later, Robinson Can fell asleep. When he showed up at Tropicana Field for the game against the Tampa Bay Rays, Can was not in the lineup. He was not really disappointed.

title: At State Level, More Attempts to Limit Guns
description: State lawmakers across the country are ramping up efforts to pass new restrictions on guns, following nearly a decade in which state legislative efforts have been dominated by gun advocates.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Monday about the value of the veteran catcher Jason Varitek to the Boston Red Sox described his history with the team incorrectly. He joined the organization in 1997 from the Seattle Mariners minor league system; he is not a home-grown player.

title: Going Getting Rough? Time to Get Some Help
description: TUCSON

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about Invisible Nation: How the Kurds Quest for Statehood Is Shaping Iraq and the Middle East, by Quil Lawrence, misstated the timing of Mr. Lawrences reporting for National Public Radio, The Los Angeles Times and The Christian Science Monitor. He reported for NPR from 1996 to 2000, and for The Los Angeles Times and The Christian Science Monitor from 1996 to 2001. He has not been reporting on Kurdistan for those three organizations for the last seven years. Mr. Lawrence is now the Middle East correspondent for the BBC/PRI radio program The World.

title: Construction Halted Ahead of Games
description: BEIJING  City officials laid out an ambitious series of measures on Monday that will freeze construction projects, slow down steel production and shut down quarries in and around this capital during the summer in an attempt to clear the air for the Olympics. Even spray-painting outdoors will be banned during the weeks before and after sporting events, which begin here on Aug. 8.

title: Weeks Notables
description: CLUB In Mexico, the countrys most popular club, Chivas Guadalajara, extended the winless streak of the richest, Club Amrica, to 10 games with a 3-2 victory on Sunday. Host Chivas built a 3-0 lead at Jalisco Stadium and played with a man advantage for the final 35 minutes after Juan Carlos Silva was red carded. But Amricas Salvador Cabaas scored two late goals in a four-minute span.

title: A Gigantic Job for Window Fixers
description: After a thousand years artisans are still using muscle, sweat and painstaking craftsmanship to preserve exquisitely painted pieces of colored glass that adorn majestic places of worship.

title: The Last Frontier of Flying
description: A few gravel streets wind through Kake, a Southeast Alaska coastal village of 536 people, and connect to miles of logging roads. Twice a week, marine ferries provide service to other rural communities, but the only fast way in or out of Kake is by small plane. The same is true for most Alaska communities.

title: Correction
description: In his column on Friday, Paul Krugman discussed an anecdote told by Hillary Clinton about a woman in Ohio who supposedly lost her newborn child, and then her life, because of bills run up when she did not have health insurance. Mr. Krugman relied on early news accounts of the incident, but later accounts, including one from The Columbus Dispatch, show that those bills did not lead to loss of care. Mr. Krugman has posted a detailed explanation on his blog at krugman.blogs.nytimes.com.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Saturday about Democratic efforts to build voter data banks misstated who can use a data bank managed by the Democratic National Committee. The data bank is being used by the Clinton and Obama campaigns; it is not closed to Democrats in primary races.

title: Hillary Clinton to Appear on Colbert Report
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will make her first appearance on Comedy Centrals The Colbert Report on Thursday, the Associated Press reports. Barack Obama has thus far declined Colberts invitation. Obamas wife, Michelle, will appear on the show Tuesday.

title: Local Station Owners Push Mobile TV
description: Owners of more than 800 local TV stations where ad revenue has plunged recently said theyve formed a group thats testing three standards for sending local digital TV signals to cell phones, laptops and other mobile devices, the Associated Press reports.

description: With Joba Chamberlain unavailable, who pitched the eighth inning for the Yankees on Monday? The same guy who gave up the lead in the seventh  Brian Bruney.

description: If the results of a study by SearchIgnite, a search advertising technology firm, prove representative of the broader search market, something unusual happened in search ads in the first quarter: Google lost share to Yahoo in the United States.

description: China has accumulated a stake of just under 1 percent in BP, raising fresh questions about Beijings strategy for investing its huge foreign currency reserves.

title: First-Quarter Earnings Dropped 79% at Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said Monday that its profit dropped 79 percent in the first quarter, which ended just two weeks before speculation about a liquidity crisis forced its sale to JPMorgan Chase.

title: DigitalGlobe Seeks to Go Public
description: It has been a brutal time for companies hoping to go public, with a record number of initial public offerings being withdrawn in the first quarter of 2008. This makes the proposed stock sale of DigitalGlobe, a provider of satellite earth images whose customers include the United States government and Google, all the more interesting. Late Monday, the Longmont, Colo.-based company filed to sell as much as $250 million in stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Tesla Motors Sues Competitor Over Design Ideas
description: Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley maker of electric sports cars, filed suit in San Mateo Superior Court on Monday against a competing company and two of its employees, saying they stole some of Teslas design ideas and trade secrets.

title: Taking Stock of Blockbusters Circuit City Bid
description: A hostile bid by Blockbuster, the financially ailing video-rental giant, to acquire Circuit City Stores for more than $1 billion in cash left Wall Street befuddled on Monday, as investors questioned the benefits of an unlikely union of two troubled companies.

title: Record Number of Pulled I.P.O.s in 1st Quarter
description: A record number of companies canceled initial public offerings in the first quarter as stock markets fell and concerns about a recession sapped demand for new shares.

title: Goldman Takes Hit on Bavaria Yacht Debt, Report Says
description: Goldman Sachs may have emerged relatively unscathed by the epidemic of write-downs of subprime mortgage loans that has hit its investment banking peers. But it appears the banking powerhouse has been hit instead by the markets reluctance to syndicate private equity debt.

title: Lehman To Spend $1 Billion on Hedge Funds, Report Says
description: Lehman Brothers is planning to invest up to $1 billion in a fund it will use to buy stakes in hedge fund managers, Reuters reported.

title: Bears Chief in Line for Rainmaker Role, Report Says
description: Bear Stearns Chief Executive Alan D. Schwartz, who found himself selling the hobbled investment bank to JPMorgan Chase in his eleventh week on the job, has been invited to stay on as a senior dealmaker, Reuters reported.

title: Britain Woos Chinas Sovereign Wealth Fund
description: The British treasury chief made a pitch Tuesday for the China Investment Corporation, that countrys $200 billion state investment fund, to invest in Britain as he visited Beijing amid strains over Tibet and Chinas trade surplus.

title: Temasek Confirms $600 Million Purchase of Merrill Shares

Roman Catholic officials hope that Pope Benedict XVIs visit to St. Josephs Seminary in Yonkers on Saturday will spur interest in religious vocations.

description: One of the defining features of the last 8 years or so has been the way ideas go from crazy stuff that only DFHs believe to stuff everyone knows, without ever going through a stage in which the holders of conventional wisdom acknowledge that they were wrong. Oh, and the people who were right are still considered DFHs; you see, they were right too soon.

title: Memories of the Nixon-Ford administration
description: This isnt the first time weve had a worldwide surge in food prices. There was a huge price rise in 1972-1974  bigger, in percentage terms, than the current spike. (The chart has a log scale, so that equal vertical distances are equal percentage increases.) Some of the causes look similar: droughts in the Southern Hemisphere (the Peruvian anchovies disappeared, too) and a period of rapid world growth. It even included some similar panic reactions: Nixon banned soybean exports!

title: The Race Between Two Forms of Sunlight
description: There is a race afoot between two energy sources that are, in essence, different forms of concentrated sunlight. Coal, of course, is one, forged from the baked, compressed remains of ancient plant life. And coal has a centuries-long head start over the newcomer, capturing the heat of the sun with arrays of mirrors and turning it into electricity.

description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton issued a statement this morning praising Pope Benedict XVI for his work on world peace, social justice and climate change and welcoming his visit to Washington and New York this week. Senator Clinton, of New York, and her rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, are intensely courting Catholic voters, particularly in advance of the Pennsylvania primary scheduled for a week from today.

title: Pirate Whack-a-Mole on the High Seas

title: Ratzenfreude

In fact, as someone remarked, it was the era in which Ratzinger functioned as something close to a swear word,  the punching bag for frustrated progressive church professionals everywhere.

title: I was born in a big town
description: OK, actually I was born in Albany, and grew up on Long Island. But heres my question: I understand why its political poison to show disrespect for small-town values  dignity is precious to all of us, and often trumps material interest. title: The Morning Skate: The Golden Brett, Mad Mike and Fabian
description: Brett Hulls fans have yet to update their MySpace page, where hes still listed as Special Advisor to Hockey Operations and Ambassador of Fun. The Stars co-GM is probably having a lot of fun with his team up two games over the defending champion Ducks, but he strongly implied in todays LA Times that his colleague Les Jackson is the brains of the operation while Hull is the public face and also provides some needed humor in the dressing room to help loosen up his team. He admits to applying more wisdom to his public statements now as a GM than he did as a player or in his brief career as a TV personality. I will never, ever do TV again, he says. I did not enjoy it at all, felt like I was penned up. Which means if hes ever out as Stars GM, expect to see him pop up somewhere as a TV personality.

title: McCains Economic Spot
description: Updated Ah, the liberation of no longer having to appeal to ones base. That has always been an onerous task for Senator John McCain. But now he is in general election mode, where hes hoping his maverick reputation will be a boon rather than a liability. The opening line of his new spot could be nails-on-a-chalkboard to conservatives ears, but it might play better in the swing states of Ohio and Pennsylvania, where the spot is running: As President, John McCain will take the best ideas from both parties to spur innovation, invest in people and create jobs.

Dickens, a Democrat who represents central Harlem on the City Council.

title: Laura Bush to Guest Host on Today

She will be joined earlier in the broadcast by her daughter Jenna to talk about their new childrens book, Read All About It!'

title: Pennsylvania Stagnation: Is Nafta the Culprit?
description: The Democratic presidential primary in Pennsylvania has drawn attention to troubles in the states manufacturing sector and to the role played by the North American Free Trade Agreement specifically and by global trade generally. Despite isolated success stories, Pennsylvania manufacturing has experienced job loss and stagnation for over a decade. Not everything that has gone wrong with the Pennsylvania economy is due to trade, but the worries of workers in the state (and throughout the country) about what globalization means for their living standards are well-founded.  Nafta became the framework for the global economy when it took effect in 1994. It was followed by the World Trade Organization in 1995 and by numerous similar agreements. While these deals were not responsible for globalization, they certainly encouraged the rapidly growing trade and investment that has occurred in the past decade.   There is no doubt that American manufacturing has been hard hit by globalization. Between 1967 and 2000, manufacturing employment went up or down with the business cycle, but never dipped below 16.5 million workers. Since 2001, the U.S. has lost 3.4 million manufacturing jobs and employment dipped below 14 million.   Pennsylvania manufacturing has been even harder hit, with 208,000 jobs lost  a 24 percent decline  in the same period. Overall employment growth in the state continues to lag that of the rest of the country; jobs in the nation as a whole have grown three times as fast as jobs in Pennsylvania. Furthermore, real median wages in Pennsylvania fell 2 percent between 2001 and 2007.   Some have mistakenly blamed productivity growth or slow demand for manufactured goods for manufacturing job losses in Pennsylvania and nationally, arguing that the sectors decline is inevitable. This is wrong. Manufacturing has always enjoyed fast productivity growth, and demand for its goods remains strong. What has changed in the past decade is that a much larger share of goods purchased by U.S. consumers are now imported, and jobs displaced by these imports have not been replaced by export-supported jobs.  In the decade after Nafta, growing trade deficits with Mexico and Canada eliminated 44,000 jobs in Pennsylvania and more than a million nationwide. In this decade, China has overtaken Nafta as the source of our largest trade deficit. From 2001, when it entered the W.T.O., to 2006, the growth of the American trade deficit with China eliminated an additional 78,000 Pennsylvania jobs alone. In both cases, about two-thirds of the losses were in manufacturing.   Some have argued that job growth and unemployment are affected by factors other than trade, and that workers laid off from manufacturing plants are more likely than not to find new jobs. True enough, but when a steelworker loses his job in a mill and ends up as a greeter at Wal-Mart, would anybody honestly say that he has not "lost a job"?  These displaced workers are only the most visible casualties of trade. Job displacement and competition for manufacturing jobs with workers in low-wage countries like Mexico and China depress the wages of not just industrial workers, but of all workers throughout the economy with similar skills and credentials. Landscapers may not know that their wages are being hurt by trade, but when laid-off steelworkers crowd into their labor force, they are.   Josh Bivens, my colleague at the Economic Policy Institute, recently wrote that in 2006, trade with low-wage countries pulled down wages of workers without a college degree by roughly 4 percent. For a married couple with no college degrees and with kids, earning the median wage, this means that trade flows have cost this household more than $2,000. This is, by the way, the net effect of trade: it takes into account the presumed savings the family members enjoy in the form of cheap foreign goods, like that T-shirt at Wal-Mart, and the presumed ability to secure work in exporting industries.  It doesnt have to be this way. For starters, we can take a number of steps to reduce the U.S. trade deficit, like forcing China to end its unfair trade practices and insisting on improvements in labor rights in Mexico and other countries. Reducing the American trade deficit can help expand U.S. exports, which have been the most rapidly growing sector of the economy for the past year, thus helping Pennsylvanias manufacturing workers.   The conversation about trade is too important to be relegated to election season polemics. An intelligent discussion will begin when the conventional wisdom catches up to the reality faced by workers in Pennsylvania and the rest of the country.   Robert E. Scott is a senior international economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington.

title: Virginia Tech: After the Shootings
description: When the shooting stopped at Virginia Tech on April 16, 2007, the air was full of questions. On the simplest level, for almost 24 hours the nation did not know the identity of the gunman who killed 32 students and himself, Seung-Hui Cho. On perhaps the most profound level, the question of why this troubled and angry youth chose to plan and carry out the killings may never be fully answered. But there were a host of other issues that had relevance for other universities and for policymakers in general. They include:* whether Mr. Chos history of mental illness should have barred him from purchasing the guns he used, and whether the system needed to be tightened* whether campuses would be safer if more students and faculty members could have guns to use to protect themselves* whether concerns over privacy stood in the way of adequate steps being taken to protect Mr. Chos classmates and himself* and what if any changes needed to be made to emergency response procedures at schools across the country.A group of people with expertise on different aspects of these questions has agreed to discuss these issues. To begin, each will address what has happened  and what hasnt  in the field they know best in the last year.
