title: Boston Allowing Ads at Start and Finish
description: Boston Marathon officials announced that for the first time in the races 112-year history, corporate advertisements would appear at the start and finish lines. The Boston Athletic Association, which organizes the race, also said that prize money for this years race would be $796,000, up from $575,000 last year.

title: Mr. Berlusconis Comeback
description: The master showman of Italian politics, Silvio Berlusconi, is back for a third term as prime minister. His victory owes little to his past, shockingly meager achievements in office. At a time when Italy is enveloped in economic and political gloom, he won with promises of a painless path to renewed prosperity.

title: Reassuring Results From JPMorgan Help Drive Market
description: JPMorgan Chase, fresh from scooping up a rival investment bank, Bear Stearns, saw earnings drop 50 percent in the first quarter as it was hurt badly by market turmoil and heavy credit losses.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Link by Link column on Monday, about collecting publicly available data and using computers to turn the information into a book, misstated the title of Philip M. Parker, who has used the process to generate more than 200,000 books. He is the chaired professor of management science at Insead, a business school based near Paris  not the schools Eli Lilly professor in innovation, business and society.

title: Sued by Harry Potters Creator, Lexicographer Breaks Down on the Stand
description: Shhh! The librarian at the heart of the Harry Potter copyright-infringement lawsuit stood up to J. K. Rowling on Tuesday in a Manhattan courtroom, and then broke down sobbing.

title: Mexico Drug War Causes Wild West Blood Bath
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  One sign of the desperation to end organized crime in this border town is that the good guy on the police recruitment posters is not a clean-cut youth in a smart police cap, but a menacing soldier in a black mask and helmet carrying a heavy machine gun.

title: Yankees to Face the Red Sox Without Chamberlain
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Yankees return home to play the Boston Red Sox on Wednesday and Thursday, but Joba Chamberlain will not be with them. He is eligible to come off the bereavement list Thursday, but Manager Joe Girardi said Chamberlain would miss the series as he tends to his father, Harlan.

title: On Again, Off Again, On Again Auction Is Not to Be ... Yet
description: It was a historic jewelry auction that was not to be. Or was. Or was not. Or may be.

title: Pettitte Finds a Way; Rays Cant Find the Plate
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  It was only an interlude, this two-day trip for the Yankees to play the Tampa Bay Rays. Every game counts the same, of course, but the ones that bookend this series can be much more revealing.

title: Governors Tax Return Gets Tough Public Audit
description: Alitha Martinez, a comic book artist who lives in Manhattan, gave several hundred dollars worth of clothing that her 6-year-old son had outgrown to neighborhood charities last year. She also took a $1,000 tax deduction for donating an old Macintosh computer. And she occasionally sells her artwork and gives the proceeds to the Hero Fund, which provides scholarships to children of military personnel.

title: Intel Reports Strong Demand for Chips in Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel to investors: What slowdown?

title: Teachers at Catholic Schools Strike Ahead of Popes Visit
description: About 350 teachers at Roman Catholic schools from New York City and its northern suburbs went on strike on Tuesday, choosing the day of Pope Benedict XVIs arrival on American soil to send a sharp message to the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Media Equation column on Monday, about the Web site The Smoking Gun, which broke the story that The Los Angeles Times relied on fraudulent documents for an article on a 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur, misstated the nature of the assault. Mr. Shakur was shot five times; he was not murdered. (He died in September 1996 of multiple gunshot wounds suffered in a drive-by shooting.)

title: The Lord Wants Us Here, Texas Pilgrims Say of Their Trip
description: WASHINGTON  The Lord provides, Ricardo Pequeo kept reminding himself.

title: Immelman Enjoys Perks of Winning Green Jacket
description: Trevor Immelman is enjoying his week of firsts as the Masters champion  first major championship victory, first visit to New York City and first meet-and-greet with an N.B.A. team.

title: Protest by Zimbabwes Opposition Falters as the Army Makes a Show of Force
description: JOHANNESBURG  The call by Zimbabwes political opposition for people nationwide to stay away from work on Tuesday to protest a 17-day delay in releasing the results of the presidential election largely failed to interrupt the normal flow of life in the cities.

title: Rare Encouraging Note for Mets
description: Progress is measured incrementally around Shea Stadium these days  a players return, perhaps sooner than expected, from injury; a dropoff in the fans bubbling resentment at their beloved Mets slow start; even a simple victory.

title: At Indian Preserves, Tigers Remain King as People Are Coaxed Out
description: NAGARHOLE NATIONAL PARK, India  At sundown, as the air began to cool and the beasts came out of the shade, K. Ullas Karanth drove slowly through this sprawling park in southern India. Elephants nibbled on the grass. A sunbird dashed across the sky. Then, Mr. Karanth nearly froze in a start. Tiger, tiger, he whispered.

title: Films Revisit Overlooked Shootings on a Black Campus
description: Two years before the deadly Kent State shootings, state troopers opened fire on a student protest on the campus of South Carolina State College. Three people died, and 28 were wounded.

title: Clinton for Governor? Democrats Dismiss Rumblings
description: ALBANY  It would mean more trips to Rome, N.Y., than Rome, Italy, more dinners with state legislators than dinners with heads of state.

title: Maybe Money Does Buy Happiness After All
description: In the aftermath of World War II, the Japanese economy went through one of the greatest booms the world has ever known. From 1950 to 1970, the economys output per person grew more than sevenfold. Japan, in just a few decades, remade itself from a war-torn country into one of the richest nations on earth.

title: Litigation Assured in Wake of Decision
description: Executions in Texas, Alabama and other Southern states with high death-penalty rates are likely to resume shortly in the wake of the Supreme Courts decision Wednesday upholding Kentuckys method of putting condemned inmates to death.

title: Flight Chaos Shows Passengers Have Few Rights
description: American Airlines cancels more than 3,000 flights because of maintenance issues. Too bad. Skybus Airlines goes bankrupt and shuts down. Find another way to get to Ohio. Youre trapped on a tarmac for 10 hours  sit tight.

title: Bread of Freedom in Times of Despair
description: AT a restaurant in the theater district, I sat down to dinner with George Perecman and his sister Frances Greenberg, both concentration camp survivors. When I told them that I was interested in food during the Holocaust, they reacted with disgust.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about a decision by Basil Paterson  a powerful union lawyer and the father of David A. Paterson, New Yorks governor  to seek the advice of a state ethics commission on avoiding potential conflicts of interest referred incorrectly to a bill that was supported by the president of the New York City teachers union. The bill would prohibit  not allow  the linking of decisions on teacher tenure to student test scores, and it was passed by the Legislature, not killed.

title: Frozen Pineapple-Coconut Truffles
description: Adapted from Susie Fishbein

title: Guild Chief for Actors Is No Pacifist
description: To understand why Hollywood is taking the threat of a strike by the Screen Actors Guild seriously, look no further than Alan Rosenbergs actions during a solidarity march last November with striking screenwriters.

title: Broadway to Begin Labor Talks
description: Yes, this again. But no, you probably dont have to worry about it.

title: All Rise! A Centenarian Will Analyze the Supreme Court
description: Ruth Proskauer Smith has a crosstown bus to catch, on the corner of 72nd Street and Central Park West. She is 100 years old, she got her first lesson in public speaking from Gov. Alfred E. Smith in 1928, and she now teaches a class on Tuesdays about the United States Supreme Court.

title: Mets Happy That Reyes and His Energy Are Back
description: The Mets were hopeful, though hardly certain, that the extent of Jos Reyess left hamstring strain was exactly as they described  mild  and that he would miss only a few games. Reyes rejoined the lineup for Tuesday nights game against the Washington Nationals after a two-game absence, although he did so feeling a bit hesitant.

title: God and Man at Notre Dame
description: POPE BENEDICT XVI will give several speeches during his visit to the United States, but the most consequential for American Catholics may be his address to the presidents of Catholic colleges and universities tomorrow.

title: Putting Scandals in Past, Officials See Gains on Doping
description: CHICAGO  Though doping scandals continue to plague Olympic sports like track and field  one of its biggest stars is in prison and one of its most successful coaches goes on trial next month  United States Olympic Committee officials said Tuesday that they were confident that American athletes at the Beijing Games would be drug-free.

title: New Ballpark in Washington Anchors an Areas Revival
description: WASHINGTON  Baseball fans flocking to Nationals Park, the brand-new stadium here, see more than a game these days. Approaching along Half Street Southeast from the nearby Metro subway station, they pass construction sites and billboards that tell of a neighborhood being transformed. From inside the stadium, they can see both the Capitol dome and construction cranes jutting into the sky.

title: Hangtown Fry (Eggs With Bacon and Oysters)
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Whos No. 1? It Depends.
description: A 90-minute Dancing With the Stars may have afforded ABC the most viewers over all on Monday, but in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49 CBS eked out a slight victory thanks to its comedy lineup. Nielsen reported that Dancing With the Stars averaged 17 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., easily the nights largest audience, but down considerably from the 19.7 million the show drew a week ago. Meanwhile, CBSs 9 p.m. comedy Two and a Half Men (13.8 million) delivered the nights top ratings in the 18-to-49 set. CBS remained in the lead in that demographic at 9:30 with Rules of Engagement (10.3 million), which significantly outperformed ABCs sitcom Samantha Who? among adults 18 to 49 despite the ABC shows competitive showing in total viewers (10 million). At 10, ABCs Bachelor earned a third-place finish (7 million) behind CBSs CSI: Miami (10.5 million) and NBCs Medium (9.6 million), which led the hour in the 18-to-49 set. NBC finished third for the night, attracting 9.6 million viewers earlier for a two-hour edition of Deal or No Deal. Fox was fourth, drawing 6.8 million viewers for the finale of New Amsterdam at 9 p.m.

title: Family Recipes, Passed Down From One Site to Another
description: WASHINGTON  It was a recipe for scandal.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about possible disruptions to air passengers because of a federal directive on aircraft inspections misstated part of the name the law firm of L. Nick Lacey, a former director of flight standards at the Federal Aviation Administration. His firm is Morten, Beyer & Agnew  not Morton, Beyer & Agnew.

title: Conflict Between 2 Unions Intensifies
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, John J. Sweeney, denounced on Tuesday what he said was a violent attack orchestrated by the Service Employees International Union against members of other unions at a conference on Saturday in Michigan.

title: McCain Outlines Broad Proposals for U.S. Economy
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  Senator John McCain offered the broadest look yet at his economic policies in a speech on Tuesday in Pittsburgh, outlining a series of tax reductions and backing away from his pledge to balance the budget by the end of his first term.

title: Shimmer and Awe, of the Acrobatic Variety
description: The crowd at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College on Sunday afternoon was restless  a sure sign of too much candy, the excitement of newly purchased Chinese toys and the general state of being younger than 10. When the lights finally dimmed, there was a booming shriek of joy. One boy simply raised his fist in the air: victory at last.

title: Fight Leaves Democrats Questioning Prospects
description: The battle between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama over whether Mr. Obama belittled voters in small towns appears to have hardened the views of both candidates supporters and stirred anxiety among many Democrats about the partys prospects in the fall.

title: A New Humility, at Least for Ducasse
description: ALAIN DUCASSE may never live down the grandiose way he first swept into town, granting blinkered New Yorkers a vision of French elegance few of them had ever experienced, expected or, for that matter, asked for.

title: Spicy Ginger Muffins With Currants and Toasted Pecans
description: Time: One hour

title: Police Dept. Settles Suit by Protesters Over Tactics
description: To settle a lawsuit, the New York Police Department has agreed to formalize changes it had made in its crowd-control procedures during political demonstrations, the authorities said on Tuesday.

title: For the Record
description: A letter from Hartford on Friday about a Connecticut connection to South Pacific misspelled the surname of the musicals composer. He was Richard Rodgers, not Rogers.

title: Off the Menu
description: Closing

title: Wine Calendar
description: To Galicia, for Tapas

title: In Defense of S.U.V.s
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey: 53 Mayors Are Fined for Backing Kurdish TV
description: A court fined 53 mayors from Turkeys largely Kurdish southeast on charges of helping rebels with their written request to the Danish prime minister, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, not to shut down the Danish-based Kurdish satellite broadcaster ROJ TV, Turkeys official Anatolian News Agency reported. Turkish authorities say the station has links with a Kurdish militant organization, the Kurdistan Workers Party. The court first sentenced the mayors to two and a half months in prison but immediately reduced the sentences to fines.

title: Pope Begins U.S. Visit; Says He Is Ashamed of Sex Scandal
description: Pope Benedict XVI landed at Andrews Air Force Base on Tuesday afternoon, beginning a six-day visit after a flight in which he told reporters aboard his aircraft that he was deeply ashamed of the Roman Catholic Churchs child sexual-abuse scandal in the United States.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Front Page

title: A Bite of Chocolate, a Salute to Greece
description: Joan Coukos, the chocolatier who owns Chocolat Moderne in Chelsea, offers themed assortments, among them a tribute to her own Greek heritage. There are six varieties, all made with Greek ingredients, robed in chocolate and decorated with Greek motifs.

title: The Limits of the Death Penalty
description: In recent decades, the Supreme Court has looked for ways to limit the death penalty, but it hears arguments today in a case that could reverse that trend  and extend capital punishment to additional crimes. The court should stand by its past rulings that murder is the only crime committed by one person against another that can be punished by death.

title: Whats for Dinner? The Pollster Wants to Know
description: IF theres butter and white wine in your refrigerator and Fig Newtons in the cookie jar, youre likely to vote for Hillary Clinton. Prefer olive oil, Bear Naked granola and a latte to go? You probably like Barack Obama, too.

title: New Mash-Up: Melody and Architecture
description: In her Cutting Edge Concerts the composer Victoria Bond seeks common ground for music and the other arts. In this years three-concert series at the Thalia Theater at Symphony Space, the other art is architecture, and in each concert a guest architect and several composers explain what they do. Ms. Bonds guest for the second installment, on Monday evening, was James Polshek, the architect for many new and reconfigured concert settings, including Carnegie Hall, the Santa Fe Opera Theater, Seiji Ozawa Hall at Tanglewood and Symphony Space itself.

title: 38 Years After Artists Suicide, His Remains Are on the Move
description: A state judge has allowed the daughter and son of the artist Mark Rothko to have his body disinterred from a Long Island cemetery and reburied in a Jewish cemetery in Westchester County over the objections of some Long Island residents.

title: Summering in Connecticut, Wintering in Rio
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil

title: Letters
description: Eating Well at Bates College

title: Too Much Heat in the TV Kitchen?
description: FOR many chefs, a simple bon apptit no longer says it all.

title: Dont Give Up on the Games, or Olympic Ideals
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Chief, but eBays Struggles Continue
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As John Donahoe takes over as chief executive of eBay, the company is still struggling to improve its business.

title: Chief of Police for Tehran Was Arrested, Iran Confirms
description: TEHRAN  Tehrans police chief, who was responsible for a crackdown on immodestly dressed women for the past year, has been arrested, a spokesman for the judiciary confirmed Tuesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the growing use of residential wind turbines to produce electricity misstated the name of the New York State agency whose president, Paul Tonko, commented on renewable energy incentives for the turbines. It is the Energy Research and Development Authority, not the Renewable Energy Development Authority.

title: Eggheads and Cheese Balls
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Pairings: Chicken With Bitter Herb Pesto
description: The goal was compatibility with Israeli white and red wines and also with a Passover Seder menu. It was a simple one, achieved with dark meat chicken, which goes with either choice and can stand up to slow cooking.

title: A Refugee Wrestles With Her Memories
description: On the anniversary of the massacre of her family in Rwanda, Juliette, a young woman who has found refuge in London, lights candles to their memories and recalls the qualities that made each of them unique: one candle for her gentle father, another for her cynical mother, on through many siblings, down to her adored 3-year-old sister. As played by the gifted Susan Heyward, the scene is unbearably sad and eloquent, yet so modestly presented and genuine that it never strains to reach the audiences tear ducts. Juliettes distinct voice is the essence of I Have Before Me a Remarkable Document Given to Me by a Young Lady From Rwanda, and Ms. Heywards vibrant performance is the best reason to see it.

title: To Rangers, Antics Are Just Avery Being Avery
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers forward Sean Avery remained the center of a swirl of attention Tuesday without saying a word.

title: Boyfriend Arrested in Bronx Murder
description: The boyfriend of an 18-year-old Massachusetts woman shot and killed over the weekend on the side of a Bronx road was charged Tuesday morning in connection with her murder, accused of hiring his cousin to kill the woman in a staged robbery of the couple, the police said.

title: Back in Office, Berlusconi Enthusiastically Seizes Reins
description: ROME  A day after his surprisingly robust victory in the Italian elections, Silvio Berlusconi immediately set out to govern with the theatrical flair that was a trademark of his two previous stints as prime minister.

title: N.Y.U. Medical Center Gets Another $100 Million Gift
description: Kenneth G. Langone, a billionaire financier and a founder of Home Depot, is giving another $100 million donation to New York University Medical Center, matching the one that he made anonymously in 1999.

title: For Microsoft, Holding Yahoo Talent May Be Costly
description: Microsofts pursuit of Yahoo, if successful, will come with more than one bill due.

title: Relief Possible for Tenants Caught in Landlords Default
description: Relief may be in sight for thousands of apartment dwellers in Texas who have been living in deteriorating conditions for months since their landlord, the MBS Companies of Metairie, La., defaulted on hundreds of millions of dollars worth of mortgages. It was the first major delinquency involving loans that were pooled and sold to investors as securities backed by commercial mortgages.

title: Larger Prey Are Targets of Phishing
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An e-mail scam aimed squarely at the nations top executives is raising new alarms about the ease with which people and companies can be deceived by online criminals.

title: Merck Wrote Drug Studies for Doctors
description: The drug maker Merck drafted dozens of research studies for a best-selling drug, then lined up prestigious doctors to put their names on the reports before publication, according to an article to be published Wednesday in a leading medical journal.

title: You Dont Have to Be Jewish to Love Them
description: PASSOVER is right around the corner and as surely as Thanksgiving leads to turkey talk, the approach of this Jewish holiday calls attention to kosher wines.

title: Canseco to Meet With Federal Agents
description: Jos Canseco is scheduled to be questioned by federal authorities in Los Angeles on April 22, his lawyer said Tuesday.

title: Footnotes
description: Andr Watts will replace Martha Argerich as the soloist in five performances of Beethovens Piano Concerto No. 1 with the New York Philharmonic, led by Charles Dutoit. The orchestra announced that Ms. Argerich had been advised by her doctor to rest after an illness. The concerts, at 7:30 p.m. April 23 and 24, 8 p.m. on April 25 and 26, and 7:30 p.m. on April 29, include Mozarts Overture to The Marriage of Figaro, Rachmaninoffs Symphonic dances and Ravels Valse. ... Since 1991, when the Shakespeare Theater Company of Washington first presented free Shakespeare shows with a production of The Merry Wives of Windsor, more than 560,000 people have attended these performances. This year, 30,000 people are expected, the company said, when it presents Hamlet at Carter Barron Amphitheater in Rock Creek Park from May 22 to June 1. ... Michael McKean, a star of the Broadway revival of The Homecoming, has a date to star for the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago in Superior Donuts, a new play from Tracy Letts, who won a Pulitzer Prize this year for August: Osage County, Variety reported. Mr. McKean will play the owner of a Chicago doughnut shop whose sole employee, a black teenager portrayed by Jon Hill, wants to improve the place.

title: Panels Bipartisan View: F.D.A. Is Underfinanced
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration needs far more money than the White House has proposed for next year, senators of both parties said Tuesday.

title: Dozens Killed in Bombings in Four Iraqi Cities
description: BAGHDAD  Bombers struck four cities across Iraq on Tuesday, killing at least 54 people and providing a stark reminder that American and Iraqi forces are still fighting a war on two fronts.

title: Abuse Victims Not Placated by Pope
description: WASHINGTON  Far from tamping down emotions, Pope Benedict XVIs expression of remorse on Tuesday for the churchs sexual abuse scandal prompted an angry and skeptical response from victims, who said they wanted actions, not words from the Vatican.

title: Separated From Children, Sect Mothers Share Tears
description: Mothers separated from their children after the police raid on a polygamist compound in West Texas have spoken out for the first time, denouncing the authorities in tear-filled accounts.

title: Topics in University Security: Lockdown 101
description: Boston

title: Tackling 40, Smiling for the Cameras
description: Forty might be the new 30. But while social attitudes about chalking up 480 months and 350,400 hours have changed, it is still a big deal, big enough for its own television show. The Big 4-0, a new reality series that begins on Wednesday night on TV Land, documents people turning 40 in the age of Botox, Viagra, fat-sucking surgery and life coaches.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a lawsuit over judicial pay filed against New York State by Judith S. Kaye, the states chief judge, misidentified the party represented by Kenneth Feinberg in a similar lawsuit filed in 1991 by Sol Wachtler, the chief judge at the time. Mr. Feinberg was the lawyer for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, not Judge Wachtler.

title: White-Collar Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Salute to Jazz Guitarists
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center will celebrate the induction of the pioneering jazz guitarists Django Reinhardt, above left, and Charlie Christian, right, into the Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame with concerts at 8 p.m. May 2 and 3 at Rose Theater in Frederick P. Rose Hall. Music by Reinhardt and Christian will be performed by Bobby Broom, Birli Lagrne, Russell Malone and Frank Vignola, backed by a rhythm section featuring the drummer and music director Lewis Nash, Peter Washington on bass and Mulgrew Miller on piano.

title: Reshaping the Knicks Will Be a Major Test
description: The final hours of the Knicks season will be meaningless and momentous, awkward and poetic, depressing and hopeful. When the contradictions are cleared away, the real challenge will begin.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about the small-business opposition to some federal tax proposals referred incorrectly to people to whom the businesses must now supply 1099 forms, which are used to report payments over $600. The forms are provided to independent contractors, not employees. (Employees receive W-2 forms.)

title: Bush to Give Goals for Greenhouse Gases
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush will deliver a Rose Garden speech on Wednesday to lay out specific goals for limiting the greenhouse gases that scientists say are responsible for warming the planet  a first for a White House that has been accused of dragging its feet in addressing the problem of climate change.

title: Goodman Theater Adds to ONeill Festival
description: The Goodman Theater of Chicago will bring in troupes from the Netherlands and Brazil as it turns a 21st-century lens on Eugene ONeill. The Goodman said on Tuesday that the Toneelgroep Amsterdam and the Companhia Triptal of Brazil would join the Wooster Group as invitees to its ONeill Festival, from January through March. The visiting companies were chosen for their contemporary, inventive interpretations, the Goodman said. Their productions will be mounted around the festivals previously announced centerpiece, Desire Under the Elms, starring Brian Dennehy and staged by Robert Falls, artistic director of the Goodman. Toneelgroep Amsterdam will present its mixed-media production of Mourning Becomes Electra; Companhia Triptal will present three of ONeills sea plays; and the Wooster Group will present The Emperor Jones.

title: Female Writers on Shortlist Prize
description: An American, three Britons and two Canadians made the shortlist on Tuesday for the Orange Broadband Prize for Fiction, an annual award for works by women published in Britain in the past year, Agence France-Presse reported. The American,  Patricia Wood, was chosen for her debut novel, Lottery, about an orphaned 31-year-old man with an I.Q. of 76 who wins the Washington State Lottery. The Britons are Sadie Jones, for The Outcast; Rose Tremain, for The Road Home; and Charlotte Mendelson, for When We Were Bad. The Canadians are Heather ONeill, for Lullabies for Little Criminals, and Nancy Huston, for Fault Lines. The winner of the prize, worth $59,000, will be announced in London on June 4.

title: In Fatal Robbery, Police See Contract Killing
description: Chelsea M. Frazier lay bleeding in her new Toyota, fatally shot after turning down a quiet street near the Bronx waterfront. Her 14-month-old son, Alijah, who had made the trip from Massachusetts with his parents on Sunday afternoon, was still strapped in the back seat, unhurt.

title: Patrick J. Hillery, Who Helped Point Ireland to Peace, Dies at 84
description: Patrick J. Hillery, a physician-turned-politician who served 14 years as Irelands president after a long ministerial career that won him admiration for his handling of the volatile issue of British rule in Northern Ireland, died Saturday in Dublin. He was 84.

title: Main Gate to Citi Field a Tribute to Robinson
description: About a decade ago, Sharon Robinson set down the nine values that defined her father, Jackie, and, by extension, guided her family: citizenship, commitment, courage, determination, excellence, integrity, justice, persistence and teamwork.

title: Chicken With Bitter Herb Pesto
description: Time: 2 hours 15 minutes

title: A Creator of Captain America, Fighting On
description: Living legend is how Joe Simon is categorized on the list of special guests appearing at the New York Comic Con at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center this weekend. Mr. Simon, 94, has a different take on it. I call it the old-geezer table, he said during a recent interview at his Midtown Manhattan apartment.

title: Bewitching
description: To the Editor:

title: The Everyday Oyster Any Time of Day
description: UNTIL recently, if you asked me for my favorite ways to eat oysters, I would have said, raw, raw and fried. (Sometimes theyre good in a stew, but usually they get lost there.)

title: Summerstage Fills Its Lineup
description: The New York buzz band Vampire Weekend and the author Richard Price will be part of Central Park SummerStage this year. In addition to concerts by Mavis Staples, Sharon Jones and others already disclosed, the City Parks Foundation has announced the remainder of its 32 free performances: Vampire Weekend with Kid Sister (June 14); the French-Israeli singer Yael Naim (June 22); Vieux Farka Tour and Fallou Dieng (June 28); Rachid Taha and Dengue Fever (July 5); dance with Rennie Harris/Puremovement (July 11); the novelist Junot Daz (July 17); Santogold with Diplo (July 20); Skatalites with Taj Mahal (July 27); Mr. Price (July 31); Roy Hargrove (Aug. 2); Los Lonely Boys with Los Lobos (Aug. 14); Battles and Black Dice (Aug. 16); and Ms. Jones (Aug. 17). Among the six paid benefit shows are Mark Knopfler (July 23); Crosby, Stills and Nash (July 29); and Sonny Rollins (Aug. 6). Information: summerstage.org.

title: Dollar Slips More Against the Euro
description: PARIS  The euro rose to a new record high against the dollar Wednesday, amid new signs of surging global inflation.

title: Reynolds and ESPN Settle Lawsuit
description: Harold Reynolds, the ESPN baseball analyst who was fired in 2006 amid accusations of sexual misconduct, has settled his $5 million wrongful termination lawsuit against the network. Details of the agreement, which was reached last week, were not released.

title: Now Playing in India: A Rare View of Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI  Of all the flattering headlines that greeted the release this month of the first Pakistani film shown in India in four decades, one stuck in the mind of its director, Shoaib Mansoor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about food shortages and rising food prices described incorrectly a comment by Robert B. Zoellick, president of the World Bank, about the World Food Programs efforts to raise $500 million in food aid for poor countries by May 1. He said that nearly half the money had been raised, not enough to meet the goal. He did not say that the program would not meet its May 1 deadline.

title: French Bill Takes Chic Out of Being Too Thin
description: PARIS  In the capital of high fashion and ultrathin models, conservative French legislators adopted a pioneering law on Tuesday aimed at stifling a proliferation of Web sites that promote eating disorders with thinspiration and starvation tips.

title: A Russian Poet Unpeels Her Many Lives
description: Anyone who knows Rebecca Schull as Fay, the den mother on the old sitcom Wings, will recognize her bobbed white hair and fluty voice. Yet she takes on a hugely different and admirable challenge as writer and star of On Naked Soil: Imagining Anna Akhmatova, a biographical play about that great Russian poet, whose work mined her many complicated love affairs and personal ordeals. A literary heroine in the early 1920s, Akhmatova was banned from publishing during the Stalin years, when her lover and son were imprisoned, only to be rediscovered after World War II and lionized in the 60s.

title: Exploring Fantasy Life and Finding a $4 Billion Franchise
description: In the winter of 1860 Milton Bradley, a lithographer in Springfield, Mass., released a new game he had developed called the Checkered Game of Life. Its players began on a checkerboard square called Infancy and tried to make their way through various trials to the destination of Happy Old Age.

title: Wall Street Winners Get Billion-Dollar Paydays
description: Hedge fund managers, those masters of a secretive, sometimes volatile financial universe, are making money on a scale that once seemed unimaginable, even in Wall Streets rarefied realms.

title: Crusty on the Outside
description: GOOD arepas make anything better  even the glum landscape outside Shachis, a new Latin American spot pinned amid the ramp that links the Williamsburg Bridge to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, a bus depot and the rusty towers for the tracks that the J, M and Z trains rattle and ride into Brooklyn.

title: Iraqi Unit Flees Post, Despite Americans Plea

title: Virginia Tech Marks a Year After the Massacre
description: By this time exactly one year ago, two students lay dead of gunshot wounds at Virginia Tech, an event that would by itself have been the latest addition to a sad storyline of campus shootings. But 30 more students and faculty members would die there at the gunmans hand that day, leaving Virginia Tech to recover from the most violent blow that an American university had ever suffered.

title: Va. Tech Marks Year Since Massacre
description: (Photo: A memorial wreath was placed on a candle guarded by the Virginia Tech Corp of Cadets on the campus of Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Va. (Photo: Rob Carr/Associated Press))    By this time exactly one year ago, two students lay dead of gunshot wounds at Virginia Tech, an event that would by itself have been the latest addition to a sad storyline of campus shootings. But 30 more students and faculty members would die there at the gunman's hand that day, leaving Virginia Tech to recover from the most violent blow that an American university had ever suffered.  How would the campus respond? How would students and staff move on? Today, on the anniversary of the massacre, voices at the university seem to agree: As the nation checks in on Virginia Tech, the campus is continuing to look inward, resolutely insisting on mourning at its own pace.   Since midnight, the school's Corps of Cadets has stood continuous guard in 15-minute shifts before a candle lit in the victims' memory. Hour by hour, a Roanoke Times blogger has recorded moments both moving and mundane at the scene.   There were tears and praying, but also joggers "decked out in Spandex and wind gear" speeding past the memorial site, and cadets breaking the solemn tribute for "friendly chatter." They are, after all, just kids.   It seemed to be a fitting illustration of the struggle to "move this institution forward," as Charles W. Steger, the university president, put it in one interview. At 10:30 a.m. Eastern, he will lead a commemoration by reading the names of the 32 victims and offer "a few words about the special qualities" about each of them. (The event will be held "rain or shine," a notice said, but the forecast calls for clear skies, calm winds and temperatures in the 60s. More on the ceremony from The Associated Press.)  (Photo: Emergency responders carried victims from Norris Hall on the Blacksburg, Va., campus on April 16, 2007. (Photo: Alan Kim, The Roanoke Times via Associated Press))   There will be many other events in Blacksburg, Va., today to mark the anniversary as well. And it's also being marked on the Web, where news of the tragedy unfolded for the students as well as the rest of the nation. A 9-minute video clip posted on Planet Blacksburg is intensely upbeat. Several members of the community shared more shaded thoughts in interviews published today in Collegiate Times, a campus paper.  "We didn't try to pretend it didn't happen," Nikki Giovanni, the renowned poet and professor at Virginia Tech, told Collegiate Times. "And we didn't try to pretend that we didn't get hurt, because we were, and we are."  Anthony Della Calce, a former student, wrote in a Blacksburg Planet column published today that Ms. Giovanni's speech at a convocation on the night after the shooting had a lot to do with starting the healing:  Her words triggered a mournful crowd to erupt into a resilient chant of Lets Go Hokies. And a phrase repeated over and over in her poem, We Are Virginia Tech, has become a rallying cry for Hokies everywhere.  More than the hurt is shared among Hokies, he added -- there is also pride for those who sacrificed their lives, like Liviu Librescu, the professor who died blocking a classroom door to the gunman.   "The dynamic of the story of that day is not fully understood through grief and tears," Mr. Della Calce wrote. "Through the cloak of tragedy, inspirational moments emerged."  Related  Day of the Massacre: The Lede's coverage of the unfolding tragedy on April 16, 2007. Browsers may be slow to load the page's 2,292 comments.  Policy Debate: The Times is asking panelists to weigh in on a host of issues, from campus safety to treatment of the mentally ill.  Photos From Today: A slide show from Blacksburg, Va.

Jeremiah Wright controversy, while 15 percent said they thought less of him. The vast majority  58 percent  said it made no difference.

title: The Church and Penance
description: Yesterdays strong reactions to Pope Benedicts unexpected comments about the sexual abuse scandal underline how much the issue is still part of the life of the Catholic Church. Though the U.S. bishops adopted draconian guidelines in 2002 to prevent future abuses; though abusive priests have been removed from ministry; though bishops, superiors of religious orders and the Vatican have pledged never to move around, let alone tolerate, sexual abuse; though clergy and members of religious orders must regularly attend seminars to teach them how to spot signs of potential abuse; and though millions of dollars in restitution have been paid to victims (sometimes willingly, sometimes unwillingly) by dioceses and religious orders, the wound is still an open one.

title: Chicken Feat
description: Alan Faena is a gazillionaire fashion designer-turned-property developer who has created an arts village of sorts in the Buenos Aires neighborhood of Puerto Madero. After opening the swish Hotel Faena + Universe there in 2004, hes building a cultural center and residential complex next. So now Faena needs some stuff to decorate them. Enter the 2nd annual F a las Artes, the only pan-Latin American arts prize, which just announced its winner. The panel of judges  Jessica Morgan from the Tate Modern among them  chose the 30-year-old Cuban installation artist Wilfredo Prieto. Prieto, who has shown at the Dia Center for the Arts and countless biennials, will fill a vast space in the soon-to-open Los Molinos building, a former grain factory, with dried corn while a single chicken pecks its way through the mounds. For this, he will be paid 100,000 Argentine pesos. We assume the chicken is just doing it for the food.

title: Milan Design Week | Day One
description: Yesterday was the first press day of the Milan Furniture Fair (Salone di Mobile). One of the most beautiful collections the T Magazine team saw was an exhibition of silver pieces by the famed Italian architect Gio Ponti. Held at the Triennale Museum, the exhibition consists of over 30 pieces designed by Ponti for Christofle, created between 1925 and 1978, many of which are now being produced for the first time. Ponti developed a close relationship with the French silver manufacturer (his niece even married the companys director at the time, Tony Bouilhet) that spanned more than 50 years. From the early symbolism of the Flche candy boxes, topped with a heart pierced by an arrow, to the sculptural modernism of the Pompeii candelabra and the Tubi vase, to the surrealism of the Il Diavolo decorative mask, the breadth of Pontis genius is covered in the new collection. The pieces will be available in limited editions in the fall.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about the physicist John A. Wheeler referred incorrectly to J. Robert Oppenheimers position when he first discussed a theory of black holes with Dr. Wheeler in 1939. Dr. Oppenheimer, who clashed with Dr. Wheeler over the theory, had yet to take over the Manhattan Project, since it had not begun. He was not formerly the head of the project at the time. The obituary also misstated the origin of the term many worlds, a description of the parallel universe theory of Dr. Wheelers student Hugh Everett. It was coined by Bryce DeWitt, of the University of Texas in Austin, not by Dr. Wheeler.

Mr. Yamadayev, a former rebel commander, has long had tensions with Ramzan Kadyrov, above, the republics 31-year-old president. title: Barry Who? and Other San Francisco Treats
description: This offseason, in the manner of the old Politburo airbrushers, the San Francisco Giants set about scrubbing virtually every reference to their erstwhile star Barry Bonds -- the banners, the murals, the signs commemorating his pursuit of Hank Aaron's record -- from their bright little toy of a ballpark. If you haven't seen it, AT&T Park is one of those overpraised retro chic palaces that was built, I suppose, to transport the paying customer back to that quaint time when all our ballparks were outfitted with 80-foot Coke bottles and ye olde Wi-fi. (Perhaps I'm being unfair. The stadium has plenty to recommend it. I hear they serve an excellent Sterling Vintners Collection Chardonnay.) Which is to say, you shouldn't go to AT&T Park, or any ballpark for that matter, expecting an honest reckoning with history. But the Giants' purge of Bonds -- from a stadium designed expressly for his game, no less -- was something else entirely. It was a fitting tribute, if not to Bonds, then to the most insecure and insufferable franchise this side of Yawkey Way.

title: Politics and Star Power, Above the Crowd and in It
description: Beth Ditto, the lead singer of the Gossip, takes a shrewdly inclusive approach to the art of spectacle. Throughout her fever-pitch show at a sold-out Webster Hall on Tuesday night, she courted participation even as she reveled in star power. The most emblematic moment was the encore, when she invited a stage takeover and then descended onto the floor, trading places with her fans. This felt more spontaneous than it probably was.

title: Times Reporter Is Cleared by Zimbabwe
description: A court in Zimbabwe on Wednesday dismissed charges against a reporter for The New York Times, Barry Bearak, who was arrested almost two weeks ago and accused of covering the elections in Zimbabwe without government permission, a lawyer for him said.

title: When Fame Cant Cross the Atlantic
description: BERLIN  On Tuesday evening the Russian pianist Grigory Sokolov played, as he does dozens of times a year throughout Europe, to an ecstatic, sold-out house. It filled the Kammermusiksaal here. An unsmiling bear of a man onstage with a babyish face and a white, monkish fringe of hair, Mr. Sokolov emerged looking shy and downcast, as if he hoped no one would notice him. He scuttled to the instrument, head bowed, then plunged in, pawing the keys.

title: Iraq Cracks Down on Seat Belt Scofflaws
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqis often complain about the problems in their country and the governments lack of obvious progress in solving them.

title: Moving Photos to an Apple TV
description: Q. My Apple TV isnt showing the photos in my Pictures folder. How do I get them off my hard drive and on the television screen?

title: U.S. Inflation Appears to Be Retreating
description: A flurry of reports on Wednesday portrayed an American economy limping its way through a broad-based downturn, as consumer demand softens and the labor and housing markets continue to struggle.

title: Digital Mammograms
description: To the Editor:

title: Financier Aims to Buy Struggling Small Banks
description: Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the billionaire financier known for buying companies cheaply, has compiled a shopping list of small struggling banks that might prove to be good investments.

title: British Leader Visits U.S. in Popes Shadow
description: LONDON  Lambasted at home by foes across the political spectrum, Prime Minister Gordon Brown began a formal visit to the United States on Wednesday, and even there he seemed to some Britons to face eclipse by a simultaneous sojourn in America by Pope Benedict XVI.

title: Race and American Memory
description: ATLANTA

title: French Singer Stirs Storm
description: A French singer who plans to sing in English at the Eurovision Song Contest next month in Belgrade, Serbia, has outraged many of his countrymen, Agence France-Presse reported. The singer, Sebastien Tellier, 33, intends to perform Divine with almost exclusively English lyrics, becoming the first French competitor to do so since the contest began in 1956. Many of our citizens will not understand why France has chosen not to uphold its language before millions of television viewers around the world, said Franois-Michel Gonnot, a French legislator.  Christine Albanel, the culture minister, said France should be solidly behind Mr. Tellier, above, but added that it is a shame that there is no French song to represent that nation. Mr. Telliers producer, Stphane Elfassi, said, Out of the 40 countries participating at least 25 will present a song in English.

title: A Drought in Australia, a Global Shortage of Rice
description: DENILIQUIN, Australia  Lindsay Renwick, the mayor of this dusty southern Australian town, remembers the constant whir of the rice mill. It was our little heartbeat out there, tickety-tick-tickety, he said, imitating the giant fans that dried the rice, and now it has stopped.

title: Former Mayor Guilty of Fraud in Newark Sales
description: NEWARK  Two blocks from the wood-paneled office where Sharpe James ran New Jerseys largest city for 20 years, the former mayor made a stealthy exit through a back door of the federal courthouse here on Wednesday after a jury found him guilty of fraud for conspiring to sell city-owned properties to a former companion at a fraction of their value.

title: Paterson Seems Ready to Remove Port Director
description: Gov. David A. Paterson will remove Anthony E. Shorris, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in a move that could come within a week, people aware of the governors plans said.

title: Steep Loss at American Airlines Illustrates Industrys Woes
description: The parent company of American Airlines, the AMR Corporation, posted a $328 million first-quarter loss as surging fuel prices sent the industry into a downturn.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on April 6 about the death of a Columbia University graduate student who was struck by a vehicle while fleeing an assault in Manhattan gave erroneous information from the police in some copies for the location of the assault. It took place on a median on Broadway at 122nd Street; the median is between 121st and 122nd Streets, not between 122nd and 123rd. (The error was repeated in articles in some editions on April 7 and April 8, and again in some copies of an article on Friday.)

title: Disaster Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: France: Suspected Pirates Arrive in Paris
description: Six suspected pirates captured by French soldiers on Friday after the release of the crew of a French luxury sailing yacht kidnapped off the Somali coast the week before arrived in Paris, where justice officials hope to put them on trial. About half a dozen other pirates escaped. The 30 crew members of the ship, Le Ponant, were freed in exchange for a ransom from its owners, said by French newspapers to have been about $2 million. No passengers were on board. French troops recovered sacks of money while capturing the pirates, most of whom were believed to be Somali fishermen.

title: Guilty Plea Entered in Case Tied to Ex-N.B.A Referee
description: One more strand in the case of the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy has been wound up as one of his childhood friends and co-conspirators admitted Wednesday to paying for inside betting information and intentionally defrauding the league of its intangible right to honest services.

title: Japan to Block Investment in Power Firm
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government said on Wednesday that it would block a British hedge fund from buying a larger stake in a power company, in a case that is being closely watched as a test of Japans openness to foreign capital.

title: Britain Considers Way to Help Ease Loan Market
description: LONDON  The Bank of England and the British government are considering an unprecedented move intended to help restore liquidity to the money markets by taking over the mortgage-backed assets of some banks.

title: Book Sales Lifted Obamas Income in 2007 to a Total of $4.2 Million
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama released his 2007 tax return on Wednesday evening, reporting a household income of $4.2 million due to a sharp increase in the sales of his books during the first year of his presidential campaign.

title: Out of the Yard and Onto the Fork
description: MY peas are coming up  sugar snaps and snow peas  and the seeds I scattered out in my cold frame a month ago are now a blanket of baby greens. A few mornings ago, while weeding, I popped a tiny bok choy seedling into my mouth and let its peppery, sweet flavor explode on my tongue.

title: Bush Sets Greenhouse Gas Emissions Goal
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush called Wednesday for the United States to stop the growth of greenhouse gas emissions by 2025 and challenged other countries, including major polluters like China and India, to abandon trade barriers on energy-related technology and commit to goals of their own.

title: Chinese Student in U.S. Is Caught in Confrontation
description: DURHAM, N.C.  On the day the Olympic torch was carried through San Francisco last week, Grace Wang, a Chinese freshman at Duke University, came out of her dining hall to find a handful of students gathered for a pro-Tibet vigil facing off with a much larger pro-China counterdemonstration.

title: Battle of the Baggage
description: After nearly a week of the bitter battering, it must have pleased Barack Obama greatly when he was able to bring up Hillary Clintons cookie debacle Wednesday night. Finally, he got a chance to remind her of the time back in 1992 when she dissed the homemakers of America by saying, rather inartfully, that she preferred legal work to baking and serving tea.

title: Two Commanders in Basra Are Sent Back to Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government recalled to Baghdad on Wednesday the two security commanders who led the recent troubled operation in the southern city of Basra that set off fighting across the south and in Baghdads Shiite neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an IAC/InterActiveCorp search engine aimed at a black audience misspelled the surname of a singer hired by IAC to promote the service. She is Regina Belle, not Bell.

title: Prairie Birds Flirt, and a Town Livens Up
description: EAGLEVILLE, Mo.  The prairie chickens flew in from the west to the booming grounds here, swooping down into the tall grass to stomp their feet and dance. This is where the more flamboyant males of the species like to make a ruckus in an effort to attract females with their steady, low-pitched calls, or booms.

title: Supreme Court Allows Lethal Injection for Execution
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld Kentuckys method of execution by lethal injection, rejecting the claim that officials there administered a common sequence of three drugs in a manner that posed an unconstitutional risk that a condemned inmate would suffer acute yet undetectable pain.

title: Akon's Rap Sheet Is Revealed
description: Another successful entertainment figure has been accused of fabricating details of a hard-knock criminal life. Only this time its not a well-reviewed memoirist but Akon, left, the multiplatinum-selling R&B singer. On Wednesday the Web site The Smoking Gun (thesmokinggun.com) posted a 3,900-word investigation of the stars criminal record, which Akon  who was born Aliaune Thiam and grew up in Senegal and the United States  alludes to in his music and has boasted about in numerous interviews. Although he claims to have spent more than four years in prison and says his crimes include leading an extensive car-theft ring, the only felony conviction among his six arrests was for gun possession, for which he received three years probation, The Smoking Gun reported. And while Akon, who titled his second album Konvicted, was arrested in 1998 for possession of a stolen BMW and was held for several months in jail, all charges were dropped, and he was released, according to the Web site. Akons representatives at Universal Motown, his label, did not respond to requests for comment.

title: Hints of Fear in the Land of Mansions
description: GREENWICH, Conn.

title: Forgettable Knicks Season Ends With a Loss
description: INDIANAPOLIS  On a night of new beginnings, uneasy transitions and unofficial farewells, Donnie Walsh got a standing ovation and Isiah Thomas got a final chance to consider what went so horribly wrong.

title: How Do You Tell the Oldest Senator to Slow Down? Very Carefully
description: WASHINGTON  Frail and the subject of swirling questions about his ability to lead the powerful Appropriations Committee, Senator Robert C. Byrd offered some advice on Wednesday to those who would whisper he is not up to the job:

title: Immigration Sweep Ends in 280 Arrests at 5 Plants
description: More than 280 workers accused of being illegal immigrants were arrested Wednesday by federal agents in coordinated operations at five plants belonging to Pilgrims Pride, a major chicken-processing company, in the largest immigration roundup at a workplace this year.

title: Easier Paper Handling and Improved Resolution on a Go-Anywhere Printer
description: When you absolutely must print on the spot, Canons iP100 mobile printer wants the gig. Available from online and offline stores this week for $249, this 4.4-pounder has a flat shape that lets it fit into a briefcase or its modern counterpart, the messenger bag.

title: Challenges Remain for Lethal Injection
description: Executions in Texas, Alabama and other Southern states with large death rows are likely to resume shortly in the wake of the Supreme Courts decision Wednesday upholding Kentuckys method of putting condemned prisoners to death.

title: Warning on Storage of Health Records
description: In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, two leading researchers warn that the entry of big companies like Microsoft and Google into the field of personal health records could drastically alter the practice of clinical research and raise new challenges to the privacy of patient records.

title: New Leader of State Police Discusses His Own Financial Missteps
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Patersons nominee to take over the beleaguered State Police, Harry J. Corbitt, was confirmed by the Senate on Wednesday after promising this week to repair the agencys reputation and to conduct a review of the security detail provided to governors.

title: Exploring Solitude, With Help From Others
description: It is not often a baritone and a pianist share billing for a song recital with a dancer and choreographer, a video designer and lighting designers. But on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall the excellent American baritone Nathan Gunn, admired for the honesty and physicality of his portrayals on the opera stage, tried to enhance the dramatic allure and philosophical richness of the song recital format by adding elements of dance, video and lighting.

title: Prepping Children for the 9 to 5
description: MANY years ago, my son was sitting in his booster seat at the kitchen table, scribbling madly on a legal pad with a crayon. When I asked him what he wanted for breakfast he waved me off with a shake of his head. I working Mommy or my editor will be mad with me, he said.

title: Police Say Fan Lost Balance Sliding on Handrail
description: A 36-year-old man who plunged more than 30 feet to his death as he left Tuesdays game at Shea Stadium had tried to slide down an escalator handrail and lost his balance, the police said Wednesday.

title: Laptop Effort for Children Starts to Show Some Offshoots
description: Child-friendly computers like the XO from the One Laptop Per Child project have paved the way for low-cost machines aimed at the global education market, and now Hewlett-Packard is making an appearance on the playground. The basic model of the companys new 2133 Mini-Note PC tips the scales at around 2.6 pounds and taps the wallet for less than $500.

title: Yankees Back Home for a Quick Hi and Bye
description: Mike Harkey and Bobby Meacham, two Yankees coaches, arrived at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday with laundry bags slung over their shoulders. Several other laundry bags piled up in the clubhouse near Mike Mussinas locker.

title: Protesters March in Advance of Torch in India
description: NEW DELHI   Hundreds of Tibetan protesters marched through central Delhi on Thursday morning shouting "Die for Freedom" hours before the Olympic torch was due to be carried through the Indian capital.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about problems facing the Catholic church in the United States even as it welcomes Pope Benedict XVI for a visit misstated the estimated number of victims of the churchs sexual abuse scandal. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops has acknowledged about 13,000 victims  not 5,000, which is the approximate number of priests and deacons who have been accused of abuse.

title: Wary Reception Among Muslims Who Recall Pontiffs Remark About Muhammad
description: The Muslim boys at Xaverian High School in Brooklyn pass under the stone gaze of the Virgin Mary every morning, and crucifixes adorn the classrooms where they receive a solid Catholic education. The school band is to play for Pope Benedict XVI when he arrives in New York on Friday, so the buzz of his first papal visit to the United States is also inescapable.

title: Restaurants Must Post Calories, Judge Affirms
description: Calorie counts must be posted alongside prices in some New York City restaurants, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday in upholding revised city regulations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the effect of biofuels on the price of food misidentified the representatives who criticized Western biofuel policy during a meeting in Washington last weekend on global economic issues. Much of the criticism came from representatives of poor countries that have been hit hard by rising food prices. It did not come from the finance ministers or central bankers of seven leading industrial countries.

title: U.S. Proposes Auctioning Runway Slots to Curb Delays at La Guardia
description: The federal Department of Transportation on Wednesday proposed auctioning landing and departure slots to airlines at La Guardia Airport to reduce persistent delays. The move drew immediate criticism from the Port Authority, Gov. David A. Paterson and Senator Charles E. Schumer.

title: Coca-Cola Faces Critics of Its Olympics Support
description: It is getting tougher to be a global brand these days. Just ask Coke.

title: Revised Batting Order Changes Dynamic for Mets
description: Carlos Beltrn had seen enough. So in a quiet moment Tuesday afternoon, he pulled a chair beside Jos Reyess locker and offered some unsolicited advice. Recalling their conversation Wednesday night after the Mets 5-2 victory against the Washington Nationals, Beltrn said he told him: I want you to be the Reyes youve always been. Forget what people say, what they write about you, what people think. Just be you.

title: Merrill Posts a Loss and Plans to Cut 2,900 More Jobs
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the investment bank, posted a loss on Thursday and announced that it would cut about 4,000 jobs by the end of the year.

title: Seeing Comments in Word
description: Q. How do I see embedded comments in Microsoft Word? I often get Word documents and files in the Rich Text Format that are supposed to have comments, but I can never find them.

description: In 35 years in television, Mike Weisman has produced baseball for NBC and Fox, has been the executive producer of NBC Sports, and has run Jane Pauleys ill-fated talk show.

title: Changing Speeds to Go the Distance
description: SARA HALL experienced an instructive epiphany in 2006. In the fall, shed won the national road-running championship for 5K (3.1 miles), a distance she specialized in at Stanford. At the time, she considered herself a 5K runner. So did everyone else.

title: More Steps Urged on Interest Rates in China
description: BEIJING  Inflation and economic growth have slowed slightly in China, the government announced Wednesday, saying price controls had limited the cost of many essential items and exports to the United States had weakened.

title: Universal Health Care to Cost Massachusetts More Than Was Budgeted
description: In its first full year, universal health coverage in Massachusetts will cost the state $153.1 million more than was budgeted, according to a supplemental budget request released Monday by Gov. Deval Patrick. The state had appropriated $472 million for the fiscal year ending June 30, but enrollment in the states subsidized insurance programs for low- and middle-income workers exceeded expectations. About 340,000 of the states estimated 600,000 uninsured have gained coverage since Massachusetts began requiring health insurance. The state had projected that 136,000 people would sign up for its Commonwealth Care policies, but 174,000 are now enrolled. Cyndi Roy, a spokeswoman for Mr. Patrick, a Democrat, said this years shortfall would be offset by surplus revenues in the states general fund. For the coming fiscal year, Mr. Patrick has requested $869 million for Commonwealth Care, but his aides have already conceded that will not be enough as enrollment continues to grow.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: Brushes to Set the Teeth on Edge
description: ONLY one thing stood, or lay, between Alexandra Avlonitis and domestic bliss after she renovated her Roxbury, Conn., bathroom: the toothbrushes. Each one was a different size, ergonomic shape and amalgam of voluptuous injection-molded plastics. The only thing they had in common was that none fit into the handsome toothbrush holder shed bought.

title: Have a Nice Day at School, Sweetie. Dont Kill Anyone.
description: The dogs are yapping for their food. Stepdad forgot to pick up the dry cleaning. Mom is still half-dressed. The bag lunches are ready, but where are those darn car keys?

title: Despite Downturn, Financing Exists for Small Companies
description: WITH all the grim earnings news from corporations and banks lately, not to mention the continuing credit squeeze and widespread talk of recession, it would seem that most small companies, too, would be having a hard time finding financing.

title: Retailers Get Stingy With Data
description: J. C. Penney says the tumultuous economy is making it impossible to predict earnings over the next year. Macys asserts that providing monthly sales information is too distracting and confusing. And Starbucks argues that annual profit estimates are unnecessary.

title: Martin S. Kimmel, 92, Co-Founder of Retail Real Estate Firm, Dies
description: Martin S. Kimmel, a real estate developer who tracked power company trucks throughout South Florida in the early 1960s to find sites for what eventually became the nations largest builder of strip malls, died Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: What to Ask About Male Infertility
description: Here are some questions you may not think to ask, along with notes on why theyre important.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Indiana, No Illusions for Thomas
description: Indianapolis

title: Dressing Up the Beds for Spring, at a Discount
description: The Dwell Studio sale, which begins on April 24, will offer deep discounts on bed linens in all sizes, from twin to king. Duvet-and-pillow-sham sets in full-queen size, for example, will be $95, reduced from $290, and sheet sets in queen size will be $85, reduced from $275.

title: Pope Praises U.S., but Warns of Secular Challenges
description: WASHINGTON  Pope Benedict XVI visited the White House on Wednesday, his 81st birthday, and praised America as a nation where strong religious belief can coexist with secular society.

title: I.A.A.F. Seeks an Explanation From Greene About Drug Allegations
description: The world governing body for track and field is seeking a fuller explanation from the American sprinter Maurice Greene, a four-time Olympic medal winner, about allegations from a government informant who says he gave athletes performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Dispute on Treatment of Children After Raid
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  Texas child welfare officials and parents of many of the more than 400 children seized in a raid on a polygamist religious compound in West Texas differ sharply on how the children are faring after two weeks in state custody.

description: To the Editor:

title: To Cut or What? The World Butts In
description: LAST August, when Sarah James of Newport Beach, Calif., was debating bangs, she decided to put the matter to a vote on her beauty blog, Whoorl.com.

title: Antidoping Program Taking Root
description: CHICAGO  To separate himself from the doping scandals that have left deep wounds on track and field, the decathlete Bryan Clay has decided to do something novel: he is trying to prove that he is clean.

title: A Line in the Yard: The Battle Over the Right to Dry Outside
description: AURORA, Ontario  Rob and Laurie Cook are not prone to breaking the law, but these days they have been given to a regular act of civil disobedience: hanging their laundry to dry out in the backyard. The deed to their home  like most in this upscale suburb  prohibits outdoor clotheslines as eyesores.

title: Shifting Gears
description: Once Sara Hall, a world-class runner, switched to competing in races about a mile long instead of more than three miles, she reconfigured her training to focus more on speed work. Now, she can run greater distances faster than ever before. Her training regimen, The Times reports today, provides a good model for how recreational runners -- not just the elite -- can get swifter and sharper. For example, Hall has reduced the miles that she runs each week, and has added hard interval sessions twice a week on a track. "The most common mistake" made by recreational runners, says Terrence Mahon, Hall's coach, "is running the same pace all the time."

title: Preserving Sanity as Well as History: Tips for Taking on a Falling-Down House
description: David Giffelss tips for taking on a falling-down house.

title: Is Bamboo Flooring a Good Idea or Just a Fad?
description: A. There are plenty of fads in the design world but bamboo flooring seems different. It is increasingly being used in both remodeling and new construction because it makes practical sense.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Hires Former G.O.P. Chairman for Public Affairs Post
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Wednesday that it had hired Ken Mehlman, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, as its head of global public affairs, a new position.

title: 2 Council Aides Accused of Embezzling Funds
description: The tiny nonprofit group was said to be named for a girl who died of cancer and was intended to provide tutoring and other services in Flatbush. But when it applied for a grant from the citys Department for the Aging, department officials noticed something odd: the groups address was the home of the top aide to the city councilman sponsoring the grant request.

title: Mistrial Is Declared for 6 Men in Sears Tower Terror Case
description: MIAMI  A federal judge declared a mistrial on Wednesday in the case of six Miami men charged with plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago as part of an Islamic jihad.

title: Socit Gnrale Chief to Step Aside
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale, the French bank that was rocked by a multibillion-dollar rogue trading scandal, said late Thursday that Daniel Bouton would step aside as chief executive but would remain nonexecutive chairman as part of a management reorganization.

title: New Morning Platform, Same Perky Candor
description: Kathie Lee Gifford has been called perky and pesky, popular and polarizing but seldom, if ever, dull. Now, after almost eight years away from live television as the sunny half of Live With Regis and Kathie Lee for 15 years, Ms. Gifford is back on morning television. She is now jazzing up the fourth hour of NBCs Today, injecting a blend of humor and candor that manages to be both self-deprecating and celebratory.

title: Behind the Scenes of an Architectural Experiment
description: In preparation for Home Delivery: Fabricating the Modern Dwelling, a show on prefabricated housing that opens July 20, the Museum of Modern Art is letting the public in on the action. The museum has set up a Web site (momahomedelivery.org) that allows visitors to follow the process as five architectural teams create houses to be installed in outdoor space west of the museums main building. Every week until the show opens, each team will present progress reports, with photos, drawings and video clips of its efforts to make, ship and assemble the structures.

title: A Small Loss, and a Warning, by A.M.D.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices reported a smaller loss for its first quarter, but revenue was weaker than expected. Even so, company executives vowed A.M.D. would achieve profitability in the second half of the year.

title: Businesses in Bay Area May Pay Fee for Emissions
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Air quality regulators in the San Francisco Bay Area appear set to begin charging hundreds of businesses in the region for their emissions of heat-trapping gases.

title: A Slam Opportunity Knocked, but Where Was That King?
description: Bridge is such a great game partly because there is little luck. Yes, especially in a tournament, you are lucky if you play a difficult deal against weak opponents. And there are boards in which many points hang on the location of one card. The diagramed deal, which occurred during a duplicate last year at Jourdans Bridge Club in Delray Beach, Fla., is an example.

title: Google Profit Beats Wall St. Forecast
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Thursday that its net income for the first three months of the year rose 31 percent on revenue growth of 42 percent from a year ago, topping estimates from Wall Street analysts.

title: In Wonder Womans Phone Booth
description: THE windows at GapKids stores around the country are shouting Bam! and Pow! just as Prada is screening a series of animated films in Los Angeles and Tokyo. Louis Vuitton has set up a shop at the Brooklyn Museums exhibition of cartoonish works by Takashi Murakami, and DKNY Jeans has hired Paul Pope, a comic book artist, to design a collection for fall.

title: Pope Praises U.S., but Warns of Secular Challenges
description: WASHINGTON  Pope Benedict XVI visited the White House on Wednesday  his 81st birthday  and praised America as a nation where strong religious belief can coexist with secular society. But he later warned that this secular tradition often prevents Americans from living their beliefs fully, accepting divorce, abortion and cohabitation outside of marriage.

title: Heroines in the Footlights, From All Sides Now
description: There is something irritating about the very premise of Girls Like Us, Sheila Wellers three-headed biography of legendary singer-songwriters. Maybe its the instant-girlfriend tone of the title. Maybe its that at least one of Ms. Wellers subjects, Joni Mitchell, objected to being lumped into the same book with the other two, Carole King and Carly Simon. Or maybe its the euphemism. Her book is about women whose musical careers took off in the 1960s, and all are now in their 60s. They arent girls. Theyre grandmas.

title: Clinton Uses Sharp Attacks in Tense Debate
description: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Barack Obama found himself consistently on the defensive as he and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton met Wednesday night in a tense debate that left him parrying questions and criticism on issues including values, patriotism and his association with onetime radicals from the 1960s.

title: Judge Rules for Inmate Long Denied Parole, Saying 2006 Hearing Was Unfair
description: Jack South, Prisoner No. 90T1984, has endured the kind of life  foster homes, post-traumatic stress from his time in the Army, drug abuse  that may or may not have led to his history of crime, including bank robbery and escape from a federal prison.

description: Behind Garden Gates

description: The New York Times Company, the parent of The New York Times, posted a $335,000 loss in the first quarter  one of the worst periods the company and the newspaper industry have seen  falling far short of both analysts expectations and its $23.9 million profit in the quarter a year earlier.

title: This Time Staal Gives Victory to Rangers
description: When the Madison Square Garden crowd erupted around him, the rookie defenseman Marc Staal could not believe his turn of fortune. He had launched a slap shot that slid beneath Devils goalie Martin Brodeur with 3 minutes 13 seconds left for the decisive goal in a series-swinging 5-3 victory in Game 4 Wednesday night.

title: Opening in SoHo, With Italian Roots and a New York Point of View
description: George Nunno and Jon Maroto clearly have an eye for fashion. Until recently, both worked for Coach  Mr. Nunno as executive vice president for design, and Mr. Maroto as senior vice president for design development. The two often traveled to Italy, where they became customers of a chain of stores called Flair, which carried new and vintage furniture and home accessories.

title: Palestinians Fight Israelis in Gaza; Toll Exceeds 21
description: JERUSALEM  At least 18 Palestinians, many of them civilians, including children, and 3 Israeli soldiers were reported killed in heavy fighting in Gaza on Wednesday, one of the bloodiest days in weeks.

title: I.B.M. Is Doing Just Fine as It Reports Strong Profit
description: I.B.M. reported strong quarterly profits on Wednesday that easily surpassed Wall Streets estimates, as its reach across global markets and its healthy services and software businesses left it unscathed so far by the weakness of the United States economy.

description: PRODUCER Obama campaign media team.

title: New Museum Offers the Official Line on Tibet
description: BEIJING  Not far from National Stadium, the citys mammoth, just-finished Olympic arena, another construction project is still facing an Olympic deadline. The building, sheathed in a green construction tent, will house Beijings first museum exclusively dedicated to Tibet.
