title: 2 Banks Said to Be Trying to Raise More Capital
description: The second week of earnings opens on Monday for the nations banks with at least two  Bank of America and the National City Corporation  looking for ways to raise fresh capital, The New York Times reported Sunday night.

title: Viacoms Vision For a New Premium Service
description: We wanted to control our destiny, said Philippe P. Dauman, president and chief executive of Viacom. Speaking to Tim Arango of The New York Times about the new joint venture between Paramount, MGM and Lionsgate for a premium television channel, Mr. Daumann said the partners wanted to create a flexible service. There are a lot of restrictions in pay-TV deals as they stand now, he said.

title: Obamas Pennsylvania War Chest
description: Girding to confront Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Pennsylvania and beyond, Senator Barack Obama started April with more than $42 million in the bank available for his primary showdown with her, according to its most recent campaign finance report filed with the Federal Election Commission tonight.

title: The Tate: Spring Makeover, 2008
description: Although spring is apparent in the parks and gardens of London with swathes of spring bulbs and blossoms on the trees, the weather is far from spring-like. Snow fell at the beginning of the month and icy April showers and winds are persisting. So until summer comes for real, why not go indoors to one of Londons many free museums and galleries?

title: Two Homers From Utley as Phillies Top the Mets
description: PHILADELPHIA  The announcement that Phillies shortstop Jimmy Rollins had been placed on the disabled list came as sweet relief to the Mets on Sunday. As Rollins tried to play through an ankle injury, he had spent the past two series looming as a threat off the bench and in the Mets heads.

title: U.S. and Iran Find Common Ground in Iraqs Shiite Conflict
description: BAGHDAD  In the Iraqi governments fight to subdue the Shiite militia of Moktada al-Sadr in the southern city of Basra, perhaps nothing reveals the complexities of the Iraq conflict more starkly than this: Iran and the United States find themselves on the same side.

title: Pettitte Is in Control as Yankees End Skid
description: BALTIMORE  Fresh from a vintage performance that included seven shutout innings in a 7-1 victory against the Baltimore Orioles, Yankees starter Andy Pettitte walked toward his locker and was met by a fan.

title: List of McCain Fund-Raisers Includes Prominent Lobbyists
description: Senator John McCain has staked his campaign for the presidency in large part on his reputation as a reformer intent on curbing the influence of money in politics.

title: Running Out of Planet to Exploit
description: Nine years ago The Economist ran a big story on oil, which was then selling for $10 a barrel. The magazine warned that this might not last. Instead, it suggested, oil might well fall to $5 a barrel.

title: Charge More, Merge Less, Fly Better
description: Palm City, Fla.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 20, 2008

title: Ex-Cleric Wins Paraguay Presidency, Ending a Partys 62-Year Rule
description: ASUNCIN, Paraguay  A former Roman Catholic bishop and self-styled champion of the poor on Sunday broke the 62-year grip on the presidency by the ruling party here, the longest-serving political party in the world.

title: Accounts, People, Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Coming Into Focus: Beethovens Middle Period
description: The pianist Andras Schiffs survey of Beethovens complete sonatas, slowly unfolding over this season and next, arguably reached the end of that composers early style on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. Divisions in Beethovens work are arbitrary and debatable. But in the four works, composed in 1800 and 1801, that Mr. Schiff played for this program, the psychological effects and heroic concerns that would dominate Beethovens middle period came into focus.

title: Hey! Show Business Is Not a Business
description: Mike Daisey is not an instantly likable performer. He starts his latest monologue, How Theater Failed America, at a ranting pitch, a self-described fat guy who in minutes has sweat pouring down his reddened face. But he changes that tone in a flash and becomes so endearingly friendly that there was a moment, deep into his opening-night performance, when the entire room was quietly rapt  not what you would expect at Joes Pub, where silverware clangs while waiters circle. It takes a remarkable performer to pull that off.

title: Tip of the Week
description: With Dean Reinmuth

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Democratic superdelegates who said in a survey that they were unswayed by Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons attacks on Senator Barack Obama in Wednesdays Democratic debate in Philadelphia referred incorrectly to the nominating contest in Colorado won by Mr. Obama. It was a caucus, not a primary.

title: Web Metrics and Grains of Salt
description: Perhaps Internet metrics should come with a warning label: handle with care.

title: Cat Lovers Appreciate Soul Mate in Vatican
description: Their names are Shadow, Butch, Misty, Rusty, Sparky, Sunshine, Esther, Marty and Spunky. They are cats, some former strays, some tiger-striped. But to Jan Fredericks of Wayne, N.J., they are family, they are Gods creatures and deserving of compassion.

title: Snippets of Debate Abounded Despite ABCs Ground Rules
description: After spending months setting up its pivotal presidential candidate debate and securing two precious hours of prime time, ABC had to set some ground rules for its competitors. But the networks biggest restriction  a 30-second time limit on debate clips that other news outlets could use  was roundly ignored by cable channels after the forum on Wednesday night.

title: Cardinal Alfonso Lpez Trujillo, 72, Dies in Rome
description: Cardinal Alfonso Lpez Trujillo, the Vaticans leading voice in defense of traditional family values and in opposition to abortion, contraception and gay marriage, died of cardiac arrest on Saturday in Rome, the Vatican said Sunday.

title: When 5 Experimentalists Just Say No to Moving
description: Dance seems to have entered into post-postmodernism, to judge by recent programs that include the five dance and performance art pieces presented Friday night by the Danspace Projects Out of Space@BRICstudio in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: A Priest in the Bronx Passes Up the Pontiff to Be With His Church
description: Based on its weekend Mass attendance of about 1,400, Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx received 39 tickets for Sundays papal Mass at Yankee Stadium. The parish priest, the Rev. Thomas A. Lynch, fished the ticket-winning names from a bowl filled with 200 cards.

title: Today in Business
description: A NEW CHANNEL The sibling rivalry that is Sumner Redstones media empire turned fractious on Sunday, as Viacoms Paramount Pictures movie studio said it would start its own premium television channel, ending a longstanding relationship in which it sold its movies to CBSs Showtime.

title: Bank of America Braces for Consumer Loan Loss
description: In another sign of the pain gripping the financial industry, Bank of America said on Monday that its quarterly profit declined 77 percent and that it was bracing for heavy losses on consumer loans.

title: What Ails the American Economy? Everything, and Theres Worse to Come
description: At a time when the Cassandras of finance are looking like realists, there is no gloomier prophet than Kevin Phillips. The author of 13 previous books including at least one classic, The Emerging Republican Majority, Mr. Phillips sees a perfect economic storm coming. The final pages of his bleak new book, Bad Money, tell of an unprecedented number of Americans planning to leave the country or thinking about it. Readers of Bad Money may come away with a similar impulse to flee.

title: A Tea From the Jungle Enriches a Placid Village
description: PUER, China  The sky is nearly cloudless, the breeze is bracing, and the tea plantation where Yao Kunxue works resembles a giant green amphitheater absorbing the last rays of a setting sun.

title: Two Generations Fading in Unforgiving New York
description: Grand sets and high-kicking chorus lines are nice, but a simple idea well executed is all you need for an engaging evening of theater. Kitty and Lina at Manhattan Theater Source fills that bill nicely.

title: Racing to Victory, and Leaving the Men and the Doubters Behind
description: When a 23-year-old rookie named Danica Patrick became the first woman to lead the Indianapolis 500 three years ago, she raised the tantalizing possibility that in a male-dominated American sport, a woman might for the first time stand in victory lane.

title: Big Browns Stock Is Up, but It Could Really Soar
description: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  Big Brown is lightly raced, has tender feet and is the early favorite to win the 134th Kentucky Derby, which, statistically, has proved to be the kiss of death on the first Saturday in May. Still, his trainer, Richard Dutrow Jr., said he would be all in on Big Brown.

title: Scott Provides the Hammer, as the Hornets Build a Legacy
description: New Orleans

title: Bart Is Back in Caracas
description: The Simpsons has returned to Venezuelan television after being deemed unsuitable for children and replaced by Baywatch, the BBC reported. A spokeswoman for the station Televen said The Simpsons, left, which had been branded inappropriate in its original 11 a.m. slot, would be broadcast at a later hour. Venezuelas National Telecommunications Commission had forced Televen to take it off the air under threat of a fine.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about companies that missed Wall Street earnings estimates after a long history of exceeding them misstated General Electrics results for the first quarter of this year. It earned $4.3 billion; it did not have a quarterly loss.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with the Economic Scene column, about the relationship between income and personal satisfaction, misidentified the country shown with a gross domestic product of just under $8,000 per capita and a satisfaction score of just over 5. It was Iran, not Ireland. (As the chart correctly noted, Ireland has a gross domestic product of more than $32,000 per capita and a satisfaction score above 7.)

title: Millionaires Amendment
description: Politics loves money, and wealthy candidates have a big advantage when they run for public office. We fear that field will never be level, but federal campaign finance law does give a much-needed break to candidates whose opponents spend a lot of their own money on their campaigns.

title: A Broadway Flop Again Raises Its Antlers
description: It is generally not a good sign for a Broadway show when people leave the opening-night party early. That is what Arthur Bicknell noticed at the celebration for the premiere of his play. As soon as the dessert forks were down, there they went, acquaintances, cast members, even family, out the door of Sardis restaurant. A friend finally approached with a report on the reviews.

title: Making Your Money Last as Long as You Live
description: EVEN for people who have built up a decent nest egg, deciding how to use it is one of the demands of early retirement. The good life may be within reach, but the financial logistics still require careful attention.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,030 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

title: A German Training Plan
description: In the first tangible evidence of a one-year-old alliance between Major League Soccer and the German Bundesliga, Borussia Mnchengladbach will train for 10 days in the United States this summer and plans to play matches against the Colorado Rapids and F.C. Dallas.

title: United Nations Agency Criticizes Treatment of Refugees Seeking Asylum in Greece
description: PARIS  The United Nations refugee agency has advised European Union countries to stop sending asylum seekers to Greece until further notice, a step that amounts to a condemnation of Greeces treatment of people fleeing conflict and persecution.

title: A Blind Governor Adjusts, and So Does Albany
description: ALBANY  It is a phone number that just a handful of the governors senior aides know.

title: Rice, in Iraq, Praises Moves Against Militias
description: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, making a surprise stop in Baghdad on Sunday, praised the Iraqi governments decision to take on Shiite militia members in Basra and in Baghdad and painted an upbeat picture of the Iraqi governments progress toward unifying the country.

title: If Only the Dollar Were Stronger
description: THE dream of retiring to a Tuscan villa or a beachfront home in Costa Rica almost always hinges on how to pay for it, but rarely do graying expatriates plan well for another pocketbook issue: the value of the American dollar.

title: Nights at the Opera? Give Ring Fans a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: No Breaks in Life, Not Even in a Fast-Food World
description: PARIS  Gerard Mortier, the brilliant Belgian-born director of major European music festivals and opera houses, is poised to shake up the cultural scene in New York when he takes charge of the New York City Opera in 2009. A tireless champion of contemporary works and a provocative impresario with a penchant for radical productions that have alternately thrilled and scandalized audiences, Mr. Mortier has said that he is eager to take the helm of the peoples opera, as the City Opera has long been called.

title: After Ground Zero Prayer, Pope Ministers to 60,000 in Stadium
description: Before a crowd of nearly 60,000 people at Yankee Stadium, Pope Benedict XVI on Sunday ended his first visit to the United States as leader of the Roman Catholic Church with a reminder to the faithful that obedience to the authority of the church, even in a country that prizes individual freedom, is the foundation of their religious faith.

title: NBC News to Help Teach Tools of Digital Reporting
description: Straying far afield from its core business of reporting the news, NBC News is getting into the education business.

title: Jerome H. Grossman, Health Care Policy Expert, Is Dead at 68
description: Dr. Jerome H. Grossman, a health care analyst at Harvard and leading hospital administrator who was influential in applying engineering solutions to make medical care more efficient, died on April 1 at his home in Boston. He was 68.

title: Evoking Their Desert Home in Song
description: Two groups of desert nomads meld their music in the sparse, spellbinding songs of Etran Finatawa, a band from Niger. Etran Finatawa, which means stars of tradition, played its mesmerizing United States debut at Symphony Space on Friday in a World Music Institute concert. It was easy to tell who was who. Three Wodaabe musicians wore long, almost rectangular robes, hats with a single feather pointing skyward and white stripes of face paint down their foreheads and noses. Three Tuareg musicians wore ornately embroidered burnooses and robes.

title: Exodus Exegesis
description: Every presidential campaign has to produce a stream of appropriate statements for religious holidays, patriotic commemorations, and the like. Campaigns dont expect to win votes with these messages. They produce them because theres a risk of giving offense to some group or other if they dont.

title: New Threat to Farmers: The Market Hedge
description: Fred Grieder has been farming for 30 years on 1,500 acres near Bloomington, in central Illinois. That has meant 30 years of long days plowing, planting, fertilizing, and hoping that nothing happens to damage his crop.

title: In the World of Books, Every Game Is the Best
description: If one game is the greatest ever, can another also be the greatest  or the best?

title: Greening the Bronx, One Castoff at a Time
description: No one would mistake Timpson Place in the South Bronx for the cradle of a new environmental movement. This short street wedged between Bruckner and Southern Boulevards and East 149th Street is lined with small homes and a couple of brick warehouses. The largest tree  or, more accurately, what remains of it  is a Beetle-size hunk of roots and trunk that was yanked out of a construction site and dumped onto the sidewalk.

title: Paramount Ready to End Movie Sales to Showtime
description: The sibling rivalry that is Sumner M. Redstones media empire turned more fractious on Sunday, as Viacoms Paramount Pictures movie studio said it would start its own premium television channel, ending a longstanding relationship in which it sold its movies to CBSs Showtime.

title: Opera Spat in Berlin
description: Conflict is roiling the hallowed halls of the 18th-century Deutsche Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin, MusicalAmerica.com reported. At a recent public meeting that included the heads of three Berlin opera houses and that citys mayor, Klaus Wowereit, the Staatsopers general manager, Peter Mussbach, denounced the mayor, who has said he would not renew Mr. Mussbachs contract when it expires this summer, and Daniel Barenboim, the Staatsopers powerful musical director, for using mafia tactics against him. Immediately afterward, the Staatsoper announced that for personal reasons, Mr. Barenboim would not conduct a coming performance of Don Giovanni, staged by Mr. Mussbach. Mr. Barenboim, the Staatsopers former general manager, had personally chosen Mr. Mussbach as his replacement, but Mr. Mussbach was said to have been annoyed by what he regarded as Mr. Barenboims less-than-focused attention to rehearsals and by his own less-than-equal position in relation to Mr. Barenboims role.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a medical journal study that raised concerns about electronic health records incompletely described the rules that currently govern the use of such records by medical researchers. As the article noted, the rules do bar researchers from access to individual patients identities. But an independent ethical review panel can allow exceptions.

title: Benoit Samuelson, 50, Surprises Even Herself
description: BOSTON  Of the 146 starters in the womens United States Olympic marathon trials Sunday, the oldest was 50-year-old Joan Benoit Samuelson.

title: Rule of the Week
description: Anne marks the position of her ball and taps down her marker with her putter. Audrey marks the position of her ball, lifts her ball and walks to the hole to remove a twig. She walks back and crouches down to read her putt. She notices that her marker has stuck to her shoe. At the same time, Anne notices that her marker is missing and has stuck to the bottom of her putter when she tapped her marker down. Do Anne and Audrey incur any penalties?

title: New Boss Wants to See Chamberlain Start (Now)
description: With the Yankees off to a 10-10 start, and with two of their young starters struggling, the Yankees co-chairman Hank Steinbrenner said there was one thing in particular he would like to change: He wants Joba Chamberlain, the Yankees hard-throwing setup man, to move into the rotation.

title: Taxes as an Investment in America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Volatile Election Campaign All in One Place
description: Months before the first primary votes were cast, every news organization worth its salt asked itself: how will our election coverage stand out?

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Romance Writer and Publisher Divorce
description: The popular romance writer Cassie Edwards and her publisher Signet Books are going their separate ways, The Associated Press reported. The works of Ms. Edwards, who has more than 100 books to her name, including Running Fox, Savage Longings, Savage Moon and Savage Beloved, were subjected to an examination by Signet, an imprint of Penguin Group (USA), after allegations that she had used large chunks of unattributed material. In a statement on Friday, the publisher said, Signet has conducted an extensive review of all its Cassie Edwards novels and due to irreconcilable editorial differences, Ms. Edwards and Signet have mutually agreed to part ways. In January Ms. Edwards told The Associated Press that she did not know she was supposed to credit her sources. When you write historical romances, youre not asked to do that, she said. Penguin has said that more than 10 million copies of her work are in print.

title: Bank of England Outlines Its Bailout Plan
description: PARIS  The Bank of England said on Monday that it would allow banks to swap mortgage-backed securities valued at about $100 billion for government bonds in an effort to restore calm to the British financial markets.

title: What Should Be the Purpose of a Presidential Debate?
description: WASHINGTON  Considering that the debate in Philadelphia last Wednesday may well have been the final meeting between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama in this presidential race, it is notable that most of the commentary has focused not on the candidates, but on the moderators.

title: She Wants a Career and He Wants Golf. Now What?
description: WITH his longtime New York City estate and business law practice winding down, Robert Rubinger was ready to retire five years ago, at age 76. But his wife, Nancy, who was then 66, was not.

title: PETAs Latest Tactic: $1 Million for Fake Meat
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals wants to pay a million dollars for fake meat  even if it has caused a near civil war within the organization.

title: For Urban Tree Planters, Concrete Is the Easy Part
description: Arthur Simpson, a professional forester, always thought that everyone likes a tree.

title: Bond Car Takes Bath
description: What in the world is James Bond going to do for wheels now that his Aston Martin DBS has gone for a swim in Lake Garda in northern Italy? A stunt driver taking the car to the set of Quantum of Solace, the new 007 film starring Daniel Craig, lost control of the vehicle early Saturday morning and it went flying into the lake, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the Italian news agency ANSA. The Associated Press reported heavy rain at the time. The unidentified driver escaped with minor bruises, a report said, and Sky Italia television later showed the car  the only one available for filming  being winched out of the water, right. The film is scheduled to be released late this year.

title: Hot Time, Living in the City
description: ONE night, not long after Joan and Bob Johnson had moved from suburban Beaverton, Ore., to downtown Portland, they saw a sign for a concert at a local church and decided to stop in. It was just the sort of urban experience that the Johnsons, who are retired, had moved to the city for.

title: People Editor Returns as Writer
description: Longtime readers of People magazine may have seen a familiar byline recently: Richard B. Stolley, the magazines former editor, who ran the place from 1974, when it was founded, until 1982, when he was promoted to an even bigger job.

title: Songs as Monologues, Injected With New Life
description: For American audiences, the unsparing view of humanity expressed in many of the best-known songs of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill is usually camouflaged by their reputation as exotic European art songs. They are further distanced from us by their English translations and by the devil-may-care attitude of singers like Bobby Darin.

title: Protests of the West Spread in China
description: BEIJING  Nationwide demonstrations against a French supermarket chain spread on Sunday as thousands of people protested what they said was Frances sympathy for pro-Tibetan agitators. The protesters have also been singling out Western news outlets, especially CNN, for what they said was biased coverage of unrest in Tibet.

title: 2 Banks Said to Be Trying to Raise More Capital
description: The second week of earnings opens on Monday for the nations banks with at least two  Bank of America and the National City Corporation  looking for ways to raise fresh capital.

title: Dont Cut Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Pit, With the Pope and Memories of a Brother
description: They found the remains of Firefighter Jimmy Riches in the rubble of the World Trade Center on March 25, 2002. A brother, Tom Riches, then just 17, walked down into the pit, and he and his father and his other two brothers carried Jimmy out on a stretcher.

title: Every Investment in Its Place
description: WHEN Bertrand de Frondeville, a retired nuclear engineer who lives in Rye, N.Y., discovered that his wife, Barbara, a former teacher, had in her 403(b) tax-sheltered account annuities that are already tax sheltered, he was alarmed. He knew that the assets were not being used to their best advantage, so he set to work restructuring the investments.

title: Sending in the Marines (to Recruit Women)
description: THE Marines are looking for a few good women.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Of Wine, Haste and Religion
description: I was dining the other night with a colleague, enjoying a respectable Russian River Pinot Noir, when he said with a steely firmness: Well pour our own wine, thank you.

title: The Forbidden Kingdom Shows Box-Office Muscle
description: The Forbidden Kingdom, the Lionsgate martial-arts film starring Jackie Chan and Jet Li, right, found the key to the weekend box office, ringing up an estimated $20.8 million to take over the No. 1 ranking from the slasher remake Prom Night. According to the tracking company Media by Numbers, Prom Night, distributed by Sony/Screen Gems, fell to the No. 3 spot with a gross of $9.12 million, and the comedy Forgetting Sarah Marshall (Universal) captured second place on its opening weekend with $17.3 million. The poorly received thriller 88 Minutes (Tristar), starring Al Pacino, finished fourth in its debut with $6.8 million; fifth place went to Nims Island (Fox), with $5.6 million in its fourth week.

title: Recalling the Right Fielder With the Halo
description: Roberto Clemente, the superb right fielder of the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1955 to 1972, the year he died in a plane crash, exists in a baseball Eden of the mind. Cut down just past his prime and just before the free-agency era, he avoided the embarrassments the sport hands out to its greatest stars: mercenary team-hopping, years of declining performance, drug scandals, card shows. For those who can remember, hes forever winding up for another monstrous throw to home plate.

title: Footnotes
description: The rapper Foxy Brown, whose real name is Inga Marchand, left jail on Rikers Island on Friday after serving an eight-month sentence for violating probation granted when she pleaded guilty to misdemeanor assault of two manicurists at a Manhattan nail salon in August 2004, The Associated Press reported. ... Bob Hicok of Virginia Tech and Charles Wright of the University of Virginia will share the $10,000 Rebekah Johnson Bobbitt National Prize for Poetry, the Library of Congress announced. Mr. Hicok was chosen for his 2007 book This Clumsy Living (University of Pittsburgh Press) and Mr. Wright for lifetime achievement. The prize  donated by the family of Mrs. Bobbitt, a sister of President Lyndon B. Johnson  is awarded every two years. ... The thriller The Girl by the Lake, directed by Andrea Molaioli, was the big winner at the David di Donatello awards, Italys Oscars, Variety reported. It won 10 prizes in Rome on Friday, including those for director, first-time director, picture, screenplay, producer and actor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about anger across the globe over a food crisis misidentified the food item that was cut in price by 15 percent after Haitis president, Ren Prval, responded to the public outcry. It is rice, not sugar.

title: In Politics, the Gaffe Goes Viral
description: In 1990, I was covering politics in Minnesota and Paul Wellstone was down double digits in the polls in the waning weeks of the Senate race. I watched in amazement as Mr. Wellstones campaign staff continued to fight tooth and nail for every vote, something I wrote off to a civic reflex that I didnt possess.

title: Corrections
description: An Inside The Times capsule summary on Wednesday of a Sports of The Times column, about protests related to the Olympics, misidentified the writer in some editions. The column was by George Vecsey, not Harvey Araton.

title: Shootings in New Jersey Leave One Dead and Two Injured
description: A man went on a shooting spree, killing one man and wounding two others, including a police sergeant, then fled in his sport utility vehicle before dawn on Sunday in Irvington, N.J., the police said.

title: In Democrats Fight, the Numbers Count
description: More than any presidential nomination race in memory, Senator Barack Obamas battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been reduced to numbers: delegates, dollars, votes, polls.

title: In Baghdad, Rice Praises Iraqi Government Progress
description: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, making an unannounced stop in Baghdad on Sunday, praised the Iraqi governments decision to take on Shiite militia members in Basra and in Baghdad and painted an upbeat picture of the Iraqi governments progress toward unifying the country.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: A team from the American University in Dubai received the international multicultural InterAd XII Award for winning the annual worldwide student marketing competition overseen by the International Advertising Association and sponsored by Global Advertising Strategies and Unilever. The team, called Los Maestros, developed integrated marketing communications plans to promote the Axe brand of mens toiletries, which is sold by Unilever, among ethnic and multicultural consumers.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Friday about the musical A Catered Affair at the Walter Kerr Theater, which is based on the 1956 film The Catered Affair, as well as on the original Paddy Chayefsky teleplay, referred incorectly to a change in the plot. The character of the dead son who was killed in Korea did indeed exist in the film; it was not added for the musical. (The time of the death has been moved closer to the events portrayed in the musical.)

title: McCain Reports Improved Fund-Raising, but Still Lags
description: Senator John McCain signaled his new fund-raising strength Sunday when he reported that his presidential campaign ended March with $11.6 million in its bank account after having raised more than $15 million that month.

title: In Push Before Vote, Obama Sharpens Tone
description: READING, Pa.  Senator Barack Obama sharpened his tone against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday as the six-week Pennsylvania primary contest raced to a close, with the rivals marshaling extensive resources in a battle for undecided voters and delegates that could determine whether the Democratic nominating fight carries on.

title: Liberals Foes Tax His Stoic Sense
description: You weak knee liberals never cease to amase me, the e-mail message from Armand read, spelling errors intact. Im glad we had a few democrats with some guts when we needed them but that type of democrat has passed on and all we have left is a bunch of cowards.

title: Before Medicare, Sticker Shock and Rejection
description: IF you want to retire before you are 65 and eligible for Medicare, health insurance is vital to your plans. Without it, you risk losing everything.

title: Troubles of Teenagers, Faithful and Cruel
description: Catherine Trieschmanns Crooked may be a small-scale play presented in the little Womens Project theater, but it is the work of a big, accomplished writers voice. This terrifically acted production makes it a gem of a discovery.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Monday in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: At a Class on Signaling, Unexpected Gold Stars
description: I teach a lot of classes throughout the year. The vast majority of my students are social players, but some venture to duplicates, a few have competed in Nationals, and a handful are life masters.

title: Tension Over Sports Blogging
description: Recently in Dallas, more than an hour before game time, Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, was in the locker room grinding on the Stairmaster, surrounded by several reporters  their microphones deployed, heads tilted away to avoid flying droplets of sweat.

title: Ochoa Wins 4th Straight Event; Now She (and the Field)  Get a Break
description: REUNION, Fla.  Lorena Ochoa won her fourth consecutive L.P.G.A. tournament Sunday, shooting a final-round 69 in the Ginn Open to defeat Yani Tseng of Taiwan, a 19-year-old rookie, by three strokes.

title: You Can Panic in a Recession, or You Can Strategize
description: WE all know the drill: invest for the long term, especially when planning for retirement. Dont panic. Even if the stock market is tumbling and the country is plunging into a recession, stick to your basic strategy.

title: Whatever You Do, Call It Work
description: RETIREMENT used to be the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, lifes reward, time as enviable as wealth. But in an age-defying, competitive culture, it has become something of a dirty word.

title: A Longer Goodbye
description: EDWARD M. HOUGHTON, a human resources executive at Pitney Bowes, was sick of traffic jams and unpredictable hours. Bina Kozak, who matches patients to cardiologists at a Scripps Health clinic in San Diego, wanted to volunteer for nonprofit agencies. James M. Wing, a pharmacist for CVS Caremark in Cincinnati, hated Ohios harsh winters.

title: Memo to Insects: Bug Off
description: Remember the skits from the glory days of "Saturday Night Live," when a devious "land shark" would turn up on women's doorsteps, pretending to be a plumber or delivering a Candygram?

title: Finances Frail, Le Monde Contemplates the Unthinkable
description: PARIS  During their second strike in a week, journalists at Le Monde streamed out of the newspapers nine-story headquarters in ghostly masks and rumpled white T-shirts painted with numbers from 1 to 129.

title: Port Authority Plans a Web Site to Help Offset Pollution
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will announce plans on Monday to become the first tolling agency in the country to set up a Web site where drivers and airline passengers can buy credits to offset the carbon emissions created by the trips they take.

title: Human Wave Flees Violence in Zimbabwe

description: Oil jumped to a record on Monday, and gasoline prices rose above $3.50 a gallon for the first time across the nation, according to AAA, the automotive group, as fears about energy supplies and a falling dollar drove prices to new records.

title: Words and Music
description: The 92nd Street Ys Lyrics & Lyricists series will present The 1959 Broadway Songbook, featuring Sarah Uriarte Berry, David Burnham, Sally Mayes, Donna McKechnie and Jeff Harnar, who is also artistic director. The show, running May 3 to 5, will include music from Gypsy, The Sound of Music, West Side Story, The Music Man, My Fair Lady and other shows. Information at 92Y.org. ... On May 3 Town Hall will present Nuyorican Poets Caf Third Millennium Celebration: Aloud and Alive at 35!, an evening of spoken word and music hosted by Rosie Perez and Flaco Navaja. Reg E. Gaines, Ishmael Reed and Ntozake Shange are among those expected to perform.

title: Beijing Pressures Automakers to Improve Efficiency
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government is putting pressure on automakers to improve energy efficiency, but consumers are increasingly interested in large sport utility vehicles and full-size luxury cars, auto executives said on Sunday at the opening of the Beijing auto show.

title: Repaying a Political Debt to Spitzer Puts an Official Under Scrutiny
description: ALBANY  Daniel Wiese has had a bad month.

title: Pakistani Parliament Will Consider Reinstating Judges Dismissed by Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans new government plans to present a resolution in Parliament calling for judges fired by President Pervez Musharraf when he imposed emergency rule in November to be restored to power, party and government officials said Sunday. It would be the first major legislative challenge to Mr. Musharraf by the new government.

title: Superhero Pitches Golf Balls (So You Can Putt Them)
description: As a golf video visionary  see my work at nytimes.com/golf  it is my duty to apprise the golf community of other notable works in the genre. Hence, golfs first rap video presented by, of all people, Top-Flite golf balls. You know the brand, often regarded as a nonpremium ball (though nonetheless used by millions). Top-Flite is working to remake its image with a rapping golf superhero in a tight leotard named D2 Man (so named after the companys new D2 balls).

title: Success Overcomes Qualms in E.A.s Iraq-Themed Game
description: Two years ago, Electronic Arts game developers hit on what they thought was an impressive idea: players as private military contractors, running around Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: New Wii Games Find a Big (but Stingy) Audience
description: Nintendo sits atop the home video-game market. Its Wii, though less technologically advanced than Microsofts Xbox 360 or Sonys PlayStation 3, continues to outsell those machines and is now in more than 20 million homes.

title: Radiant Line of Russian Style Energized in a Triplet of Balanchines
description: A colleague of Serge Diaghilev (1872-1929) shrewdly wrapped up that great impresarios work into three categories: To reveal Russia to itself; to reveal Russia to the world; to reveal the world  the new world  to itself. We can now see that a fourth project remained: to reveal that new world to Russia. Only after the Iron Curtain had lifted, decades after his death, could that be possible. The Kirov Ballet closed its three-week season at New York City Center on Sunday with a triple bill of ballets by George Balanchine, the last of the five choreographers Diaghilev introduced to the West. These three  Serenade (Tchaikovsky), Rubies (Stravinsky) and Ballet Imperial (Tchaikovsky)  demonstrated just how this process is still going on.

title: Corrections

She is A. Sprightley Ryan, not Sprightly.

title: Buck Dawson, 87, Promoter of Swimming, Is Dead
description: Buck Dawson, the first executive director of the International Swimming Hall of Fame in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and a leading promoter of the sport, died on April 4 in Fort Lauderdale, where he lived. He was 87.

title: Gasol Proves Lakers Are a One-Man Band No More
description: LOS ANGELES  It has been a long time since Kobe Bryants summer of fear and loathing, in which he called Jerry Buss, the Los Angeles Lakers owner, an idiot; mocked the acumen of Mitch Kupchak, the teams general manager; ripped his teammate Andrew Bynum in a parking lot video; and kept the news cycle spinning with demands that he be traded, sprinkled with occasional backpedaling, apparently to make sure everyone was listening.

title: Staying in the Orbit of Satellite Radio
description: When satellite-radio customers are asked whether they will keep their subscriptions through the end of the year, they answer differently depending on whether they have sought out the service or received it free through radios already installed in new or leased cars. People in the latter group, by 26 percentage points, are less likely to say they will absolutely keep the service, according to a questionnaire answered by about 3,510 users who also listen to AM/FM stations, and prepared by Jacobs Media, a consultancy for broadcast radio.

title: Protecting a Basic Freedom
description: The effort to enact a federal shield law for journalists got a much-needed bipartisan boost last week. Speaking before a press group, Senator John McCain announced his support for the Free Flow of Information Act. The measure would give reporters limited protection against being compelled to reveal confidential sources in federal court. Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Clinton officially signed on as co-sponsors.

title: Corrections

It was the Pirates  not the Phillies  and the Giants lost the game by 9-1, not 2-1. (The Phillies defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers that day, 2-1.)

Capping a frenzied final weekend of campaigning in Pennsylvania, the Democratic presidential candidates escalated their attacks on each other in speeches and in a last-minute barrage of advertisements on Sunday, aiming at voters who are still undecided just two days before the states marathon primary battle culminates.

Innocuous as this may seem, being generous can also subject you to gift tax. While helping a family member often occurs under the radar, if the gift exceeds a certain value and the I.R.S. catches it, you could be forced to pay the tax as well as interest.

title: Mob Returns to Cuba
description: Times have changed since Havana was known as the Latin Las Vegas, and the mob and the government of the dictator Fulgencio Batista worked hand in hand. But now Tony Soprano is headed to Cuba because the go-ahead has been given for broadcasts of the prize-winning drama The Sopranos to begin on state-run television on Tuesday evenings, Reuters reported, citing the Communist youth newspaper Juventud Rebelde. And on Thursday nights, Greys Anatomy, about the lives of doctors working in a hospital, will be broadcast. Juventud Rebelde said that the programming demonstrated state televisions proven rigor in the selection of drama of high ethical quality and powerful presentation. These are not the first American television shows to be broadcast in Cuba.

title: Forest Fire Scorches 3,000 Acres in Ulster Park

Katherine Legge will not be happy hearing that epithet, since the British driver has owned that line since she won races in the Toyota Atlantic series three years ago. description: Shares of the French bank Socit Gnrale jumped nearly 6 percent Friday as investors applauded the decision of its chief executive, Daniel Bouton, to step aside three months after the bank disclosed nearly 5 billion euros in losses linked to a rogue trading scandal.

description: Dissident shareholders of Office Depot, who sought to oust the struggling chains chief executive, Steve Odland, have abruptly abandoned their proxy fight just a few days before the companys annual meeting.

description: Sears Holdings said on Friday that a credit agreement with Bank of America would come to an end after the bank would not agree to renew it under existing terms. Shares of Sears fell 3 percent in after-hours trading after it said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the secured credit agreement would end in July.

title: Who Is Against Planting Trees?
description: Working as a forester in New York, you get your head screamed off at times  a lot of times, says Erin Roche, 24, a senior forester for Brooklyn. She is one of the 40-or-so foresters who work for the city Parks and Recreation Department. For every one of those million trees the mayor has announced he would like to see planted in New York City by the year 2017, theres apparently a reason people dont want them in front of their homes. The struggle between city workers who plant trees and the city residents who do not want them planted was the topic of todays Big City column. People worry about being held responsible for the cost of fixing sidewalks that have heaved up from wayward tree roots, but now, Ms. Roche assures them that the city will pay for those repairs if the damage is bad (that wasnt always the case).

description: Sensing a lack of concern about global warming? So are two important sources quoted in the news today: Al Gore and a Gallup poll of more than 1,000 Americans.

title: Paterson on Prayer, Property Taxes and Privacy
description: Gov. David A. Paterson kicked off a weeklong radio tour this morning with an interview on Talk 1300 AM in Albany, on the show in which The New York Posts Fredric U. Dicker was the host. What was new?

title: The E-Piano Competition
description: Heres an interesting idea submitted by a reader. It refers to my review of Yamahas Disklavier Mark IV, a self-playing, Internet-connected grand piano.

title: A Surge of the Heart
description: Yesterday, during the Papal Mass at Yankee Stadium, I experienced two brief moments that I hope I never forget. Or, as Psalm 137 says, Let my tongue cleave to the roof of my mouth, if I should forget you!

title: The Morning Skate: Skating With Shakespeare, and Songs
description: A king enacts a law and that law comes back to dethrone the king  or at least bite him on the derrire. One of Shakespeares tragedies surely must contain this plot, but no one at the Morning Skate reads great literature. We read only the sports pages. Sometimes we only look at the pictures. Still, its the story of the dethroned Stanley Cup champs.

title: Kamsky-Topalov Match Down to (New) Deadline
description: The situation surrounding a potential match between Gata Kamsky of the United States and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria remains up in the air as a new deadline for bids approaches. The winner will play a match against the winner of a match between Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia that is taking place in October in Germany. The winner of that subsequent match will be world champion.

title: Alternatives to a City Hotel: Outlying Island Hostels
description: I will get back to my snacking link, I promise. But first, here is the first of two more time-sensitive posts.****CY from New Jersey asks if there are places to stay other than the usual hotels.Because Hong Kong is so densely urban and commercial, there are not many guesthouses, B&Bs, or opportunities to home-stay with a family. And because Hong Kong society is so obsessed with face and status, people see little appeal in somewhere old, quaint and adventurous, when they can find somewhere shiny, new and connected to a mall.

title: In New Ad, Clinton Says She Can Stand the Heat
description: Barack Obama recently said Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has been throwing the kitchen sink at him. Now, in her latest ad, shes throwing him out of the kitchen.

title: Keens and a Cocktail
description: When I posted an item earlier this month about an act of courteousness by servers at the Mexican restaurant Crema, I said I wanted this blog to do a better job of spotlighting the many ways and many times restaurants surprise and delight us, not just our frustrations and complaints with them.

title: CNNs Newest Product: Headline T-Shirts
description: Broadcasting & Cable: Apparently not content to offer news you can use, CNN is peddling news you can wear. Call it prt-a-reporter: Beginning Monday, visitors to CNN.com will be able to purchase T-shirts featuring headlines from the sites video reports.

title: Jail for Altomare?
description: Richard Altomare, who made millions from illegally selling billions of shares in Universal Express  and then blamed naked short-sellers for all the volume  may be headed for jail.

title: A Quiet Call for BofAs Chief
description: Bank of Americas chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, appeared humbled by the banks third consecutive drop in quarterly earnings, telling investors on a conference call that the current environment is the most challenging I have dealt with.

title: HD Enthusiasts Crying Foul Over Cable TVs Crunched Signals
description: As cable TV companies pack ever more HD channels into limited bandwidth, some owners of pricey plasma, projector and LCD TVs are complaining that theyre not getting the high-def quality they paid for, the Associated Press reports. They blame the increased signal compression being used to squeeze three digital HD signals into the bandwidth of one analog station.

title: Merck's Chief Discusses Earnings
description: CNBC interviews Richard T. Clark, chief executive of Merck, on his company's earnings.

title: Home Breadbakers, Another Good Recipe for You
description: Fantastic piece about breadbaking from The Guardian, and a good recipe for whole-grain loaves. You might also try Jim Laheys technique (see the overhyped but still interesting piece I did with him in 2006, or Google Bittman and Lahey and stand back) with 50 percent whole grain flour. Also of interest is Nick Foxs Times piece about yet another good home-baking technique.

title: Chelseas Grant Cant Win for Winning
description: Avram Grant, the Israeli manager of Chelsea, has been bombarded by many more than four questions from an often-hostile news media during his tumultuous eight-month reign with the English Premier League club.

title: If It Were Up to Mike Holmgren, Seattle Would Draft a Second-Day Quarterback
description: Seahawks coach Mike Holmgren learned about the N.F.L. draft from his old boss in Green Bay, the former Packers general manager Ron Wolf. And Wolf, who worked with Holmgren from 1992 to 1998, had a simple philosophy: Take a mid- or late-round quarterback every year.

title: CNBC Video: National Citys Costly Fundraising
description: National City became only the latest bank to seek additional funds in the wake of the housing market slump, unveiling a plan on Monday to raise $7 billion from a group of investors. The bank, the tenth-largest in the United States, is now following in the footsteps of a score of peers  from Citigroup to Washington Mutual  to rely on a big infusion by outsiders.

title: From Oprahs Big Give To Fords Big Drive
description: Ford Motor seems to have taken to heart the title of the ABC reality series it was sponsoring, Oprahs Big Give. The company is giving away a dozen cars and trucks as part of an elaborate promotion tied to the show, which ended its run on Sunday night.

title: CNBC Video: A Rough Quarter for Hedge Funds
description: So far, 2008 has played havoc with nearly every sector of the economy, from housing to retail to banks. But what about the so-called smart money  that is, hedge funds? Such investors are supposed to make better decisions in times of turmoil, justifying their sometimes eye-popping income statements.

title: Lundqvist Makes It Three in a Row
description: The N.H.L. announced the three finalists for the Vezina Trophy as the leagues top goalie and the Rangers Henrik Lundqvist was among them for the third straight year.

title: No Surfing at Our Tables, Please
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Spain Next to Deal With Somali Pirates
description: Piracy was up 20 percent in the first three months of 2008, and attacks show no signs of subsiding in April. As usual, the waters off Somalias coast are a hot spot, though the sea bandits are facing increasingly swift actions from various military forces from far away.

title: Dems Abroad Slate Ready for Denver
description: With the exception of two superdelegates who have yet to decide, Democrats Abroad, which will send 22 delegates representing 11 votes to the partys convention in Denver, has settled on its slate of delegates.

title: Danica Wins!
description: The weekends results in racing and more

title: Paris Journal: Backstage at the Opra Bastille
description: PARIS  Ever since it opened, on July 14, 1989, the 200th anniversary to the day of the storming of the Bastille, the Opra Bastille has been a controversial place. The building itself, I mean. The main home of the Paris National Opera, its an imposing structure of sleek black stone, concrete and glass, all gleaming and modern, hideous to some, utterly cool to others. I mostly sympathize with the latter group.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Apr. 21:

title: Surviving Cancer Doesnt Lead to Healthier Lifestyle
description: Most cancer survivors are just as overweight and inactive as everyone else, a new study shows.

title: A Preview of Oxygens New Look
description: MediaPost: NBC Universal will unveil a re-branding of the recently acquired Oxygen network at an upfront event on Wednesday. While details are still being worked out, the Oh! moniker that the network turned to in its early, struggling stages will be history.

title: Fox Renews Terminator
description: The Hollywood Reporter: Fox has picked up Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles for a second season. The network on Monday handed a 13-episode order to the sci-fi drama. The series debuted on Fox in January.

title: Where People Know the Meaning of the Word Smackdown
description: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are taking full advantage of television one day ahead of the Democratic Pennsylvania primary, appearing on shows as disparate as Larry King Live and The Daily Show. But their most interesting appearance will likely come on the cable channel USAs wrestling program WWE Raw.

title: For the Moment | Mark Jolly on Emerging Hotel Trends
description: This weeks guest blogger is Mark Jolly, the founder and editor of globorati, a Web site dedicated to luxury travel news and trends. A travel authority who has lived in four continents and reported from over 60 countries, Jolly divides his time between London, Valencia and New York.

title: A New Partner For NBC News: The New York Film Academy
description: Elizabeth Jensen reports:

title: Can You Trust Someone Like You?
description: If Groucho Marx wouldnt belong to any club that would let him be a member, would you believe a survey that would let you be part of the sample?

title: Raw Politics
description: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are taking full advantage of television one day ahead of the Democratic Pennsylvania primary, appearing on shows as disparate as Larry King Live and The Daily Show. But their most interesting appearance will likely come on the cable channel USAs wrestling program WWE Raw, in a series of videotaped messages.

title: Onstage With Denis Johnson
description: Last November, when Denis Johnsons sprawling Vietnam novel Tree of Smoke won the National Book Award, he had good reason to miss the ceremony: he was on assignment for Portfolio magazine, in Iraq. (Northern Iraq, he clarified. The peaceful part you never hear about.) But the National Book Foundation, which bestows the prize, didnt want the occasion to go uncelebrated, so after Johnsons safe return it arranged for him to give a belated reading last week at a New School auditorium in Greenwich Village.

title: Soft Serve | Brazilian Rail, A Bong Boutique, Leatherman Diet
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Quilters Serenade McCain
description: GEES BEND, Ala.  Senator John McCain was serenaded with old Negro spirituals by the quilters of Gees Bend, Ala., on Monday as he and his campaign entourage made a slow-moving trip by ferry in this isolated, overwhelmingly Democratic pocket of the state.

title: Eds Salami and Eggs
description: Ed and I both grew up eating salami and eggs. You cut thick slices of salami (Eds right: kielbasa is better, but we didnt know that back then), into chunks and brown them a little bit. In Eds household you would use that as the base of an omelette; in mine, you would scramble the eggs, keeping them soft, and top with mustard. (I dont usually disagree with Ed, but when hes wrong, I have to say so.) These were the delicacies that defined New York a half-century ago. MB

title: Wrigley Gets a New Look
description: Its that time of year again. The Mets annual trip to Wrigley Field  will there be another one in October?  which means that Im resisting the urge to wax poetic on how ridiculously great this place is.

title: Times Square Weathers a Brief Shower, With No Beef
description: We all know how territorial the Naked Cowboy is about Times Square (a place all too familiar with flesh-baring), having sued Mars for the Naked M&Ms appearance in tighty-whities.

title: Milan Design Week | Reflecting on Ettore Sottsass
description: Gli Specchi di Dioniso, Glass Italia/Ettore Sottsass; image from ICFF.

title: Kamsky, Grischuk Take Early Lead at First Grand Prix
description: Gata Kamsky of the United States and Alexander Grischuk of Russia won their first round games to take the early lead at the Grand Prix tournament in Baku, Azerbaijan. The official Web site has live games, a cross table and a list of the players.

title: The Last Spy Who Did It for Greed Alone
description: An article in Sundays New York Times  by Scott Shane focused on a rising motivation for spying against the United States: divided loyalty.

title: Court Throws Out Lawsuit Challenging Deal or No Deal
description: Associated Press: Georgias highest court on Monday threw out a lawsuit contending that NBCs Deal or No Deal violated state anti-gambling laws when it invited viewers to take part in a game via text message.

title: Sunday Ratings: Ten Million For Oprahs Big Give Finale
description: With its eighth and final episode of the season, Oprahs Big Give earned a modest audience of 10 million viewers on Sunday, down from earlier this season but enough to help lift ABC to No. 1 on the night, according to Nielsens estimates. The reality charity competition has seen its ratings decline steadily after drawing 15.7 million viewers in its debut on March 2. Still, the finale managed to dominate its 8 p.m. time slot ahead of CBSs Big Brother (6.8 million) and NBCs Monk (5.7 million).

title: Colbert Report In Philadelphia Sets Viewership Record
description: Comedy Centrals week-long broadcast of The Colbert Report from Philadelphia boosted the show to its highest-rated week in its three-season history, delivering an average of 1.5 million viewers an episode.

title: Therell Be 1 Inches Less of The Post
description: Updated, April 22 | Readers of The New York Post may have noticed something different in the tabloids pages on Monday: white space. The margins at the top and bottom of each page were significantly larger than usual, and the bottom of each inside page  even the ones with advertisements  was a thin strip advertisement.The change was not a printing error, but rather a dry run, if you will, for a change in the papers look. Starting on Tuesday, The New York Post will be 12 inches high, down from 13 inches now.

title: A Nixon for Obama
description: If the children who have inhabited the White House are Americas princes and princesses, Senator Barack Obama already got a head start in collecting royal blessings with Caroline Kennedys endorsement earlier this year.

title: Friday Prayers for the Deaf
description: Video

title: Is Victorias Secret a Stolen Bra Design?
description: Hear the phrase intellectual property, and the mind might wander to the epic struggle between the recording industry and Napster or the more recent battle between J. K. Rowling and a fan who wanted to publish The Harry Potter Lexicon as a literary love note.

title: Swooping In for a Landing
description: Swoopers, or canopy pilots, have made the all important landing in skydiving into a new sport of agility.

title: Top of the Charts, All Clogged Up
description: Update, Tuesday, 7:50 a.m. The Fortune 500 list, just released today, outdoes the first two lists we mentioned, maintaining its top 9 companies between 2006 and 2007. Only one or two companies moved a spot up or down, though the names remain the same: Wal-Mart, Exxon, Chevron, General Motors, ConocoPhillips, General Electric, Ford Motor, Citigroup and Bank of America Corp.

title: Do Get Personal
description: In Defense of the Freak Show: Ross Douthat, at his blog for The Atlantic, explains why reporters are doing a service to the Republic when they obsess over Obamas relationship to Jeremiah Wright and Bill Ayers, for instance, or his decision not to wear a flag pin, or his comments about working-class voters.

title: Secret Service Now Guard McCain
description: THOMASVILLE, Ala. Secret Service agents joined Senator John McCain for the first time on the campaign trail on Monday, a security arrangement that the presumptive Republican nominee had resisted until now.

title: Temper? What Temper?
description: Cindy McCain brought up a hot topic  stories of her husbands hot temper  while dishing to Barbara Walters and the ladies of The View on Monday.

title: My Smart Car Arriveth
description: John Schwartz is writing about his experience in buying and (now) owning a Smart Fortwo.

title: Stadium Religion
description: The media have rightly devoted much coverage to the Popes visit to the 9/11 site in New York City, while not as much detail was provided regarding the Sunday mass at Yankee Stadium. That is understandable. There is not much to say about the actual content of a Catholic mass, since the prescribed rite does not allow for many surprises. But in this case the very fact of the stadium event is worth thinking about.

title: Anchorage Mayor to Challenge Stevens
description: Mark Begich, the mayor of Anchorage, made it official today and announced he would oppose Senator Ted Stevens in November, a decision that will put the Alaska Senate race on the watch list.

title: Drastic Deer Damage Requires Drastic Deer Reduction
description: Land managers are aware of the catastrophic impact of super-abundant deer on tree regeneration and the loss of biodiversity in the metropolitan New York regions herbaceous forest wildflowers. Now another phenomenon, the loss of the woody shrub layer, has reached a critical stage across most of the region (outside the New Jersey Pine Barrens). Above-ground stems of native forest shrubs are relatively short-lived compared with the life span of the rootstock. Vigorous new shoots replace older, senescent stems on a regular basis.

title: Dont Blame the Deer
description: In the Washington area, we are always hearing about the deer problem faced by suburban communities. The main complaint is the danger they pose to traffic. I wrote a piece on the subject in The Washington Post and received a flurry of letters from people angry at my seeming indifference to human safety, one woman telling me about her friends daughter who had died in a deer-related car accident. Among the lesser complaints is that the deer are known to avail themselves of shrubbery adorning peoples finely kept gardens, remorselessly nibbling away at the petunias and azaleas.

title: Whos Rooting for Good Yahoo Earnings?
description: Fresh off the heels of Googles spectacular earnings last week, some think that Yahoo will top the consensus forecasts Tuesday afternoon when it announces its first-quarter earnings after the closing bell. (For the record, analysts are predicting revenues of between $1.68 billion and $1.84 billion.)

title: Deer and Deer Management
description: The following post covers issues related to the deer population in the United States, from debates and information on how to manage the white-tail herds in the Northeast to discussions about hunting to advice on how to build a deer fence.

title: Food Network Names New Dinner: Impossible Host
description: The Food Network announced on Monday that Ohio chef Michael Symon will take over as host of the Dinner: Impossible series, which challenges its chef to prepare meals under extreme conditions, the Associated Press reports.

title: The Oud
description: Dhia Jabbar, an Oud player, plays a song in Baghdad as helicopters fly by.

title: McCains Optimum Look
description: Can a typeface truly represent a presidential candidate? It depends on the typeface and the candidate. John McCains printed material relies on Optima, a modernistic sans serif designed by the German type designer Hermann Zapf in 1958 that was popular among book and magazine designers during the 1970s.

description: Alessandra Stanley reviews a presidential appearance on Deal or No Deal:

title: N.C. Debate Officially Canceled
description: Will Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton debate again? Maybe  but not on April 27.

description:
Heather Hurlburt of the National Security Network and Eric Posner of the University of Chicago Law School debate whether politicians can convince Americans to go green.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: The Race Reaches Pennsylvania
description: John Harwood, of The New York Times and CNBC, previews Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary.

title: Jury Rejects Suit Over Attempted Rectal Exam
description: Ending a case that has wended its way through the court system for several years, a Manhattan jury on Monday quickly rejected a Brooklyn mans claim that employees of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital improperly forced him to undergo a traumatic rectal examination after he sustained an on-the-job injury in 2003. After only a few minutes, the jury decided that the man, Brian Persaud, failed to prove the chief claim in his civil lawsuit, that he suffered assault and battery at the hands of hospital workers who wanted to perform a rectal exam to ensure that he did not have internal injuries.

title: Snow to Join CNN
description: From cable news star to White House press secretary and back again: Tony Snow, who worked at the Fox News Channel for 10 years before serving as the Bush administrations chief spokesman for 17 months, is moving to CNN to be a political contributor.

title: Verklin, In Surprise, Stepping Down at Aegis
description: David Verklin, one of the best-known media agency executives, is unexpectedly stepping down after 10 years at the Aegis Group, he and the company said Monday afternoon.

title: Some Banks Rethink Investments as Money Tightens
description: After loading up on Asian assets, could suffering Western banks be forced to sell out?

title: The Art of the War Room
description: Brian Bassett, a guest blogger for the Fifth Down this week, writes for TheJetsBlog, a blog partner with Sports Net New York.The draft only recently became the glitzy production with which many of us are now so familiar. The NFL has picked up on the draft as a crucial bridge for fans to pass time during the longest dormant period of any major sport. For football fans, it represents the possibility of redemption.

title: Preview of The First Saturday in May
description: The New York Timess Triple Crown blog. Wow. This is huge for us. Before we made our film, we couldnt get a job blogging for the Secaucus High School Sentinel.

title: In Japan, Looking to Belmont
description: Its Derby fever here, but in Japan, horseplayers are already thinking they have the winner of the Belmont Stakes, the third leg of the Triple Crown. His name is Casino Drive and the New York Racing Association press office has been deluged with credential requests from Japanese news media members. The colt broke his maiden in dazzling fashion his first time out Feb. 23 in Kyoto. He rocketed the one and one-eighth miles, taking the lead from the start and, while still under a strong hold, he continued to increase his advantage with every stride, winning by about 12 lengths under a hand ride from Yutaka Take.

title: Saying Goodbye to Cliff Guilliams
description: Cliff Guilliams was one of the finest guys ever to lean over the press box rail at Churchill Downs. Just listening to him was enough to show how dearly he loved thoroughbred racing. He delivered barb-wired opinions in a honeysuckle baritone cured by bourbon and cigars. He was a chart caller, journalist, handicapper and historian. Sadly, on April 12, he died in his hotel room in Lexington after calling the chart for the Blue Grass Stakes.

title: Working While Chronically Ill
description: In researching my column on how small business owners deal with health insurance, I talked to Rosalind Joffe, an executivecoach who specializes in helping people who have chronic illnesses. Ms. Joffe has suffered from multiple sclerosis and ulcerative colitis, both of which have stabilized with treatment  the removal of her colon for the colitis, and the medication, Avonex, for her MS. Prior to getting sick, Ms. Joffe had two successful careers, first as a multimedia producer and then as a professor of communications at Boston University. She became a coach because she wanted a job that she could do from home and that would be flexible enough to allow her to modify her schedule whenever she had a bad day. She credits her ability to make that career change to the fact that her husband had a good health insurance policy that could cover her as well  yet another example of health insurance affecting a career choice.

title: Photos: Last Push Before the Primary
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama made their final push across Pennsylvania, rallying their committed supporters and seeking to win over a dwindling lot of undecided voters in the most expensive  and exhaustive  presidential primary in state history.

title: In Lou They Trust
description: The Devils posed for their team photo at Prudential Center, packed their bags and headed into the summer earlier today. They complimented the Rangers (the Rangers not named Sean Avery, that is) for playing very well in their five-game playoff series, but the Devils still thought they were much better than a one-round playoff team.

title: An Atlas of the Human Body
description: David L. Bassett, a professor at Stanford, and William B. Gruber, the photographer who invented the View-Master, spent 17 years dissecting and photographing the human body, completing their work in 1962.

title: Tony Snow, A Fox News Veteran and Former Bush Spokesman, Joins CNN
description: From cable news star to White House press secretary and back again: Tony Snow, who worked at the Fox News Channel for 10 years before serving as the Bush administrations chief spokesman for 17 months, is moving to CNN to be a political contributor. CNN announced Mr. Snows hire on Monday, concluding months of wooing by the channels executives.

title: CBS Debate Plans Are Thwarted
description: The North Carolina Democratic Party has canceled the Democratic debate that was scheduled for Sunday night. The change in plans comes as a disappointment for CBS, which had offered the candidates prime air time after the newsmagazine 60 Minutes for the debate.

title: So It Goes': How It Went
description: Joe Henry and I had been talking about writing together for ages, and even tried it once, circa 2000, with uneven results. But now seemed the right time. He started the engine, so he gets to take the wheel. I wrote him an e-mail.

title: Exercising My Typing Skills
description: So what have I been up to the past eight months? I have been traveling racetrack to racetrack  from Pennsylvania to Kentucky, Texas and now Canada  to learn more about horse welfare and horse racing issues. I am an exercise rider by choice, a business entrepreneur by education, and I have blended my passion for horses and the power of the Internet.

title: East Whittled Down to Final Game 7
description: With Montreal finally disposing of Boston in Game 7 Monday night, the East has one small matter of Washington vs. Philadelphia to clear up with its own Game 7 Tuesday night in Washington. Capitals superstar Alex Ovechkin played a huge role in staving off his teams elimination with two crucial goals and will certainly be revved up for a winner-take-all game at home.

title: Obama Talks About Rumors
description: McKEESPORT, Pa.  On the eve of the Pennsylvania primary, Senator Barack Obama was asked about two challenges that have dogged his candidacy for months: What could he do to dispel rumors circulating on the Internet  and beyond  that he is neither a Christian nor a patriotic American?

title: Era of celebrity real estate journalism comes to an end
description: Every industry must have its pioneer, its trailblazer, and in the world of celebrity real estate journalism it was Los Angeles Times columnist Ruth Ryon. She started covering the property transactions of the rich and famous in 1984, eventually turning Hot Property into a syndicated column carried by newspapers around the United States.

title: Accoona Shrinks To Focus on Twing
description: Accoona is a Jersey City search company named after the Swahili phrase Hakuna Matata memorialized by Walt Disney in the Lion King that roughly means no worries.

title: Accoona Shrinks to Focus on Twing
description: Accoona is a Jersey City Internet search company named after the Swahili phrase Hakuna Matata, translated in the Disney movie The Lion King as meaning no worries.

title: Oil Market Rattled by Attack on Tanker
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A Japanese oil tanker was damaged Monday when it was attacked by a small boat in Middle Eastern waters off the coast of Yemen, the tankers owner said. Word of the attack helped to drive world oil prices to a new record.

title: Carter Says Hamas and Syria Are Open to Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Jimmy Carter said here on Monday that in talks in Damascus, Syria, over the last several days, he obtained a significant concession from the militant group Hamas regarding Israeli-Palestinian peace and found Syrian leaders eager for a full peace treaty with Israel.

title: Pounding Keys, Not Gavels, to Sell Indias Tea
description: GUWAHATI, India  Traders crowd around wooden desks in a huge dusty auditorium, poring over thick catalogs describing chests of tea. A broker seated at the front of the room calls out prices in a quick, rolling cadence as the traders shout and gesture, signaling their bids.

title: An Urn or a Gravestone? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hard Plastic Is Raising Hard Questions
description: Are toxic plastics lurking in your kitchen?

title: Hazards: Gymnastics Grades High in Injuries, Too
description: Its not all handsprings, cartwheels and round-offs. Its also sprains, dislocations and fractures.

title: Canada: Minerals Company Acquires a Nickel Mine
description: First Quantum Minerals, a Canadian miner of copper in Zambia and Congo, agreed to buy Scandinavian Minerals for about 281 million Canadian dollars ($280 million) to add a nickel mine in Finland. Scandinavian Minerals investors will receive 9 Canadian dollars in cash and 0.01 of a common share of First Quantum for each share they hold, First Quantum said. The offer values Scandinavian Minerals at 41 percent higher than its April 18 closing price. The transaction will give First Quantum, which is based in Vancouver, full control of the Kevitsa property in northern Finland, which has as much as 831 million metric tons of nickel-ore resources on an indicated and inferred basis, according to Scandinavian Minerals.

title: Justices Turn Down 11 Death Row Appeals
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday turned away appeals from 11 death row prisoners in seven states, including one who killed his adoptive parents and continued to live in their home as their bodies decomposed, then cleaned up the scene so he could have a party for friends.

title: NBC Relocates Its Rock
description: Two weeks after NBC was criticized for showing a racy episode of 30 Rock during its self-proclaimed family hour, 8 to 9 p.m., it has changed course and moved the show to 9:30 p.m. on Thursdays, although, network officials say, for a different reason. Beginning this week 30 Rock will follow The Office rather than precede it; Scrubs will move to 8:30 after My Name Is Earl. The April 10 30 Rock episode attracted criticism for its focus on a reality show-within-a-show whose title included a crude acronym. An NBC executive said the shift was made to give 30 Rock a better lead-in audience to try to capitalize on the rising profile of its star, Tina Fey, who has a feature film being released this week. The executive said the network planned to show 30 Rock at 8:30 p.m. in the fall, partly because an Office spinoff is planned for 9:30.

title: Wireless Unit Lifts AT&T Profit 22%
description: Profit at AT&T, the telecommunications company, jumped 22 percent in the first quarter, meeting expectations, as its wireless business continued to grow fast enough to make up for its shrinking traditional service.

title: As Construction Deaths Rise, Buildings Chief Faces Scrutiny
description: The sleek glass tower at 51st Street and Second Avenue, where a crane collapse last month killed seven, rises 18 stories, nearly halfway to its promise of 43 stories, 180 luxury apartments and panoramic views of the city.

title: Russian Court Jails American Pastor
description: MOSCOW  A Moscow court sentenced an American pastor to more than three years in prison on Monday for illegally bringing a box of hunting ammunition into Russia.

title: A Panoramic Backdrop for Meaning and Mischief
description: With its breathtaking, panoramic views of Central Park and the Manhattan skyline, the Cantor Roof Garden at the Metropolitan Museum of Art may strike you as an excellent place to mount a seasonal outdoor sculpture show, which it does every year. In truth, it is an inhospitable site for sculpture, as demonstrated by the 2008 display that opens on Tuesday: three wonderful, previously unexhibited works by the celebrated Pop artist Jeff Koons. Each of these sculptures is a greatly enlarged, glossily lacquered, stainless-steel representation of something small: a toy dog made of twisted-together balloons; a chocolate valentine heart wrapped in red foil, standing en pointe; and a silhouette of Piglet from a Winnie the Pooh coloring book, randomly colored as if by a small child.

title: Airlines to Charge for Second Bag
description: Five of the six major airlines in the United States plan to start charging coach passengers as much as $25 next month to check a second bag, the latest move in their quest to offset high fuel prices.

title: At Chelsea, Success Isnt a Satisfying Answer
description: The coach of Chelsea, the Israeli Avram Grant, has been bombarded by many more than the four questions of Passover the past week from the news media, which have often been hostile during his tumultuous eight-month reign with the English Premier League club.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on April 13 with an article about lessons that the privatization of the Indiana East-West Toll Road might hold for New Jersey  whose governor, Jon S. Corzine, wants to lease his states toll roads  misidentified the toll plaza shown. It was the eastern entrance to the Chicago Skyway, not the western end of the Indiana toll road.

title: British Bank Seeks New Funds

She said the new book would have an initial print run of one million copies. Its rare that you hear from someone her age that they want to talk about their family, Ms. Mosure said.
