title: Yale Demands End to Students Performance
description: Yale University said on Monday that it would not allow a senior to participate in a campus art exhibition unless she made a written statement that her performance, in which she repeatedly inseminated herself and then induced miscarriages, was a fiction that she had concocted. In an article on Thursday in The Yale Daily News, the student, Aliza Shvarts, right, was quoted as saying that she had inseminated herself as often as possible over several months while taking herbal drugs to induce miscarriages, which she recorded on video to display for her senior-year art project at a show beginning on campus on Tuesday. Her claim drew intense criticism. Yale said last week that Ms. Shvarts had told three university officials that she had not inseminated herself or induced abortions but had made up the story as part of the project. On Friday, however, Ms. Shvarts insisted she had really experienced repeated, self-induced miscarriages, although she said that she had not known if she was actually pregnant. Yale officials said the denials were part of the continuing art performance, and on Monday demanded that it end. Peter Salovey, the dean of Yale College, and Robert Storr, dean of the School of Art, also said that they had found serious errors of judgment on the part of Ms. Shvartss adviser and an art instructor who knew of the project. They did not identify the adviser or instructor, though Ms. Shvarts has said that her adviser was Pia Lindman. Mr. Salovey said that appropriate action had been taken against the two teachers, but did not elaborate. Neither Ms. Shvarts nor Ms. Lindman could be reached for comment.

Mr. Leighton, left, was the chief executive of Asda Stores, a British supermarket chain, when it was acquired by Wal-Mart in 1996. He was subsequently made president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Europe and later became nonexecutive chairman of the Royal Mail of Britain. The Weston family of Toronto, who control Loblaw as well as several businesses in Britain, brought Mr. Leighton to the Canadian chain as deputy chairman in 2006, a position he will retain. title: Pain as an Art Form
description: (Photo: Selections from the Pain Exhibit. To see a slide show, click here. ) Pain doesn't show up on a body scan and can't be measured in a test. As a result, many chronic pain sufferers turn to art, opting to paint, draw or sculpt images in an effort to depict their pain.  "It's often much more difficult to put pain into words, which is one of the big problems with pain,'' said Allan I. Basbaum, editor-in-chief of Pain, the medical journal of The International Association for the Study of Pain. "You can't articulate it, and you can't see it. There is no question people often try to illustrate their pain.''  (Photo: "The Broken Column," by Frida Kahlo (Banco de Mxico Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo Museums Trust))   One of the most famous pain artists is Mexican painter Frida Kahlo, whose work, now on exhibit at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, is imbued with the lifelong suffering she experienced after being impaled during a trolley accident as a teenager. Her injuries left her spine and pelvis shattered, resulting in multiple operations and miscarriages, and she often depicted her suffering on canvas in stark, disturbing and even bloody images.  Sacramento resident Mark Collen, 47, is a former insurance salesman who suffers from chronic back pain. After his regular doctor retired due to illness, Mr. Collen was struggling to find a way to communicate his pain to a new doctor. Although he has no artistic training, he decided to create a piece of artwork to express his pain to the physician.  "It was only when I started doing art about pain, and physicians saw the art, that they understood what I was going through," Mr. Collen said. "Words are limiting, but art elicits an emotional response.''  Mr. Collen wrote to pain doctors around the world to solicit examples of art from pain patients. Working with San Francisco college student James Gregory, 21, who suffers from chronic pain as the result of a car accident, the two created the Pain Exhibit, an online gallery of art from pain sufferers. The images are evocative and troubling.  "Some of them are painful even to look at,'' Dr. Basbaum said. In November, he included an image from the site on the cover of Pain; it can be seen here.  Finding ways to communicate pain is essential to patients who are suffering, many of whom don't receive adequate treatment from doctors. In January, Virtual Mentor, the American Medical Association Journal of Ethics, reported that certain groups are less likely to receive adequate pain care. Hispanics are half as likely as whites to receive pain medications in emergency rooms for the same injuries; older women of color have the highest likelihood of being undertreated for cancer pain; and being uneducated is a risk factor for poor pain care in AIDS patients, the journal reported.  Some of the images from the Pain Exhibit, like "Broken People" by Robert S. Beal of Tulsa, Okla., depict the physical side of pain. Others, such as "Against the Barrier to Life," convey the emotional challenges of chronic pain. "I feel like I am constantly fighting against a tidal wave of pain in order to achieve some quality of life,'' wrote the work's creator, Judith Ann Seabrook of Happy Valley in South Australia. "I am in danger of losing the fight and giving up.''  Mr. Collen said the main goal of the exhibit is to raise awareness about the problem of chronic pain. However, he said he hopes one day to find a sponsor to take the exhibit on tour.  "People don't believe what they can't see,'' Mr. Collen said. "But they see a piece of art an individual created about their pain and everything changes.''   To see a slide show of selections from the Pain Exhibit, click here, or visit the Web site to see the full gallery of photos. Another slide show from The Times in February features art created by migraine sufferers.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 10 about possible disruptions to air passengers because of a federal directive on aircraft inspections misspelled part of the name of the firm for which L. Nick Lacey, a former director of flight standards at the Federal Aviation Administration, now works. And a correction in this space on Wednesday rendered the firms name incorrectly and misidentified the nature of its business. It is Morten Beyer & Agnew  not Morton, Beyer & Agnew  and it is an airline consulting firm, not a law firm. (The name contains no comma. Morten Beyer is a senior adviser in the firm, not the surnames of two associates.)

title: Charity Walk | Blahnik Steps Up
description: Manolo Blahnik has helped out during many a crisis of footwear, but coming to the aid of Thai elephants? Its not such a stretch for the shoemaker, who just debuted a special-edition stiletto to benefit the Golden Triangle Asian Elephant Foundation. Blahnik got involved after Carolyn Butler, the owner of the Napa Valley shoe shop Footcandy, vacationed with her husband at the Four Seasons Tented Camp in northern Thailand. Butler fell in love with the resorts resident elephants and later convinced Blahnik to create the shoes, a pair of sexy pony-hair, leopard-print pumps with patent leather trim, three-and-a-half-inch heels and an open toe. All proceeds from the $645 shoes, which are sold exclusively at Footcandy (and can be shipped anywhere), go toward creating a safe haven for abused elephants.

The companys earnings, after special charges, were 11 cents a share, compared to the 9 cents that analysts had forecast. Its revenue, excluding payments to sites that display its ads, were $1.35 billion, $30 million more than analysts expected.

title: The Bride Wore Ritzy
description: We are in a new gilded age (though this is not a good time to remind us how the first one ended), and the weddings have blossomed to match. There was no better place to witness that phenomenon on Monday than the Wedding Salon, a luxury bridezilla convention that was founded by Tatiana Byron and held at Gotham Hall. The entrance fee was $75, but women (almost all were women) lined up around the block. By the end of the day, about 2,800 people marched through the hall to talk with florists, caterers and honeymoon specialists.In New York, luxury weddings are taken to another level: more personalized, more indulgent. A New York wedding could easily run in excess of $100,000, compared to $28,000 for the nationwide average, Ms. Byron said. (Of course, cost is all relative, as some cultures are arguably even more demanding that a wedding be celebrated in grand style).

title: A Closer Look at The Wine Trials

This year, though, I was thinking about dry rieslings because Ive had a fair number of really good ones in the last few months. You can read my column on dry German rieslings in the newspaper on Wednesday.

title: Court Upholds School Cellphone Ban
description: It might feel a bit like dj vu, but its official  no cellphones allowed in public schools. The Appellate Court has ruled that the Department of Education has the right to enforce a cellphone ban, despite the outcry from students and their parents. The battle has been waged for several years, with parents claiming that it was a violation of constitutional rights and that because they were unable to reach their children by phone, their safety was being endangered.

title: Polls Show Strong Concern About Economy
description: The Pennsylvania Democrats who cast their ballots in Tuesdays primary did so with the economy weighing heavily on their minds, according to surveys of voters leaving polling places. Those surveys showed that more than half the voters questioned believe that the worsening state of the American economy is the most important issue confronting the country, with about 90 percent saying the United States has already slipped into a recession.

title: Canada: Central Bank Reduces Lending Rate
description: The Bank of Canada reduced its benchmark lending rate by one half of a percentage point, bringing it to 3 percent. It was the second consecutive cut in the rate and its announcement came with a warning about deteriorating economic conditions in the United States. The bank is now projecting a deeper and more protracted slowdown in the U.S. economy, it said. This has direct consequences for the Canadian economic outlook, with declining exports projected to exert a significant drag on growth in 2008. The central bank added that it did not expect the economy of the United States to stabilize until the middle of 2010.

The Metropolitan Operas visually drab but industriously comic new production of Donizettis Fille du Rgiment represents theory No. 1 with touches of theory No. 2.

A representative of Jive, her label, said, Jordin is on a vocal rest, but shes expected to make a full recovery and join Alicia on tour in May. ... Budd Schulberg, 94, above right, who wrote the screenplay for the Academy Award-winning 1954 film On the Waterfront and the novel What Makes Sammy Run?, among many other screenplays, television scripts and books, has been chosen by the Writers Guild of America West as the recipient of its 2008 Laurel Award for Screen, Variety reported. The accolade honors lifetime achievement in writing for motion pictures. Mr. Schulberg is to be honored on Wednesday at a guild luncheon in Los Angeles. ... The David Rabe drama Streamers will be revived in the fall by the Roundabout Theater Company. The play, about young soldiers awaiting deployment to Vietnam, will open in previews on Oct. 17 and open officially on Nov. 11 at the Laura Pels Theater.

Lancaster, New York Citys buildings commissioner, after a series of fatal construction accidents misstated the source and timing of a revelation that an East Side building that was the site of a fatal crane accident last month was too tall for its location. title: Beware the Road of Good Intentions
description: The plot of Stuff and Dough is, at least at first glance, as plain and straightforward as the movies title. A young man named Ovidiu (Alexandru Papadopol) is hired by a smooth, shady businessman to drive a mysterious package  that would be the stuff  from the Romanian coastal city of Constanta to the capital, Bucharest. The dough hell earn for performing this simple task will help his parents, who run an informal convenience store out of their apartment, move their business into a proper kiosk. Ovidiu has his best buddy, Vali (Dragos Bucur), for company. What could go wrong?

title: Mona Lisa Emerges From the Shadows
description: How did the Mona Lisa, above, get those shadows around her mouth and eyes? A study in the periodical Applied Optics says it has the answer. Using a multi-spectral camera that can measure 100 million luminous spectrums in as many points on the paintings, the study determined that Leonardo da Vinci (1452-1519) accomplished the effect by means of a technique known as sfumato. Widely used by Italian painters of his time, it overlays translucent layers of color to create perceptions of depth, volume and form, Agence France-Presse reported. Leonardo first applied paint containing manganese, then a layer that contained vermilion, according to Mady Elias, the studys author. title: French Jewel Heads Home

But on May 12, 1887, the French crown jewels were sold at public auction in the Louvre by order of the Third Republic. The buyer, for $135,000, was the jeweler Emile Schlesinger acting for Caroline Astor of New York. The brooch, above, remained in the Astor family but after 121 years was to be offered for auction at Christies in New York on April 15. Then the Louvre and the Friends of the Louvre decided the jewel belonged in France. So when the auction sale was canceled for legal reasons, the Louvre was able to negotiate a private sale with the agreement of the owner, the jeweler Ralph O. Esmerian, Christies announced on Tuesday. Franois Curiel, president of Christies Europe, expressed pleasure that a French crown jewel has reclaimed its position among the museums royal collections. The brooch was recently estimated by Christies to be worth $6 million to $8 million.

Although second in total viewers for the night, CBS actually outperformed ABC among adults 18 to 49, earning the nights top ratings in that demographic at 9 with Two and a Half Men (13.3 million). Over all, CBSs comedy lineup from 8 to 10 averaged 10 million total viewers, about the same as NBCs two-hour Deal or No Deal, which included a taped message from President Bush. A gallery and foundation that represent Haring, who died of AIDS at 31 in 1990, hired a team of artists to celebrate the 50th anniversary of his birth, on May 4, by recreating his untitled Day-Glo pink, orange and green mural. The artwork, on a freestanding concrete slab near Houston Street and the Bowery in 1982, soon began to fade, and Haring painted over it to forestall further decomposition. Artists intend to rely on photographs of the mural and paint samples recovered from scraping graffiti at the site to replicate the design and match the color of the paint used by Haring. For people like myself who were around in the early 80s, this Houston Street mural remains a landmark, said Jeffrey Deitch of Deitch Projects, the gallery that is a sponsor of the resurrected mural. The Keith Haring Foundation is also sponsoring the work.

description: The rising design star Martino Gamper has collaborated on the interior of the shoe designer Diego Dolcinis new store, which opened here in Milan this week. Gamper, who is known for such design derring-do as If Gio Only Knew, a performance piece in which he chopped up Gio Ponti furniture from the hotel Parco dei Principi, Sorrento and reassembled it into other furniture of his own design, or the relatively self-explanatory project 100 Hundred Chairs in 100 Days, has created a series of stacked wooden shelves for the store that coyly mimic the boxes Dolcinis shoes come in. Its a little like Payless, but a lot more elegant. As high-concept as Gamper can sometimes seem, hes definitely not one to only think outside of the box: word on the street is that he and Dolcini are working together on a collection of shoes for the fall.

We have lots of chances, but we dont put it in the net. In overtime, its about luck. Today we dont have luck.

title: Bloggers Unite
description: Hello, Im Patrick Patten of Handride fame. Is it fame? Well my relatives are at least amused by my web-logging, so that counts for something. Im your basic blogger: I think Im always right, I look down on your opinions, and I have no fundamental connections to the sport I write about. However, I do love the sport in a way that is not healthy: switching cable providers to one with the horse racing networks, leaving my 4-week-old first-born to go to Chicago and watch the Arlington Million, writing and updating a blog every day. Its this passion that Im allowed to pass on that some professional writers are sometimes unable to. For example, in my next post Im listing seven horses that are NOT going to win the Derby.

description: Amid the debate over how to handicap synthetic racing surfaces, a question remains  are they better for the horses? Alex Brown, in his posts on The Rail, maintains that horsemen by and large love the surface and believe its safer. His view was supported by the results of a poll of trainers at Santa Anita. (Bob Baffert, for one, has spoken out against the synthetic track at Santa Anita, which is scheduled to be replaced because of drainage problems, calling it a bill of goods.)

description: To mark Earth Day on Tuesday, the Natural Resources Defense Council issued its second annual Green Apples and Bad Apples report, which identifies five promising environmental developments and five things or places that arent so good for the environment. One of the biggest complaints: businesses that leave the doors open while running the air-conditioning at full blast. Our colleague Clyde Haberman has complained about this phenomenon in his NYC column, in 2006 and 2007, but it was interesting to see a leading environmental advocacy group take up the banner.

title: The Search for a New Buildings Chief
description: A day after the resignation of Patricia J. Lancaster, the first woman in a long line of embattled buildings commissioners, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered a sympathetic view of the pressures she faced and acknowledged the challenge of finding a replacement.When you go and do big search you always say, Oh its going to be tough,' Mr. Bloomberg said at a public school in St. Albans, Queens, adding that it would be a great challenge but he would find someone to run the Buildings Department. Being a commissioner in the city of New York is a really challenging job, but a wonderful job, and there are people who like being challenged, who like being, have to work under pressure, who like what looks like at the beginning an insurmountable problem. Those are the people who take it to the next level.

title: Rome: Finding A Real Meal in a Tourist Town
description: In a city deluged with throngs of tourists year round, it is often hard to find a meal that feels genuine. Many restaurants in the center have transformed themselves into McTrattorias, mass market Italian fare with plastic menus catering to tourists. They have neither the charm nor the food that makes Rome dining unique.

description: For all you Mets fans ready to jump off the Triborough, some food for thought: The Mets have been criticized for some moves that they have made over the past few years  Brian Bannister, Heath Bell, Matt Lindstrom, you get the idea. But just imagine, for a second, if they had gone ahead and pulled off the deal for Washingtons Chad Cordero that they were talking about in the final minutes before last Julys trade deadline. Cordero, the Nationals closer, is having his shoulder examined by Dr. James Andrews, which is never a good thing.

title: Paterson Vetoes His First Bill
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson, fresh off calls to cut state spending and avoid passing spending mandates on to local governments, wielded his veto pen for the first time today.The offending bill? Legislation that would have required smaller municipalities to hire a full-time police chief, even if they only have part-time police officers in their departments. It was supported by the state police chiefs association, among other groups.)

title: A Brief Encounter on the City Hall Steps
description: It was one of those chance encounters on the City Hall steps. As the Rev. Al Sharpton prepared to begin a news conference calling for guilty verdicts for the detectives on trial in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell, Mr. Sharpton was greeted by somewhat of a surprise guest. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was on his way out of the building to a press conference to open the TriBeCa Film Festival when he greeted Mr. Sharpton and others, including Mr. Bells fiance, Nicole Paultre Bell.After the mayor left, Mr. Sharpton went on to call for convictions for the three detectives on Friday morning, when a verdict is expected from Justice Arthur J. Cooperman. He also denounced speculation about violence on the streets if the detectives are acquitted.

The delay ordered by Judge Robert A. Katzmann is only temporary, until Tuesday, when he said a three-member panel of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals would hear oral arguments on continuing the delay. The regulations had been scheduled to go into effect on Saturday.

description: Apple has a little iPod problem. And it is doing an amazing job of rising above it.

title: Your Comments on my Colombia Column
description: My Thursday column is about the Colombia free trade agreement. Im a little harsh on Obama and Clinton for opposing it  perhaps because Im sure they know better. When Bush says something silly to antagonize the world and cost us international standing, theres always the possibility he really believes it. But Obama and Clinton are so smart and savvy about international affairs that the only excuse is that theyre pandering.

The two Internet giants also said they had answered questions from Justice Department officials about their arrangement.

title: McCain and His Shadow

title: No crisis in Palm BeachEstate sells for record $81.5 million
Bostons High Entry Barrier
description: The Boston Marathon, won for the fourth time by Robert Cheruiyot on Monday, requires strict requirements for entry, and most runners find the standards all but impossible to meet. As Gina Kolata writes in The Times today, "All of this helps make the Boston marathon unique and makes running it a dream for many athletes. It also raises two questions: Why does the Boston Marathon make it so hard to enter? And how often do runners sneak in by trading or buying one another's entries?"

title: Spoleto Festivals to Renew Their Ties
description: No sparks yet, but the passion is rekindling.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about John King, the CNN political reporter, misstated the size of the increase in CNNs prime-time viewership in February. It rose 130 percent  not 15 percent  compared with February 2007. Because of an editing error, the article misidentified the network that presents Meet the Press, whose host, Tim Russert, commented on Mr. King. It is NBC  not MSNBC, which rebroadcasts the program.

title: Six Suspects Will Be Tried a Third Time in Sears Plot
description: MIAMI  Federal prosecutors said Wednesday that they would try for a third time to convict six men accused of conspiring to destroy the Sears Tower in Chicago and join the ranks of Al Qaeda.

title: Remote Comes Prepared to Learn
description: A universal remote needs to know all the commands for your entire pile of audio and video gear. But it must come preloaded with all the devices instructions, or you need to connect it to a PC or teach it the commands by aiming it at the original remotes.

title: The Not Michael Jordan Club: Its Growing
description: For a league that seems to be reinventing itself every three years or so, the N.B.A. sports a fan base and chattering class that are awfully concerned with its players' legacies. It is an old maxim that an athlete's career is never quite complete unless he wins a championship. But there's a difference between the way Ernie Banks and Barry Sanders are remembered, and the way, say, Charles Barkley, Patrick Ewing and Karl Malone are remembered.

title: A Camera With a Range So Big, No Extra Lenses Are Needed
description: At first glance, Nikons Coolpix P80, due out next month, looks a lot like a digital single-lens reflex camera. Look a little closer and youll see that the lens is a lightweight zoom fixed to the compact body.

title: Tip of the Week: Voice-Activated Web Search for Your BlackBerry
description: If you find tapping out search terms on your BlackBerrys keyboard frustrating, make your fingers stop walking and just start talking. Yahoos oneSearch software offers voice-activated control that lets you speak your keywords out loud to send the browser running for results for movie listings, restaurant addresses, Web sites and more. The voice-enabled version of oneSearch can be downloaded to your phone at m.yahoo.com/voice. Although it currently works only on certain BlackBerry models like the Curve and the Pearl, Yahoo plans to add more devices soon.

title: CURRENTS | A Stool for Summer That Smiles at Rain
description: Puddles that form on outdoor seating are as irksome as they are commonplace, a problem that Bottega Montanas Spool stool was designed to address. The 17 1/2 -inch- tall wooden stool has a 15-inch-diameter seat with a hollow center, allowing for drainage and encouraging air circulation, so the wood can breathe.

title: What Audiences Havent Seen Before
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Novelty as cause for celebration! In ballet, an art so often stuffed with the same old chestnuts, it takes real courage to promote creativity rather than conservation. Diaghilev remains the exemplar here, but in this regard the United States has led the world for several decades. The concept of presenting a multiple-program bonanza of new choreography goes back to the 1972 Stravinsky Festival of New York City Ballet. That event included old works too, but its wealth of innovation became the stuff of legend. At least four of the new works choreographed then have gone into international ballet repertory.

title: Bona Fide or a Bust? Dont Rush to Judgment
description: As soon as the N.F.L. draft ends Sunday, the judging will commence. Fans, the news media and all other self-proclaimed draft experts will grade teams on their selections, even though the picks will not play meaningful football for more than four months.

title: Visible Man
description: I TRY to keep a low profile. Maybe you see me in the hallway but dont know my name. Say hi to me in the coffee room but dont really know me. I break my silence now because of this election mess. Before the primary in Pennsylvania this week, Bill Clinton was doing magic tricks  now you see the race card, now you dont. Geraldine Ferraro and Bob Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television, have been complaining that Barack Obama is leading in the Democratic presidential campaign only because of his skin color. Multimillionaire TV pundits are lecturing the common man on how outraged they should be about Mr. Obamas elitism.

title: Wind Chills Critics
description: A new London musical version of Gone With the Wind doesnt seem destined for a long run after many critics took their cue on Wednesday from Rhett Butlers parting words of disdain, Reuters reported. Frankly my dear, its not up to too much, Quentin Letts wrote in The Daily Mail. Frankly, my dear, its a damn long night, Charles Spencer of The Daily Telegraph wrote of the show, which runs more than three and a half hours at the New London Theater in the West End. Frankly this show is damned, The Evening Standard asserted. Oh for the fire and passion of Gable and Leigh, said Benedict Nightingale of The Times of London, recalling the stars of the classic 1939 film adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning 1936 Margaret Mitchell novel. Directed by Trevor Nunn, renowned for his staging of Cats and Les Misrables, the musical has a book, lyrics and music by Margaret Martin, a novice. It stars Darius Danesh, a British television talent show discovery, as Rhett Butler, and Jill Paice as Scarlett OHara.

title: Acting With Intent?
description: The San Antonio Spurs have revived the Hack-a-Shaq strategy in building a 2-0 lead over the Phoenix Suns, intentionally fouling Shaquille O'Neal even when he doesn't have the ball. This turns the game into a slow-motion hugging match. Should the league consider altering the rules, and if so, how? Or is the strategy a legitimate way to exploit a player's poor free-throw shooting?

title: Correction: But Enough About Them
description: An article last Thursday about Reeve Lindbergh, a daughter of the aviator Charles Lindbergh, described speeches he gave during World War II incorrectly. The speeches, made after the war broke out in Europe but before the United States had joined it, were anti-interventionist, not pro-Nazi.

title: 'Kitchen' Warms Fox
description: Singing, dancing and cooking topped the ratings on Tuesday as reality series on Fox and ABC attracted the most viewers for the night. Foxs American Idol dominated the competition as usual, drawing 24 million viewers at 8, Nielsen reported. At 9, the results episode of ABCs Dancing With the Stars led its time slot with 17.5 million viewers, but Foxs Hells Kitchen (11.6 million) managed to earn higher ratings in the hour among adults 18 to 49. Fox easily finished first for the night, followed by ABC, which struggled during the 8 oclock hour with two episodes of According to Jim, averaging 4.2 million viewers. ABCs Boston Legal drew 10.5 million viewers at 10. CBS was third, faring well at 8 with NCIS (14.1 million) but struggling with Big Brother at 9 (6.7 million) and 48 Hours at 10 (4.8 million). NBC finished fourth in total viewers while edging past CBS for third place in the 18-to-49 set, largely because it topped the 10 oclock hour with Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (11.5 million).

title: Pressed by the Economy, Starbucks Lowers Its Forecast
description: For some consumers, not even the morning cup of coffee is immune from economic woes.

title: Met Shifts Gears for Park Series
description: The Metropolitan Opera is replacing its summer parks series with one free mega-concert this year. The soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna, operas married power couple, right, will sing a musical bon-bon program of arias and duets in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on June 20, the Met said on Wednesday. Six jumbo screens will be placed in the Long Meadow, which can accommodate 150,000 people. Bank of America will provide 25,000 bus and subway passes for the event. Usually, the Met produces concert performances of entire operas by lesser-known singers in Central Park and the other boroughs in the summer. Peter Gelb, the Met general manager, called the plan an experiment. We upped the ante, to make it feel more like an event, he said.

title: Israel and Syria Hint at Progress on Golan Heights Deal
description: JERUSALEM  Peace overtures between Israel and Syria moved up a gear on Wednesday when a Syrian cabinet minister said that Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel had sent a message to President Bashar al-Assad to the effect that Israel would be willing to withdraw from all the Golan Heights in return for peace with Syria.

title: Seeing the World More Clearly
description: Q. When I zoom in on a photo using the Google Earth program, the image is sometimes blurry. Is there a way to fix this, or are there other similar services available that have better picture quality?

title: To Screen or Not for Lung Cancer: Does It Make a Difference?
description: For as long as I can remember, a diagnosis of lung cancer has been virtually a death sentence. Most victims die within a year or two, and some 95 percent ultimately succumb to the disease. So it is hard not to be intrigued by a bold claim that most lung cancers could be cured through a screening program to detect tumors early and remove them promptly.

title: For Obama, a Struggle to Win Over Key Blocs
description: It is the question that has hung over Senator Barack Obamas presidential campaign, and it loomed large on Tuesday night after his loss to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Pennsylvania: Why has he been unable to win over enough working-class and white voters to wrap up the Democratic nomination?

title: How to Live Longer Without Really Trying
description: MY neighbor Bruce has the healthiest lifestyle on the block. He eats small portions and skips dessert. He walks to work. His hobbies  coaching Little League, riding his bike and taking his dog on hikes  all involve getting wholesome, fresh air.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A chart with an article in some editions on April 16 about the 2007 tax return of Gov. David A. Paterson of New York and his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson  which listed a single charitable donation of $150 on a combined income of $269,815  misstated the year that the average deduction for those in the governors income range was $8,528. It was 2005, the last year for which such figures are available  not 2007.

title: City Orders Safety Check of High Risk Building Sites
description: A day after the resignation of the citys embattled buildings commissioner, the Bloomberg administration announced a $4 million plan Wednesday to hire specialized engineers to inspect high risk construction sites citywide and develop new procedures to make the work safer.

title: Bullies, Addicts and Losers: A Poet Loves Them All
description: A couple of years ago, writing in Poetry magazine, August Kleinzahler lighted a string of firecrackers under Garrison Keillor and his Writers Almanac segments on National Public Radio.

title: Correction: Everyones a Critic
description: An article last Thursday about perfume critics who present their views in books and magazines and on the Web misstated the Web address for Now Smell This, a perfume blog. It is nowsmellthis.blogharbor.com.

title: When the Waters Yield Macabre Secrets
description: In any standard lexicon, the term floater refers to a few whimsical images of nature: a gull on the breeze, a passing cloud.

title: A Four-Gigabyte Thumb Drive With Two Safety Nets
description: Just when it was becoming really difficult to get excited about U.S.B. thumb drives, SanDisk unveils the Cruzer Titanium Plus. This four-gigabyte drive automatically copies its entire contents to an online backup location, ensuring that even if the drive is lost, you still have your precious data.

title: Life After That Very Profitable Fake Witch
description: The Blair Witch Project, the cult hit released in 1999, ends without ending, but the viewer is pretty sure that what follows after the abrupt camera cut is quite grim. And one of the people who never seemed to make it back from those dark, awful woods was Daniel Myrick, the films co-director.

title: A Son Peers at His Father and Finds a Sociopath
description: At 42 Augusten Burroughs is the first to admit he has written more memoirs than anyone my age should be entitled to write.

title: With First Car, a New Life in China
description: SHUANG MIAO, China  Li Rifu packed a lot of emotional freight into his first car. Mr. Li, a 46-year-old farmer and watch repairman, and his wife secretly hoped a car would improve the odds of their sons, then 22 and 24, of finding girlfriends, marrying and producing grandchildren.

title: Order Against Union Is Lifted in California
description: A judicial officer in Oakland on Tuesday lifted an order that the Service Employees International Union and its president, Andrew L. Stern, not stalk or harass officials of the California Nurses Association. The officer, Jon Rantzman of Alameda County Superior Court, decided that the nurses association did not provide sufficient evidence to justify the order that he issued on Thursday. In recent weeks, the union sent members to California to confront officials in the nurses group after its organizers campaigned in Ohio to undermine the service employees effort to unionize 8,300 hospital workers there. The service employees said their members were not stalking or harassing nurses union officials, but were exercising their free speech.

title: McCain Says Government Isnt Povertys Sole Solution
description: INEZ, Ky.  Senator John McCain walked in the literal footsteps of President Lyndon B. Johnson on Wednesday as he stood near the now-abandoned Appalachian front porch where Johnson declared a war on poverty. Forty-four years later, Mr. McCain said, We have a lot to do.

title: Giant Vacuum Cleaners and Green, Green Grass
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that when choreographers become directors of dance companies, they tend to hog repertory space. This is not usually a good thing.

title: Joness Relay Teammates Will Try to Keep Their Medals
description: Marion Joness relay teammates announced Wednesday that they planned to appeal a decision by the International Olympic Committee that stripped them of medals they won in the 2000 Sydney Olympics because of Joness admitted use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: CORRECTION: FOR THE RECORD
description: A report by The Associated Press in some editions on Sunday about the Major League Soccer tie between the Red Bulls and the New England Revolution misstated, in some copies, the amount of time missed by striker Juan Pablo ngel of the Red Bulls when he aggravated a hamstring strain. It was the entire second half, not the final 30 minutes. The article also misidentified the player who committed the foul that led to a direct free kick for the Revolution that tied the game at 1-1. It was Chris Leitch, not Jeff Parke.

title: Bush and Jordans King Meet on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush and King Abdullah of Jordan met privately for breakfast on Wednesday morning, as the White House tries to resuscitate the ailing Middle East peace talks before Mr. Bush leaves for Israel next month.

title: Amazon Gains, Despite an Economic Slowdown
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An economic slowdown has not affected the nations largest online retailer, Amazon.com.

title: Illuminating a Rare Portrait of Stravinsky on Piano
description: If Stravinskys piano music isnt especially well known, there are a number of reasonable explanations. There isnt much of it, and what there is doesnt tend toward hummable tunes, surging passions or flamboyant calisthenics. Listening to a whole program of it, like the one Stephen Gosling and Eric Huebner presented in the chapel of St. Bartholomews Church on Tuesday night, you could admire much while being seduced by comparatively little.

title: Maoist Ex-Rebels Are Likely Leaders of Nepal Transition
description: NEW DELHI  Nepal, the worlds last Hindu kingdom, appeared Thursday to be on the verge of Maoist-led rule, as election results signaled that the countrys former guerrillas had won the largest share of seats for a Constituent Assembly in the landmark vote held this month.

title: Cannes Festival Lineup
description: The 61st Cannes Film Festival will present films by Clint Eastwood and Steven Soderbergh in a main competition that will be reduced to 20 films this year from 22 in 2007, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Eastwood will be represented by Changeling, a mystery set in the 1920s in Los Angeles starring Angelina Jolie as the mother of a kidnapped child. Mr. Soderbergh will present Che, a four-hour film about the Argentine revolutionary Che Guevara. Other films in the competition will come from Belgium, Turkey, France, Argentina, Brazil and Italy. Eight of the directors have never previously appeared in the main competition. Woody Allens Vicky Cristina Barcelona and Steven Spielbergs Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull will be shown out of competition. The festival, its opening and closing films yet to be announced, will run from May 14 through 25.

title: After Threats, Danes and Dutch Close Embassies Abroad
description: Citing serious threats, Denmark closed its embassy in Afghanistan and relocated all staff members, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Daniel Laursen, said in a telephone interview. He said that Denmarks embassy in Algeria was also evacuated and closed this week and that a separate threat prompted that closing. The Netherlands also closed its embassy in Afghanistan and placed its staff in a temporary location due to the security situation, said a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Han Peters.

title: Apple Riding a 51% Jump in Mac Sales
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Signs of a consumer slowdown abound in the United States, but Apple customers appear not to have noticed.

title: Bring on the Right Biofuels
description: Fads come fast and furious in our viral age, and the reactions to them can be equally ferocious. Thats what were seeing right now with biofuels, which everyone loved until everyone decided they were the worst thing since the Black Death.

title: Kips Bay: Coloring In the White Boxes
description: THE strange and painful metamorphosis of Manhattan House, the vast pale brick building on East 66th Street, from a genteel and dowdy rental into a luxury condominium, entered a new stage last week. On Friday afternoon, on a slim penthouse terrace on the 21st floor, Larry Laslo, a veteran interior designer, fell to his knees before a concrete Buddha head the size of a large pouf and said, This is where you come to pray for the mortgage.

title: Making Long-Distance Partnerships Work
description: Technology makes it possible to run a business from practically anywhere on the planet. But what if your business partner lives in a different city or a different time zone? How do long-distance partners make it work?

title: Better Roses Than Cocaine
description: BOGOT, Colombia

title: G.M. Says Toyota Has Lead in Global Sales Race
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Wednesday that the slowdown in the United States market had led to a first-quarter sales decline that gave Toyota the early lead in this years global sales race.

title: Tankleff Awaits Decision on Future
description: WESTBURY, N.Y.  The very first thing Martin H. Tankleff ever looked up on the Internet was martytankleff.org, the elaborate Web site created in the campaign to free him. Having spent 17 years in prison, Mr. Tankleff was an Internet novice, and pulled the site up on a cousins computer, finding Marty Didnt Do It T-shirts ($15), an extensive archive of legal briefs, and the Marty Blog, which chronicles his life and times. He clicked and scrolled through it with delight.

title: Hoping to Be Feeder for N.F.L., a League Plans to Open in 09
description: From the United States Football League to the XFL, alternatives to the N.F.L. have traditionally fizzled not long after the first kickoff.

title: What's On Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY Betty (America Ferrera, above) plans a romantic 24th birthday with Henry (Christopher Gorham), but her plans go up in smoke when Charlie (Jayma Mays), the mother of his child, makes a surprise appearance. Meanwhile Wilhelmina (Vanessa Williams) tries to sabotage the budding relationship between her sister, Renee (Gabrielle Union), and Daniel (Eric Mabius) by hinting at an ugly past.

title: To Raise Their Offense, the Mets Lower Delgado
description: WASHINGTON  It took Manager Willie Randolph until May 23 of last season to drop a struggling Carlos Delgado to sixth in the batting order. He did not wait as long this year, moving Delgado down in an effort to revive a stagnant offense that scored two runs and managed a total of 10 hits in two losses in Chicago.

title: Wharton's House Wins a Reprieve
description: The Mount, Edith Whartons house in Lenox, Mass., which has been in financial trouble for months, has been given another reprieve. In February a local bank that had been lending money to the Edith Wharton Restoration, the organization that owns and maintains the house, to cover operating expenses, threatened to begin foreclosure unless the Mount raised $3 million by March 24. The deadline was later extended to April 24, and Hannah Burns, one of the trustees, said on Wednesday that it had been pushed back yet another month, to May 24, which means that the house will now be able to open for visitors as scheduled on May 9. So far more than $800,000 of the needed sum has been raised.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The continuation of an article on Sunday about a Pentagon effort to use military analysts to generate favorable news coverage carried 10 paragraphs that were partly obscured in some editions by a chart.

title: No Ebert at His Festival
description: On doctors orders, Roger Ebert, below, will have to forgo a trip to Urbana-Champaign, Ill., for the 10th annual Ebertfest film festival, which began on Wednesday and continues through Sunday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ebert wrote in his blog on The Chicago Sun-Times Web site (suntimes.com) that doctors had told him to remain in a Chicago hospital, where he is recovering from hip surgery after a fall. A Sun-Times film critic for more than four decades, Mr. Ebert, 65, has had a series of operations for cancer in recent years.

title: Garbage Bags Save Man Who Jumps From Burning Room
description: Wednesday night was garbage night in part of East Harlem, and it may have saved a man who jumped from his flame-engulfed apartment.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,034 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

title: CORRECTION: FOR THE RECORD
description: A picture caption with an article in some editions on Wednesday about the history of corruption in the New York City Buildings Department misstated, in some copies, the location of a construction site where a crane collapse killed seven people last month. The site is on East 51st Street, not East 50th.

title: Dragging Big Business to Disclosure
description: Resisting every inch of the way, the powerful National Association of Manufacturers has finally agreed to follow Congresss new ethics law and disclose which of its members have been funding its lobbying operations on Capitol Hill.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Darwin and the Plant World

title: Lights. Camera. Cellphone Action.
description: Who says cellphones are good only for talking? Today they are bringing together two unlikely brand names: Nokia and Spike Lee.

title: Penguins Fans Are Certain to Boo When Jagr Takes Flight
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Being booed comes with being Jaromir Jagr.

title: McCain Revisits War on Poverty With His Own Ideas
description: INEZ, Ky.  Senator John McCain walked in the literal footsteps of President Lyndon Baines Johnson on Wednesday as he stood near the now-abandoned Appalachian front porch where Johnson declared a war on poverty, and the senator then said, 44 years later, that we have a lot to do.

title: White House Influence Is Cited in Corruption Trial
description: WASHINGTON  A prominent Illinois Republican Party leader may have tried to use his friendship with the former White House political aide Karl Rove to push for the ouster of the United States attorney in Chicago, a federal prosecutor said in court on Wednesday.

title: Credit Suisse Reports $2.1 Billion Loss
description: PARIS  The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss banking giant, on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss nearly three times worse than analysts had expected as it wrote down $5.3 billion in soured investments.

title: Judge Rules on Terrorism Watch Lists
description: A federal magistrate judge in Chicago has ruled that protecting state secrets is not a valid argument for the government to refuse to tell American citizens whether they are on the terrorism watch list, the Terrorist Screening Database. The ruling, signed on April 16 but made public by the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois on Wednesday, ordered the Department of Homeland Security and the F.B.I. to give the court the files regarding the 10 Muslim or Arab-American plaintiffs who filed a lawsuit starting in 2005, seeking court protection from what they contend is unwarranted harassment at the border. The magistrate judge, Sidney I. Schenkier of Federal District Court, said the court could review the information to decide whether it should remain classified. The F.B.I. said it had no comment.

title: Russian Readers Comment on Article About Religion
description: MOSCOW  What do Russians themselves think about the ties between the Russian Orthodox Church and the Kremlin, or about the rights of Protestants? The New York Times posted a translated version of the accompanying article on its Russian-language blog on livejournal.com on Tuesday. The entry was among the top 10 most read in the Russian blogosphere, according to livejournal.com, and generated nearly 1,000 comments.

title: Republican Senators Block Pay Discrimination Measure
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked a measure intended to overturn a Supreme Court decision limiting pay discrimination suits in a politically charged vote certain to be replayed in the presidential and Congressional campaigns.

title: Room to Improve
Drug Executive Is Indicted on Secret Deal
description: A former senior vice president at Bristol-Myers Squibb has been indicted on federal charges of negotiating a secret pact between the company and a generic drug maker and then hiding the deal from federal regulators.

title: City Order to List Calories Is Delayed for Appeal
description: A federal appeals judge on Wednesday delayed the enforcement of new city rules requiring calorie counts to be posted alongside prices in some restaurants.

title: CORRECTION: FOR THE RECORD
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about a split in the Democratic primaries between older and younger voters misidentified a Clinton supporter from Sullivan County, Pennsylvania. Of the two women shown looking over a pamphlet, Germaine Donahue was at left. (The woman on the right was not identified.)

title: About $100 Each to Customers in 06 Blackout
description: Customers in western Queens can expect to receive about $100 each from Consolidated Edison as compensation for having to sweat through nine days without power in July 2006, according to officials who have been briefed on the settlement.

title: Recreating 19th-Century Trek, A&E and History Channel March to Reinvention
description: If we can presume that David Livingstone  he of the 19th-century expedition to find the source of the Nile  was the original survivor of popular imagination, then why shouldnt Mark Burnett  he of the television phenomenon Survivor  find common ground with him?

title: Violas Outplay Pansies
description: Q. Last year I planted pansies and violas together in partial shade in good soil. But although the seedlings seemed almost identical, the violas made dense growth covered with flowers while the pansies got leggy, bloomed sparsely and died. Why didnt they both do well?

title: Men in Plaid Do Mix
description: TO someone learning English, or learning how to dress, it is not the four-syllable words or the obscure necktie knots that provoke the most confusion. It is the simplest idioms  say, That doesnt go  that are the most baffling.

title: A Seemingly Ordinary Result Attained by Extraordinary Play
description: A columnist looks for a deal in which declarer found a brilliant play to snatch victory, or where a defender produced a coup to defeat an impregnable-looking contract. A defense that turns down one into down two usually does not merit much attention, but the diagramed deal, in which that happened, features probably the best defense in the last 12 months.

title: For Bronx Water Plant Being Built 10 Stories Down, a Towering Price Tag
description: In a city of big projects, it ranks among the biggest. New York Citys Department of Environmental Protection is building one of the largest water filtration plants in the world in a 10-story-deep hole it blasted out of bedrock in the Bronx. When completed in 2012, the plant, capable of purifying 300 million gallons of water a day, will be buried there.

title: China Eases Trading Rules and Markets Soar
description: SHANGHAI  Stock prices soared in China on Thursday, gaining over 9 percent after the government moved to restore confidence in the market by reducing taxes on trades.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on April 16 about Joe Simon, who helped create Captain America and appeared at the New York Comic Con last weekend, misattributed a character to him and his partner, Jack Kirby. The Sandman was first written and drawn by Gardner Fox and Bert Christman  not by Mr. Simon and Mr. Kirby, who took it over later.

title: Keep It Short, and Cheap
description: Q. I thought S.M.S. text had to be kept short, but I seem to be able to send out longer messages anyway. Is the 160-character limit a myth?

title: Philadelphia Raises Enough Money to Retain a Masterpiece by Eakins
description: Its taken a citywide fund-raising effort and the sale of two paintings and two drawings by Thomas Eakins, but the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts have now managed to raise the entire $68 million needed to keep an Eakins masterpiece, The Gross Clinic, in Philadelphia.

title: Actors Talks Extended
description: Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers agreed on Wednesday to extend their current round of contract talks through May 2, they said in a joint statement.

title: Profit Declines, but Microsoft Tops Forecast
description: Microsoft may be struggling to buy Yahoo, but the giant software makers current business is humming along smoothly.

title: Delta and Northwest Post Losses on Revaluations
description: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, preparing to merge amid a steep industry downturn, reported a combined first-quarter loss of $10.5 billion on Wednesday, most of it an accounting recognition that the two carriers are worth far less than when they emerged from bankruptcy a year ago.

title: A Passion for Persia, Disneyland and Dolphins
description: KISH, Iran  The indoor dolphin show was in full swing as Hossein Sabet walked in to a burst of applause from the 1,200 people in attendance. Clad in tight beige equestrian pants and tall black boots, he waved at the crowd and went straight to his office behind the pool.

title: Today in Business
description: OVERSEAS DEBT COLLECTORS As the economy weakens and consumers struggle to pay their bills, debt collection is becoming a growing business for outsourcing companies.

title: Chvezs Takeover Spree
description: Venezuelas president, Hugo Chvez, is in political trouble. He is clearly hoping that a new expropriation spree will fire up his supporters, at least long enough to keep his allies from suffering heavy defeats in Novembers state and municipal elections.

title: Rocking Reunions
description: Dormant for 16 years but still influential, the British rock band My Bloody Valentine will embark on an American reunion tour this fall, according to the Web site The Daily Swarm (thedailyswarm.com). The group, led by Kevin Shields, is preparing a program and will play at an American edition of the British festival All Tomorrows Parties (atpfestival.com), from Sept. 19 to 21 in Monticello, N.Y. It will also release a new album this year. ... The reunion docket this summer includes the Feelies, a New Jersey new-wave group that was one of the most beloved local underground acts of the early 1980s. The Feelies will be at Maxwells in Hoboken, N.J., on July 1 and 2 as part of that clubs 30th-anniversary festivities, and will also open for the Sonic Youth free concert in Battery Park on July 4.

title: Demand Lifts Boeing and General Dynamics
description: Boeing and General Dynamics reported first-quarter profits on Wednesday that beat analysts estimates on rising demand for passenger and business jets and increased military spending.

title: Measuring Up, on the Doorway and on the Draft Board
description: AUDUBON, N.J.  The first charting of Joe Flaccos rising stock appears in the doorway to his familys living room, scratched in pencil on an avocado-green wall.

title: Stewards of James Brown Estate Sue Morgan Stanley
description: A dispute over the estate of the legendary soul singer James Brown has reached a bitter new pitch  on Wall Street.

title: Making a Home Away From Home for Hurricane Victims
description: BAKER, La.  It was not long after Hurricane Katrina, in late 2005, that local governments all over Louisiana started saying no to clusters of the tinny white shelters now known, infamously, as FEMA trailers.

title: In Surprise, Ford Swings to Profit in First Quarter
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said on Thursday that it earned $100 million in the first quarter, after a loss in the same quarter a year ago, a surprising improvement amid a slump in the United States market that has cut sales of lucrative trucks and sport utility vehicles.

title: What You Said
description: Here are some of your responses to last week's question, about the effect of the N.B.A.'s rule requiring players to spend a year in college:

title: Keeping Watch Where Rocks Abide
description: OJAI, Calif.

title: Democrats Divided Over Effect of Long Campaign
description: On Wednesday morning, the hope crowd woke up feeling just a little less hopeful.

title: Long Live the Dress (for Now)
description: ANYONE who pays attention to fashion may want to know that those in charge of deciding these things have pronounced doom on the dress. They, meaning mainly fashion editors and designers, claim the dress is dead. Kaput. Three years of women in dresses is enough.

title: In Europe, Attempts to Fit iPhone to Needs of Service Providers
description: Will the iPhone change Europe? Or will Europe change the iPhone? Two recent newspaper reports say that Europe appears to be exerting the greater influence so far.

title: Daphne Strips Down
description: SPRING cleaning, as anyone with a small closet would recognize, is a journey that ends either by giving up too much, or simply giving up.

title: Flirting With $4 at His Pump, Old-School Gas Man Looks Back
description: WEST HARRISON, N.Y.

title: CURRENTS | A Sale of Woodard Weave Rugs and Runners
description: Woodard Weave rugs, which are based on 19th-century American Shaker and Amish designs, will go on sale Monday. The sale will include runners, area rugs and room-size carpets in patterns like Cornwall, Bristol and Georgetown (left, from top to bottom), many of them floor or factory samples, odd sizes and remnants. The rugs, normally $19.50 a square foot, will be reduced in price by 40 to 75 percent. Not all patterns will be available in all sizes. Through May 7 (except Saturday and Sunday), at 37-24 24th Street (38th Avenue), Long Island City. For directions and information: (212) 988-2906.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 23, 2008

title: Trying to Connect in a Crowd
description: LOVE is all you need, Subaru declares in a push for its 2009 models  along with all-wheel drive, a safety pedal system, low-emission engines and an environmentally correct plant.

title: Rift Over Zimbabwe Unity Plan
description: JOHANNESBURG  As Zimbabwes political impasse drags into its fourth week, talk of a power-sharing deal between the governing party and the opposition came to the fore Wednesday, though both sides indicated they were unprepared for the compromises that would be required.

title: Revered New Jersey Imam, Facing Deportation, Has Interfaith Support
description: PATERSON, N.J.  For a dozen years, Mohammad Qatanani has supported the members of the Islamic Center of Passaic County by speaking at funerals, hashing out ethical dilemmas and sometimes opening his home to domestic-violence victims at a moments notice.

title: Former Patriots Video Assistant Reaches Deal With N.F.L.
description: After more than two months of negotiations and dozens of proposals, lawyers for the N.F.L. and Matt Walsh, a former Patriots video assistant, came to an agreement Wednesday. Now, Walsh can share what information he says he has regarding New Englands videotaping practices.

title: South Korea Faces Question of Corporate Control
description: SEOUL, South Korea  It was a scene that stunned South Korea. Lee Kun-hee, the reclusive chairman of the Samsung Group, the conglomerate that dominates this countrys dynamic economy, abruptly resigned amid criminal indictments, apologizing in disgrace.

title: Sadr Tells Forces Not to Attack Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  Under pressure from Iraqi government troops and the American military, Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers to stop the bloodshed, unite with all Iraqis and focus their firepower on driving out the occupation forces, meaning the United States military and its foreign allies.

title: Corrections
description: The Arts

title: North Carolina G.O.P. to Run Ad Using Obamas Ex-Pastor
description: Despite objections from Senator John McCain, the North Carolina Republican Party is planning to roll out a television advertisement on Monday attacking two Democrats who are running for governor by linking them to Senator Barack Obama and playing a clip of his former pastor excoriating the United States.

title: New Jobs Set for 2 Generals With Iraq Role
description: WASHINGTON  Under a plan announced at the Pentagon on Wednesday, the two commanders most closely associated with President Bushs current strategy in Iraq would be elevated into new posts with responsibilities extending into the next administration over the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: France: Sarkozy Still Undecided on Beijing Games, to Check Allies
description: Jean-David Levitte, the chief diplomatic adviser to President Nicolas Sarkozy, said the president would consult with fellow European Union leaders before deciding whether to boycott the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Beijing. France will take over the European Unions six-month rotating presidency on July 1, putting the country in charge of the 27-nation bloc during the Olympic Games.

title: A Downside to Digital TV
description: MIKE DUFFY wanted to be ready to switch from over-the-air analog TV broadcasts to an all-digital signal that will occur across the country next February. His Chattanooga, Tenn., hilltop home was nearly in the line of sight to a nearby TV station antenna and he had never had a problem getting analog TV signals.

title: Worker Hurt in Lincoln Center Fall
description: A construction worker at Lincoln Center was hospitalized after falling 30 feet from a scaffold on Wednesday night, according to the police and officials at the performing arts complex.

title: Children From Sect Are Dispersed by State
description: Scores of children from among the more than 400 who were seized from a polygamous sects ranch in west Texas three weeks ago are being dispersed across the state, to group homes and shelters as far as 500 miles away, according to the Associated Press and other news sources.

title: Club With a Past Survives, Even Without Any Liquor
description: The club where Sean Bell spent the final moments of his life celebrating at his bachelor party still occupies a narrow plot at 143-08 94th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. Half-naked women still twirl on poles, trying to interest dollar-tossing patrons. The A.T.M. with the high surcharge still occupies a corner in the back.

title: As Economy Slows, So Do Laser Eye Surgeries
description: Call it the Lasik indicator. With the weak economy forcing consumers to cut back on discretionary spending, the number of laser vision-correction surgeries has been falling  as it did during the last recession.

title: Santana Helps Mets End Skid at 3
description: WASHINGTON  There are no style points, no rewards for creativity or flair reflected on the scoreboard. A run is a run, counting the same whether achieved via error, home run or divine intervention. That is why there was no protesting inside the Mets clubhouse after Johan Santana shut down the Washington Nationals in a 7-2 victory Wednesday night to snap a three-game skid.

title: Hillarys Smackdown
description: Philadelphia

title: After the Smoke Cleared, Where Did All the Bingo Players Go?
description: Banning smoking at charity bingo games may have health benefits, but it is proving harmful to earnings.

title: CORRECTION: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on April 10 about the coming film The Incredible Hulk referred incorrectly to the portrayal of the Hulk in the 1978-82 television series about him in citing earlier depictions of the character. He did not speak.

title: Zuma Backs Zimbabwe Unity Idea
description: LONDON  One of South Africas most senior political leaders lent support Wednesday to the idea of forming a national unity government in Zimbabwe to resolve its deepening crisis.

title: Survivalist Spirit at the Milan Furniture Fair
description: MILAN

title: Footnote
description: Judgment day is coming for hosts of reality shows. The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences has created an Emmy Award to recognize outstanding host for a reality or reality-competition program, The Associated Press reported.

title: New-Home Sales Fall to Low Last Seen in 1990s
description: The worst days of the housing slump may lie ahead.

title: Levels of Carbon Dioxide in Atmosphere Increase
description: Atmospheric levels of carbon dioxide, the principal heat-trapping gas, are continuing to rise at an accelerating rate, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported. And after a decade of stability, levels of an even more potent heat-trapper, methane, rose as well. The agency said atmospheric levels of carbon dioxide reached nearly 385 parts per million last year, up from 280 in 1850 and an increase of 2.6 parts per million from 2006, chiefly from the burning of fossil fuels. The methane situation is less clear. Methane is produced naturally by swamps but also by activities including burning fossil fuels. The issue is important because climate experts have long worried that if Arctic permafrost thaws, the process would release potentially catastrophic amounts of methane into the atmosphere. In a statement, the agency said the most likely causes of the methane increase were economic development in Asia and emissions from Arctic wetlands. It said it was too soon to tell if the increase signals an Arctic thaw.

If there's any excuse to engage an automobile, it's for traveling to San Antonio's excellent collection of public golf courses. Westin La Cantera's Resort layout has played host to the P.G.A. Tour since 1995. Justin Leonard's up-and-down career includes three wins there; perhaps it's no surprise that the seventh fairway of this rolling Tom Weiskopf and Jay Morrish design overlooks a theme-park roller coaster.
