description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has postponed a plan to spray pesticides over several heavily populated counties this summer to fight the light brown apple moth, an unwelcome migr that threatens Californias critical agriculture industry.

title: Correction: Amid the Ghosts of Alabama
description: An article last Friday about Alabama ghost towns rendered incorrectly the name of the river where the former town center of St. Stephens was located. It is the Tombigbee River, as shown on the accompanying map, not the Tom Bigby River.

title: Plastic-Bottle Scare Is a Boon for Some
description: OTTAWA  Canadas decision to label as toxic a chemical that is used to make a popular form of plastic has created headaches for some makers of baby bottles, sports water bottles and other food and beverage containers.

title: Southfork Landing and Wyndham Resort and Residences Jac Beach
description: Southfork Landing

title: McCain Criticizes Katrina Response as Disgraceful
description: NEW ORLEANS  Senator John McCain took direct aim at the Bush administration on Thursday as he stood in the lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans, the area hardest hit by Hurricane Katrina in 2005, and declared that never again will a disaster of this nature be handled in the terrible and disgraceful way that it was handled.

title: Buyers Choice: Seaside Village or Waterfront Resort?
description: TWENTY-ODD years ago, cheap gas and cheap milk were leading attractions in the border town of Blaine, Wash.  at least for the steady flow of western Canadians who crossed into the area for regular visits.

title: Drama, Energetic Drives and Colorful Dynamics
description: It was clear in the opening bars of Mozarts Nozze di Figaro Overture that Charles Dutoit would have the New York Philharmonic performing at its vigorous and colorful best on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Thats usually the case when Mr. Dutoit is on the Philharmonics podium these days, but it wasnt always. It was hard not to compare the sizzlingly fast, finely polished Mozart reading with Mr. Dutoits puzzlingly bland appearances with the orchestra in the mid-1980s, when he was making magnificent recordings with a handful of ensembles and giving thrilling performances with the Montreal Symphony Orchestra in its frequent visits to New York.

title: A Town Loved for What It Is  and Isnt
description: WHEN local residents talk about the lure of Stuart, a dot-on-the-map place on the southeast coast of Florida, they often start by noting what it lacks: as in buildings taller than four stories or a downtown fast-food restaurant.

title: Court to Hear Challenge on Sect Children
description: SAN ANTONIO  A Texas appeals court agreed on Thursday to hear arguments over the legality of placing hundreds of children taken from a polygamous sects West Texas compound into foster care without granting their families individual hearings.

title: Pain of Foreclosures Spreads to the Affluent
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  This wooded town of roughly 60,000 on Long Island Sound  home to dozens of hedge funds, many millionaires and more than a few billionaires  is one of the wealthiest enclaves in the country. But even Greenwich is not immune to the wave of home foreclosures sweeping the nation.

title: Simon and Song Reunion: Celebrating a Lifes Work
description: Wheres Paul? somebody shouted during a lull halfway through American Tunes, the final stretch of Paul Simons monthlong residency at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. This indecorous question roused just a bit of awkward applause. Then the stage lights brightened, and out walked ... Josh Groban. Thats pretty funny, as cosmic rejoinders go.

title: S.E.C. Accuses Trader of Spreading Rumors
description: In what the Securities and Exchange Commission said was its first rumormongering case, a former securities trader settled accusations Thursday that he had spread false rumors to profit from a pending merger.

title: Bebe Barron, 82, Pioneer of Electronic Scores, Is Dead
description: Bebe Barron, who with her husband Louis composed the first electronic score for a feature film  the eerie gulps and burbles, echoes and weeeoooos that accentuated invisible monsters and robotic creatures in the 1956 science-fiction classic Forbidden Planet  died Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 82.

title: Starbucks Revamps Entertainment Unit
description: Starbucks shook up its entertainment division on Thursday in the latest bid by the company to invigorate its sagging sales.

title: Hudson Yards Project
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Places First
description: With the end of Andrew Lloyd Webber week on American Idol, Fox breezed to a first-place finish in the ratings on Wednesday. Nielsen estimated that 22.6 million viewers tuned in to Idol at 9 p.m., dominating all other programming. Fox earned smaller audiences in the low-rated 8 p.m. hour with the comedies Til Death and Back to You, which drew 6.2 million and 7.3 million viewers. Those shows lifted Fox to first in the hour among adults 18 to 49, edging past ABCs Wife Swap (5.9 million), CBSs Big Brother (6.7 million), and the first half of NBCs two-hour Deal or No Deal. NBC was second for the night over all, winning the 10 p.m. hour with Law & Order (12.6 million), which delivered its highest ratings since its season premiere. CBS finished third despite repeats from 9 to 11. ABC was fourth, drawing 5.4 million viewers for Supernanny at 9 and 5.2 million for Men in Trees at 10.

title: Knights, Unicorns and Persecution
description: To the Editor:

title: A World of Dancers, Stranded in a Transportation Limbo
description: The ingredients are many and complex in bahok, presented by the Akram Khan Company on Wednesday night at City Center. One of two premieres by Mr. Khan being performed during the troupes week at City Center, the piece features dancers from six countries, among them members of the National Ballet of China, who play passengers stranded in the limbo of an airport or train station where all communication has broken down. A timely topic indeed.

title: Companies Return Criticism From Darfur Group
description: AFTER taking criticism from activist groups over the last few months, some Olympic sponsors are starting to criticize right back.

title: How to Rescue a Faltering Airline System
description: To the Editor:

title: Write-Downs Give Credit Suisse $2.1 Billion Loss
description: PARIS  The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss banking giant, on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss nearly three times worse than analysts had expected as it wrote down $5.3 billion in soured investments.

title: Tamayos Trovador Is Again Up for Sale
description: TAMAYOS TROVADOR

title: That Book Costs How Much?
description: College students and their families are rightly outraged about the bankrupting costs of textbooks that have nearly tripled since the 1980s, mainly because of marginally useful CD-ROMs and other supplements. A bill pending in Congress would require publishers to sell unbundled versions of the books  minus the pricey add-ons. Even more important, it would require publishers to reveal book prices in marketing material so that professors could choose less-expensive titles.

title: Ford Posts a Profit, Surprising Wall Street
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company said on Thursday that it earned $100 million in the first quarter, a pittance compared with the $15.3 billion it lost in the previous two years but an astonishing improvement given a slump in the United States market that has ravaged sales of its most lucrative vehicles.

title: Rikers Officers Face Charges Involving Drugs and Bribes
description: Seven current or former New York City correction officers were arrested on Thursday on charges of taking bribes and trying to smuggle illegal drugs to prisoners at Rikers Island, the authorities said.

title: After Trading Scandal, Banker Gets I.T. Job
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the Socit Gnrale trader who used his knowledge of the French banks electronic risk controls to conceal billions in unauthorized bets, has a new job  at a computer consulting firm.

title: Black Leader in the House Sharply Criticizes Bill Clinton
description: One of the nations most influential African-American political leaders sharply criticized former President Bill Clinton on Thursday afternoon for what he called his bizarre conduct during the Democratic primary campaign.

title: Valuable Mural Is a Major Headache
description: Joy is usually the emotion felt when a $90,000 mural turns out to be valued at $15 million. Not so in the case of the art-rich, cash-poor Port Authority of Allegheny County, The Associated Press reported. In 1984 the agency installed in the Pittsburgh subway system a 60--by-13-foot tile mural, Pittsburgh Recollections, above, by Romare Bearden, who was paid $90,000. The station that housed the mural is to be demolished in an extension of the system, and the authority wanted to know the murals value before taking it down. The authority found out, and also learned that it would cost more than $100,000 a year to insure the work. We dont have the wherewithal to be a caretaker to such a valuable piece, said Judi McNeil, a Port Authority spokeswoman. The agency is looking for an organization to pay for removing, restoring and maintaining the mural.

title: What Darwin Saw Out Back
description: IN 1860, while studying primroses in the garden of Down House, his home in Kent, England, Charles Darwin noticed something odd about their blooms.

title: Probation, and Remorse, for Figure in Oil-for-Food Case
description: An Iraqi-American businessman who was ensnared in  and eventually cooperated with  the sprawling investigation into improprieties in the United Nations oil-for-food program was sentenced on Thursday in Manhattan to three years of probation.

title: Two Buddies, Several Tokes Over the Line
description: If you think the last seven years have been one long, dumb, dirty joke  or maybe if, sometimes, you just wish you could believe as much  then Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay, written and directed by Jon Hurwitz and Hayden Schlossberg, just might be the perfect movie for you. That it is, quite unapologetically, far from perfect in every respect almost doesnt matter. The simple fact that a movie exists with the title Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay is cause for hope. Or maybe for alarm. In any case, for a few laughs.

title: Bush Administration Releases Images to Bolster Its Claims About Syrian Reactor
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration released detailed photographic images on Thursday to support its assertion that the building in Syria that Israel destroyed in an airstrike last year was a nuclear reactor constructed with years of help from North Korea.

title: Pakistan Asserts It Is Near a Deal With Militants
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The Pakistani government is close to an agreement to end hostilities with the most militant tribes in its turbulent border area, whose main leader is accused of orchestrating most of the suicide bombings of recent months and the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

title: Criticism for Degree to Governors Daughter
description: West Virginia University showed seriously flawed judgment in awarding the daughter of the states governor a masters degree she did not earn, an independent panel has said in a report.

title: Swivel-Hipped Rebel and Restless Virgin Meet Cute
description: Brace yourself for a shock, gentle theatergoer. Theres no delicate way of putting this. Cry-Baby, the latest Broadway musical based on a John Waters movie, is ... tasteless.

title: Russian Aluminum Tycoon Buys 25% of Nickel Giant
description: MOSCOW  The aluminum tycoon Oleg V. Deripaska said Thursday that he had bought 25 percent of the Arctic mining company Norilsk Nickel, a deal that furthers Mr. Deripaskas quest to consolidate the Russian metals and mining industry.

title: A Man of High Style and Punk Tastes
description: JUST back from a downtown photo shoot for the Chuck Taylor sneakers he designs for Converse  those lucrative laceless ones were his invention  John Varvatos saunters into his Chelsea headquarters wearing a pair of limited-edition python-embossed black leather sneakers. Flashy as spats, but infinitely more practical. Because?

title: It Gets Late Early Out There
description: If in seven years you went from being a bouncing baby boy to Old Man River, you would most likely look around to try to figure out which mirror you had broken. But in the world of Major League Baseball, that is exactly what happens to you  if youre lucky.

title: Wachovia to Pay as Much as $144 Million in Marketing Case
description: The Wachovia Corporation, the banking giant, has agreed to pay as much as $144 million to end an investigation accusing the bank of allowing telemarketers to use its accounts to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims.

title: Cutoffs and Pleas for Aid Rise With Heat Costs
description: After struggling with soaring heating costs through the winter, millions of Americans are behind on electric and gas bills, and a record number of families could face energy shut-offs over the next two months, according to state energy officials and utilities around the country.

title: We, the People Behind the Abuse
description: A blockbuster of a documentary, Errol Morriss Standard Operating Procedure is an inquiry into the prisoner abuse scandal at Abu Ghraib. It is, predictably, a bleak, depressing movie, but if you stick around through the end credits, you may also be in for a few surprises. In addition to the usual complement of helpers  a research coordinator, a consultant on Iraq  the credits mention a costume designer, a wardrobe stylist, six hair and makeup people, an action consultant, an armorer, 5 set dressers, 7 animal handlers, 10 prop makers, 33 cast members and Danny Elfman, the longtime composer for Tim Burton.

title: Verdict Awaits Detectives in Death of Sean Bell
description: Seventeen months to the day since two bullets from a swarm of 50 fired by the police killed Sean Bell, the verdict in the case against three detectives arrives about 9 a.m. on Friday, with the judges decision sure to set off an outcry no matter what it is.

title: Opposition Clear Victor in Zimbabwe, U.S. Says
description: This article was reported by Celia W. Dugger, David Barboza and Alan Cowell and written by Ms. Dugger.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Chelsea Coach Avram Grant, who has a tense relationship with the news media despite his English Premier League clubs success, misstated the outcome of a game against Everton on April 17. Chelsea won, 1-0; the game was not a 1-1 draw.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,038 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Germaine Tillion, French Anthropologist and Resistance Figure, Dies at 100
description: Germaine Tillion, a major figure in contemporary French thought who used experiences studying peasants on the edge of the Sahara, fighting Nazis and surviving a concentration camp as compelling intellectual fodder, died on Saturday at her home in St.-Mande, France. She was 100.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 24, 2008

title: Pen Petitions China
description: With its annual World Voices Festival of International Literature coming to town next week, PEN American Center, the human rights organization for writers, is focusing on China as the Beijing Olympic Games approach. Next week a group of writers including Salman Rushdie and Edward Albee will present a petition to the Chinese Mission to the United Nations, calling for the release of 39 writers and journalists imprisoned in China. PEN has been working on the cases of four of those prisoners for several years. Larry Siems of PEN American Center said, We see this as an opportunity, in the middle of all the noise about China, to make sure that what is not lost is that there are very specific individuals in prison unjustly in violation of their right to free expression, and the Chinese government has the power to release them at a moments notice. On Monday PEN American Center will award its PEN/Barbara Goldsmith Freedom to Write Award to Yang Tongyan, a Chinese journalist serving a 12-year prison sentence for subversion. His lawyer, Li Jianqiang, will accept the award in his honor.

title: Lesson on How Not to Build a Navy Ship
description: With the crack of a Champagne bottle against its bow, the newly minted Navy warship, bedecked with bunting, slid sideways into the Menominee River in Wisconsin with a titanic splash.

title: U.S. Jews Create New Lobby to Temper Israel Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Several prominent American Jews have formed a new pro-Israel lobby as an alternative to traditional organizations that, they assert, often impede progress in the Middle East because of their generally reflexive support of Israel.

title: China Supporters Greet Olympic Torch in Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia  Thousands of people rallying in support of China swamped the route of the Olympic torch on Thursday as it passed through Canberra, adding a new dimension to the tarnished symbolism of the relay.

title: His Forearm Is Better, but Schneider Is Out With Infected Thumb
description: WASHINGTON  Brian Schneiders return to the Mets lineup lasted one day. Schneider left the team Thursday to have an infected left thumb examined at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York and was scheduled to remain hospitalized overnight as doctors tried to eliminate the infection with intravenous antibiotics.

title: Crede Returns to the White Sox, but for How Long?
description: CHICAGO  There were hours, too many depressing hours, when Joe Crede of the White Sox had doubts about his future. Not his baseball future, but his future as a healthy man. Crede experienced so much pain in the days after back surgery that diving for grounders or swinging a bat were not even pondered.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Thursday about the role of the weak economy in the declining number of patients who correct their vision with Lasik surgery misidentified the part of the eye that gets reshaped. It is the inner part of the cornea, not the lens. The article also overstated the scope of a medical study being designed by federal regulators and doctors groups. The study would look at only the outcomes of Lasik procedures. It would not include patients who have received implanted contact lenses.

title: Parking Rules for Orthodox Good Friday
description: Because of Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: A Robot as Conductor
description: Is it time for Lorin Maazel, Kurt Masur and other illustrious conductors to fear for their futures? A child-size robot from Honda will lead the Detroit Symphony Orchestra when it performs The Impossible Dream from Man of La Mancha on May 13 during a youth music program including the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, The Associated Press reported. With its bubble head, the Honda Asimo robot, above  the letters in its name stand for Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility  resembles a child in a space suit. It can walk, jog, wave, avoid obstacles and carry on simple conversations. Honda, which uses it to inspire students to study math and science, designed it to assist the elderly and disabled.

title: For a Pinball Survivor, the Game Isnt Over
description: MELROSE PARK, Ill.  Being inside a pinball machine factory sounds exactly as you think it would. Across a 40,000-square-foot warehouse here, a cheery cacophony of flippers flip, bells ding, bumpers bump and balls click in an endless, echoing loop. The quarter never runs out.

title: Soggy Game Ends With Chamberlains 1st Loss
description: CHICAGO  As he surveyed the field here two hours before the scheduled first pitch, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi all but sighed.

title: Sarkozy, Admitting Errors, Vows to Speed Up Change
description: PARIS  Acknowledging mistakes of both substance and image, President Nicolas Sarkozy on Thursday still vowed to accelerate his controversial program of systemic reform, arguing that France would sink in power and influence unless it changes its ways.

title: Fault-Finding in Dallas Between Controllers and Pilots Becomes a Problem for the F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Air traffic control supervisors in Dallas, caught in 2005 hiding instances in which planes had passed too closely, switched to blaming pilots for the incidents when they were actually the controllers fault, aviation officials said Thursday.

title: Musings on Life and Death, Guided by William Blake
description: Time Is the Mercy of Eternity: A Meditation in Four Acts is the kind of very grave title that should be read in a deep English accent, preferably by a thespian with a gravelly, somber voice. Named after a line in a poem by William Blake, it provides a hint at the ambitions of Deb Margolins overwritten and under-rehearsed quartet of one-acts, directed by Marc Stuart Weitz, about death, the afterlife and the decaying human body.

title: Ethics Panel Admonishes Domenici
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Ethics Committee admonished Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, on Thursday for creating an appearance of impropriety by telephoning the top federal prosecutor in New Mexico at home shortly before the 2006 midterm elections to ask whether an indictment was imminent in a politically sensitive case.

title: Iris Burton, 77, an Agent for Child Actors, Dies
description: Iris Burton, a chorus girl in the 1940s and 50s who later started a talent agency that represented many of the top juvenile actors in Hollywood, including River and Joaquin Phoenix and Henry Thomas, the wide-eyed little boy in E.T.: The Extraterrestrial, died on April 5 in Los Angeles. She was 77.

title: Hair-Raising Convergence of the Mystical and the Mundane
description: Mary stands on a crescent moon. Enveloped in mauve satin and blue velvet, hands prayerfully joined, she gazes with pensive beneficence upon a dark, pastoral landscape. Twelve twinkling stars circle her head, and clouds irradiated by golden light billow behind her.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Snoop Dogg Appeal Upheld
description: The rapper Snoop Dogg has come up a winner in the latest round of his battle with Britain, The Guardian of London reported. Last year the entertainer, whose real name is Calvin Broadus, was refused a visa for a tour after he and five members of his entourage were arrested during a reported melee at Heathrow Airport in 2006. In January an immigration judge, Nehar Bird, said he had found no evidence that Snoop Dogg was responsible for any public disorder. A video recording of the incident showed that at one point he was entertaining young children; he was twice pushed by a police officer and did not retaliate; he complied with an instruction to lie face down; and he did not resist when handcuffed. The Home Office appealed. On Wednesday a senior immigration judge, George Warr, upheld the January decision. The Home Office has until Wednesday to decide if it will appeal again. Snoop Doggs lawyer, Phillip Trott, said, It has been an appalling waste of public money to pursue this man.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: North Korea Redux
description: It is more than a little suspicious that the ever-secretive Bush administration has suddenly decided to go public with what it knows about North Koreas nuclear connection with Syria. After seven months of refusing to acknowledge Israels air strike last Sept. 6 on a suspected Syrian nuclear reactor, the intelligence community has now provided Congress with video images showing North Koreans inside the secret facility.

title: For Airlines, Runways Are the Danger Zone
description: WASHINGTON  The recent groundings of thousands of flights have raised flags about skipped airplane inspections and botched repairs to wiring.

title: A Visit to Old China, Before It Drowns
description: Imagine the Grand Canyon turned into a lake. That image is summoned by Yung Chang, the Chinese-Canadian director and occasional narrator of Up the Yangtze, an astonishing documentary of culture clash and the erasure of history amid Chinas economic miracle.

title: New-Home Sales Fall to Low Last Seen in Early 1990s
description: The worst days of the housing slump may lie ahead. Buyers vanished from the housing market in March, as sales of new homes plummeted to the lowest level since the housing recession of the 1990s, the Commerce Department said on Thursday.

title: Animated Look at the Virtue of Keeping on Keeping On
description: How to show children the hell that awaits them? The nerd-versus-mean-girl dualism that is a staple of adolescent television, film, fiction and life gets a new workout in The Mighty B! This smart and amusing animated series, which will be shown on Nickelodeon on Saturdays, features a lisping 9-year-old heroine named Bessie Higgenbottom (Amy Poehler), and her nemesis, a Paris-Hilton-in-training named Portia (Grey DeLisle). But because B skews younger, Bessie doesnt actually know that Portia is her nemesis.

title: Turner Landscape to Be Auctioned
description: A landscape by the British master J. M. W. Turner will be offered at auction by Sothebys in London on July 9 at a starting price of $10 million, Reuters reported. The oil-on-canvas painting, Popes Villa at Twickenham, a depiction of the destruction of the poet Alexander Popes house, was bought by the art patron John Leicester in 1808 as soon as it went on view in Turners gallery. In 1827 Leicester sold it to the collector James Morrison, whose descendants have passed it from generation to generation. Referring to the artists interest in Popes house, Emmeline Hallmark, head of British art at Sothebys, said Turner couldnt understand how an artifact from the past could be wantonly destroyed. The proceeds will help pay for the restoration of Sudeley Castle, where the work has hung for 40 years.

title: Polling Stations Quiet in Iran Parliamentary Election
description: TEHRAN  Polls opened in Tehran and other areas of Iran on Friday for runoff elections to fill the 82 seats in the 290-member Parliament in which there was not a clear winner in the first round.

title: A New Chapter on Cape Cod
description: WHEN Marylouise Oates bought her current house on Cape Cod in 2001, shed never seen the inside.

title: Top Sunni Bloc Is Set to Rejoin Cabinet in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs largest Sunni bloc has agreed to return to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis cabinet after a boycott of nearly a year, several Sunni leaders said Thursday. They cited a recently passed amnesty law and the governments crackdown on Shiite militias as reasons for the move.

title: Top N.F.L. Pick Exhales; Others Hold Breath
description: Jake Long was tossing passes to some children running quick out routes in Central Park on Thursday when one got away from him.

title: Italian Saint Stirs Up a Mix of Faith and Commerce
description: SAN GIOVANNI ROTONDO, Italy  The only visible parts of Padre Pio are his fingers, blackened now 40 years after he died. The palms, which once provoked sharp debates over how they came to be marked with the same wounds as Christs, are covered by his famous half gloves (replicas of which can be bought here for $8, or for $4.75, a Padre Pio snow globe).

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Leaving High Drama Behind for a Trip to Grovers Corners
description: Modesty and a taste for the ordinary are not operas usual ingredients. Thornton Wilders Our Town, in the operatic version by Ned Rorem, came to the Juilliard Opera Center on Wednesday night. Its just-folks serenity could only be American.

title: The Trouble With Not Being Earnest
description: Senator John McCain sells himself for the presidency as a champion of campaign finance reform, a sworn enemy of Congressional handouts and a maverick who is immune to the corrupting influence of big money. In two campaigns, he has vowed not to dispense favors to contributors.

title: Against Nationals, Not Much Goes Right for the Mets
description: WASHINGTON  A quick glance at the calendar reveals that, yes, it is still April and still early. There is more than enough time for the Mets to remedy their bullpen woes, their lackluster play and their paucity of clutch hitting, all of which conspired Thursday night to yield a dispiriting 10-5 loss to the National Leagues worst team, the Washington Nationals.

title: Torre Enjoys Underdog Status With Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES  With each Andruw Jones strikeout, each sign of Nomar Garciaparras frailty, each feeble evening at the plate and each day that the distance between the Arizona Diamondbacks and his Los Angeles Dodgers grows a little bit farther, Manager Joe Torre might find it easy to grow wistful for what he left behind.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Minor League Team as a Major Drawing Card to Scranton
description: SO, whats in a name?

title: Jimmy Giuffre, Jazz Musician, Is Dead at 86
description: Jimmy Giuffre, the adventurous clarinetist, composer and arranger whose 50-year journey through jazz led him from writing the Woody Herman anthem Four Brothers through minimalist, drummerless trios to striking experimental orchestral works, died on Thursday in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 86 and lived in West Stockbridge, Mass.

title: The Doctor Is in, and the Wounds Are Psychic
description: A hero with a dysfunctional childhood and an even more dysfunctional family; grisly and graphic deaths; alarming dreams and premonitions; strange coincidences that may be the product of paranoia or hidden conspiracies; obsessive thoughts and outrageous psychotic behavior: these have been the staples of Patrick McGraths fiction.

title: Britain: Suicide Bombers Farewell to Daughter Played in Court
description: A home video played in a suburban London courtroom where three Muslim men are on trial for allegedly helping the four British suicide bombers who carried out the London transit attack that killed 52 people in July 2005 showed one bomber, Mohammad Sidique Khan, the cells suspected leader, bidding farewell to his 6-month-old daughter and telling her, I have to do this thing for our future. The court heard that Mr. Khan, 30, made the tape eight months before he blew himself up at the Edgware Road subway station. Cradling the infant in his arms, Mr. Khan could be heard saying, Sweetheart, not long to go now, and Im going to really, really miss you. I absolutely love you to bits and you have been the happiest thing in my life. I just wish I could have been part of your life. But I have to do this for our future and it will be for the best in the long run. Prosecutors said the tape was among several that Mr. Khans wife gave to a friend who later handed them to the police. In a tape to be played later at the trial, prosecutors said, Mr. Khan says to his daughter: Be strong. Learn to fight. Take care of Mummy.

title: In Reversal, Families of Slain Auxiliary Officers Will Receive U.S. Benefits
description: Reversing rulings that had prompted public protests, the United States Department of Justice announced on Thursday that the families of two unarmed auxiliary police officers who were killed last year by a gunman in Greenwich Village were entitled to federal death benefits.

title: Making Their Way Back to the Garden
description: MAKING THEIR WAY

title: Britain: Day of Nationwide Strikes for More Pay, Led by Teachers
description: The embattled Labor government of Prime Minister Gordon Brown faced a fresh challenge when as many as 400,000 civil servants, more than half of them teachers, mounted a one-day strike to protest years of below-inflation salary increases. It was the teachers first nationwide walkout in 20 years, and the most widespread work stoppage since the Labor Party, which relies heavily on union support, came to power in 1997. It came as a series of missteps in managing the economy have contributed to a sharp fall in Labors popularity ratings. According to government figures, the average annual pay of Britains teachers is $67,000.

title: Learning on the Job About Birthing Babies
description: In the new comedy Baby Mama Tina Fey plays a 37-year-old single career woman who, desperate for a baby, hires a womb of her own in the dizzy, slap-happy form of Amy Poehler. The film never comes fully to term, as it were: the visual style is sitcom functional, and even the zippiest jokes fall flat because of poor timing. But, much like the prickly, talented Ms. Fey, it pulls you in with a provocative and, at least in current American movies, unusual mix of female intelligence, awkwardness and chilled-to-the-bone mean.

title: Peltz Offer Is Accepted by Wendys
description: After more than two years of bickering, Wendys International and Nelson W. Peltz have tied the knot.

title: A Sliver of Thrills
description: A would-be erotic thriller with no heat and zero chills, Deception has the kind of glassy, glossy sheen and risible story that mean to suggest Basic Instinct but instead invoke lesser laughers like Jade and Sliver. A miscast Ewan McGregor plays a mouse who falls in with a charismatic (or so the screenplay insists) stranger played by the miscast Hugh Jackman. One improbable thing leads to another, and suddenly the mouse is roaring, having been inducted into a sex club in which beautiful women in French lingerie crawl around on all fours as if auditioning for a remake of 9  Weeks. At one point a bony Michelle Williams shows up in a fabulous haircut and towering heels that would fell a lesser woman. Complications ensue.

title: Republican Lawmaker in a Heavily Democratic District Is Atop Election Hit List
description: State Senator Serphin R. Maltese strode slowly through the midmorning crowd at the Peter Cardella Senior Citizens Center like a shepherd corralling a weary but loyal flock. In the corridors and cafeteria, Mr. Maltese, 75, stopped repeatedly and leaned in to hear the greetings or gripes of his constituents  most of them Italian-Americans  who in the twilight of their lives have traded their neighborhood social clubs for centers for the elderly like this one in Ridgewood, Queens.

title: Hamptons Prep Work
description: DIANE SAATCHI, a senior vice president in the East Hampton, N.Y., office of the Corcoran Group, the real estate firm, doesnt need to check the calendar to know when early April has become late April has inched over to May.

title: Malevich Heirs Settle
description: The city of Amsterdam and the heirs of the Russian avant-garde painter Kasimir Malevich have reached an agreement in a long-running battle over the ownership of 14 works that the heirs had said were rightfully theirs. The city announced on Thursday at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam that the heirs would be given title to five important Malevich paintings owned by the city that have been in the Stedelijks collection for many years. In return, the heirs have agreed to drop claims to the other works and end a lawsuit filed against the city. The heirs had said that the 14 artworks were among more than 100 that Malevich took to Berlin in 1927 for an exhibition. When he was unexpectedly called back to the Soviet Union, he entrusted the art to several friends, including the German architect Hugo Hring. Malevich never returned to Germany (he died in 1935), and the Nazis banned such art as degenerate. Hring left Berlin in 1943 and died in 1958; that year his heirs sold the bulk of his Malevich collection, including more than 30 paintings, to the Stedelijk Museum.

The testimony by Dr. Kussman, the under secretary for health at the department, came in the fourth day of a trial in a lawsuit that accuses the department of providing inadequate mental health care. We dont obfuscate, he said, arguing that 80 percent of the recommendations made in a 2004 plan to address treatment problems had been put into effect. It is a very large plan, and we are working hard to complete the last 20 percent. Arturo Gonzalez, the lawyer questioning Dr. Kussman, repeatedly suggested that the department was deficient in tracking suicide rates. Internal agency e-mail released Monday revealed that 18 veterans a day commit suicide, four or five of them among the 5.6 million veterans the department treats.

title: Tom Cruise Returns to Oprah's Couch
description: Tom Cruise is scheduled to return to The Oprah Winfrey Show, nearly three years after an appearance that spawned countless YouTube parodies and jokes, The Associated Press reported. The two-part show will coincide with the 25th anniversary of Mr. Cruises film Risky Business. Ms. Winfrey will interview Mr. Cruise from his home in Telluride, Colo., for the first show on May 2, her production company said. On May 5 he will appear in Ms. Winfreys Chicago studio. Mr. Cruise became the butt of jokes after a May 2005 appearance on her show where he repeatedly jumped on her couch, saying that his love for his girlfriend, and now wife, Katie Holmes, was beyond cool.

title: F.D.A. Panel Urges More Data on Laser Vision Surgery
description: After hearing testimony from patients whose vision was impaired by laser surgery, a Food and Drug Administration panel said Friday that the agency should do a better job informing patients of the surgerys risks. It also recommended that a system that reports adverse medical incidents associated with laser vision surgery include data about poor quality of vision, to encompass the visual glares, starbursts, and halos commonly reported by patients with negative experiences. The F.D.A. recently recruited the National Eye Institute to study how patients quality of life has been affected by laser eye surgery.

description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Bruney May Miss the Season
description: CLEVELAND  Fortune did not smile on Brian Bruney on Thursday. He learned that his uncle was in a coma, his truck was damaged in an accident involving the 18-wheeler transporting it to New York, and his right foot was killing him.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Assails Irans Role in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  The government of Iran continues to supply weapons and other support to extremists in Iraq, despite repeated promises to the contrary, and is increasingly complicit in the death of American soldiers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Friday in a stark new assessment of Iranian influence.

title: Bad Inning by Pettitte Gives Game to Indians
description: CLEVELAND  Before a plague of bugs ensnared the Yankees here last October, the story of the night was Andy Pettitte. Under playoff pressure, with just one run of support, Pettitte stifled the Cleveland Indians, turning back all of their rallies for nearly seven innings.

title: Superdelegate Stalemate Shows No Sign of Easing
description: Jeanne Lemire Dahlman, a Montana superdelegate and rancher, has declared her allegiance to Senator Barack Obama. But she said voters in her state, whose primary is June 3, are thrilled by the unresolved Democratic nominating fight, which gives them a potential voice in a nominating process that has usually bypassed them.

title: Russia: Lawmakers Back Media Clampdown
description: Parliaments lower house gave initial approval to a bill that would allow courts to close media outlets that disseminate libelous or slanderous material. The move came after a newspaper published an article saying that President Vladimir V. Putin was getting divorced and marrying a young gymnast. Mr. Putin bluntly denied the report. The bill was approved nearly unanimously, but it faces additional votes before becoming law. Sometimes such legislation ends up being shelved, and even without the additional restrictions, the Kremlin has shown that it has the legal tools to clamp down on the media. The newspaper that published the article, Moskovsky Korrespondent, has suspended publication.

title: Continental and United Said to Be Closer to a Merger
description: United Airlines and Continental Airlines are getting closer to a merger agreement and would like to wrap up a deal by the end of next week, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said Friday.

title: Acquitted but Facing Uncertain Futures, Detectives Express Their Thanks
description: Four hours after their acquittal, Detectives Gescard F. Isnora, Michael Oliver and Marc Cooper appeared in a room crowded with reporters and cameras, speaking publicly for the first time since Sean Bell died in a hail of 50 police bullets on his wedding day in November 2006. The detectives remarks were brief and, with the exception of Detective Coopers, all but stripped of emotion.

title: Levitation and Smoking: Signature Images in Video Works
description: Few things say serious art like a darkened gallery and multiple video screens, which makes Marian Goodman one of the most serious galleries in town. In side-by-side solo shows through Wednesday, it is screening new work by two prominent artists in the cinematic medium, Chantal Akerman and Eija-Liisa Ahtila. Their combined efforts add up to more than the sum of their parts: a lesson in big budgets, ambition and making sense.

title: New Homes Turning Old as the Inventory Piles Up
description: THE prices are coming down, but new homes in the United States are still not selling, and some of them are getting old while waiting for a buyer.

title: Smithsonian Suspends Its Merchandising
description: The Smithsonian Institutions catalog and online store have suspended operations but plan to be back in business by the end of the summer, the Smithsonian said on Friday. In 2002 the two operations were turned over to an outside vendor, the AB&C Group, a West Virginia subsidiary of BlueSky Brands. AB&C Groups closure on March 14 caused the Smithsonian to suspend sales. The suspension was reported on Friday in The Washington Post. The Smithsonian is now searching for a replacement, said a spokeswoman, Linda St. Thomas, who added that AB&C had handled as many as 300,000 orders a year for the museum.

title: The Tarnished Brass
description: As it prepared to invade Iraq five years ago, the Bush administration called up retired military officers to help sell the war. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld and his propaganda team courted as many as 75 retired military officers who could best market the Pentagon line, particularly on television. As detailed in The Times on Sunday, many of these officers used their access to Pentagon bigwigs to promote their private businesses.

title: The Real Value of a Fossil
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Smoke Cleared
description: SHOULD employers have the right to punish workers who smoke when they are not working?

title: Ohio State Workers Are Coping: Its Now 8 to 5, With a 5-Day Week
description: As flextime and telecommuting are becoming increasingly popular, state officials in Ohio have begun moving in the opposite direction with a plan to greatly restrict such arrangements for state workers.

title: Fatally Flawed Police Work, but Not Criminal
description: The colors rippled along Queens Boulevard in a declarative statement. Clad in royal blue polo shirts and pullovers, men and women stood in ranks five or six feet apart, their public identity instantly apparent from the gold-stitched lettering, NYPD Community Affairs, that blazed across their chests and backs. On their heads they wore navy blue baseball caps with big white letters that said NYPD.

title: Socit Gnrales Rogue Trader Finds a New Job
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the Socit Gnrale trader who used his knowledge of the French banks electronic risk controls to conceal billions in unauthorized bets, has a new job  at a computer consulting firm.

title: The Recurring Agonies of Asbury Park
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  For nearly a quarter-century, the rusting, hulking skeleton of a never-completed high-rise apartment building stood on the corner of Fourth and Ocean Avenues, a sad symbol of stalled redevelopment in this faded resort town. Then in April 2006, the abandoned structure was demolished to make way for another high-rise amid a nascent construction boom here, sparking optimism as long and wide as the citys barren boardwalk.

title: Questions Linger on Scope of Irans Threat in Iraq
description: This article is by Mark Mazzetti, Steven Lee Myers and Thom Shanker.

title: A Jazz Lifeline to Academia Is Severed
description: Over the last week, the jazz world has been reeling from the announcement that the International Association of Jazz Educators, a de facto trade organization, is going out of business.

title: Sect Children Face Another World, but Still No TV
description: SAN ANTONIO  Workers at the Childrens Shelter on this citys gritty west side began this week to remove anything and everything colored red from the walls, the floors, even from their clothes.

title: Top Official on Economy Steps Down in Argentina
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Martn Lousteau, Argentinas embattled economy minister, resigned late Thursday after less than five months in the job, amid rising inflation and a protracted conflict with farmers over government tax policy.

title: McCains Compassion Tour
description: John McCain  this is the guy, you may remember, whos going to be the Republican presidential nominee  has been visiting the poor lately. Appalachia, New Orleans, Rust Belt factory towns. This is a good thing, and we applaud his efforts to show compassion and interest in people for whom his actual policies are of no use whatsoever.

title: Tentative Deal Reached in Congress on Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional negotiators said Friday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a five-year farm bill that would increase spending on food stamps and other nutrition programs while mostly maintaining existing farm subsidies at a time of record profits for farmers.

title: 3 Detectives Acquitted in Bell Shooting
description: Three detectives were found not guilty Friday on all charges in the shooting death of Sean Bell, who died in a hail of 50 police bullets outside a club in Jamaica, Queens, in November 2006. The verdict prompted calls for calm from the mayor, angry promises of protests by those speaking for the Bell family and expressions of relief by the detectives.

title: Jimmy Giuffre, Imaginative Jazz Artist, Dies at 86
description: Jimmy Giuffre, the adventurous clarinetist, composer and arranger whose 50-year journey through jazz led him from writing the Woody Herman anthem Four Brothers through minimalist, drummerless trios to striking experimental orchestral works, died on Thursday in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 86 and lived in West Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Footnotes
description: The Argentine poet Juan Gelman received the Cervantes Prize, the Spanish-speaking worlds highest literary honor, from King Juan Carlos of Spain on Wednesday in Alcal De Henares. Mr. Gelman, 77, lost his son and daughter-in-law during the Argentine dictatorship and has written of it in poignant verse. ... Adding Machine, the musical adaptation of Elmer Rices 1923 play, will extend its run at the Minetta Lane Theater through August 31. ... Carol Fishman will become the general manager of Playwrights Horizons, the company said, replacing William Russo, who will become the managing director of New York Theater Workshop. ... A 9-year-old Australian actress, Jordana Beatty, was chosen from among 4,000 auditioners to play Eloise in Eloise in Paris, a film based on Kay Thompsons book about a girl who lives at the Plaza Hotel. Uma Thurman will co-star. ... Lawrence Rinder has been named the director of the Berkeley Art Museum/Pacific Film Archive, succeeding Dr. Jacquelynn Baas, the interim director.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,043 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Vocal Mavericks Solve One Issue With Victory
description: DALLAS  The Dallas Mavericks played a game Friday night, providing a temporary safe haven from embarrassing radio interviews and other self-inflicted damage.

title: Amy Winehouse Is Arrested
description: The singer Amy Winehouse, right, was arrested on suspicion of assault after reports that she scuffled with two men during a wild night out, The Associated Press reported, citing Sky News television. Ms. Winehouse, 24, was at a London police station to answer questions relating to the incident, her representatives said. She said nothing to a crowd of photographers and cameramen as she walked into the Holborn station late on Friday afternoon. The police said only that a 24-year-old woman was being held on suspicion of assault, but a man was quoted in newspapers as saying that Ms. Winehouse hit him in the early hours of Wednesday morning when he got in her way while she was playing pool at a bar in the Camden neighborhood of London. The man said she then head-butted another man, who was trying to hail her a cab.

title: The Word Is Out on Legal Tussles Among Creators of The Secret
description: The secret does not seem to have brought happiness to some of those involved in the creation of The Secret. But perhaps high-priced lawyers will help.

title: Daily News Owner Matches Murdochs Offer for Newsday
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News in New York, believes that he can snatch Newsday from Rupert Murdoch and the News Corporation without offering a dime more than the $580 million already on the table.

title: Boy Taken Off Life Support; Murder Charge for Mother
description: The Queens district attorney on Friday upgraded the criminal charges against the mother of an infant who was declared brain-dead on Thursday, more than three weeks after the authorities said the woman beat him so badly that he required life support.

title: Smiling, Everyday Faces of the Killers at Auschwitz
description: The Holocaust survivor story told by a woman named Ruth Brand in Scrapbooks From Hell: The Auschwitz Albums is familiar, but the context provided by this engrossing documentary on Sunday on the National Geographic Channel makes it horribly new all over again.

title: A Decision of Many Words Put the Fateful Ones Last
description: Criminal verdicts almost always contain either one word or two. The Sean Bell verdict ran 1,164 words, a methodical and unusual look into a judges examination of the burden of proof by the people of the County of Queens.

title: Stunned Silence Is Followed by Sobs in Court and Vows of Protest
description: They felt angry and defiant and sad. Mostly, they felt empty.

title: After First N.F.L. Pick, Day of Tantalizing Choices
description: At the end of the week, it was easy to pick out the player for whom the N.F.L. draft had already ended. Jake Long, signed, sealed and delivered as the top pick by the Miami Dolphins, had moved on by the time he got to Manhattan for Saturdays proceedings at Radio City Music Hall.

title: As Newark Rebuilds, Help From Beyond City Limits
description: NEWARK  William A. Ackman, the manager of a multibillion-dollar Manhattan hedge fund, has no personal ties to Newark and has visited the city only a few times. But next week Mr. Ackman, 41, plans to write checks from his foundation that total around half a million dollars to buy equipment for the Police Department and to pay for job fairs, block parties, concerts and outdoor movies and other recreational activities during the citys violence-prone summer months.

title: Shiite Cleric Tells Followers to End Fighting and Unite Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD  Under pressure from Iraqi government troops and the American military and with his eye on coming provincial elections, Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers Friday to stop the bloodshed, unite with all Iraqis and focus their firepower on driving out the occupation forces, meaning the United States military and its foreign allies.

title: Judge Wants Notes Shared in a Track Doping Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  United States District Judge Susan Illston said Friday that she intended to require that the United States Anti-Doping Agency hand over notes on interviews with a drug adviser turned government informant and three elite athletes expected to testify at next months felony trial of the track coach Trevor Graham.

title: Pentagon Suspends Briefings for Analysts
description: The Pentagon announced on Friday that it was suspending its briefings for retired military officers who often appear as military analysts on television and radio programs.

title: Sarkozy, Seen Through a Playwrights Artful Glass
description: PARIS  Best known for her award-winning play, Art, Yasmina Reza is a writer with no ambition to be a reporter. It was presumably for this reason that Nicolas Sarkozy felt safe in granting her an insiders view of his campaign for the French presidency last year.

title: Complicated Heroines, Puzzling Partnering
description: SAN FRANCISCO  By what criteria do we judge new works of art? Of the three seen in Program C of San Francisco Ballets New Works Festival on Thursday night, two  Margaret Jenkinss Thread and Val Caniparolis Ibsens House  gave hostages to fortune by announcing what they had in mind. And so, if you knew a thing or two about their subject matter, it was easier to explain their shortcomings than their strengths. Since, by contrast, Jorma Elos Double Evil left any specific intention unsaid, it seemed to succeed the most readily on its own terms. Yet I like it the least. Why? I object to those terms.

title: China Says It Is Ready to Meet Dalai Lama Envoys
description: BEIJING  China appeared to bend to international pressure on Friday as the government announced it would meet with envoys of the Dalai Lama, an unexpected shift that comes as Tibetan unrest in western China has threatened to cast a pall over the Beijing Olympics in August.

title: McCain Goes Where Few Republicans Dare, Deep in Democrats Territory
description: NEW ORLEANS  I want to inform you that everybody in the camp here is not a Republican, an African-American participant at a town-hall-style meeting at Xavier University told Senator John McCain of Arizona here on Thursday.

title: For Many, Thrift Shops Are a Wardrobe Essential
description: SHEENA MASSIE, dragged by her mother to garage and estate sales as a child, once cringed at the sight of used goods.

title: No More Cappuccinos or Corner Kicks
description: LAngolo  Finito.

title: A Shameful, Ugly Ad
description: Manipulative. Shameful. Race-baiting. Those are the only words to describe a new television ad from the Republican Party running in North Carolina that attacks Senator Barack Obama as too extreme for the state.

title: Afghan Leader Criticizes U.S. on Conduct of War
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai strongly criticized the British and American conduct of the war here on Friday, insisting in an interview that his government be given the lead in policy decisions.

title: ABC Is Ratings Leader
description: On the first night of the May sweeps period, new episodes of Ugly Betty and Greys Anatomy gave ABC the ratings lead on Thursday among adults 18 to 49, Nielsen estimated. Both shows were down some 20 percent in that demographic compared with their previous season averages. CBSs Survivor (13 million) and CSI (16.7 million) drew the largest audiences at 8 and 9 p.m., and CBSs Without a Trace did at 10 (13.5 million), opposite ABCs Lost (12.4 million). That ABC drama was second to Greys Anatomy in the 18-to-49 age group. NBC placed third, and Fox fourth.

title: Stravinsky Got Off to an Early Start in Recycling
description: For anyone as devoted to money as Igor Stravinsky, the Russian Revolution came as a terrible shock. Hello, proletariat. Goodbye, royalties. The ruling classes disappeared into the chaos, and with them the copyrights that protected such surefire breadwinners as The Firebird, Petrushka and The Rite of Spring. Performers and presenters were making money by playing these pieces, but out there in the public domain, Stravinsky was not.

title: Truck Rams Into Chicago Train Station, Killing 2
description: CHICAGO  A tractor-trailer careened into a busy local train station here during the evening rush hour on Friday, killing two people and injuring nearly two dozen others just south of downtown in Chinatown.

title: Making Ships Green, in Port and at Sea
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  Something unusual is happening in Swedish waters. Crews docking at the Port of Gothenburg are turning off their engines and plugging into the local power grid rather than burning diesel oil or sulfurous bunker fuel  a thick, black residue left over from refining oil.

title: Directing Bilbo Baggins
description: Guillermo del Toro, right, will direct The Hobbit, the much-anticipated two-part film adaptation of the book by J. R. R. Tolkien, Variety reported. Mr. Del Toro is moving to New Zealand for the next four years to work on the movies, whose events precede those of the Lord of the Rings trilogy. The films are being produced and financed by New Line Cinema and MGM. The hiring of Mr. del Toro comes four months after New Line settled a lawsuit with Peter Jackson, the director of the Lord of the Rings movies and co-executive producer of The Hobbit, over profits from the trilogy. Mr. Del Toros new film, Hellboy 2, is due out in July. His previous film was Pans Labyrinth.

title: A Witness Startles Court in Pellicano Trial
description: LOS ANGELES  An 11th-hour surprise in the Hollywood wiretapping trial resulted in the jury being sent home abruptly on Friday after a government witness asserted her Fifth Amendment rights on cross-examination and a defendant demanded a mistrial.

title: Outdoor Living Rooms Bring Touches of Cheer to Central Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Their requests could have been lofty, expensive and totally unrealistic, but in the end what the people of central Los Angeles really wanted was just a place to sit down.

title: Enrico Donati, Surrealist Artist, Dies at 99
description: Enrico Donati, an Italian-born American painter and sculptor considered by many in the art world to be the last of the Surrealists, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: Anchor Has Surgery
description: Jim Lehrer, the longtime anchor of The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer, PBSs evening newscast, underwent successful heart valve surgery on Wednesday. Jim plans to be back at full speed and on the program within a few weeks, the network said on Thursday. A spokeswoman for Mr. Lehrer said he first felt ill on April 18 and checked into the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Substitute hosts will fill in on the show while he recovers.

title: Detainees Mental Health Is Latest Legal Battle
description: Next month, Salim Ahmed Hamdan, a Yemeni who was once a driver for Osama bin Laden, could become the first detainee to be tried for war crimes in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. By now, he should be busily working on his defense.

title: Finally Able to Stand Straight, a Scorer Stands Out
description: LYNCHBURG, Va.  Tyler Tolson did not want anyone to know that his left leg was three and a half inches shorter than his right.

title: Meditations on Live Art and the Woes of Teenagers
description: After the lights have gone down and bows have been taken for Yasuko Yokoshis Reframe the Framework DDD, a short film clip plays.

description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Apr. 26 column.

description: Put those mock drafts down: its time for the real thing. Those mock drafts might not be much use to you anyway for this particularly unpredictable draft, which Judy Battista explains in an article in todays Times.

title: At Friday Prayers in Sadr City
description: Hundreds of men prayed in Baghdads Sadr City on Friday alongside flags said to bear the names of people killed in fighting with the United States military and Iraqi troops. In a statement read at the prayers, the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr called on his followers unite with all Iraqis and focus their firepower on driving out the occupation forces.

title: Experiment by Suns Works Out Well for Spurs
description: PHOENIX, Ariz.  Like mad scientists, the Suns tinkered with their chemistry, shipping out their best perimeter defender, Shawn Marion, so they could acquire Shaquille O'Neal's hulking presence in the paint.

description: Alexander Grischuk of Russia and Wang Yue of China are tied for the lead of the first Grand Prix tournament with 3.5 points after five rounds. Four players are a half point back. Standings, games and video interviews with the players are available on the tournaments official Web site. Today is the first rest day of the tournament; it resumes tomorrow.

description: This is not a running commentary. Here are some pre-game notes, with a report to follow after the game.

title: Tight qualifying, brilliant Alonso lap
description: The crowd went absolutely nuts as Fernando Alonso appeared out of nowhere and grabbed provisional pole position for a few seconds before Kimi Raikkonen crossed the finish line a tenth of a second faster than him. So much for Pat Symonds downplaying Renaults strength this weekend yesterday. Still, with that crowd behind him, Alonso may have found that half second at home that Nigel Mansell spoke about with his home races  Nelson Piquet Jr., Alonsos teammate, was in 10th position nearly a second behind. The Spanish crowd knew what an achievement this was for their star driver and they rose to their feet and stayed there for several minutes cheering.

title: McCain the destroyer
description: One of George W. Bushs lesser but still important talents is his uncanny ability to destroy peoples reputations: from John DiIulio to Michael Mukasey, well-regarded figures have entered the Bush administrations doors, only to reemerge soiled and diminished.

title: Chelsea 2, Manchester United 1
description: Chelsea pushed its unbeaten streak to 19 games in the English Premier League on Saturday, beating the defending league champion Manchester United, 2-1, at Stamford Bridge to draw even in points (81) with the Red Devils with two regular-season games to play. United could have virtually clinched the title with a victory or a draw.

description: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are each making two campaign stops in Indiana today, but thats a cakewalk compared to what Bill Clintons got on his agenda  six rallies in Oregon.

title: A Bad Headache
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Last night, we had Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger on the show. You know, I always like having him on, because after we tape the show, I like to go home and watch the closed captioned version so I can find out what he said.

title: Letters: The Readers Speak
description: Re Change Can Be Painful, but This One Shouldnt Hurt (April 6):Im one of those passionate readers who love the printed paper. I do like the slimmer version  in part because it helps the environment, as well as The Timess purse. The newest change was, I admit, quite irritating at first.But at my advancing age of 77, I dont trust myself to accept habits and customs with sufficient grace. So I forced myself, and after a couple of days I scanned the pages and sure enough found references to which I immediately turned.I do read the whole paper, so its overkill for me, but it can be handy. I agree that two full pages is a bit much. Im glad to note that it will be pared down some. Onward and upward.Nadia KoutzenToms River, N.J., April 6, 2008

description: A few weeks ago, my wife passed on her copy of Oryx & Crake by Margaret Atwood. Its a horrifying sci-fi novel about a near future where genetic engineering has gone amok, global warming has made North America baking hot with daily torrential downpours and a human-engineered virus has wiped out just about everybody on earth.

title: Saving Sudan
description: Its becoming increasingly obvious that the Save Darfur movement needs to expand to try to Save Sudan. Thats because the international communitys failure to respond adequately to Darfur is also leading the fragile north-south peace agreement in Sudan to unravel. If the north-south war resumes, as seems increasingly likely, the death toll will be measured in millions. Andrew Natsios, the former U.S. special envoy for Sudan, makes that case in an important article in the latest Foreign Affairs. Andrew argues that we need to engage Sudan and offer carrots, and I agree with him on that; he also argues against threats and sticks, and I disagree with him on that. My bet is that we need to have more credible sticks and carrots alike to get the Sudanese government to stop slaughtering its people, but Andrew knows his stuff and his article is well worth reading.

title: Peppers Pride Going for 16th Win in a Row
description: Off the Triple Crown front, Peppers Pride, the Pride of New Mexico, is going for her 16th consecutive victory this afternoon. If she is successful in the $75,000 Russell and Hellen Foutz Distaff Handicap at SunRay Park, she will equal the modern-day record.

title: Clinton at the Bat
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Senator Hillary Clinton began her campaign speech at a minor league stadium here by brandishing a baseball bat and promising to hit balls out of the park. She ended it by challenging Senator Barack Obama to a different sort of contest.

description: On the Triple Crown front this Saturday morning we have a few workers and a scare for the Smooth Air team.

title: Slap Shot Talks With Mike Bossy
description: Mike Bossy, the former New York Islanders star, recently completed his second season with the NHL team as the executive director of its business club, a networking job involving sponsors, suite holders and season-ticket holders. Bossy was recently in Calgary to help promote a fund-raising street hockey tournament headed by former Canadian national womens team captain Cassie Campbell and Slap Shot sat down with the four-time Stanley Cup champion to discuss his views on the game. Here is an edited transcript of the interview.

title: If You Squint
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Today, at the White House, President Bush signed a proclamation declaring this Malaria Awareness Week. There was an awkward moment when, during the ceremony, Bush said, This is a great day for all Malarians.

title: N.F.L. Draft: First Round
description: Greeting from Radio City, football fans! Were finally up and running after some Internet connectivity issues, the worst kind for a blogger. I have a seat behind the Jaguars representatives and in front of the NFL Network crew. Come to think of it, my seat is quite near where I was the last time I was here, for the Christmas Spectacular. I thought it would be cheesy, and it was, but it was also awesome because the Rockettes are a world wonder. Im sure five hours from now, when the Giants finally make the last pick of the first round, Im going to be wishing Roger Goodell was dressed in a bear costume dancing to The Sugar Plum Fairy.

title: Tough Competition at the European Championships
description: Sergei Movsesian of Slovakia, the top seed and No. 25 in the world, and Emil Sutovsky of Israel are the leaders of the mens European Championships after six rounds. Each has 5.5 points. Viktorija Cmilyte of Lithuania, Anna Ushenina of the Ukraine and Ekaterina Kovalevskaya of Russia, who each have 5 points, are tied for the lead of the womens championship which is running concurrently in Plovdiv, Bulgarias second-largest city. The Web site for the tounaments includes standings, lists of participants, games and results of previous championships.

Philadelphia: DeSean Jackson, WR, CaliforniaMinutes before the selection was announced, Jackson was seen on the big TV screens here receiving a phone call and celebrating, which caused a celebration among the Eagles fans. An electrifying player whose draft stock was hurt by his size, Jackson will probably play a significant role in the return game. As one excited Eagles fan told me after the draft, Goodbye, Reno Mahe.19/50. Arizona: Calais Campbell, DE, Miami (Fla.)20/51. Washington: Malcolm Kelly, WR, OklahomaWe are starting to see teams drafting highly-regarded players whose stock dropped after the combine and pro days. Campbell is one, and Kelly, coming out of college, was considered one of the top receivers available, but injuries and perceived attitude problems hurt him. But Washington may have gotten a steal, particularly when paired with its earlier pick of Devin Thomas.21/52. Green Bay: Brian Brohm, QB, LouisvilleThis pick got a mini-ovation from a row of Packers fans in the first mezzanine. Now that the Aaron Rodgers era has begun, Rodgers was going to need a backup. Or maybe its competition?26/57. Miami: Chad Henne, QB, MichiganAnd here come the quarterbacks. This years class is not deep, but it is a bit surprising that we have gone 57 picks and only four quarterbacks have been taken.27/58. JacksonvilleTampa Bay: Dexter Jackson, WR, Appalachian StateThe Buccaneers, after trading down for this pick, used up all of their seven minutes, the first team to see the clock go down to 0:00 so far in this streamlined draft, as the N.F.L. likes to call it. And they used all the time for a player they already had. Oh, different Dexter Jackson. That Jackson, a safety now with the Bengals, was the Super Bowl MVP for Tampa Bay in 2003.28/59. Indianapolis: Michael Pollak, OG, Arizona StateThis was the Colts only first-day pick, but the last offensive lineman on a day for the trenches, which was expected. The first two rounds took less than six hours, less time than it took to complete the first round last year.

title: Searching for Classical Music in Paris
description: Paris wallows in so much physical beauty that many visitors and residents are content to pass Sunday merely strolling along the Seine and admiring the architectural wonders that make this the most popular tourist spot on earth. But a mere feast for the eye  or, indeed, the stomach, given French cuisine!  is not always sufficient sustenance. Great classical music is a bit harder to find. You have to know where to look:

title: Peppers Pride Ties the Record
description: Peppers Pride notched her 16th straight victory at SunRay Park to remain unbeaten, the Blood-Horse writes. She has now equaled the modern-day record of consecutive victories held by Cigar, Citation, Hallowed Dreams and Mister Frisky.

title: Obama Picks Up Superdelegate
description: INDIANAPOLIS  While much of the political establishment is attending the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner tonight in Washington, the superdelegate operation is still churning.

title: The Good and the Bad From a Loss to the Indians
description: First, the good stuff from the Yankees 4-3 loss to the Cleveland Indians:

title: A Championship Makes a Long Draft Day Sweet
description: It was approaching 9 p.m. and Cesar Pellerano of the Bronx and his friend Justin Williams had been at Radio City Music Hall for 18 hours. They had stuck it out until their team, the Giants, made the final pick of the second round, only to be a bit confused about it.

title: Readers Respond to Grace Wang and Chinese Nationalism
description: Heres a selection of comments on Nicks post about Grace Wang (). The furor that she caused can be sampled on Chinese Web sites, where she has been labeled as a traitor ( or ) by Chinese netizens. Views range from the angry to the sympathetic. Grace, in her own defense, had this to say about what happened. For a Chinese version, you can go here.

title: Your Comments on my Amazon Column
description: My Sunday column is about deforestation in the Amazon, focusing on an unusual partnership between an American and an Amazon native who are struggling to preserve the rainforest by educating and empowering local people. You can find out more about Douglas McMeekin and Juan Kunchikuy at the Yachana website. Im doing something a bit unusual, and will continue their story in my column on Thursday.

title: Water Works
description: With gentleness and precision, tugboats guide ships through waterways.

title: So, Do You Have a Horse in the Derby?
description: Steve Zorn is managing partner of Castle Village Farm, a New York-based racing partnership that has brought some 350 people into thoroughbred ownership over the past eight years. He is also a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Thoroughbred Horsemens Association, which represents owners and trainers.

title: Witness to Darker Days
description: Jill Freedman, known for her raw photographs of 1970s New York, has a new exhibition.

title: As the Jets Fans Turn
description: O.K., Jets fans, your turn. You made a lot of noise at Radio City. Commissioner Roger Goodell could hardly get out a word starting with J without a roar starting. Even the most fleeting image of the Patriots on the video screens brought out robust boos. The Jets first pick, Vernon Gholston, was serenaded by chants before he was even drafted. Then when the Jets traded up to get a second first-round pick, the crowd, a bit moribund as the round dragged on, was brought back to life. With the Giants now selecting after the Jets, the atmosphere at Radio City was electric, with dueling chants and people on their feet waving their colors in the mezzanines.

title: Laura Bergs Letter
description: The PEN American Center, the literary organization committed to free expression, is honoring an American most people in this country have never read or even heard of: Laura Berg. She is a psychiatric nurse at a Veterans Affairs hospital who was threatened with a sedition investigation after she wrote a letter to the editor denouncing the Bush administrations bungling of Hurricane Katrina and the Iraq war.

title: Recession Diet Just One Way to Tighten Belt
description: Stung by rising gasoline and food prices, Americans are finding creative ways to cut costs on routine items like groceries and clothing, forcing retailers, restaurants and manufacturers to decode the tastes of a suddenly thrifty public.

title: Joining the Car Pool, in the Internet Age
description: TWO years ago, Tina Amarante began to look around for a way to share her 25-mile daily commute to Hartford from Cheshire. She found the solution on the Internet through a Web site that allows commuters  or people who want to share a ride anywhere  to find others going their way.

title: A Chapel the City Fought to Save
description: IN his book Building Memory in New York, to be published by the University of Minnesota Press later this year, Randall F. Mason devotes an entire chapter to the 1807 St. Johns Chapel on Varick Street, which survived demolition threats for more than two decades until it finally fell in 1918.

title: Talking the Talk
description: Of late, Barack Obama has come under criticism for gauzy speeches heavier on music and exhortation than substance. But those wondering why Obama often shuns policy talks on the stump miss the pragmatic nature of his decision. He is channeling the most narcotic form of oratory in modern America for whites as well as blacks: a preacherly style of speaking rooted in black American tradition.

title: Triple-A Failure
description: The Ratings Game

title: Times Up. Everybody Out of the Community.
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.

title: The Spirit of 68
description: AT least according to legend, the events of May  the strikes and disturbances that convulsed France in the spring of 1968  began at the movies. On Feb. 9 Henri Langlois, president of the National Cinmathque Franaise in Paris and a shambling, revered godfather of the French New Wave, was removed from his post by Andr Malraux, the minister of culture in Charles de Gaulles government. Young cinephiles reacted with outrage, and their angry protests flowed into a tide of political and social discontent that quickly reached the flood stage.

title: 32 Gas Stations in Report Show Spillage Signs
description: THE water that fills the drinking glasses and bathtubs of Long Islanders comes from right beneath their feet. Thousands of public and private water wells wick groundwater from aquifers, the sole source of drinking water for 2.7 million people.

title: Why the Income Gap?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dry Cleaners Feel an Ill Wind From China
description: THE wholesale price of wire hangers would seem an unlikely source of urban dismay.

title: Jacqueline Heinze, Kyle Kinsella
description: Jacqueline Elizabeth Heinze and Kyle Leonard Kinsella were married on Saturday at Allenberry Resort in Boiling Springs, Pa. The Rev. Anne Benefield, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Can a Co-op Compel Residents to Get Cable?
description: Q Recently, our New Jersey co-op entered into a bulk rate deal with a cable company, which saves each subscriber $20 a month or more after we add $29.95 plus tax to each shareholders maintenance charges. We have one or two shareholders who are disputing the arrangement, however. Our lawyer said that under New Jersey case law and under our bylaws, the co-op is permitted to require all shareholders to participate. Is he right?

title: U.S. Relay Team Is Hit With Some Bad Luck
description: PHILADELPHIA  For Leroy Dixon, a relay gold medalist in last years world championships, Saturday started fine. It ended for him with an opponents hand in his face, a patch over his left eye and a trip to the doctor. The accident also cost his 4x100-meter relay team a victory in the USA vs. the World competition, the feature of the closing day of the 114th Penn Relays.

title: Letters: The Aria of Chris Matthews
description: Chris Matthews is indeed an acquired taste, but he is all heart and all politics. Chriss feelings may be very tender after Mark Leibovichs article, albeit he had to know there was a 50-50 shot that he would take several hits (April 13). He would expect nothing less. The guy has an ego thats huge, but he is as smart as anyone who has ever played the game. I love this piece . . . all Mark had to do was take notes!

title: Muslim Rebel Sisters: At Odds With Islam and Each Other
description: Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Irshad Manji are two of the most prominent and outspoken critics of what they and others see as mainstream Islam. Brilliant, dynamic women  the overused word charismatic is not inappropriate for either one  they have each rebelled against a Muslim upbringing to become public figures with large and devoted followings. Both are successful authors: Ms. Hirsi Alis autobiography, Infidel, was a New York Times best seller; Ms. Manjis combination memoir-polemic, The Trouble With Islam Today, has been published in almost 30 countries. They are firm and unyielding in their support for the West, feminism, reason, freedom  and they have paid a price: both have been targets of death threats and have required protection; in Ms. Hirsi Alis case, around-the-clock protection.

title: East 20s Al Fresco
description: The al fresco dining season has begun, and sidewalk cafes, patios and gardens are opening up all over the city, including these in or near Madison Square Park.
