description: Leave it to the Oakland Raiders to take one of the biggest risks of the draft, selecting running back Darren McFadden with the fourth overall pick.

title: Sonoma, Calif.: Cornerstone Gardens
description: Usually when I hear the words garden center, I glaze over, imagining rows upon rows of tiny plastic containers, sprouting stalks so wobbly and forlorn itll be months until they resemble actual plants. I picture tedious displays of hose nozzles and my horticulturalist husband rattling off the Latin name of every species in sight.

title: Oil in Their Veins: Racing Fathers and Racing Sons
description: Nico Rosberg, Nelson Piquet Jr. and Kazuki Nakajima, three sons of former Formula One drivers who are racing in the series, probably resemble one another more than they do their famous fathers.

title: Nicole Pearson, Bradley Kleinsteuber
description: Nicole Melissa Pearson, the daughter of Deborah and Randall Pearson of Hickory, N.C., was married on Saturday evening to Bradley Jason Kleinsteuber, a son of Judy Staples and Bruce Kleinsteuber, both of Louisville, Ky. title: Sedona Fitzgerald, Todd Gaspard
description: Sedona Jane Fitzgerald, the daughter of Joy J. Tobin and the stepdaughter of Thomas J. Tobin of Brewster, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Christopher Todd Gaspard, a son of Dinah A. Gaspard and James L. Gaspard of Dallas. The Rev. David R. Harkness performed the ceremony at the Irvington Presbyterian Church in Irvington, N.Y.

title: A Living Heritage: The Earthen Homes of Yongding County
description: FROM Chinas Fujian coast, its a grinding drive up narrow roads through villages built around exhausted coal mines to reach the remote mountains of Yongding. Morning mist clings to the slopes of dense trees and brush. Below, in a valley, rests an eerie collection of beige cylindrical structures, one as enormous as a football field.

title: John McConnell, Steel Magnate and N.H.L. Owner, Is Dead at 84
description: John H. McConnell, a self-made steel magnate and sports enthusiast who borrowed $600 against his car to establish what became a multibillion-dollar company and later brought professional hockey to Columbus, Ohio, died Friday in Columbus. He was 84.

description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

Until then, America thought she was witnessing nothing more serious than the worst aviation disaster in history; now she had a sense of the fantastic vehemence ranged against her.

title: How to Show a Dictator the Door
description: Zimbabwes political crisis lurched on last week as President Robert Mugabe, the strongman who has ruled the California-size country in southern Africa for the past 28 years, refused to release the results of the March 29 elections. In old-fashioned autocratic style, the governments police began to round up opposition supporters.

title: For Rangers, Second Period Is First in Woes

title: Young Gay Rites
description: LAST NOVEMBER IN BOSTON, Joshua Janson, a slender and boyish 25-year-old, invited me to an impromptu gathering at the apartment he shares with Benjamin McGuire, his considerably more staid husband of the same age. It was a cozy, festive affair, complete with some 20 guests and a large sushi spread where you might have expected the chips and salsa to be.

title: Conservatives Prevail in Iran Vote, but Opposition Scores, Too
description: TEHRAN  Although conservatives won the majority of the seats in Parliament as expected, critics of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad also made a strong showing, according to results released Saturday, suggesting he could face opposition in next years presidential campaign.

description: Lauren Danielle Burton and Adam Jason Horowitz were married on Saturday evening at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi Howard J. Goldsmith officiated.

title: Modern Performances in a Medieval City
description: If you love cutting-edge theater, you cant do much better than Avignon, France, in July. The Avignon Festival (www.festival-avignon.com), known for its provocative theater and dance programming has invited about 30 artists to present works in the medieval Provenal town from July 4 to 26. The experimental stage director Romeo Castellucci, whose production featuring pink slime, fog and nude women, Hey Girl!, recently toured the United States, will be showing three works based on Dantes The Divine Comedy: Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso.

title: Cocktails and Cheddar
description: ON any given evening in Carroll Gardens, several neighborhood denizens will stop on Brooklyns bustling Smith Street in front of the JakeWalks large picture window, peering into the smallish, packed rectangular bar.

description: TALLADEGA, Ala.  The crowd of reporters and photographers closed around Jeff Burton when he stepped outside the sanctuary of his racecar hauler Friday afternoon. He acted poised and confident, a contender in the glare of attention.

title: Corrections: 36 Hours in London
description: The 36 Hours column last Sunday about London misidentified the member of the Beatles who scrawled on a piece of paper the first lyrics to the song Help!, part of the collection at the British Library Reading Room. It was John Lennon, not Paul McCartney. The column also misstated the years during which Samuel Johnson worked on his famous English dictionary. It was published in 1755; he did not work on it in the mid-1800s.

title: Green With Envy
description: Since fashion is a reflection of the times, it makes sense that designers should be looking for lasting ways to conserve the environment while still setting trends. Theyre taking into account that the cotton industry uses 25 percent of the worlds pesticides, with terrible consequences for wildlife and aquifers; that in an increasingly profligate society, recycling clothes might be a worthwhile endeavor; and that PVC, a chemically-produced plastic that doesnt break down, perhaps isnt the slickest of materials after all.

description: IN 1941, a Staten Island man named Emiel Fox died of a heart attack in his home on Fox Lane, which, among other streets in the area, had been named for him.

description: ALBANY  It was on a quiet Friday last October that the Democrats cellphones stopped working.

title: Suns Spirits, and Hopes, Are Fading
description: PHOENIX  Like a big man in the lane, the Spurs have planted themselves in the Suns heads and seem inclined to stay there as long as they can get away with it. Three seconds in the lane? That is a trivial transgression next to six years on the brain.

title: McCain Frequently Used Wifes Jet for Little Cost
description: Given Senator John McCains signature stance on campaign finance reform, it was not surprising that he backed legislation last year requiring presidential candidates to pay the actual cost of flying on corporate jets. The law, which requires campaigns to pay charter rates when using such jets rather than cheaper first-class fares, was intended to reduce the influence of lobbyists and create a level financial playing field.

title: Van Becidyan, Chad Broussard
description: Van Laura Becidyan, the daughter of Victoria Becidyan and A. Nurhan Becidyan of Paramus, N.J., was married Saturday to Chad Michael Broussard, a son of Melonie B. Broussard and Larry J. Broussard of Grosse Tete, La. Bishop Manuel Batakian, the leader of Armenian Catholics in the United States and Canada, performed the ceremony in St. Anns Armenian Catholic Cathedral in Brooklyn with the Rev. Raphael Andonian, an Armenian Catholic priest, taking part.

title: With One Move, the Falcons Take a Quarterback and Cut a Tie
description: Matt Ryan, the highly regarded quarterback from Boston College, was quizzed by many teams in the weeks leading to Saturdays N.F.L. draft. No team wants to make a mistake when selecting a franchise quarterback, but no team in this draft could less afford an error this year, at that position, than the Atlanta Falcons.

title: In Argentinas Grain Belt, Farmers Revolt Over Taxes
description: WENCESLAO ESCALANTE, Argentina  When the government decided in March to raise taxes on farmers profits, it set off a rural revolt in Argentina. For three weeks enraged farmers blocked roads nationwide, paralyzing grain and meat sales and causing food shortages.

title: Seeking Tranquillity, on Less Than $200 a Day
description: THE Saturday sun beamed down on central Kyoto, taking the edge off the November chill as I climbed onto my rented bicycle. I swerved through quiet alleys, past centuries-old wooden houses and Shinto shrines tended by generations of monks, and pedaled west to Arashiyama, a suburb of gardens, temples and bamboo forests at the foot of the mountains that ring this former imperial capital of Japan.

title: Almost Dead
description: To call Jack OConnells novels imaginative, or even original, doesnt begin to say it. Offbeat and eerie, they open as standard crime stories set in Quinsigamond, a depressed New England factory town where citizens and criminal lowlifes perform to type  for a while. But somewhere in the telling, his tales hurl themselves into some narrative black hole where logic breaks down and genre conventions no longer apply. In keeping with the new rules of OConnells game book, someone might come up with a drug that causes insanity by overstimulating linguistic comprehension and verbal skills. Or start a guerrilla war by hijacking talk-radio shows. Or attempt to expand human consciousness by altering classic movies.

title: In the Playoffs, Paul Quickly Asserts Himself
description: DALLAS  Chris Pauls playoff rsum is brief, which makes measuring its impact a thorny endeavor. But when Paul had a bad night Friday and came out with 16 points and 10 assists, one truth became clear: He will not be measured by mortal standards.

title: Freer Trade Could Fill the Worlds Rice Bowl
description: RISING food prices mean hunger for millions and also political unrest, as has already been seen in Haiti, Egypt and Ivory Coast. Yes, more expensive energy and bad weather are partly at fault, but the real question is why adjustment hasnt been easier. A big problem is that the world doesnt have enough trade in foodstuffs.

title: Air Passengers Want Ways to Fight Back
description: AIRLINE passengers are not just frustrated with the continued deterioration of customer service. Theyre upset by the lack of retaliatory measures available to them when the airlines let them down.

title: No Shoes, No Shirt, No Worries
description: WHEN Larry Massa says he likes to travel light, he means it. No need for a jacket and tie at dinner, a pristine set of tennis whites when he hits the court, or even a bathrobe to wear when heading from his hotel room to the pool or the spa.

description: MILES was blowing All Blues when we walked in, and a line of young folk, all dressed in black, sat shoulder to shoulder at the bar, eating bowls of frise salad, pasta with pesto and onion soup, thickly topped with melted cheese.

title: A History of Violence
description: In 1898, 42-year-old Edgar J. Watson became a living legend when a book credited him with shooting the outlaw queen Belle Starr nine years earlier. The descendant of a prominent South Carolina family, the legal or common-law husband of five women, the father of possibly 10 children, a leading pioneer on the southwest coast of Florida and a man killed by a large group of his neighbors in 1910, the historical Watson has obsessed Peter Matthiessen for three decades. Between 1990 and 1999, the novels that grew out of that obsession  Killing Mister Watson, Lost Mans River and Bone by Bone  were first published. In his authors note to Shadow Country: A New Rendering of the Watson Legend, Matthiessen says his initial manuscript ran to more than 1,500 pages, which he was persuaded to trim and split into three books. Shadow Country is not a restoration of the original version but a substantial revision and the kind of rendering done in slaughterhouses, a reduction of the trilogys 1,300-plus pages to a more easily consumed 900 or so.

title: Aspiring Filmmakers Rub Elbows at Festival
description: Aerial shot of Manhattan. Camera pans down to office building. Dissolve. Behind a desk, a movie producer reads a script for Northanger Abbey.

description: Bridgehampton

description: Inside the Glyndor Gallery at Wave Hill, housed in an old mansion overlooking the Hudson River, are works by eight artists that explore the impact of humans on the environment. Sound the Alarm: Landscapes in Distress may not be the most radical art exhibition aimed at confronting environmental issues, but it is probably the most beautiful.

description: To the Editor:

title: BlackBerrys Quest: Fend Off the iPhone
description: STEVE JOBS, Apples chief executive and field general, has Napoleonic dreams of global conquest for his 10-month-old wonder gadget, the iPhone. So it may be fitting that hes encountering his most serious resistance in a city called Waterloo.

title: In Zimbabwe Jail: A Reporters Ordeal
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  I had never been arrested before and the prospect of prison in Zimbabwe, one of the poorest, most repressive places on earth, seemed especially forbidding: the squalor, the teeming cells, the possibility of beatings. But I told myself what Id repeatedly taught my two children: Life is a collection of experiences. You savor the good, you learn from the bad.

title: Toronto Transit Workers Strike Suddenly, Stranding Thousands
description: OTTAWA  Thousands of passengers were stranded early Saturday morning after an unexpected strike by transit workers in Toronto.

title: Correction: Some Just See Old Carpet. These Two See a Golden Opportunity.
description: An article last Sunday about two entrepreneurs involved in carpet recycling technology misstated the middle initial of one of the two men. He is Frank J. Levy, not Frank L. The article also misstated the standing of their project and others in an international competition, the Energy Globe awards. Although the project won first place among all United States entries, there has not yet been a winner in the international competition for the Earth category. That winner will be announced in Brussels on May 26.

title: Zipcar, Zapped by Parking
description: IN 2002, when the car-sharing company known as Zipcar brought its first 10 small Volkswagens to the city, an article in the Automobiles section of The New York Times offered the speculation that the ventures cars might one day become as familiar to New Yorkers as the pushcart hot dog vendor.

title: Allegations Lead Army to Review Arms Policy
description: MOSCOW  The United States Army has begun a broad review of procedures used to supply security forces in Afghanistan and Iraq with foreign arms, prompted by an allegation of fraud and questions about the competence of the main private supplier of ammunition to Afghanistan.

title: Odysseus Unplugged
description: The poet, novelist and playwright Simon Armitage turns up in some interesting places. In January of this year, Armitage, the author of an acclaimed recent translation of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight appeared on a BBC program called Pop! What Is It Good For?, where he helped the music journalist Paul Morley explain the appeal of the Smiths 1983 single This Charming Man. The two men, both from the north of England, were filmed in a Manchester bar, chewing over the excellence of Morrisseys lyric in an atmosphere of nonscholastic expertise. I would go out tonight / But I havent got a stitch to wear / This man said, Its gruesome / that someone so handsome should care  the second half of the last couplet, in particular, elicited a swoon of approval. The patterning of vowels and consonants across that line, Armitage murmured. Its incredibly seductive.

title: Kate Phillips, Actress Who Christened The Blob, Is Dead at 94
description: Kate Phillips, who played mostly supporting roles on Broadway and in more than 50 films in the 1930s and 40s and who later was a co-writer of the 1958 horror film The Blob, died on April 18 in Keene, N.H. She was 94.

title: Home Brew for the Car, Not the Beer Cup
description: WHAT if you could make fuel for your car in your backyard for less than you pay at the pump? Would you?

title: Where Alaa Al Aswany Is Writing From
description: One evening last fall I joined a small crowd in a dusty room off busy Qasr-Al-Nil street in Cairo, facing a banner that read, Welcome to the Cultural Salon of Dr. Alaa Al Aswany. Many of those seated around me seemed to be simple celebrity spotters, there to see in the flesh the biggest-selling novelist in Arabic, Al Aswany, who is also an increasingly bold critic of President Hosni Mubaraks regime, which in Egypt has held power uninterruptedly for 27 years. The rest appeared to be aspiring writers or students eager for literary and political instruction. Austerely furnished with a single fluorescent light, half-broken chairs and a solitary table scarred with overlapping teacup rings, the room defused all expectations of literary glamour. Nevertheless, it offered a frisson of political danger. When the salon was held the previous year, Egyptian intelligence agents so intimidated the owner of the cafe where the meeting was taking place that he screamed at Al Aswany and his audience to go away. He later apologized, explaining that he had done it for the sake of the government spies who were watching him.

title: Knowing How to Change With the Times
description: SHELTON, cupped into a valley at Fairfield Countys easternmost edge, 68 miles from Midtown Manhattan, has a distinct knack for reinventing itself.

title: Through Weegees Lens
description: BACK in the 1970s, a gutsy blonde named Jill Freedman armed with a battered Leica M4 and an eye for the offbeat trained her lens on the spirited characters and gritty sidewalks of a now-extinct city.

title: Award Helps Young Players to Compete, and Pay the Bills
description: To make a living at chess, top players have to be successful enough to live off their tournament winnings or income from teaching or coaching.

title: Through Sickness, Health and Sex Change
description: NEW MILFORD, N.J.

title: Produced in Champagne, but What Do You Call It?
description: CHAMPAGNE, Switzerland  Makers of sparkling wine in the United States, Russia and Ukraine can appropriate the Champagne name for their products, but an innocent biscuit maker in this tiny Swiss town is out of luck.

title: 36 Hours in Naples, Italy
description: THE Italian port city of Naples might be knee-high in trash. And, sure, it has had its share of negative press, from bloody Mafia wars to political corruption. But theres real vibrancy, and even a little beauty, in all that chaos. Monumental piazzas add an aristocratic touch to the noisy markets and Vespa-choked streets. Mount Vesuvius looms nearby, a haunting reminder that this volatile town can erupt any second. And then theres pizza. That savory pie that calls this ancient city home is reason enough to visit.

title: Israels Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Robbinss Legacy of Anguish and Exuberance
description: THE choreographer and director Jerome Robbins, who would have been 90 on Oct. 11, died 10 years ago this July. This double anniversary is a cue for worldwide commemoration. Gypsy, the show he directed and choreographed in 1959, is again a hit on Broadway. A handsome Robbins exhibition, reflecting many facets of his career, is running until June 28 at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, at Lincoln Center. New York City Ballets spring season, starting Tuesday, will include no fewer than 33 Robbins works, ranging chronologically from Fancy Free (1944) to Brandenburg (1997). Other companies  from Seattle to Sydney, from San Francisco to Paris  have presented or will present Robbins programs during the year.

title: Jessica Pressler, Benjamin Wallace
description: Jessica Pressler and Benjamin Wallace were married on Saturday evening at the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America in Philadelphia. The Rev. Sean E. Mullen, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Gerard Sloyan, a Roman Catholic priest, participated in the ceremony.

title: At the Ready When Artists Think Big
description: Los Angeles

title: Bowling 1, Health Care 0
description: Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: A Literary Critic Drops His Ax and Picks Up His Pen
description: AFTER a touch football game on a recent Saturday in Prospect Park, and an impromptu post-game salon on Don DeLillo, Keith Gessen warily brought up the subject of his own debut novel, All the Sad Young Literary Men.

title: A Market That Dashes Assumptions
description: INVESTORS entered the year sure of one thing  that the economy was bound for recession, or at least for a severe downturn. And based on that assumption, they drew several conclusions.

title: Youre an Author? Me Too!
description: Its well established that Americans are reading fewer books than they used to. A recent report by the National Endowment for the Arts found that 53 percent of Americans surveyed hadnt read a book in the previous year  a state of affairs that has prompted much soul-searching by anyone with an affection for (or business interest in) turning pages. But even as more people choose the phantasmagoria of the screen over the contemplative pleasures of the page, theres a parallel phenomenon sweeping the country: collective graphomania.

title: M. Lois Murphy, 91, Dies; Leader in Cancer Research
description: Dr. M. Lois Murphy, a pediatric oncologist whose leadership advanced early work on chemotherapy, especially for childhood cancer, and led to markedly higher survival rates, died on April 8 in New York City. She was 91.

title: Tracking the Spoils of the Private Sector
description: There are so many barn doors to be closed on the Bush administrations wasteful, murky world of government contractors that Congress barely knows where to begin. The House has made a start in plugging the multibillion-dollar loophole that the White House let slip into its promised crackdown on fraudulent contractors.

title: Desperately Seeking Street Cred
description: WASHINGTON

title: Stamford Restaurants Face Ban on Trans Fats
description: stamford

title: Block Party
description: Terrines seem sophisticated and intimidating, but theyre actually homey and only as complicated as you allow them to be. Like many things French, theyre worth working through the fear factor for. Because all of the cooking is done the day before, you can affect an air of effortlessness at the table: add a salad, bread and wine, and you have a solidly impressive lunch or first course.

title: Letters: Thai Night Market
description: To the Editor: Having been to Chiang Mai myself, I was surprised the article 36 Hours in Chiang Mai, Thailand (April 13) did not mention the incredible nightly market. True, it can be somewhat of a tourist trap, but it is a wonderful experience and I still kick myself over things I didnt buy there as I thought I would find more and better things in Bangkok or Malaysia. It is well worth a visit.

title: Seized, Reclaimed and Now on View
description: Greenwich

title: An Enigma Gliding Through Time
description: ANYONE could see shed been a great beauty. Nothing, not the effects of 90-something years on skin or hair or shape, could hide that. She moves through these long halls like an apparition. She brings to mind the 100-year-old Rose of Titanic (less so Gloria Stuart, the actress who portrayed Rose). But she exceeds Rose in her loveliness and grace. Her eyes are the color of the ocean. She really should have gotten the role. Ours is a large, quietly elegant Art Deco building near Gramercy Park. The lobby could, in fact, be one of the grand public rooms of a trans-Atlantic liner. It is, like many other New York apartment buildings, a mix of old money and new, some money and not much at all. There are those holding fast to rent-controlled apartments from a pre-co-op era, those who bought just in the nick, and those buying since and now, at prices that offer a platform for the buildings most lively gossip. This woman is in the first category, and word is that she raised three children in a wildly desirable two-bedroom.

title: Italian Favorites, Celebrating Comfort Food
description: WESTCHESTER has more than its share of Italian restaurants, most of them glorified pizzerias or mediocre white tablecloth spots. But the county is blessed with a scattering of strong old-school efforts. Mamma Assunta Ristorante, a 28-year-old Tuckahoe fixture, is one.

title: Letters: In Search of the Skeptical, Hopeful, Mystical Jew That Could Be Me
description: As a five-year-student at New Yorks Kabbalah Center, I thought that Daphne Merkins article (April 13) was balanced and reasonably fair. There were, however, a couple of points with which I take issue  the first being that the center somehow insulates celebrities from the common herd. I am a typical, working-class person, yet I have had many interesting conversations with Guy Ritchie (we are both interested in kabbalistic symbolism in Masonry). I have chatted with Donna Karan and Sandra Bernhard, and I even made the tabloids, photographed entering the center with Gwyneth Paltrow.

title: A Fatigue Factor After a Long Rest Between Meetings
description: The Montreal Canadiens and the Philadelphia Flyers hurtled into the Eastern Conference semifinals as if it were Game 8 of their difficult opening-round series.

title: An Old Capitals New Look in Ecuador
description: QUITO, the bustling capital of Ecuador, was for many years just a stopover for tourists heading to the Galpagos. Its Old Town was a maze of litter-strewn streets and dilapidated colonial facades, and its New Town was known for raucous partying and muggings.

title: Terror and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

description: EDISON

description: OWNERS of hybrid cars from Boston to San Francisco like to boast about how their vehicles not only save them money at the gas pump, but help the environment, too.

title: For a Taste of Thai Mixed With French
description: ALMOST seven and a half years after bursting onto the Somerville dining scene with stellar food and service to match, Origin Thai expanded to Morristown in 2003 and to Basking Ridge this March. The original, rated Excellent in 2001, has slipped only a smidgen in its power to please.

title: Not-So-Personal Finance
description: ARIELLE GREEN, a publicist in Manhattan, knows what most of her friends earn, whether it is $28,000 a year or $100,000. And she does not seem particularly shy about disclosing her income ($30,000 a year, plus overtime).

title: From a Time Before BlackBerries
description: SATIRE, as George S. Kaufman famously said, is what closes on Saturday night. Which partly explains why Ralph Bakshis strange bombshell of a film  part live action, part animation  called Coonskin came and went so suddenly back in January 1975.

title: They Did Gatsby. But Can They Handle Faulkner?
description: JOHN COLLINS approaches a play much like a scientist trying to prove a difficult theory. He starts with an untested idea and brainstorms ways to make it work on the stage. Many hypothetical solutions are posed, proved not to work and rejected. Often he finds himself back at Square 1 at the end of a day.

title: Public Radio Tries to Reignite Its Public
description: PUBLIC radio is drawing its largest audience ever, some 28 million listeners nationwide each week. But if its a golden era, you wouldnt know it from the frenetic activity to remake the genre.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: When to Shout Eco-Friendly
description: BUY any magazine this week at one of 35 New York newsstands and the cashier will throw in the latest issue of O2, whose 64 pages include articles and splashy photos.

title: Clown Prince of the City
description: London

title: What Adams Saw Through His Lens
description: WAWONA TUNNEL is a passageway from civilization to natural splendor. The tunnel, dug through a hill on the western end of Yosemite Valley in Yosemite National Park in the 1930s, hides the coming view like a mile-long blindfold.

title: For Humble Bungalows, a Plan to Save the Sunshine
description: SUSAN ANDERSON lives on Beach 26th Street in Far Rockaway, on one of the areas remaining bungalow-lined blocks. Ms. Anderson, who is an artist, bought two bungalows on the street in 2004, and she hopes to turn the one that still has its original cedar shingles into her studio. But over the past few years she has watched in dismay the construction of a 15-story oceanfront condominium just a few yards away.

title: Maverick With a Message of Solidarity
description: IN photographs the American composer Frederic Rzewski resembles an Old Testament prophet, all high-domed brow, deep-gazing eyes and white, wind-swept hair. Over the phone from Brussels, his home since the 1970s, he projects a different image: casual, common-sensical, to the point. Toss him a question sure to prompt the self-important to pontificate  something about the extramusical associations of old songs, say, or the consolations of tragedy  and Mr. Rzewski (pronounced ZHEV-ski) shoots it down. I dont think I have any more to say about that, he replies. Or, I think were getting into deep waters here.

title: Wall Street, Run Amok
description: You dont really need to find out whats going on.

title: Bouquets, Only Edible
description: It may already be too late to reserve a table at a favorite restaurant for Mothers Day, which is two weeks away. But there is still time to put a bit of a spin on the usual gift, and order something beautiful to eat.

title: Mexican for the Soul
description: THIS is a bit harrowing, Jamie Lidell said as he walked into a near empty theater at the Film Forum. Were going to come out crying. Unlike the majority of theatergoers on this particular evening, Mr. Lidell, the 34-year-old British soul singer, chose to forgo Cate Blanchetts performance as a Bob Dylan-like character in Im Not There in favor of Ezra, Newton I. Aduakas tragic tale of child soldiers in Sierra Leone.

title: Hard Lessons Learned in the Ring
description: JEAN RENOIR said he made movies for the close-ups. I didnt understand what he meant until I made a fight film. There is little more beautiful than a fighters face. Audrey Hepburn was the face of beauty, but if wisdom is knowledge perfected by suffering, the fighters is the face of wisdom.

title: Refining the Rationale for Condos
description: WHEN compared with the first quarter of 2007, condominium sales so far this year have dropped 25 percent in Nassau County and 18 percent in Suffolk County, according to Jonathan Miller of Miller Samuel, a real estate appraisal firm.

title: Homey Food That Speaks of Brazil
description: With bologna sandwiches on the menu, Ritas Kitchen and Deli in Kearny definitely qualifies as an ordinary luncheonette. Yet, inside this tiny shop at lunchtime, the extraordinary occurs: school-age children order home-style meals instead of junk food.

title: Stephanie Pottruck and Aaron Goldman
description: ON Valentines Day 2004, Stephanie Pottruck discovered she had a problem of the heart.

title: Material Woman, Restoring Her Brand
description: WHEN in doubt, take Madonna at face value. Since the beginning of her career she has telegraphed her intentions and labeled herself more efficiently than any observer. She has titled albums Music, Erotica and, in 2005, Confessions on a Dance Floor for a collection that mingled personal and Biblical reflections with club grooves. Flaunting her ever-changing image, she named one tour Whos That Girl?, another Re-Invention.

title: Kaisa Greenberg, Bradley Weaver
description: Kaisa Rebecca Greenberg, a daughter of Kaija A. Greenberg and James B. Greenberg of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married on Saturday to Bradley Clarke Weaver, the son of Kathleen A. Weaver and Paul E. Weaver of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Debra L. Duke, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a growing movement among Latino immigrants to leave the Roman Catholic Church for Pentecostal congregations misspelled, in some editions, the surname of two pastors, father and son, at a Pentecostal church in Astoria, Queens. They are Fabio Tinouco and his father, Zeny Tinouco  not Tinuoco.

title: The Short End of the Longer Life
description: Throughout the 20th century, it was an American birthright that each generation would live longer than the last. Year after year, almost without exception, the anticipated life span of the average American rose inexorably, to 78 years in 2005 from 61 years in 1933, when comprehensive data first became available.

title: Seeking the Key to Employment for Ex-Cons
description: NEWARK  Over the past two years, Peter Santos has hired 40 ex-convicts to help him build and renovate apartments here; 36 did not last, many of them doing unacceptably sloppy work or simply disappearing after a few weeks  or a few days  on the job.

description: To the Editor:

title: Saddled With Legacy of Dioxin, Town Considers an Odd Ally: The Mushroom
description: FORT BRAGG, Calif.  On a warm April evening, 90 people crowded into the cafeteria of Redwood Elementary School here to meet with representatives of the State Department of Toxic Substances Control.

title: Next on His Docket: A Supreme Challenge
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Paperback Row
description: DEAD CERTAIN: The Presidency of George W. Bush, by Robert Draper. (Free Press, $15.) Certitude, intransigence, obstinate streak and compulsive optimism are some of the words that describe the subject of this unusual biography. Draper, a national correspondent for GQ magazine, was given extraordinary access  six hourlong private meetings with the president and interviews with some 200 other sources. Although there is almost nothing here about executive power ... or the treatment of detainees, Michiko Kakutani wrote in The Times, the book provides an intimate sense of the presidents personality and how it informs his decision making.

title: 500 Home Runs, Zero Certainty for Thome
description: Jim Thome hits long homers, prodigious homers, majestic homers, a lot of homers. Thome is patient and powerful, a left-hander hitter with an open stance, with an uppercut swing and with forearms as massive as telephone poles. Before he ever swings, he looks like someone who should pound homers.

title: After Killings, Escorts for Chicago Students
description: CHICAGO  Ever since one of their classmates was shot down just a block from school last month, a group of sleepy-eyed teenagers here has been meeting in the early morning at a community center southwest of downtown to walk to class together, hoping there is safety in numbers.

title: Sepia No More
description: Lets face facts: the Web, after nearly 20 years, has failed to uncover new masters of noble art forms like poetry, sculpture and the airport thriller. But it has engendered  for good or ill  new forms of creative expression. Blogs and viral videos are only the most obvious. Fan fiction, wikis, Flash animation and Second Life avatars are a few more. People dont upload to the Web words and images they had fashioned apart from the Web; they fashion their stuff specifically for online platforms and audiences.

title: Natasha Volyanskaya, Thomas Fox
description: Natasha Volyanskaya and Thomas Bayley Fox were married on Saturday evening at Auberge du Soleil, a resort in Rutherford, Calif. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Baptist minister, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: What a Fine Pairing: Music and Poetry
description: THE Gunn Memorial Library in Washington is distinguished for its local luminaries fund-raiser, an annual event that draws area celebrities and residents together to drink, dine and donate money to the 1908 institution.

title: Fear, but Few Facts, on Hybrid Risk
description: ALMOST without exception, scientists and policy makers agree that hybrid vehicles are good for the planet. To a small but insistent group of skeptics, however, there is another, more immediate question: Are hybrids healthy for drivers?

title: 3 Candidates With 3 Financial Plans, but One Deficit
description: The Republican and Democratic presidential candidates differ strikingly in their approaches to taxes and spending, but their fiscal plans have at least one thing in common: each could significantly swell the budget deficit and increase the national debt by trillions of dollars, according to tax and budget experts.

title: Shakespeares Wife
description: Introducing the extensive and reputable family of Hathaway alias Gardner of Shottery together with the curious fact that one of their kinsmen was a successful playwright for the Admiral's Men.

title: Drawing Lessons
description: Well before he championed the arts as weapons of mass instruction in his presidential campaign, Mike Huckabee was busy on behalf of the cause. He was also busy playing bass guitar in a rock band, Capitol Offense. Its a hard act to follow, but lately Barack Obama has gotten on the arts-education bandwagon. In a speech this month, he riffed a little stiffly about the good old days, before No Child Left Behind, when all schools made time for the arts: People understood, even though they hadnt done the scientific research back then we have done now, that children who learn music actually do better in math, children whose imaginations are sparked by the arts are more engaged in school. Obama also did his best to kick back, recalling his boredom at learning old show tunes like Oklahoma! when he was more into Stevie Wonder.

description: NEW HAVEN

title: Letters: Mutual Memories
description: To the Editor: I was delighted, and envious, to read that on her return to Florence (Florence, Italy: Cammillo Trattoria, April 13), Mimi Sheraton found Cammillo warm, welcoming setting and flavorful cuisine relatively unchanged.

title: No Way Out
description: At one point in John Edgar Widemans new novel, the narrator imagines a question posed by his brother about the book (this very book) the narrator is trying to write: Why Fanon. The narrator continues: Im disappointed when my brother asks the question. The answers obvious, isnt it. Given the facts of Fanons life, my brothers life, my life, the decades in prison, the besieged lives of the people we love and who love us, the lives and deaths shared with them, why wouldnt my brother, of all people, understand my need to write about Fanon.

title: Pujols Agitates With Patience
description: Even with the bases loaded, pitchers are not giving Albert Pujols anything to hit, preferring to take their chances with the rest of the Cardinals lineup.

description: NORWALK

title: Cameron Argetsinger, 87, Road Racing Pioneer, Dies
description: Cameron Argetsinger, whose love of speed cultivated on country roads led him to help revive road racing in postwar America and establish Watkins Glen, N.Y., as a stop on the Formula One circuit, died last Tuesday at his home in Burdett, N.Y. He was 87.

title: Black Baseballs Rich Legacy
description: ON a fine September night in 1946, in a ballpark out on the marshy edge of Newarks East Ward, the Newark Eagles  one of the two professional baseball teams, one black and one white, that shared Ruppert Stadium  trotted onto the field in jerseys so new and bright they looked almost incandescent under the lights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Danica Patricks victory in the Indy Japan 300, in which she defeated the two-time Indy 500 winner Hlio Castroneves by nearly six seconds, prompted these reactions from readers on nytimes.com.

title: Leslie Evans, Landon Thorne III
description: Leslie Jean Evans and Landon Ketchum Thorne III were married on Saturday in Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. John S. Livingston, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the United Church of Rowayton.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about James D. Farley, the chief marketing officer of the Ford Motor Company, referred incorrectly to his grandfathers work history there. While the grandfather was indeed hired by Ford in 1914, he did not immediately work at its Rouge plant. (The plants construction did not begin until 1917.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in the special Education Life section last Sunday with an article about colleges that do not charge tuition referred incorrectly to Berea Colleges $1.1 billion endowment. It exceeds Dukes and Dartmouths endowment per student, not in total value.

description: NEWARK

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Foot Soldiers
description: Are there any two more overused words in the book business than changed and forever? Browse through the bookstore and how many books will you find with those words on the cover? The war that changed us forever. The speech that changed America forever. Even, if you can believe it, The Match: The Day the Game of Golf Changed Forever. I read a description of the book on Amazon.com. It didnt. Change golf forever, I mean.

title: Street Fare That Aims Higher
description: At Souperfry, a jaunty new luncheonette in Mineola, Jonathan Passman, a 1999 graduate of the Culinary Institute of America, applies his training to New York City street food.

title: Is Trade the Problem?
description: Americans are angry about trade, and a lot of politicians  especially the two Democratic presidential candidates  are eager to capitalize on it. The country would be far better served by a serious, dare we say fact-based, discussion of what is causing the dislocations in American workers lives, how much trade is to blame and what government can do to help.

title: Reclaiming the Shrew
description: Few endeavors would appear as arduous and maddening to a responsible scholar as a biography of Shakespeares wife, Ann Hathaway. We have almost no solid facts about Mrs. Shakespeares life, and we know almost nothing about the Shakespeares marriage. We know that the playwright could have brought his wife to live with him in London and did not, though we dont know how often he made the three-day trip back to Stratford. We know that in his will, he left his wife only his second-best bed.

title: Correction: Evening Hours
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the Evening Hours column misidentified a guest at the New Yorkers for Children dinner-dance on April 16. She is Jennifer Missoni  not Margherita Missoni, who is her cousin.

title: Jennifer Carmona, Brian Bodine
description: Jennifer Marie Carmona and Brian Enos Bodine were married Saturday at the Holy Name of Jesus Church in New York. The Rev. Daniel Kenna, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Victor Self, Christopher Fraley
description: John Victor Self and Christopher L. Fraley affirmed their partnership Saturday evening in St. Barts. The Rev. William Warner-Prouty, a United Church of Christ minister, led a commitment ceremony at the Hotel Le Toiny.

title: Opposite of Color-Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Making (Closet) Room for Spring
description: AMONG the women in my family, switching closets is the terse description of a lost weekend  actually two a year  when each of us removes the past seasons clothes from the household closets and replaces them with clothes for the coming season. No errands are done in that two-day period; no appointments are made or met. For me, its a weekend of pure household labor, broken by meals and commiserative phone calls to my mother and my sister-in-law Vronique.

title: Letters Give C.I.A. Tactics a Legal Rationale
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has told Congress that American intelligence operatives attempting to thwart terrorist attacks can legally use interrogation methods that might otherwise be prohibited under international law.

title: Kristy Hong, Jonas Blank III
description: Kristy Hong and Jonas L. Blank III are to be married on Sunday at the New York Botanical Garden. The Rev. Hilda M. Gieco, an interfaith minister, will officiate.

title: Ballack Gets Chelsea Even in the Premier League
description: Michael Ballack scored on a penalty kick with four minutes remaining Saturday as Chelsea beat visiting Manchester United, 2-1, to leave the teams even on points atop the English Premier League.

title: Heather Ferguson, Gus Coldebella
description: Heather Lees Ferguson, a genetic counselor, and Gus Peter Coldebella, the acting general counsel for the Homeland Security Department in Washington, were married on Saturday. The Rev. Paul D. Lee performed the ceremony at Epiphany Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Married to Art and to Each Other
description: Can the two artists in a couple be identified based on the artwork they create? That is the question behind Couples, the exhibition currently at the Islip Art Museum. More than just an art show, it is a parlor game.

title: Lets Say You Want to Date a Hog Farmer
description: STEPHANIE BETIT first read Atlas Shrugged, The Fountainhead and Ayn Rands essay collection The Virtue of Selfishness in 2004. The books changed her life, she said, turning her from a devout Christian into an atheist and a follower of objectivism, Rands philosophy of independence and rational self-interest.

title: Big S.U.V.s Drink Less
description: IT would take a magician of considerable skill to turn a large, thirsty S.U.V. into a gas-sipping hybrid, but General Motors has tried to pull just such a big green bunny out of its hat. For 2008, the companys engineers have installed an innovative hybrid system in a couple of the companys larger sport utilities, the Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon, and plan to add the system to other models, including the Cadillac Escalade and full-size pickups, in the coming months.

title: Was I on a Date or Baby-Sitting?
description: A CUTE guy from a rock band sent me an e-mail message out of the blue. We had a friend in common, and he saw me sing Christmas Wrapping by the Waitresses one night in Brooklyn, at karaoke. He wanted to say hi, he wrote, but was unshaven at the time and didnt want to make a bad impression.

title: As Players Bulked Up, Value of Memorabilia Weakened
description: Before steroids became a part of our national pastime, my baseball memorabilia was all the rage.

title: Fighting in Sadr City Cuts Short Effort to Collect Trash
description: BAGHDAD  Thirty trucks rolled down the main streets of Sadr City on Saturday morning, sent in to begin shoveling trash after a parliamentary delegation visited the Shiite neighborhood and expressed concerns that fighting had sidelined basic services.

title: Angola Allows Chinese Ship to Dock, but Not Unload Arms for Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  In a slap to Zimbabwe, its longtime ally Angola announced Saturday that a Chinese ship bearing arms for Zimbabwe would not be allowed to unload the weapons while it docked in Luanda, the Angolan capital.

title: When the Share Price Is a Factor in Pay
description: HAVING trouble feeling sorry for people with stock options, deferred stock and other kinds of stock-based pay as the market bobs and weaves?

title: After Initial Promise, Hybrid Trucks Stall
description: ONCE upon a time, hybrids were going to rule commercial vehicles. In May 2003, when gasoline was $1.50 a gallon, FedEx was predicting that it would have 30,000 hybrids on the road in a few years. But today, all companies together have only about 300.

title: A Stalwart of Retirement Planning: The I.R.A.
description: WITH so much contradictory advice floating around, it is sometimes hard to figure out the best way to save for retirement.

title: Where Was the Wise Man?
description: EVERY month or so, Citigroup invites a select group of clients to dine with a singular and very special host: Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary who, for the last nine years, has been the banking giants self-described consigliere.

title: Nicole Plumail, John Sharpe Jr.
description: Nicole Alexandra Plumail, a daughter of Sylvia J. Handal of Manhattan and Michel C. Plumail of Lake Hopatcong, N.J., was married on Saturday to John Richard Sharpe Jr., a son of Linda T. Sharpe and Dr. Sharpe Sr. of Londonderry, N.H. The Rev. Mark A. Villano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Church on the campus of Boston College in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Cover Story: The King of Visceral Design
description: GEORGE LOIS, one of the most influential admen of his generation, is the sort of person who has a dozen brainstorms an hour, at least half of them good and only a few really harebrained. Among the better ones were the early Xerox commercials showing a chimpanzee deftly operating a photocopier, the I want my MTV campaign and Lean Cuisine.

title: The High Life
description: IN the real estate market, outdoor space is gold. Its expensive, its rare, and it can add enormous value to a home.

title: Calling In Experts to Get Rid of Junk
description: FOR people whose spring cleaning has left them with piles of unwanted stuff, here are a few ways to get rid of that junk.

title: The Return (and Reform?) of Harmony Korine
description: HARMONY KORINE catapulted to fame as an enfant terrible, and for a few years he played the part to perfection. He was the young skateboarder turned wunderkind screenwriter behind Larry Clarks 1995 sensation, Kids. At 24 he directed Gummo (1997), about glue-sniffing, cat-killing teenagers in a Rust Belt backwater. Most critics hated its junkyard, freak-show aesthetic, but it spawned an instant cult, with devotees including Werner Herzog, who became a mentor and collaborator, and Gus Van Sant. Mr. Korines next film, Julien Donkey-Boy (1999), inspired by his schizophrenic uncle, continued the gutter-punk provocations.

title: Lighght Verse
description: This book collects nearly all the poems Aram Saroyan wrote in the 1960s, when he was in his early 20s and, as he put it, the only person available at a typewriter who didnt have some predetermined use in mind for it. The resulting pages, tapped in Aram Saroyan by his typewriter, were succinct. Saroyan was the master of the one-word poem. But his works were as musical and meaningful as more conventional poetry, too, and a lot more amusing. The minimal poems were eye openers, ear openers and mind openers, and no one else was doing anything much like them at the time, and no one has since.

title: A Flood of Emotion in a Song
description: IN the nearly three years since the levees failed during Hurricane Katrina, you havent had to wait very long at a Louisiana festival or nightclub before a singer croons, What has happened down here is the winds have changed. Thats the opening line of Louisiana 1927, which has become the states unofficial anthem in the wake of the 2005 tragedy. Written by Randy Newman in the mid-1970s about a flood that covered a good deal of Mississippi, Arkansas and Louisiana half a century earlier, the song climaxes with its plaintive, singalong chorus, Loo-eez-ee-ann-a, theyre tryin to wash us away."

title: The Catastrophist
description: On Sept. 10, 2001, nobody in America seemed to know anything about Islam. On Sept. 12, 2001, everybody seemed to know everything about Islam. Well, not quite; but it is really a wonder the way the arcane particulars of an alien civilization now trip off every tongue. People who would not know if a page of Arabic is upside down or right side up helpfully expound upon the meaning of jahilliyah. Sayyid Qutb is quickly overtaking Reinhold Niebuhr as the theologian about whom the un- or antitheological pronounce with the most serene authority. Nothing creates intellectual confidence like catastrophe. After the mind breaks, it stiffens; in the aftermath of grief, it lets in only certainty. In a time of war, complexity is suspected of a sapping effect, and so a mental curfew is imposed. From the maxim that we must know our enemy, we infer that our enemy may be easily known.

title: LonelyPlanet.tv Looking for Amateur Videos
description: If you travel with a video camera and you think you have a colorful story to tell, you might try uploading it to LonelyPlanet.tv. The travel guide and information company uses the Web site to promote its own short films and scout for interesting videos sent in by amateurs, paying $500 for videos it would like to showcase as one of its picks. The company also might choose to feature an amateur video on its new YouTube channel: Youtube.com/lonelyplanet. Earlier this month, the channel was started with 20 selected Lonely Planet videos, and new clips are to be added every week. Current videos include The Top Three Places for Bohemian Rhapsody, Amsterdam Anime and Polar Plunge.

title: Patch Job
description: In April 1970, the astronauts on the Apollo 13 space mission faced a life-threatening crisis. Levels of carbon dioxide inside their craft were climbing dangerously, and there were no filters to replace the ones that were failing. Working quickly, the crew members assembled a makeshift filter out of materials on board  including a sock, a plastic bag and some duct tape  allowing them to return safely to Earth.

title: Diagnosis: Female
description: Back when Zelda Fitzgerald, her skirts wet from diving into public fountains, was accelerating from madcap toward outright madness, a Wharton School economist named George Taylor made the seemingly fey observation that hemlines rose and fell with the stock market, proposing a causal connection between two presumably separate spheres of human enterprise. Fashion, as the now familiar hemline index suggested, is socially determined. With prosperity come optimism and tolerance for risk; women are emboldened to show off a more daring length of leg. But what of more empirical, utilitarian domains? Surely doctors hypothesize independently of whatever forces drive style. Take, for example, the diagnosis and treatment of mental illness. Most of us trust psychiatry to remain immune to fads. And it does, doesnt it?

title: Paris Journal: A Break From Music
description: When a music critic travels to Europe with a doctor, once in a while the events and sights they take in have to center on science. My partner, Ben, is a psychiatrist. So when we went a few years ago to Norway, where I was covering the Risor Chamber Music Festival (a jam-packed offering with nearly 20 concerts in six days), he insisted that we spend an afternoon in Bergen at that enchanting little citys historic leprosy museum. That may sound depressing, but it was actually fascinating.

title: Sunday Workouts and the Derby Minute
description: Smooth Air was back on the track at Churchill Downs this morning, jogging a mile. His temperature has returned to normal and all seems well for his team.

title: The Last Winstrol Derby?
description: The best part of a morning on the rail at Keeneland this Triple Crown season is the regular appearance of Curlin, the 2007 Horse of the Year who recently vanquished international competitors in Dubai to become the undisputed race horse champion of the world.

title: His Guy Barbaro
description: John Eisenberg is an author and sportswriter who worked in newspapers for 28 years, mostly at The Baltimore Sun, where he was a columnist until June 2007. He has written five books, including Native Dancer, the Grey Ghost: Hero of a Golden Age, and The Great Match Race, about the first major sports event in American history, a North-South horse race in 1823. He co-wrote his most recent book, My Guy Barbaro, with jockey Edgar Prado.

title: Clock Stops on Obama Watch
description: Fox News Sunday finally got its moment with Senator Barack Obama. The long-awaited interview was broadcast on Sunday, and the agenda was very similar to that of every other television news organization: electability, race, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., William Ayers and Mr. Obamas liberal record.

title: A Warm Welcome for Pacman Jones
description: The trade of Pacman Jones to the Cowboys was completed today. Last week, the Dallas sports anchor Dale Hansen disagreed with Jerry Joness decision to make the deal. By disagreed, I mean he seemed to want him brought before a tribunal at the Hague.

title: Grand Theft Auto IV
description: A look at the new video game from Rockstar Games.

title: South Korea's Top Students
description: At two elite prep schools in South Korea, students study with an eye toward prestigious American universities.

title: Three Presidential Candidates on WWE
description: On April 21, the main contenders in the presidential race addressed viewers of World Wrestling Entertainment.

title: Giants Take a Chance on Super Mario
description: The Giants began their second day of the draft by selecting Michigan receiver Mario Manningham in the third round.

title: Reclaimed Art on View
description: A family's paintings that were looted by the Nazis, and later recovered, are on view at the Bruce Museum.

title: Luxury Airline Eos Files for Bankruptcy
description: Eos Airlines, the high-flying luxuries airline, came to an end Sunday as the Purchase, N.Y.-based company ceased operations after filing for bankruptcy protection, the latest casualty of a credit crunch and a money-losing airline industry that has been hit hard by high fuel prices.

title: Continental Calls Off Merger Talks With United
description: Continental Airlines said Sunday that it had abandoned merger talks with United Airlines and was planning to remain an independent carrier, a blow to lengthy efforts by United to find a merger partner.

title: Lauren & Adam
description: Lauren Burton and Adam Horowitz give the play by play on his touchdown pass to her that inspired their romance.

title: Doing the Highland Fling
description: Bill Pennington attempts to hit his golf ball out of thick fescue grass.

title: Rangers Postgame: Smaller Controversy, No Complaining
description: The Rangers lost Sundays playoff game to Pittsburgh, 2-0, with none of the uproar over a late penalty as there was in Game 1. In fact, the Rangers got two late power plays to try to overcome a 1-0 late in the third.

title: Living in Shelton, Conn.
description: At Fairfield Countys easternmost edge, Shelton, Conn., has a distinct knack for reinventing itself.

title: Jets and Giants: Day 2
description: The second day of the draft is when general managers and player personnel guys really earn their money  or set the stage for their firings. It is also, more than ever, a time when filling needs is paramount.

title: Much Ado
description: In 1952, when McCarthyism was at its height, Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas labeled the investigative techniques of the junior senator from Wisconsin guilt by association (Adler v. Board of Education). Douglas added that McCarthyite tactics were repugnant to our society because, despite the absence of any overt wrongdoing, the pasts of those attacked were combed for signs of disloyalty and for utterances that might be read as clues to dangerous thoughts.

title: Lions Like an Army Man
description: Caleb Campbell, a safety from West Point, was selected in the seventh round by Detroit. The Lions secondary can certainly use the help, but Campbells pick is significant because a new rule implemented at the United States Military Academy will allow Campbell to play football immediately instead of serving in the military.

title: Passing on the Ivy
description: Paul Raymond, a receiver from Brown who was the only Ivy League player with a chance to be drafted, was not among the 252 players selected this weekend. Raymond might have been the fastest receiver in the draft, but he is 5 feet 9 inches. Raymond, who was profiled last week in The Times, is expected to be signed as an undrafted free agent. Another Brown player, Zak DeOssie, played for the Giants as a rookie after being drafted last year.

title: Tech Support: the Good Old Days
description: Found here:

title: The Democratic Ad War
description: The TV ad war between the Clinton and Obama campaigns has passed the $100 million mark, a blitz unlike anything the party has ever seen.

title: Giants Draft Breakdown
description: ROUND: 1 (31ST OVER ALL)Kenny Phillips S, MiamiHeight: 6-2 Weight: 213Phillips is what General Manager Jerry Reese called a clean pick. Not only is he a skilled athlete out of a program that produces many defensive back difference-makers, but he has few question marks. The Giants were not even in contact with him during the off-season except for at the combine and Phillipss pro day at Miami. Primarily a free safety in college, he also played strong safety and cornerback. He is a smart player with experience in man and zone coverages. Coach Tom Coughlin said he would contribute on special teams right away if nothing else.

title: Jets Draft Breakdown
description: ROUND: 1 (6th OVER ALL)Vernon Gholston DE, Ohio StateHeight: 6-3 Weight: 264Gholston is defined by numbers that defy description. Where to start? Gholston weighs 264 pounds, up from the 238 he weighed at the start of college. Off the field, he ran a 4.56-second 40-yard dash, bench-pressed 455 pounds and squatted 405 pounds 20 times. On the field, he racked up 87 tackles, 22 sacks and 30 tackles for loss in his career at Ohio State, including a school-record 14 sacks his junior season.

title: Odds and Ends From the Draft
description: The N.C.A.A.s most prolific rusher and most prolific passer were each available in this years draft, but no teams paid them any mind until the draft was nearly over.

title: N.F.L. Draft Winners and Losers
description: From Jake Long first to David Vobora as Mr. Irrelevant, and with 250 picks in between, the N.F.L. draft has come and gone more quickly than ever before, making the real winners the fans who want to watch the draft without allowing it to consume every waking hour of a weekend.

title: Two Horses From the Track
description: One issue that has become important to me, as a race fan as well as someone who works closely with racehorses, is what happens to horses once they have finished racing. I want to highlight two horses, one who retired a little while ago and was slow, and one who recently retired and was quite fast.

title: Fillys Owner Courts Criticism
description: Alan Mann writes the Left at the Gate blog.

title: A Fourth Try at the Derby
description: Jack Wolf and his wife, Laurie, founded Starlight Stables in 2000 when they purchased six yearlings at the Fasig-Tipton Kentucky July sale. He and his partners own Monba, who will be his fourth starter in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Are You Confused Yet?
description: Jacob S. Hacker is a professor of political science at Yale (full biography).

title: The Toughness of Jorge Posada
description: A few weeks ago, I was asked a simple question: if you could have one Yankee at the plate in a big situation, who would it be?

title: Tennis Match Is Up For USA
description: Wall Street Journal: USA Network, the longtime home of weeknight coverage of the U.S. Open Tennis Championships, will no longer televise the tournament after this year. ESPN may pick up the rights.

title: Brothers & Sisters,  Ugly Betty Win GLAAD Awards Again
description: The Associated Press: Two ABC series were in repeats  as winners  at the annual awards honoring good work in media presentations of gays and lesbians. Brothers & Sisters and Ugly Betty received awards for outstanding drama and comedy series during the 19th annual Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Media Awards at the Kodak Theatre on Saturday night.

title: Keeping Idol Attuned To Its Audience
description: Broadcasting & Cable: The ratings for American Idol are softening. But Fox execs arent just standing around staring aimlessly off into space like Idol robo-contestant David Archuleta. An online market research survey by Fox asks some interesting questions that could portend changes to next years show. More

title: Lawyers Fear Monitoring in Cases on Terrorism
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Thomas Nelson, an Oregon lawyer, has lived in a state of perpetual jet lag for the last two years. Every few weeks, he boards a plane in Portland and flies to the Middle East to meet with a high-profile Saudi client who cannot enter the United States because he faces charges here of financing terrorism.

title: An Identity Stuck in the Swamps of New Jersey
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: United Evaluates Its Merger Options
description: The chief executive of United Airlines, Glenn F. Tilton, indicated Monday that the carriers efforts to find a partner would continue after a rival, Continental Airlines, abandoned merger talks on Sunday.

title: TNTs Smith Has Interest in Knicks
description: Kenny Smith, a TNT analyst and 10-year veteran of the N.B.A., confirmed Sunday that he was interested in joining the Knicks front office.

title: A New Phantom
description: John Cudia will become the 12th actor to play the title role in the Broadway production of The Phantom of the Opera when he replaces Howard McGillin on May 22 at the Majestic Theater. Mr. Cudia, who played the Phantom in the national tour of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, previously played Raoul in the Broadway production, which has been running for more than 20 years. Mr. McGillin, who has played the title role more than 2,000 times, will return to the production on July 28.

title: Loan Industry Fighting Rules on Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON  The mortgage industry, facing the prospect of tougher regulations for its central role in the housing crisis, has begun an intensive campaign to fight back.

title: In Cellphones, Price Gains on Quality
description: In a recent survey, proportionally fewer cellphone users than in 2006 cited signal quality as their main reason for having switched to their current carrier, according to comScore, a research firm. And a larger proportion than before cited price as the deciding factor; that percentage crept up to 19 percent from 14 percent.

title: Michael White, 59, Dies; Used Stories as Therapy
description: Michael White, a social worker and family therapist who developed an innovative and highly practical technique using storytelling to help patients of all ages deal with childhood traumas, died on April 4 in San Diego. He was 59.

title: Kremlin Joins Russians Keeping an Eye on Prices
description: MOSCOW  Tamara V. Nikolskaya was laden with plastic shopping bags, scurrying about the Enthusiast outdoor market in eastern Moscow on Friday to pick up last-minute items for Sundays Orthodox Easter feast.

title: Son Plans to Publish Nabokovs Last Novel
description: Dmitri Nabokov plans to defy the wishes of his father, Vladimir Nabokov, by publishing his fathers final, incomplete novel rather than destroying the manuscript by fire. The Guardian of London reported that Dmitri, 73, told the German magazine Der Spiegel: Im a loyal son and thought long and seriously about it. Then my father appeared before me and said with an ironic grin: Youre stuck in a right old mess. Just go ahead and publish. For three decades the fragments of the novel, The Original of Laura, on a collection of 50 index cards, have been in a bank vault in Switzerland, where Vladimir Nabokov, the author of Lolita and Pale Fire, died in 1977. Dmitri Nabokov, his fathers literary executor, once described it as the most concentrated distillation of his fathers creativity. In an interview with the BBC, Dmitri Nabokov said he found very disturbing the thought that no one would ever read the manuscript. But he said he would not complete it himself. I would never presume to finish my fathers works for him because there are so many strands and threads and thoughts there that perhaps might have been developed further, he said. And simply I dont have the right.

title: Bungees to Bridge a Divide
description: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballets new Glassy Essence is one of those installation works that keep the audience on its feet  literally. When faced with multiple viewing points and no seating, its helpful to recall a hockey truism: Dont chase the puck; it will come to you.

title: Humiliation and Death on a Fateful Journey
description: Akram Khan continued his engagement at City Center on Friday night with zero degrees, a work for himself and the Flemish-Moroccan choreographer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui. Like bahok, performed earlier in the week, the duet deals with cultural identity, anger, humiliation and frustration.

title: Baby Mama Tops Box Office
description: Two new films  Baby Mama and Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay  took over the top spots in the weekend box office rankings, relegating last weeks favorite, The Forbidden Kingdom, to third place. The box office tracking company Media by Numbers reported that the comedy Baby Mama, distributed by Universal Pictures and starring Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, from left above, took in an estimated $18.2 million to capture the No. 1 spot. Second place went to another comedy, Harold & Kumar (Warner Brothers), starring John Cho and Kal Penn, with $14.5 million. The Forbidden Kingdom (Lionsgate), the martial arts adventure starring Jackie Chan and Jet Li, finished with $11.2 million, just ahead of Forgetting Sarah Marshall (Universal) with $11 million in its second week. Fifth place went to Nims Island (Fox) on a gross of $4.5 million in its fourth week.

title: Wang Earns Fifth Win With a Little Improvisation
description: CLEVELAND  The national anthem was played at 12:55 p.m. on Sunday, Jos Molina remembered, and the first pitch was at 1:07. The 12-minute interval in between was all Molina had to prepare to start at catcher.

title: Songs and Poems Extoll a Green and Pleasant Land
description: Bryn Terfels recital at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening described the wave of nostalgia that swept across Edwardian music. Pastoral England was disappearing and an industrial England replacing it, but maybe a great empire could have it both ways: enjoying its material gains but retaining in the collective imagination the comforts of antique beauties.

title: Gear of the Week
description: A lot of pro golfers are paid to use their equipment. So its worth noting a recent trend on the Champions Tour, where the most popular putter is made by one of the smaller companies, Rife Putters.

title: Learning a Lesson, Kyle Busch Prevails
description: TALLADEGA, Ala.  Talk of Tony Stewarts future has become background noise, or no noise at all. Whether Stewart, a two-time series champion, wants to play his hand as a free agent or stay with Joe Gibbs Racing will bring some who-cares shrugs this week because of the continued rush of wins from Stewarts new teammate, Kyle Busch.

title: Critics Cost Muslim Educator Her Dream School
description: Debbie Almontaser dreamed of starting a public school like no other in New York City. Children of Arab descent would join students of other ethnicities, learning Arabic together. By graduation, they would be fluent in the language and groomed for the countrys elite colleges. They would be ready, in Ms. Almontasers words, to become ambassadors of peace and hope.

title: Ban Urged on Gifts at Medical Schools
description: Drug and medical device companies should be banned from offering free food, gifts, travel and ghost-writing services to doctors, staff and students in all 129 of the nations medical colleges, an influential college association has concluded.

title: Karzai Escapes Attack in Kabul by Gunmen
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A well-coordinated assassination attempt on President Hamid Karzai by suspected Taliban insurgents at the Afghan national day military parade in central Kabul has turned into a moment of national embarrassment for the government, which has been pressing to take over responsibility for Kabuls security from foreign troops.

title: Signs of Attacks on Zimbabwes Opposition
description: JOHANNESBURG  Evidence of widespread retribution against people who supported Zimbabwes opposition party in last months election has begun to stream out despite the governments efforts to restrict press access to the worst of the violence.

title: Kerkorian Buys 4.7% of Ford and Plans More
description: DETROIT  The billionaire financier Kirk Kerkorian made a dramatic move on another Detroit automaker Monday with an announcement that he had acquired a 4.7 percent stake in the Ford Motor Company and planned a $170 million cash offer for an additional 20 million shares.

title: Hillary Gets No Respect
description: I normally dont claim to speak for other members of the vast right-wing conspiracy. After all, were each nefarious in our own, individual way. Indeed, we often disagree with one another.

title: The Magic Flute as Underground Opera
description: Mozarts Magic Flute is going for a ride. More than 200 years after it was first performed in Vienna, the opera  updated for the 21st century by the avant-garde director Christoph Hagel  is being performed in a subway station in Berlin, Agence France-Presse reported. The production is intended to draw attention to the unopened Bundestag station, designed by the architects Axel Schultes and Charlotte Frank, that is a final piece in a two-decade project, to construct a line linking the Brandenburg Gate with the new Hauptbahnhof main station. In Mr. Hagels production, the bird catcher Papageno is transformed into a homeless bohemian on welfare who is played by Jan Plewka, former frontman of the German rock band Selig. The hero, Tamino, is chased by a train, not a serpent; and his love object, Pamina, cast as a typical Berlin student, is arrested for not having a ticket. Other characters wear baseball caps and ride skateboards. The production will run through May 25.

title: Columbias Radicals of 1968 Hold a Bittersweet Reunion
description: Spring, with the trees and flowers in blossom, is a time when colleges hold their reunions. So over the weekend a very specific group of Columbia University alumni gathered in Morningside Heights to recall their campus days.

title: Pasha & Co. in Mozarts Singspiel
description: When David Robertson first conducted at the Metropolitan Opera in 1996, he had the distressing experience of leading a performance of Janaceks Makropulos Case in which a tenor died onstage.

title: With Slump Paramount, Fed Is Likely to Cut Rates
description: WASHINGTON  This time, will the Feds words speak louder than its actions?

description: Lions Take Army Man

title: Dental Clinics, Meeting a Need With No Dentist
description: UNALAKLEET, Alaska  The dental clinic in this village on the edge of the Bering Sea looks like any other, with four chairs, a well-scrubbed floor and a waiting area filled with magazines.

title: Murdochs Head of Content
description: In a long career, Robert Thomson has left a trail of happy reporters in his wake  at The Financial Times and more recently at The Times of London, where the newsroom under his guidance was, in the words of a former colleague, the happiest place to work on Fleet Street.

title: Olympic Protests, Then and Now
description: I was in Red Square one day during the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow when some poor protester apparently tried to set himself on fire. We never learned who he was or what really happened because of the amazing reaction of the authorities, which was caught on film by a tourist.

description: Wow, looks like someone saw your movie.
