title: After Life in White House, No Place Feels Like Home
description: Biographical reporting has as much to do with selection and emphasis as it does with the unearthing of raw data. So the way that Carol Felsenthal, in her book about Bill Clintons post-presidential life, describes a 2006 newspaper editors convention is revealing. This was an event at which the former president spoke pro bono, was warmly received and delighted listeners by ignoring his handlers advice that he keep the appearance brief.

title: Iran Versus Barbie
description: Irans prosecutor general railed on Sunday against the invasion of Barbie, Batman, Spider-Man and Harry Potter and demanded that the countrys young be protected against them, Agence France-Presse reported. Urging measures to safeguard Islamic culture and revolutionary values, the prosecutor, Ghorban-Ali Dorri Najafabadi, was quoted by the ISNA news agency as saying: Promoting figures like Barbie, Batman, Spider-Man and Harry Potter and the uncontrolled import of CDs of video games and films should alarm all the countrys officials. We need to find substitutes to ward off this onslaught, which aims at children and young people whose personality is in the process of being formed. Although officials in Iran regularly denounce Western culture, Western toys have been popular there, and affluent parents often indulge their children with them. The prosecutor said, These toys, which do not respect the required norms, present dangers for the health of children and affect the survival of toy factories in this country. In July 2007 Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows went on sale in Tehran. Two years ago the police raided toy shops and put black stickers on the packaging of Barbie dolls to hide their bodies. Barbie contravenes Irans rule that women must cover all bodily contours. Irans rivals to Barbie and her partner, Ken, are Sara and Dara, who respect Islamic rules but do not enjoy Barbies popularity.

title: Hungry for a Comeback, but Pretty Thirsty, Too
description: A single breath of suspense, as faint as a half-stifled sigh, occasionally stirs the inert revival of Clifford Odetss Country Girl, which opened on Sunday night at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater. This anxiety does not arise from the fraught plot-propelling questions posed in this backstage drama from 1950: Will the washed-up actor stay off the sauce long enough to make his comeback? Will his wife leave him if he does (or if he doesnt)? Will the play theyre all working so darn hard on make it to Broadway?

title: Iraq Struggle Unfolds in Peaceful Protest and Violent Attacks in Sadr City
description: BAGHDAD  The latest episode in the struggle between the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr and the Iraqi government unfolded Sunday on the streets of Sadr City, where members of Parliament demonstrated peacefully while clashes occurred a few blocks away.

title: Better Days, and Even the Candidates, Are Coming to W.W.E.
description: For most of 2007, the reputation of World Wrestling Entertainment seemed to be in tatters, its ratings and share price staggering after a suicide-murder involving one of its biggest stars.

title: From Prison to Freedom, and Telling Their Tales
description: Politicians have said plenty about zero tolerance for criminals, and the country has an overcrowded prison system to show for it. The Castle, a simple, fascinating production about four ex-convicts, presents the other side of the coin, describing the obstacles that criminal offenders face upon their release.

title: John McConnell, 84, Steel and Hockey Magnate, Dies
description: John H. McConnell, a self-made steel magnate and sports enthusiast who borrowed $600 against his car to establish what became a multibillion-dollar company and later brought professional hockey to Columbus, Ohio, died Friday in Columbus. He was 84.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about criticism of Bill Clinton for statements he has made during the presidential campaign, including likening Barack Obamas victory in the South Carolina primary this year to Jesse Jacksons win there in 1988, misidentified the type of nominating contest the state held in 1988. It was a caucus, not a primary. The same error appeared on Thursday in a correction about the year Mr. Jackson won and in an article on Jan. 29 about support for Mr. Clinton in Harlem.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a review on April 27 about "Shakespeare's Wife," by Germaine Greer, misstated the nature of a return Shakespeare made in 1611, the subject of one of the book's chapters. It was from London to Stratford-upon-Avon, not "to London."

title: Legislators End Toronto Transit Strike
description: OTTAWA  Ontarios legislature swiftly passed a bill on Sunday ordering 8,900 striking transit workers in Toronto back to work immediately.

title: Negotiations Put Europeans Closer to Pact With Serbia
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union is moving closer to signing a long-delayed pact with Serbia after the Netherlands and Belgium said Sunday that they would drop their opposition under certain conditions.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Critics Choice column on Tuesday, about new DVDs including a collection of Shirley Temple films, referred incorrectly to the song On the Good Ship Lollipop. It is about an aircraft, not a seagoing ship. (The reference comes in the seldom-heard opening lyrics: Ive thrown away my toys./Even my drum and train./I wanna make some noise/with real live aeroplanes./Some day Im going to fly./Ill be a pilot too./And when I do, how would you/like to be my crew.)

title: A Pampered Derby Champions Finicky Taste
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It is perhaps fitting that the 2002 Kentucky Derby winner War Emblem resides in luxury, cloistered in his own barn and surrounded by high-quality mares on the island of Hokkaido in Japan. By all accounts, he is a happy horse  gamboling through fields most of the day, showing the turn of foot that propelled him to lead every step of the way in Americas greatest horse race.

description: National

description: Five things you never want

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A listing of credits on Friday with a film review of Then She Found Me, using information from the distributors Web site, misspelled the surname of a producer. She is Pam Koffler, not Koeffler.

title: Director to Leave Berlin Philharmonic
description: Pamela Rosenberg, below, the first woman and the first American to become the administrative director of the Berlin Philharmonic, plans to leave the job when her contract expires in 2010, Bloomberg News reported. Pamela Rosenberg has decided she no longer wants to be attached to an institution and wants to spend her time on individual projects, Stefan Stahnke, the orchestras spokesman, said in a telephone interview. That means she wont go to any other institution, like an opera house, either. Before joining the Berlin Philharmonic in 2006 as intendant, as the orchestra calls the administrative post, the Los Angeles-born Ms. Rosenberg, now 63, was the general director of the San Francisco Opera. She has spent much of her career in Europe. News of her plans came as the orchestra prepared to discuss details of a new contract with its conductor, Simon Rattle. That agreement expires in 2012.

title: Body Movement in a High-Tech Society, Seriously
description: The seven accomplished dancers in the Dutch duo Leine & Roebanas Sporen (or Traces) had been putting themselves through the paces for quite a few minutes Friday night when something magical happened: One of them smiled, the kind of unconscious, exalted smile people sometimes make while pushing their bodies past their limits.

title: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Philippines Introduces Cash Subsidies and Cheaper Rice for the Poor
description: MANILA  Poor Filipinos who are reeling from high food prices not seen since the 1970s will get some relief this week when the Philippine government starts to distribute rice passes to the most impoverished families across the country, officials said Sunday.

title: Telling Stories About the Fish on Your Plate
description: A new campaign for a restaurant chain that specializes in seafood is telling customers not only about the meal on their plates but also how it got there.

title: Austria Says Man Jailed Daughter for 24 Years
description: FRANKFURT  Austrian police arrested a 73-year-old man who they say kept his daughter locked in a cellar for 24 years and fathered seven children with her, three of whom never emerged into daylight from their prison until now.

title: Revealing Photo Threatens a Major Disney Franchise
description: LOS ANGELES  Fifteen years old and suggestively wrapped in what appears to be a satin bedsheet in the June issue of Vanity Fair. Did Miley Cyrus, with the help of a controversy-courting magazine, just deliver a blow to the Walt Disney Companys billion-dollar Hannah Montana franchise?

title: Former Pastor of Obama Says He Isnt Divisive
description: DETROIT  The Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., Senator Barack Obamas former pastor, whose sermons have been criticized as inflammatory, anti-American and racially polarizing, described himself on Sunday as descriptive, not divisive.

title: Group Urges Ban on Medical Giveaways
description: Drug and medical device companies should be banned from offering free food, gifts, travel and ghost-writing services to doctors, staff members and students in all 129 of the nations medical colleges, an influential college association has concluded.

title: Kidds Signature Moment Is Ugly One for Mavericks
description: DALLAS  Jason Kidd made his long-awaited playoff impact here Sunday night, with the wrong play, at the wrong time and with perhaps the worst possible result. It just might have been his last meaningful moment of the season.

title: Mars Reportedly Near Deal to Acquire Wrigley
description: Mars, the makers of M&Ms, was near a deal last night to acquire the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the chewing gum concern, for more than $22 billion, people involved in the talks said. The transaction would create a confectionery behemoth and could pressure rivals into a cascade of other mergers.

title: Making Their Own Mistakes
description: When Pervez Musharraf was running Pakistan he repeatedly cut deals with tribal leaders intended to calm the countrys lawless regions. The results were always disastrous. The Taliban and Al Qaeda used the time to regroup and launch attacks both inside Pakistan and against Afghanistan.

title: WB Network Returns as a Web Site
description: The WB brand, born as a broadcast network in 1995 and closed in 2006, will return as an online video Web site combining short original series with classic shows, the Warner Brothers Television Group announced Monday.

title: Grand Theft Auto Takes On New York
description: I was rolling through the neon deluge of a place very like Times Square the other night in my Landstalker sport utility vehicle, listening to David Bowies Fascination on the radio. The glittery urban landscape was almost enough to make me forget about the warehouse of cocaine dealers I was headed uptown to rip off.

title: German Academy Honors Its Films
description: The Fatih Akin ensemble drama The Edge of Heaven, a Turkish-German production about two deaths that bring strangers together, won prizes for best picture, director and screenplay when the 58th German Film Awards were bestowed at a gala in Berlin on Friday night, Variety reported. In winning the best-picture Lola  Germanys equivalent of an Oscar  The Edge of Heaven beat the favorite, Cherry Blossoms, a film by Doris Drrie about a cranky old Bavarian civil servant and his metamorphosis in Japan after his wifes death. Nevertheless it won three prizes, including the Silver Lola that goes to the runner-up for best film and a best-actor prize for Elmar Wepper as the widower. The award for best actress went to Nina Hoss as a businesswoman grappling with inner demons in the Christian Petzold drama Yella. Financed by Germanys culture ministry and voted by the more than 1,000 members of the German Film Academy, Lolas are presented in 15 categories and carry $4.4 million in prizes.

title: At Journal, the Words Not Spoken
description: On Wednesday night, employees of The Wall Street Journal gathered in the Grill Room at the World Financial Center to bid farewell to Stuart Karle, the former general counsel of The Journal, a tenacious defender of journalism who is regarded as a reporters lawyer.

title: Cartoons of a Racist Past Lurk on YouTube
description: Among the millions of clips on the video-sharing Web site YouTube are 11 racially offensive Warner Brothers cartoons that have not been shown in an authorized release since 1968.

title: Articles in the Business Section of The New York Times

title: Desert Reign: Coachella as Princes Castle
description: INDIO, Calif.  Less than three weeks before this years Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, still the countrys banner festival of alternative rock, Prince joined the bill in the most prominent slot. He was Saturday nights final main-stage show, at the end of a day including important sets by Portishead and M.I.A. The addition seemed like a last-minute attempt to increase ticket sales, but it also raised the question: What does Prince signify these days to alternative-rock America? We know what he means in the physical world, even in the California desert here. But what about in the state of mind that is alternative culture; what does he mean in Indie-O? And what would he do to address the credibility issue, the chimerical question that hangs over just about every performer here?

title: Winehouse Incident Leads to Warning
description: The latest brush with the law for the Grammy-winning singer Amy Winehouse, below, ended on Saturday when the police issued her a formal waning, known as a caution for assault and released her without charge after she spent a night in custody, The Associated Press reported. The caution means that the matter will remain on her record and could count against her should she be charged with a similar offense. Her spokesman, Chris Goodman, said Ms. Winehouse, 24, had admitted to a common assault by slapping a man with an open hand and accepted a caution. The statement said, Amy was fully cooperative and apologized for the incident. She was arrested on suspicion of assault after reports of a scuffle with two men during a wild night out. Ms. Winehouse and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were arrested in Norway in October on charges of drug possession. Ms. Winehouse was arrested in London in December on suspicion of attempting to interfere with a court case involving her husband, who is in jail awaiting trial on charges of perverting the course of justice in a case in which he is accused of assaulting a barman.

The shows producers have held auditions in Nashville; Orlando, Fla.; and other cities. Now the producers will hold auditions on the Internet as well. One episode of the variety show will be devoted to the submissions of MySpace.com users. People are uploading music videos, tricks and stunts to MySpace all the time, said Josh Brooks, MySpaces vice president for marketing and content development. title: City Room: Lost World of the Fulton Fish Market
description: "Row of Filleters," 1982. One of 37 images on display at the South Street Sea Port Museum by a Brooklyn-born artist. (Photo: Barbara Mensch, Courtesy Bonni Benrubi Gallery)  See a Slide Show  When the city closed the Fulton Fish Market in 2005, moving it to the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, it marked the end of a 183-year tradition of working-class life on the Manhattan waterfront. A new exhibition of photographs at the South Street Seaport Museum, by a photographer who devoted years to documenting the lives of the men who worked along the piers, pays tribute to that tradition, not long gone yet seeming already to be an element of the city's mythic past.   The 37 images in the exhibition, which opened on Saturday and is on view through December, are largely but not entirely drawn from "South Street," which Columbia University Press published last year. The photographs in the book are drawn from a four-year period, 1979 to 1983, when Barbara G. Mensch, a Brooklyn-born artist who attended Hunter College and moved to the seaport area soon after, slowly managed to earn the trust of the fish workers, enabling her to compile an extraordinary portrait of waterfront life.   (Writing about the book last year, Sam Roberts of The Times noted that that way of life already seemed long vanished. "Savoring the vivid faces in Ms. Menschs photographs, though, and reading her picturesque profiles of the loaders, lumpers and other workers, you can almost still smell the fish," he wrote.)  Attracted by what at the time was one of the city's more affordable neighborhoods, Ms. Mensch moved to an apartment near the seaport in 1979; she has never left.  Ms. Mensch, who grew up in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, had studied drawing and earth sciences at Hunter, says she picked up a Rolliflex medium-format camera at the suggestion of an art instructor and began taking pictures of her mother, who was dying of cancer. Ms. Mensch's died in 1979, and her father in 1980.   The men of the seaport, she said, became a substitute family. "There was a certain warmth and genuineness," she said. "I dont know if its because of that old immigrant culture  primarily Italian or Jewish  where people care about you and want to make sure you're O.K. They would watch your back. They'd ask, 'Have you eaten enough?' One guy used to make me meatball sandwiches to take home because I was too skinny. Another would hand me a flounder that had fallen off a truck to take home."  These were big tough guys, she emphasized: "Their muscles were so enormous they could crush you like a bug. I was terrified the whole time. I look back on the things I did and the risks I took and I could never do it today. Theres no way."  Eventually, photography became the main thrust of Ms. Mensch's artistic practice. The fish market became an enduring subject, which Ms. Mensch would visit again and again. Many of the images are not only of the physical environment, but also revealing portraits of the workers.   "I caught the last wave of the old waterfront -- the bars, the flophouses," she said in a phone interview. "The essence of the market was the old-timers, those amazing faces that come out at you."   In 1985, she published "The Last Waterfront: The People of South Street," a book of photographs and taped interviews, but today she views it as an early, inadequate work. "The photographs in there were more illustrative of the market as opposed to the essence of my own artistic endeavor, which was to get into the soul of the place," she said. "It wasnt really the story I wanted to tell. I was a kid. I was a bambino."  Ms. Mensch is fascinated -- and saddened -- by what she views as the "profound change in the urban landscape of New York," a change that is sweeping away so much of the city's past. Yet, she insisted, "Its not about nostalgia. It's about what do we replace all these things were destroying with? Where are we going as a culture -- as a civilization - when we walk around and everything looks like interchangeable?"   Last year, around the time her book was published, the Museum of the City of New York approached Ms. Mensch, who is represented by the Bonni Benrubi Galley, about putting up an exhibition of her work. Mary Ellen Pelzer, the executive director of the South Street Seaport Museum, said that Susan Henshaw Jones, the president of the Museum of the City of New York, generously agreed to let the downtown museum have the show after Ms. Pelzer expressed interest.   "The fish market has been so instrumental in the recent development of the region but also in the long history over the past two centuries," Ms. Pelzer said in a phone interview. "Since our mission is to preserve and interpret the port of New York and the culture and commerce of it, this is perfect for us. More specifically, Barbaras work is so evocative of just what a working mans life was like in this district: the harsh environments, the difficult tasks, things that some people wouldn't really treat with respect and honesty."  Thomas Mellins, who is curator for special exhibitions at the Museum of the City of New York and organized the exhibition of Ms. Mensch's photographs for the South Street Seaport Museum, said he went through hundreds of images for the show. He also included some of Ms. Mensch's more recent images of the seaport -- as recent as 2005 -- for the show. In a phone interview, he said he was struck by the haunting power of Ms. Mensch's photographs. He said:   I would say they are unflinching, but they go far beyond documentation. Its almost elegiac. It has great respect for people and places and the activities that are being portrayed. There certainly is an element of the old New York and the kind of reverence for the past that people often have, but at the same time, I would say that any sense of nostalgia is tempered by the harsh realities of the work that was conducted at the market. Its not a romanticized vision, but it is clear that this is a place that Barbara had a strong sense of tie to.   In an introduction to Ms. Mensch's book, the writer Phillip Lopate examines the market and what it meant for New York. He wrote:   Its obstinate prolonged existence points to one of the main paradoxes embedded in the city's character: for all that the image of Manhattan has rightly become identified in the world's imagination with modernity, its local population has often resisted technological upgrading and clung to provisions, stopgap work practices that become fixed through tradition.   The fish market used to be one of only several large commercial operations along the waterfront, but the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883 "sounded the death knell of the Fulton Market as an all-purpose emporium," Mr. Lopate wrote. "No longer would housekeepers arrive daily from Brooklyn on the Fulton Ferry; instead, pedestrians and passengers would be deposited many blocks west, on Centre Street." Construction of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in the 1940s helped isolate the market even further, casting moody shadows over the market but also protecting it from developers who might otherwise have wanted to seize the valuable land, with its proximity to the Financial District.  The market where Alfred E. Smith had once toiled as a teenager seemed increasingly obsolete in an era of refrigerated trucks and air travel. Talk of relocating the market went as far back as 1956, when David Rockefeller, then the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, led a group of businesses that considered the future of Lower Manhattan. The city announced that the fish market would move to Hunts Point in 1969, but the subsequent fiscal crisis postponed such plans. The last trawler to dock at the fish market did so in 1979.   "If the adjoining docks no longer served any function and the fish market was nothing more than a staging area for trucks, it could be located anywhere -- preferably near a major highway, with plenty of parking," Mr. Lopate wrote.   In 1983, the Rouse Company, a private developer, transformed much of the seaport area adjoining the fish market into a tourist-oriented recreational zone and placing more pressure on the commerce remaining in the area. The market's reputation for organized crime did not aid its survival.   In 1987, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States attorney in Manhattan at the time, announced the filing of a civil lawsuit seeking to seize control of the Fulton Fish Market on the ground that the Genovese crime family dominated it, driving up fish prices and improperly influencing the union of seafood workers. (At the time, Ms. Mensch was quoted in The Times saying she was upset about the racketeering accusations. ''These guys are out there shoveling fish carcasses,'' she said. ''They're as far from the Mafia as you can get.'')  In 1990, Ms. Mensch joined community residents who expressed opposition to the proposed rehabilitation of the Lettie G. Howard, a 19th-century fishing schooner that had been declared a national landmark. The residents supported the idea of restoration, but worried that the project would imperil the area's delicate balance of tourist, residential and maritime uses. ''If they have that big giant boat in there, in addition to the noise and the construction, it's another situation where the fish market cannot conduct its business,'' Ms. Mensch said at the time.   Lower Manhattan has gained residents since 9/11 -- against most expectations -- and the combination of residential growth and the desire to promote tourism meant that the fish market's days were numbered.   In 2004, as the city prepared to move the Fulton Fish Market to Hunts Point in the Bronx, Ms. Mensch was the subject of an About New York column by Dan Barry. Now I look at this place, and it's like death to me, she said at the time. There's nothing living.   Mr. Barry suggested that the seaport itself had become indistinguishable from other tourist-centered visitors' areas, comparing it to other tourist districts like Quincy Market in Boston and the Inner Harbor in Baltimore: "Novelties on cobblestones, nothing more."  Ms. Mensch's images, then, are a reminder of all that was lost. "Mensch's photographs sometimes give the impression of dating from another, much earlier era, although she used no antiquing tricks to achieve that effect: it is simply that the tribe she portrays seems a throwback," Mr. Lopate wrote. "Their faces and bodies express an almost ancient awareness of the price that must be paid to be a man, to hold one's ground, especially in a society less and less respectful of working-class culture."

title: Indiana Rules
description: The Supreme Court on Monday upheld Indianas voter-identification law, declaring that a requirement to produce photo identification is not unconstitutional and that the state has a valid interest in improving election procedures as well as deterring fraud, reports The Timess David Stout. In a 6-to-3 ruling in one of the most eagerly awaited election-law cases in years, the court rejected arguments that Indianas law, probably the strictest in the country, imposes unjustified burdens on people who are old, poor or members of minority groups and less likely to have drivers licenses or other acceptable forms of identification.

title: Is Breath-Holding Hazardous to Your Brain?
description: Hes risking heart failure, brain damage . . . even death. Paramedics are standing by . . . youll have to see it for yourself!Ah, nothing like daytime television when it comes to sober presentations of science. The Oprah Winfrey Show is promoting David Blaines appearance this Wednesday as a death-defying feat, which is not quite the way scientists (or Mr. Blaine) see his attempt to break the world record for breath-holding. Underwater breath-holding can lead to fatal blackouts if you do it without proper supervision, but Mr. Blaine will be carefully observed. Experts like Ralph Potkin, the pulmonologist who monitored Mr. Blaine during his training (which I described in my Findings column), say that prolonged breath-holds dont appear to cause harm to the body  at least not in the short term.

title: The Court Fumbles on Voting Rights
description: Democracy was the big loser in the Supreme Court on Monday. The court upheld Indianas voter identification law, which solves a nearly nonexistent problem by putting major barriers between voters  particularly minorities  and the ballot box. Worse, the court set out a standard that clears the way for other states to adopt rules that discourage disadvantaged groups from voting. It is a sad reversal for a court that once saw itself as a champion of voting rights.

title: Breezing Through the Derby Workouts
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Until Big Brown hits the racetrack Tuesday morning, Colonel John wears the title Best in Show. He is a chiseled colt with a regal bearing who has invited comparisons to Street Sense and Barbaro, who conducted themselves as if they were movie stars here and won the last two Derbies.

title: Suing Over Pay Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: New Look at Death Sentences and Race
description: About 1,100 people have been executed in the United States in the last three decades. Harris County, Tex., which includes Houston, accounts for more than 100 of those executions. Indeed, Harris County has sent more people to the death chamber than any state but Texas itself.

title: Unearthing Tangled Roots of a Towns Family Trees
description: A terrible act of racism stands at the center of Louise Erdrichs masterly new novel: in the early years of the 20th century, after five members of a white family are found murdered, a group of men run down a party of Indians and deliver what was called at the time rough justice. Three men and a boy are hanged  one miraculously survives  while the actual murderer of the Lochren family goes unpunished.

title: Chinese Students in U.S. Fight View of Their Home
description: LOS ANGELES  When the time came for the smiling Tibetan monk at the front of the University of Southern California lecture hall to answer questions, the Chinese students who packed the audience for the talk last Tuesday had plenty to lob at their guest:

title: As North Carolina Primary Looms, Eyes on Edwards
description: WILMINGTON, N.C.  What will the Edwardses do?

title: In Hepatitis Trends, Good News and Bad
description: Rates of new hepatitis A and B infections have declined to the lowest levels ever recorded, largely because of routine childhood vaccination, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But the news is not so good about hepatitis C, for which there is no vaccine.

title: North Korean Officer Defects to the South
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A North Korean military officer defected to South Korea across its heavily armed border, the first Communist officer to do so in a decade, a South Korean military spokesman said on Monday.

title: Thats So Bad Its ______
description: The word unconscionable has become one of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs favorite verbal jabs. Here are some examples:

title: Consumer Confidence Slips as Home Prices Drop
description: Americans confidence in the economy continued to plunge this month as their homes lost value at the fastest rate in two decades, according to reports released on Tuesday.

title: Obama Adds to Distance From Pastor and Opinions
description: WILMINGTON, N.C.  If it was not clear before Monday, Senator Barack Obama said, it should be clear now: His presidential campaign has no control over what the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., his former pastor, says or what he does.

title: Study Warns Job Losses Will Strain Government Health Programs
description: Leading health researchers projected Monday that each percentage-point rise in unemployment during the economic downturn would swell the uninsured by 1.1 million, stoking demand for government health coverage just as states face pressure to cut benefits.

title: Coldplay at No Charge
description: Free music for fans of the English band  Coldplay will be available for a week beginning Tuesday when it offers a download of Violet Hill, the first single from its new album, Viva la Vida, The Associated Press reported. The music, as well as preliminary information about Coldplays free shows at the Brixton Academy in London on June 16 and at Madison Square Garden on June 23, will be available on the bands Web site, coldplay.com. The band also announced on Monday that the British release of Viva la Vida has been advanced four days, to June 12, when the album will be released in much of the world.

title: The Acquittal in the Sean Bell Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy: Ex-Premier Declines Russian Energy Job
description: Romano Prodi, Italys departing prime minister, declined an offer from Gazprom, the Russian energy company, to become chairman of a new Russian-Italian natural gas pipeline. Aleksei Miller, Gazproms chief executive, made the offer in Rome where he met with Mr. Prodi and executives at its partner in the project, the Italian energy group Eni. Analysts said Gazproms attempts to entice Mr. Prodi to the project showed its determination to match its ever-growing energy power in Europe with political influence. Once complete, the pipeline, running under the Black Sea, would have a capacity of about 1 trillion cubic feet of natural gas a year, according to Gazprom and Eni. Gazprom is also building a pipeline beneath the Baltic Sea to ship natural gas to Germany.

title: Getting Modern Weapons Into Our Soldiers Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lexicon Debate (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: An Irascible Firebrand, Quieted by Term Limits
description: LINCOLN, Neb.  The senior senator of Nebraskas unicameral Legislature is going out just the way he came in nearly four decades ago: obstinately, and with a whole lot to say in his T-shirt and jeans.

title: 2 Casualties Dont Deter All-Business-Class Rivalry
description: THE two start-up airlines that helped established the international all-business-class model in late 2005 have now expired and joined the Choir Invisible, as the Monty Python sketch said of the dead parrot.

title: Frey Defends His Memoir
description: James Frey, below, the best-selling author of A Million Little Pieces who was publicly shamed after admitting he made up or exaggerated details in his memoir of drug addiction and recovery, said in a new interview that he had always made it very clear to his editor and agent that the book began as a novel, and that, as such, he had fudged some particulars. In an exclusive interview with Mr. Frey in Vanity Fair that will be on newsstands Wednesday in New York and Los Angeles, Evgenia Peretz quotes an authors questionnaire that Mr. Frey filled out for his publisher, Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, a Random House Inc. imprint, in which he described the book as more a work of art or literature than a work of memoir or autobiography. Ms. Peretz also refers to two unidentified publishing sources who say that Sean McDonald, Mr. Freys editor, aimed at heightening the drama, without questioning the veracity of the text. Mr. Frey, who is preparing for the publication of his novel, Bright Shiny Morning, did not return a phone call seeking comment. Through a spokeswoman Mr. McDonald, who is now an editor at Riverhead Books, a unit of Penguin Group, declined to comment.

title: Decision Is Likely to Spur Voter ID Laws in More States
description: WASHINGTON  Far from settling the debate over voter identification, the Supreme Court ruling on Monday upholding Indianas voter ID law is likely to lead to more laws and litigation, voting experts said.

title: Voting Group Sues Florida Over Penalties
description: MIAMI  The League of Women Voters of Florida sued state election officials on Monday to challenge a law that fines voter registration groups for losing registration forms or returning them late.

title: A PBS Assignment for Aaron Brown
description: Aaron Brown, below, a former anchor for CNN, will return to television after an absence of more than two years when he joins the PBS Wide Angle series, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown said that his new job as anchor of Wide Angle, a weekly public affairs series with a global focus, offered an opportunity to work in an environment where people just think about making good TV and good journalism. The series begins its seventh season on July 1. Mr. Brown, 59, left CNN in November 2005 during a shakeup that gave his time slot to the rising star Anderson Cooper. Mr. Brown said he was contractually barred from working in television until last June. He has been teaching at Arizona State University as its first Walter Cronkite professor of journalism.

title: On the Web
description: THE LOEWS CORPORATION, the conglomerate run by the Tisch family, posted an unexpected decline in first-quarter profit, hurt by the results of its CNA Financial insurance unit. (REUTERS)

title: Senate Democrats Calling for More Food Assistance
description: WASHINGTON  Citing hunger riots in developing countries and soaring grain prices around the world, Senate Democrats called on Monday for a swift increase of $200 million in foreign food aid, on top of an additional $350 million that President Bush has requested in a supplemental spending measure.

title: Austria Stunned by Case of Imprisoned Woman
description: AMSTETTEN, Austria  With his Mercedes-Benz and his fine clothes, Josef Fritzl looked every inch a property owner, neighbors in this tidy Austrian town said Monday. Even when running errands, they said, he wore a natty jacket, crisp shirt and tie.

title: Mavericks Only Certainty Is a Cloudy Future
description: NEW ORLEANS  The itinerary Monday called for the Dallas Mavericks to hold a brief practice, then fly to New Orleans. But the practice was decidedly unconventional and the Mavericks ultimate destination is anything but clear.

title: Aging: Depression Tied to Alzheimers
description: A history of depression is associated with an increased risk for Alzheimers disease, a new study has found, especially when the depression develops before age 60.

title: Nostrums: Study Critiques Antioxidant Supplements
description: A review of 67 randomized trials of antioxidant supplements has found no evidence that they prolong life, and strong evidence that they might shorten it. The trials included almost a quarter-million participants, including healthy people and those with various diseases.

title: Muzzling the Watchdog
description: THE downfall of Bear Stearns, the release of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulsons sweeping blueprint for the overhaul of our financial regulatory structure, and the worsening health of the stock market and our economy has raised serious questions for the future of the Securities and Exchange Commission. As the capital-markets regulator and investors advocate, the S.E.C. is a natural recipient of finger-pointing during a market crisis.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Schedule information with a theater review on Monday about The Castle, at New World Stages on West 50th Street, misstated the scheduled length of the plays run. It is open-ended; it is not scheduled to close on May 18. The review, using information provided by a publicist, also misstated the surname of an actor who also collaborated on the script. He is Kenneth Harrigan, not Harrington.

title: A Tantalizing Look at Irans Nuclear Program
description: Barbed wire and antiaircraft guns ring a maze of buildings in the Iranian desert that lie at the heart of the Wests five-year standoff with Tehran over its program to enrich uranium.

title: Old Teammates Understand Why Winning and Drury Seem Inseparable
description: When they came home from Williamsport, Pa., as Little League World Series champions that beautiful August day in 1989, the 15 boys from Trumbull, Conn., were full of youth and spunk, with seemingly boundless futures ahead of them.

title: Prevention: So Many Mosquitoes, Only So Many Nets
description: Simple as they are, even mosquito nets generate complicated numbers games.

title: Mourning Construction Workers, and Fearing More Shutdowns
description: As the city kicks off Construction Safety Week, there is growing concern among developers, builders and unions that the safety crackdown by the Buildings Department is causing unnecessary delays and layoffs at some major construction sites, including the Goldman Sachs headquarters downtown.

title: Gazan Mother and 4 Children Killed
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian mother and her four young children were killed in northern Gaza on Monday during an Israeli operation against militants there, and a dispute quickly arose over exactly how they had died.

title: Filly Is Ready to Take on the Colts, but Will She?
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It is not the competition that has Rick Porter worried. As the owner of Eight Belles, Porter figures he has the type of filly with the talent and toughness to beat the males in the Kentucky Derby. It is the luck of the draw that has him concerned, so much so that he was still not sure where his filly will race this week, in the Kentucky Oaks or the Derby.

title: A Vigilant Building Department for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: William H. Stewart Is Dead at 86; Put First Warnings on Cigarette Packs
description: Dr. William H. Stewart, a surgeon general in the Johnson administration who put the first health warnings on cigarette packs and integrated the United States Public Health Service and many Southern hospitals, died on April 23 in New Orleans. He was 86.

title: Crisis Catches Up to Deutsche Bank
description: FRANKFURT Deutsche Bank won praise and envy in financial circles for appearing to weather the credit storm better than most of its peers, but its luck finally ran out on Tuesday.

title: Shell and BP Report Record First-Quarter Profits
description: LONDON  Higher oil and gas prices helped Royal Dutch Shell and BP report record first-quarter profits on Tuesday, beating analysts expectations and prompting a rise in stock prices across the industry.

description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review on Monday about a recital by Bryn Terfel, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the first word of a Mozart aria he performed. It begins Io ti lascio, not Lo ti lascio.

title: Political Theories Abound in North Carolina, but Dont Ask John Edwards for His
description: WILMINGTON, N.C.  What will the Edwardses do?

title: Should They Send a Thank-You Note?
description: Doctors almost always take umbrage at the notion that their judgments can be influenced by free lunches or plane tickets to a resort paradise. Most patients would prefer that their doctors arent even tempted.

title: Coachella Builds a Bigger Game
description: INDIO, Calif.  Indie cred is a shell game, and the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival keeps moving the shells around.

title: Strike Possible This Week at Bloomingdales Main Store
description: Bloomingdales storied window displays could soon be obscured by an unusual sight: picketing workers.

title: In Manhattan, a Plan to Turn 3 Landmark Homes Into One
description: When Andrew Carnegie decided to build himself a mansion in 1898, he headed to the northernmost reaches of the city at the time, situating his 64-room Georgian-style country home on a relatively undeveloped tract of land at 91st Street and Fifth Avenue. There was even enough space for what was then one of the citys largest private gardens.

title: Indian Prime Minister Denounces Abortion of Females
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian prime minister described the widespread practice of aborting female fetuses as a national shame on Monday, and called for stricter enforcement of laws devised to prevent doctors from helping parents to avoid the birth of unwanted daughters.

title: United Said to Restart Talks With US Airways
description: For the last five years, Glenn F. Tilton has talked often about the need for mergers and consolidation in the airline industry, hanging out the equivalent of a for sale sign at his troubled United Airlines.

title: Sallie Wilson, Dramatic Ballerina, Dies at 76
description: Sallie Wilson, whose performances with American Ballet Theater during the 1960s and 70s established her as one of Americas finest dramatic ballerinas, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

title: Supposed Hendrix Sex Tape Is Offered
description: LOS ANGELES  In a twist on the recent string of sex tapes of Hollywoods young stars, Vivid Entertainment plans to release what it says is a film from the vaults of classic rock: a sex film supposedly of Jimi Hendrix.

title: Emergency Radio Network Contractor Agrees to Pay New York $4 Million in Dispute
description: The company building New York States $2 billion emergency radio network has agreed to pay the state $4 million to settle a dispute over other longstanding radio contracts, the state comptrollers office announced on Monday.

title: New Yorks Slush Addiction
description: Politicians in New York City and Albany really enjoy giving away the publics money and making it seem like their own largess. As the latest news out of the New York City Council attests, these grants are, at best, a political trick intended to buy voter loyalty. At worst, they have led to outright theft.

title: Wright Says Criticism Is Attack on Black Church
description: Attacks on him are really attacks on the black church, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. said in a speech to the National Press Club in Washington on Monday, in which he mounted a spirited defense of views and sermons that have become an issue in the presidential campaign because Senator Barack Obama attended his church for many years.

title: ABC Dominates Prime Time
description: ABC proved unbeatable in the ratings on Sunday, as new installments of Desperate Housewives, right, with Eva Longoria, Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Brothers & Sisters led all four hours of prime time. Nielsen reported that Desperate Housewives earned the largest audience over all, drawing 16.2 million viewers during the 9 p.m. hour. Preceding it a two-hour edition of Extreme Makeover delivered 9.6 million viewers from 7 to 9, while at 10 Brothers & Sisters attracted 11.6 million, easily outpacing a Law & Order: Special Victims Unit repeat on NBC and Dexter on CBS, both of which averaged 6.5 million viewers. CBS finished second for the night, drawing 6.7 million viewers at 8 p.m. for Big Brother 9. CBS fared better both before and after the reality shows finale, earning 9.7 million viewers for 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. and 11.5 million for Cold Case at 9. Meanwhile Fox, led by Family Guy at 9 (8.5 million) and The Simpsons at 8 (7.7 million), finished third in total viewers but second among adults 18 to 49, well ahead of CBS. NBC was fourth for the night.

title: Oil Price Rise Fails to Open Tap
description: As oil prices soared to record levels in recent years, basic economics suggested that consumption would fall and supplies would rise as producers drilled for more oil.

title: Colleges High Cost, Before You Even Apply
description: As the frenzied admissions season winds to a close, many students finally know where they will be attending college in the fall.

title: $81 Million for Reserve of Teachers
description: New York City is paying $81 million over two years in salaries and benefits for teachers without permanent teaching jobs, according to a report being released on Tuesday.

title: Delgado Will Wait to Take His Bow
description: Carlos Delgado was not booed by the home fans for making outs or cheered for hitting home runs Monday night.

title: Today in Business
description: PUZZLING OIL RESPONSE Energy analysts are concerned that higher oil prices have done little to slow demand or to spur new production.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Reunites
description: JOHANNESBURG  With many of their activists under violent attack and hundreds of their supporters in jail, the leaders of Zimbabwes divided opposition formally announced Monday that the two groups had reunited, claiming control of Parliament for the first time in the nations history and demanding that President Robert Mugabe concede the recent election.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kenya: Raises for Striking Jail Guards
description: The government announced that it was raising the salaries of jail guards to end a strike in which the guards had threatened to release hard-core inmates if their demands were not met. The government increased salaries by $80 a month and promised to improve the squalid conditions many guards live in. But it also arrested nine senior officers and called the strike an illegal mutiny. Hundreds, if not thousands, of guards have been on strike since last week, refusing to feed inmates. Many guards had returned to their posts by Monday night but some were still refusing to work.

title: Kerkorian Buys Stake in Ford
description: DETROIT  This time, Kirk Kerkorian seems content to hitch a ride on the potential turnaround of a Detroit automaker instead of grabbing the wheel himself.

title: Exploiting Real Fears With Virtual Kidnappings
description: MEXICO CITY  The phone call begins with the cries of an anguished child calling for a parent: Mama! Papa! The youngsters sobs are quickly replaced by a husky male voice that means business.

title: Tax Rebates in $168 Billion Stimulus Plan Begin Arriving in Bank Accounts
description: The federal government began issuing electronic tax rebates on Monday under a $168 billion program to bolster the economy.

title: Cleared as Criminals, but Forever on Trial
description: You had to wonder if the setting was somebodys misguided stab at irony.

title: France Still Divided Over Lessons of 1968 Unrest
description: NANTERRE, France  Forty years ago, French students in neckties and bobby socks threw cobblestones at the police and demanded that the sclerotic post-war system must change. Today, French students, worried about finding jobs and losing state benefits, are marching through the streets demanding that nothing change at all.

title: Desperation Gathers and Makes a Nightly Dash for Britain
description: CALAIS, France  It is midnight, and eight hooded figures slip around the side of a freight truck at a gas station on the outskirts of this northern French port. They wait in the orange half-light while one tries the locked truck door. It doesnt give, and seconds later the figures vanish among the dozens of semitrailers at this, the last truck stop before England.

title: Torch Nears, Posing Test of Autonomy in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  The Olympic torch relay coming here on Friday, the first on Chinese soil, is turning into a broader struggle over Hong Kongs evolving role as an autonomous territory of China.

title: The Pastor Casts a Shadow
description: The Rev. Jeremiah Wright went to Washington on Monday not to praise Barack Obama, but to bury him.

title: With Demand Slipping for Its Pickups and S.U.V.s, G.M. Will Lay Off 3,550
description: DETROIT  General Motors said Monday that it would slash production of big trucks and sport utility vehicles by nearly 140,000 units this year, a move that would eliminate assembly shifts at four plants and cause about 3,550 workers to be laid off.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Tells of Push by Pentagon on Detainees
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  The former chief prosecutor here took the witness stand on Monday on behalf of a detainee and testified that top Pentagon officials had pressured him in deciding which cases to prosecute and what evidence to use.

title: Another Elite Eventing Rider Is Injured; Two Horses Are Euthanized
description: A top rider in the Olympic equestrian sport of eventing was seriously injured after her horse somersaulted over a fence Saturday at the Rolex Kentucky Three-Day Event, the nations premier eventing competition. Her horse and another horse, after a separate fall, were euthanized.

title: No Prosecution for bin Laden Prank
description: Australian television comics escaped punishment on Monday when a prosecutor dropped charges lodged against them for bringing an Osama bin Laden look-alike, above, through security at the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Sydney in September, Agence France-Presse reported. The team from the show The Chasers War on Everything came within yards of a hotel where President Bush was staying when they posed as part of a Canadian motorcade and their three-car convoy was waved through security checkpoints. They were halted after one of the comedians from the show emerged dressed as Mr. bin Laden from a car. The 10 men and one woman working on the show were charged with entering a restricted area without justification. Nicholas Cowdery, the director of public prosecutions for New South Wales, said that the circumstances were unusual, and that the charges had been dropped. He noted that the comics, driver and crew, carrying fake security passes, had been waved into the secure zone by the police. He said, Police permission in fact constitutes special justification for entry.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Noble Eagles, Nasty Pigeons, Biased Humans
description: The other day I glanced out my window and felt a twinge of revulsion delicately seasoned with indignation. Pecking at my bird feeder were two brown-headed cowbirds, one male and one female, and I knew what that meant. Pretty soon the fattened, fertilized female would be slipping her eggs into some other birds nest, with the expectation that the nave hosts would brood, feed and rear her squawking, ravenous young at the neglect and even death of their own.

title: Cardinal Egan Says Giuliani Shouldnt Have Received Communion From Pope
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan said on Monday that former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani should not have received holy communion during the visit of Pope Benedict XVI because Mr. Giuliani supports abortion rights.

title: Vexing Issue for the Clinton Campaign: What to Make of Bill?
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of a week in which Bill Clintons stumping for his wife was again overshadowed by a distraction, many Democrats were asking: Is this method, or madness?

title: Its Candidates Otherwise Engaged, Democratic Party Goes After McCain
description: WASHINGTON  With no end in sight to the nominating contest between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, the Democratic Party has begun its first sustained advertising campaign against Senator John McCain, introducing a new commercial this week criticizing his recent comments that he could envision a United States presence in Iraq for 100 years.

title: Hotels Try New Features With Test Rooms
description: It is known simply as the X-room.

title: Even After Acquittal, Careers of 6 Officers in 50-Shot Case Remain in Limbo
description: One pushes paper at a base for Staten Island detectives. Another makes phone calls to investigators whenever theres a homicide in the Bronx. Four others perform administrative tasks at desks at various spots in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: School Campus Receives a Living Senators Name, Much to His Opponents Annoyance
description: It is there in black and white: New York City public schools cannot be named after living people, according to the chancellors regulations, the set of rules and policies governing the citys school system.

title: Revival for Owen, and Renewal for Newcastle
description: After struggling with injuries for much of the last three seasons, Michael Owen has apparently rediscovered his scoring touch  and not a moment too soon.

title: The Mayor Has a Word for Almost All Occasions
description: Its Michael R. Bloombergs favorite epithet. And if you have ever done anything to pique his ire, chances are he has hurled it in your direction.

title: A Great Poxs Greatest Feat: Staying Alive
description: The findings were hardly earth-shaking. They dealt with an obscure bacterial infection found in an equally obscure group of natives in Guyana. Nonetheless, they made headlines.

title: A New Mideast Paper Vows to Be Different
description: ONE of the Middle Easts wealthiest ruling families has a new asset: The National, a newspaper that promises independence from its royal owners.

title: Bob Dylan Joins Baltimore Festival
description: Bob Dylan, below, has joined the lineup of the Third Annual Virgin Mobile Festival at the Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore on Aug. 9 and 10. The indie-alternative rock, hip-hop and electronic music show will also include Iggy & the Stooges, Chuck Berry, Cat Power, Wilco and the Swell Season, as well as Foo Fighters, Jack Johnson, Kanye West, Stone Temple Pilots and Nine Inch Nails, according to an announcement from Richard Branson, the founder and chairman of the Virgin Group. In addition to the two main stages the setting will include a dedicated dance tent featuring electronic music by Moby and others.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Voter Identification Law in Indiana
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court upheld Indianas voter-identification law on Monday, declaring that a requirement to produce photo identification is not unconstitutional and that the state has a valid interest in improving election procedures as well as deterring fraud.

title: More Checked Bag Fees in Coach
description: MORE CHECKED-BAG FEES The lone holdout among the network carriers, American Airlines, said Monday that on May 12 it would join the competition and start charging $25 for a second checked bag. The fee will apply to all coach passengers except those on full-fare tickets and those with elite status in the AAdvantage frequent-flier program. The Alaska Air Group, which operates Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air, said it would also start charging $25 for a second checked bag, starting this summer. The fee for an overweight bag will double, to $50, and the extra fee for an unaccompanied minor will rise to $75 from $30. Horizon Air, meanwhile, will get rid of 20 CRJ-700 regional jets as part of a plan to fly only 76-seat Bombardier Q400 turbo-propeller planes. The CRJ-700s are less fuel-efficient.

title: For Gamers, the Craving Wont Quit
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The troubled economy and rising prices for food and gas wont keep fast-twitch video gamers from splurging on their latest must-have diversion, Grand Theft Auto IV.

title: Democrats Divided Over Gas Tax Break
description: WASHINGTON  As angry truckers encircled the Capitol in a horn-blaring caravan and consumers across the country agonized over $60 fill-ups, the issue of high fuel prices flared on the campaign trail on Monday, sharply dividing the two Democratic candidates.

title: Of Diversity and Bacteria (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: You Name It, and Exercise Helps It
description: Randi considers the Y.M.C.A. her lifeline, especially the pool. Randi weighs more than 300 pounds and has borderline diabetes, but she controls her blood sugar and keeps her bright outlook on life by swimming every day for about 45 minutes.

title: Iran Advises Self-Censorship
description: Irans culture minister reacted on Monday to publishers criticisms of the countrys evaluation process by urging writers to censor their own books if they hoped for publication in the Islamic republic, Agence France-Presse reported. At a news conference the minister, Mohammad Hossein Safar, said: This is what we ask publishers and writers, You are aware of the vetting code, so censor pages which are likely to create a dispute. Declaring that publications should conform to the systems religious, moral and national sensitivities, he warned against graphic descriptions of relationships or sex, saying, It is a clear violation of the law to give an excessive portrayal of a man and womans private relationships and to subject our youth and adults to descriptions of intercourse, adding that if anyone makes fun of religion, be it Islam or Christianity, the country should not allow opposition to God to be reflected in the media. All publications in Iran must be approved by the Culture Ministry. Publishers have complained of tighter censorship of new books since Mahmoud Ahmadinejad became president in 2005. The culture minister made his remarks in reply to a recent letter from the Tehran Publishers Association complaining that the ministry employed a prolonged and arbitrary vetting process. The letter said, It has been frequently seen that an issue which has resulted in a book being banned is abundant in another one that is published.

title: Waiting (Too Long) for Relief
description: A year into the worst foreclosure crisis since the Depression, the House only now is getting serious about a foreclosure prevention bill.

title: Long Road Ends With Guarded Optimism
description: CLEVELAND  The Yankees clubhouse was hopping after Monday nights game, not what you would expect from a team that had just set a major league record for road games in the month of April.

title: The Beetle Factor in a Carbon Calculus
description: Trees have been fighting climate change for ages, using photosynthesis to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and sequestering it for the long term in their tissues. Most forests are considered net sinks of carbon dioxide, meaning they store more carbon than they give up.

title: A Poet of the Piano, in the Company of His Forebears
description: Listening to the pianist Richard Goode playing Bach and Chopin on Sunday was a perfect, soul-soothing tonic after a busy week. He appeared as part of the lively series Free for All at Town Hall, juxtaposing works by those two composers, Beethoven and Debussy in a program that intelligently illuminated their connections.

title: WB Network to Return as a Web Site
description: The WB brand, born as a broadcast network in 1995 and closed in 2006, will return as an online video Web site, combining short original series with classic shows, the Warner Brothers Television Group announced Monday.

title: New Faces in Hamlet
description: Thirty-three years after he played the title role of Hamlet when it was last presented by the Public Theater in Central Park, Sam Waterston will join the cast in this years production at the Delacorte Theater. This time, Mr. Waterston will portray Polonius, while Michael Stuhlbarg plays Hamlet. Also joining the cast, in the role of Ophelia, is Lauren Ambrose, last summers Juliet. Mr. Waterston and Ms. Ambrose replace Richard Easton and Lily Rabe, who became unavailable because of scheduling conflicts. Previews of Hamlet, staged by Oskar Eustis, the companys artistic director, begin on May 27. Opening night is June 17. The show runs through June 29.

title: Nady Could Fill the Void He Left
description: The decision to trade Xavier Nady came suddenly.

title: Demography Is King
description: Fifty-five years ago, 80 percent of American television viewers, young and old, tuned in to see Milton Berle on Tuesday nights. Tens of millions, rich and poor, worked together at Elks Lodges and Rotary Clubs. Millions more, rural and urban, read general-interest magazines like Look and Life. In those days, the owner of the local bank lived in the same town as the grocery clerk, and their boys might play on the same basketball team. Only 7 percent of adult Americans had a college degree.

title: Quieting the Demons and Giving Art a Voice

Since 2006, when the contract took effect, more than 600 teachers have been placed in the reserve after failing to find new positions.The reserve is an outgrowth of the citys contract with the teachers union, which ended seniority rights in staffing decisions as well as the automatic transfer of teachers who had been cut because of shrinking enrollment, the closing of large schools or the elimination of particular programs. At the time, the schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, said that he would rather absorb the cost of the teachers in the reserve pool than saddle principals with teachers they did not want.

But very few children  and not that many more grown-ups  ever got inside the two great fortresslike showroom buildings on the west side of Madison Square Park.Young David W. Levinson was an exception. In the late 1950s, he was taken to the annual fairs at the Toy Center by his father, Herman, the proprietor of the Artcraft Hobby Shop on Union Turnpike in Queens. The younger Mr. Levinson grew up surrounded by Lionel, American Flyer and Tyco trains. (One disadvantage: he and his father had to work on Christmas, even though the shop was nominally closed that day, because so many families were calling for help in setting up their new floor-level railroads.)Now Mr. Levinson, chairman of L&L Holding Company, is an owner of the former toy building at 200 Fifth Avenue. This 15-story structure, originally called the Fifth Avenue Building, was designed by Maynicke & Franke and completed 99 years ago. It sits in the Ladies Mile Historic District. Its sidewalk clock is an individually designated city landmark.

title: Shakespeare Patron Emerges, Ghostly

While preparing an oil portrait of Wriothesleys wife, Elizabeth Vernon, for an exhibition, the historians discovered a ghostly male figure that had been painted over. From his appearance and long auburn hair, they concluded it was her husband. The experts said the find was significant, but they have no plans to chip away at the Vernon portrait to raise the specter.

The version Robert Bass conducted on Monday was based on a completion assembled and partly composed by John H. Roberts.

Unfortunately, the unifying idea is so ridiculous, so unworthy of the people aspiring to lead our nation, it takes your breath away. Hillary Clinton has decided to line up with John McCain in pushing to suspend the federal excise tax on gasoline, 18.4 cents a gallon, for this summers travel season. This is not an energy policy. The winner, Nuru Rimington-Mkali, is preparing to propose ideas to the Filmaka partners Deepak Nayar, producer of Bend It Like Beckham and Buena Vista Social Club, and Sandy Grushow, former chairman of the Fox Entertainment group. In the contest, Filmaka challenged nonprofessionals to tackle monthly assignments to produce short films based on a brief idea posted on its Web site, filmaka.com. The judges included Colin Firth, Werner Herzog, Neil LaBute, Paul Schrader and Wim Wenders, among others. Mr. LaBute called Mr. Rimington-Mkalis final winning short, And I Refuse to Forget, a wonderfully impressive paranoid thriller that was told with great economy and vivid imagery.

European ministers had to overcome sharp divisions over the Serbian governments failure to hunt down war-crimes suspects, and the signing gave the clearest signal yet that Serbia could eventually join the 27-nation bloc. It could help turn the elections next month into a test of whether Serbia wants to join the union, the worlds largest trading bloc, or adopt a nationalist path more closely aligned with Moscow. The unions 27 foreign ministers and the Serbian deputy prime minister, Bozidar Djelic signed the deal in Luxembourg.

description: For the record, Elevator Repair Services Sound and the Fury (April Seventh, 1928) lasts over two and a half hours, counting intermission. Or thats what my watch said at the end of this hypnotic re-creation of the opening section of William Faulkners 1929 novel.

title: Wine and Beer Calendar
description: Mexico in Midtown

title: Pakistans Planned Accord With Militants Alarms U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Bush administration officials are expressing increasing alarm that a deal being negotiated between the new Pakistani government and militant tribes in the countrys unruly border area will lead to further unraveling of security in the region.

title: California: Union Files Suit Against Local
description: The Service Employees International Union filed a federal lawsuit in Los Angeles, accusing the president and nine other leaders of its giant health care local in California of breaching their fiduciary duties. The lawsuit accused them of setting up an educational fund that the parent union said was used to spend money for internal political purposes off the books and without proper accountability. The lawsuit comes as Sal Rosselli, the president of the California local, United Healthcare Workers-West, has accused Andrew L. Stern, the S.E.I.U.s president, of being undemocratic. Jonathan Siegel, a lawyer for the local, said its board had approved the creation of the fund and dissolved it last week and returned all the money, some of which was used to educate the locals nearly 150,000 members about the push for universal health coverage in California.

title: Young Rappers Plan: Move Up From Makeup
description: I love you, oh my God, you my idol! Ashley Smellie, a Long Island high school student, gushed as the young Brooklyn rapper Lil Mama emerged from a tour bus outside of a club in Queens last week. It was near midnight, and Lil Mama had been scheduled to perform for an audience of mostly teenage girls. They came to hear Lip Gloss, last summers hit novelty single, in which she brags about her makeup over a simplified beat:

title: Mexico: Government Accepts Talks With Guerrillas Who Bombed Pipelines
description: The government said it was willing to negotiate with a guerrilla group that blew up several oil and gas pipelines last year, a day after the guerrillas offered to suspend attacks. The group, Ejrcito Popular Revolucionario, or Popular Revolutionary Army, said in a communiqu on Monday that it was willing to open a dialogue with the government through intermediaries. It has been seeking the release of two members it maintains were kidnapped last May. Interior Minister Juan Camilo Mourio said the government would accept the proposal if the guerrillas ceased their campaign of sabotage but did not offer them amnesty.

title: Silk, Spices, Gold and Destiny: Global History Is Part of the Bargain
description: In 2006 the worlds countries exported $11.8 trillion in goods and services, far above the gross domestic product of any single country except the United States, which itself exported over $1 trillion worth. World trade has nearly doubled in less than a decade, and its increase since World War II is simply staggering.

title: Taking a Bow Wont Stop Fans From Booing
description: There is a school of thought that says if baseball fans insist on a curtain call, they get one.

title: Philippines Bans Kidney Transplants for Foreigners
description: MANILA  The Philippines is banning kidney transplants for foreigners, as part of a government crackdown on a growing but illicit trade in human organs bought from the poor, officials said Tuesday.

title: In Love With the History Our Teachers Never Told Us
description: CUTTYHUNK ISLAND, Mass.  Tony Horwitzs new book, A Voyage Long and Strange, is about the American history most Americans never learned, including the story of the short-lived, early-17th-century colony established on this windswept island eight miles west of Marthas Vineyard.
