description: To the Editor:

title: Pairings: Vodka Ceviche and Spiked Mimosas
description: Both cooks and drink-makers (in many households they are not the same person) can find myriad uses for vodka infused with citrus flavors. It does a fine job in cocktails and in marinades for seafood or fruit. Add it to the mixture for sorbet or a frozen souffl and the alcohol, which does not freeze hard, will improve the texture.

title: Mayor and His Wife Are Guilty in Federal Extortion Case in New Jersey
description: NEWARK  Once again the town of Guttenberg  a dense sliver of a place where about 11,000 residents are shoehorned into an area that measures only 4 blocks by 11  has proved that it is hardly immune to the infamous grip of Hudson County politics.

title: Race Is On to Advance Software for Chips
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  In the computer worlds equivalent of The Amazing Race, three rival teams of computer researchers are working on new types of software needed to better use computer chips that can process many tasks at the same time.

title: The Deluxe Chains Want to Be Chic, Too
description: LONG a five-star fuddy-duddy, Le Mridien has entered a more glamorous phase. Flush with cash since 2005 from its new American owners  the Starwood Hotels and Resorts group  and eager to exert its presence beyond the Continent, Le Mridien, a European luxury brand, is moving from stodgy to sexy.

title: Some Athletes Genes Help Outwit Doping Test
description: The 55 men in a drug doping study in Sweden were normal and healthy. And all agreed, for the sake of science, to be injected with testosterone and then undergo the standard urine test to screen for doping with the hormone.

title: On Arrests, Demographics, and Marijuana
description: Among those washed into Manhattan Criminal Court by the Tuesday morning tides was a 25-year-old man who works in technology support for a large company.

title: Investigation of Council Said to Grow
description: The federal inquiry into how City Council members spend the discretionary money they control appears to be expanding, and city investigators have begun questioning workers at a variety of nonprofit organizations that received money, according to a person familiar with the investigation.

title: Verizon May Soon Join Local TV Market, Adding a Cable Option
description: Cable television viewers in New York who are frustrated with Cablevision or Time Warner Cable may soon have another option for service.

title: Life Stalls in Venezuela as Power Shuts Off
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A sweeping power failure left Venezuelas largest cities without electricity on Tuesday, snarling traffic, halting subway trains underground and mobilizing police forces here in the capital to thwart possible public disturbances.

title: With Books as a Catalyst, Minneapolis Neighborhood Revives
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Back in the heady days of Web 1.0, it seemed that every city tried to create its own Silicon Alley, and this one was no exception.

title: An Officer and a Linebacker for the N.F.L.
description: It was not until he was a sophomore on the Army football team that Caleb Campbell learned his job after graduation might be something other than as a platoon leader, guiding 32 soldiers in Iraq or in Kuwait.

title: Some Chinese Exporters Prefer Euros to Dollars
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Facing the double-barreled threat of a falling dollar and weakening American demand, some Chinese exporters are starting to ask European customers to pay in euros.

title: In Poland, Converting a Palace to a Home
description: NAKLO, Poland

title: Go-To Gadgets
description: Traveling on business these days means having the right information at the right time, packing light, saving money when possible and trying to enjoy at least part of the trip. While the latest technological gadgets and services cannot promise to deliver the deal, they can help make the trip more bearable, a bit more affordable and perhaps even fun.

title: Henry Brant, Avant-Garde Composer, Dies at 94
description: Henry Brant, an adventurous American composer best known for his spatial music, in which the placement of performers on the stage and at carefully specified places around a concert hall is a crucial element, died on Saturday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 94.

title: Jason Shinder, 52, Poet and Teacher, Dies
description: Jason Shinder, a poet, anthologist and teacher who founded the Y.M.C.A. National Writers Voice program, one of the countrys largest networks of literary-arts centers, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 and also lived in Provincetown, Mass.

title: N.Y.U. Plan Threatens Historic Theater
description: New York Universitys proposal to demolish the historic Provincetown Playhouse in Greenwich Village as part of its planned expansion over the next 25 years is meeting resistance from community leaders and scholars who say the building, where Eugene ONeills plays were first produced, is an important site in American theater history.

title: Vodka Ceviche
description: Time: 15 minutes, plus 30 minutes marinating

title: Malkin Again Provides the Spark
description: Pittsburgh center Sidney Crosby was booed virtually every time he touched the puck Tuesday night. But when Evgeni Malkin was involved, the boisterous fans at Madison Square Garden tended to groan, often sinking back into their seats in dejection.

title: M.T.A. Derails Poetry
description: Those poems on the subways are going the way of the No. 9 line  that is, coming to an end after 15 years. Poems may still be posted now and then, but mostly the quotations seen on subways and buses will pertain to a number of different subjects, including history, philosophy, literature and science. Were expanding the breadth of the program to include other areas, said Jeremy Soffin, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Fifteen years is a long time. We had an opportunity to diversify things a little. The content  formerly selected by the Poetry Society of America, which started it in 1992  will now be determined by the Columbia University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. Alice Quinn,  executive director of the Poetry Society, said she would try to find a new sponsor, adding, Were going to try to keep poetry in the public eye.

title: Your Cheese Is Gasping for Breath
description: European-style double-ply cheese paper, with a sheer wax coating on the outer layer and a breathable film inside, helps keep a hunk of Parmigiano-Reggiano or a slab of Manchego at its best, retarding the spoilage that can occur when cheese suffocates in plastic wrap.

title: McCain Strengthening His Political Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCains recent harsh critique of the Republican-led response to Hurricane Katrina no doubt reminded some of his newfound allies in Congress that his independent image was often honed at his partys expense.

title: Judge Dismisses Connecticuts Challenge to Education Law
description: A federal judge has dismissed a closely watched challenge to President Bushs signature education law, ruling that the State of Connecticut failed to prove that federal officials had forced it to spend its own money to comply with the laws requirements.

title: Private Jets Are Flying Higher
Meeting on the Right Side of the Brain
description: WHEN Leslie Marquard, an executive coach, holds strategy sessions for consulting firms or university administrators, she ushers her buttoned-up clientele into rooms full of Pogo sticks, ethnic art, hammocks, vintage furniture and a pillow harem.

title: Citigroup Sells $4.5 Billion in Shares
description: Citigroup, the banking giant, said Wednesday morning that it would sell $4.5 billion of new common shares in another effort to shore up its balance sheet. The offering was priced at $25.27 a share.

title: A New Way for Zimbabwe?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Easing the Pain at Airports
description: KAREN W. ELLIS, customer services manager at the airport in Atlanta, is used to getting a certain reaction when she describes her job.

title: Primary Loss and Furor Over Ex-Pastor Hurt Obama in Poll
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obamas aura of inevitability in the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination has diminished in the wake of his loss in the Pennsylvania primary and the furor over his former pastor, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Juleps That Go Beyond Mint
description: Watch the Kentucky Derby on Saturday at a flat-screen party, or better, land an invitation to Louisville, Ky., and you will most likely drink mint juleps. Like eggnog at Christmas, they have their moment. But bartenders at the Brandy Library, Blue Smoke, Smiths and Wildwood Barbeque, among others, are now mixing this cocktail far beyond the first Saturday in May.

title: Georgia-Russia Tensions Rise
description: Tensions flared again between Russia and Georgia, its southern neighbor, after both sides accused each other of an improper military buildup related to a disputed border area. Georgia criticized Russia for sending extra peacekeeping troops to Abkhazia, the breakaway region of Georgia that is allied with Moscow. The Kremlin said in turn that it had evidence that Georgia was planning to attack Abkhazia, a charge denied by the Georgian government.

title: A Sporting Gesture Touches Em All
description: Something remarkable happened in a college softball game last Saturday in Ellensburg, Wash. At least, I am conditioned to think it was remarkable, since it involved an act of sportsmanship, with two players helping an injured opponent complete the home run she had just slugged.

title: Putting the Rental Cars Farther Out to Cut Congestion
description: IF you have ever rented a car at an airport you might understand what it is like to be caught in traffic trying to return the vehicle with your departure time looming.

title: Bill Regulating Air Monitors Draws Concern at Hearing
description: Industrial hygienists, academics, residents and a long list of others testified at a City Council hearing on Tuesday against a bill that would make New York the first city in the nation to require certain chemical, biological and radiation detectors to be registered with the police. They said the measure, which the Bloomberg administration has been pushing, was unnecessary, intrusive and counterproductive.

title: Trial Opens for Former Hussein Aide
description: BAGHDAD  Tariq Aziz, who for years was the public diplomatic face of Saddam Husseins government, went on trial in Baghdad on Tuesday, facing charges over the execution of Iraqi merchants during the Baathist era.

title: The Road to a Jumbo Mortgage Was Supposed to Get Easier
description: In early February, Congress gave beleaguered mortgage borrowers a rare cause for celebration. As part of the economic stimulus package, it passed rules intended to make it easier and less expensive for people to take out hefty loans in the nations costliest housing markets.

description: Time: 10 minutes

title: Footnote
description: Scott Weiland, the lead singer of the band Stone Temple Pilots, was sentenced on Monday to eight days in jail for drunken driving, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Weiland, 40, right, entered a plea of no contest to a single misdemeanor count, his second conviction in four years for driving under the influence. Besides jail, he was placed on four years unsupervised probation, ordered to enroll in an 18-month alcohol program and fined about $1,600, said Frank Mateljan, a spokesman for the Los Angeles City Attorneys Office.

title: G.M. Posts $3.3 Billion Loss
description: DETROIT  The General Motors Corporation said Wednesday that it lost $3.25 billion, or $5.74 a share in the first quarter, as a parts shortage and declining vehicle sales increased losses in North America and its financing arm grappled with a slump in the United States housing market.

title: Ruling Favors Online Bets
description: Three online gambling companies won a ruling against the French Tennis Federation when a Belgian court rejected the organizations move to block them from taking bets on the French Open. The court ruled that Bwin, Betfair and Ladbrokes do not encourage corruption by taking bets on tennis.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on March 1 about Ben Chapman, who played the title role in the 1954 horror film Creature From the Black Lagoon, erroneously included some medals among the decorations he received as a marine in the Korean War. According to the National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis, he was authorized to wear the Korean Service Medal with one star and the United Nations Service Medal. The center said it had no record of his receiving the Silver Star, Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts. This correction was delayed for research.

title: A Tinge of Citrus in a Vodka Bottle
description: OH, do I have a headache.

title: CBS Newscast Rating Drops Even More
description: The downward trend for the CBS News anchor Katie Couric continued last week as the networks evening newscast dipped again in the ratings. One week after setting a record low, with about 5.39 million viewers, the newscast attracted about 50,000 fewer people, averaging about 5.34 million. The number is the lowest total for the CBS Evening News since Nielsen research introduced its new rating system in 1987. The broadcast was far more popular before that date. Ms. Courics ratings have been sliding since reports that she and the top management of CBS have held discussions about her future at the network, although network executives, including the chairman, Leslie Moonves, have expressed faith in her and the program. The race at the top of the newscast competition was closer than the prior week as NBCs program beat ABCs by about 227,000 viewers. A week earlier the gap was about 700,000 viewers as ABC faced possible negative fallout from widespread criticism of its presentation of the Democratic presidential debate in Pennsylvania. For the week NBC averaged about 8.01 million viewers, with ABC at about 7.79 million.

title: Detroit Mayors Messages to Ex-Aide Are Released
description: DETROIT  Text messages released publicly on Tuesday provide details of the extramarital affair between Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick and his former chief of staff, Christine Beatty, and expand on his plan to fire police officers whose investigations could have exposed the affair. The messages appear to contradict testimony the two gave in court last year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on March 26 about the installation of microturbines to produce power in Manhattan buildings referred incorrectly to the output of two units installed at Astor Wine and Spirits on Lafayette Street. The two units can put out about 120 kilowatts of power; the measure used in the article, 120 kilowatts of electricity an hour, is meaningless. A readers e-mail message pointing out the error was misdirected at The Times.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the rising environmental costs of shipping food globally misspelled the surname of the head of Bellona, a Norwegian environmental group, who commented on pollution from transport. He is Frederic Hauge, not Hague.

description: Writers on Beard

title: Corzine Weighs Options on Toll Increases
description: NEWARK  After spending much of the past 18 months creating a plan to reduce New Jerseys debt and finance transportation improvements by drastically raising highway tolls, Gov. Jon S. Corzine is apparently back to Milepost 1.

title: House Buoys Fox
description: After a 12-week absence from Foxs schedule, House returned with a new episode, lifting the network to first place in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that the medical drama led the night in that age group while drawing 14.5 million total viewers during the 9 p.m. hour. Fox finished first in the 18-to-49 set despite drawing more modest ratings at 8 p.m. with Bones (9.7 million). Fox did trail ABC in total viewers for the night, as ABCs Dancing With the Stars remained the nights most-watched show with 17.9 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. CBS ranked third in total viewers behind both ABC and Fox, but second in the 18-to-49 set ahead of ABC, earning solid ratings from its comedy lineup. CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour with CSI: Miami (13.6 million), which outperformed both ABCs Bachelor (7.8 million) and NBCs Medium (9.6 million). NBC was fourth over all.

title: Trial of Chief of Milosevics Secret Police Begins
description: Slobodan Milosevic is dead, but a new trial touching the heart of his regime has begun in The Hague.

title: Whos on First? Trying to Fix the Primary Calendar
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- For all the bellyaching about the current presidential primary system -- it starts too early, goes on too long, is insanely expensive and gives undue influence to two small states (and you know who you are) -- it is possible that the same system will be in place for the next presidential cycle.

description: To the Editor:

title: Alou Is Finally Ready to Play, but Schneider Is Not
description: Moises Alou returned to the Mets on Tuesday, but he will probably not be back on the active roster until Friday, when the team opens a series against the Diamondbacks in Arizona. The return of catcher Brian Schneider is less certain; he remains in a hospital with an infected left thumb.

title: Brown Goes to Bobcats in Return to His Roots
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Larry Brown received a long, loud standing ovation from fans, guests and staff members who attended a news conference Tuesday introducing him as the new coach of the Charlotte Bobcats.

title: A Team on the Rise Dismisses Dallas
description: NEW ORLEANS  In a city seeking revival, in an arena they were once forced to abandon, the New Orleans Hornets celebrated a rebirth Tuesday night, and set off a party that may not end until June.

title: One Newsday Suitor Steps Aside, Another Returns
description: The escalating contest for ownership of Newsday took a couple of new twists on Wednesday.

title: From a Speakeasy to a Showboat
description: THE Waverly Inn, said one of my friends, as she took in the scene at the new restaurant Commerce. I think she was focusing on the oil mural painted on one of the walls and on the way the restaurants Art Deco flourishes and situation in a 1911 building give it the feel of old New York.

description: DANA POINT, Calif.

description: Africa in Chelsea

title: Syria Returns Iraqi Loot
description: Golden necklaces, daggers, clay statues and pots were among more than 700 antiquities, including the one above, returned this week to the National Museum of Iraq by Syria, where they were seized from traffickers after being looted in the chaos that followed the United States-led invasion five years ago, The Associated Press reported. This was a positive initiative taken by Syria, and we wish the same initiative to be taken by all neighboring countries, said Mohammad Abbas al-Oreibi, Iraqs acting state minister of tourism and archaeology, who led the negotiations with Syria. He said he planned to visit Jordan soon to seek the return of more than 150 items. Dr. Muna Hassan, who heads a committee working to restore the artifacts, said similar discussions were in progress with the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Germany and Italy. Between 3,000 and 7,000 items are believed to be missing, Laurent Levi-Strauss, a Unesco culture official, said last month. Syria said it arrested some of the traffickers but did not provide details. The National Museum, in Baghdad, remains closed to the public as a result of its poor condition and a lack of security.

title: The Hollow Man
description: THESE days, as I watch Robert Mugabe tighten his 28-year-old stranglehold on Zimbabwe while the forces of opposition try to pry away his fingers, I cant help thinking back to a conversation he and I once tried to have about T. S. Eliot, poetry and the month of April.

title: Traffic Money for N.Y. May Benefit Other Cities
description: CHICAGO  Sometimes one citys loss is anothers gain.

title: Ritzenhein Returns
description: Dathan Ritzenhein, who has claimed a berth on the United States Olympic marathon team, will defend his title in the Healthy Kidney 10-kilometer race in Central Park on May 17. The field also includes the 2006 New York City Marathon champion Marilson Gomes dos Santos of Brazil. Ritzenhein set the Central Park 10K record last year, in 28 minutes 8 seconds.

title: Barricades of May 68 Still Divide the French
description: NANTERRE, France  Forty years ago, French students in neckties and bobby socks threw cobblestones at the police and demanded that the sclerotic postwar system must change. Today, French students, worried about finding jobs and losing state benefits, are marching through the streets demanding that nothing change at all.

title: Iron Worker Falls 25 Feet From Building
description: Just one day after thousands of workers gathered to mourn the loss of the 13 people killed in construction accidents in New York City this year, an iron worker was critically injured on Tuesday when he fell 25 feet from a building under construction on East 29th Street in Manhattan.

title: No Goodbye, Columbus
description: The Columbus Symphony Orchestra in Ohio, bedeviled by financial problems that threaten its existence, said late Monday that a board member had made an emergency donation to allow it to finish the season. After the musicians rejected a contract on Friday that would have cut their pay by 40 percent, the orchestras management said it might have to suspend operations because revenue was not meeting costs. Management is seeking to cut the $12 million budget to $9.5 million, the most it said Columbus could support through ticket sales and donations. The emergency gift allows the orchestra to go ahead with its remaining concerts in May but, the board said, defers to another day the inevitable suspension of operations due to a lack of funds.

title: A New Wave of Vilifying Short Sellers
description: In the days when square-rigged galleons plied the spice route to the East, the Dutch outlawed a band of rebels that they feared might plunder their new-found riches.

title: Saying Times Are Tough, Bush Urges Congress to Act
description: WASHINGTON  With consumer confidence falling and gasoline and food prices at record highs, President Bush delivered an unusually dark assessment of the economy on Tuesday, saying the nation is in very difficult times, very difficult.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about Chinese students in the United States who have to deal with negative images of their home country misspelled the family name of a doctoral student at the University of Southern California who said the Western news media were biased against China. He is Chau Wu, not Chou Wu.

title: Federal Money in Health Care Plan From McCain
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Senator John McCain detailed his plan to solve the nations health care crisis in a speech here Tuesday, calling for the federal government to give some money to states to help them cover people with illnesses who have been denied health insurance.

title: An Unlikely Way to Save a Species: Serve It for Dinner
description: SOME people would just as soon ignore the culinary potential of the Carolina flying squirrel or the Waldoboro green neck rutabaga. To them, the creamy Hutterite soup bean is too obscure and the Tennessee fainting goat, which keels over when startled, sounds more like a sideshow act than the centerpiece of a barbecue.

title: And Now, Foie Gras for People on the Go
description: IN the ambitious menu for Gordon Ramsay Plane Food, a restaurant that opened last month in the new Terminal 5 of London Heathrow Airport, Mr. Ramsay, the celebrity chef, has made few obvious concessions to the locale. A diner might start with a pea, leek and goat-cheese tart, followed by braised lamb with honey and cloves or steamed wild sea bass with lemongrass and white asparagus. And if the prospect of a belt-straining flight isnt too alarming, theres a Valrhona chocolate fondue with bananas, marshmallows and waffles for dessert. Three courses cost about 32  or $64  before wine or tip.

title: Federal Mortgage Plan Falls Short, Critics Say
description: WASHINGTON  Fewer than 2,000 homeowners at risk of foreclosure have been helped by a Federal Housing Administration program that President Bush promised would help homeowners who had fallen behind on their mortgage payments, federal housing statistics show.

title: Cox Enterprises to Acquire Adify, an Ad Tech Firm
description: Cox Enterprises, a media company with broad holdings in newspapers, radio and television, said Tuesday that it would pay $300 million in cash for the advertising technology company Adify. The move would put Cox in competition with companies like Google that have built up big online advertising franchises.

title: Afghan President Was Warned of Attack
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai was warned that an attack was being planned on a military parade on Sunday, when he escaped an assassination attempt, Afghanistans intelligence chief told Parliament on Tuesday. He said two groups of attackers were thwarted the same day, though a third succeeded in opening fire on the ceremony.

title: Who Needs Cachet if You Have New York?
description: Over the course of its seven-year history the Tribeca Film Festival has built a following, hosted numerous world premieres and played a significant role in helping a neighborhood find its footing after Sept. 11. Every year thousands of filmmakers clamor for hundreds of slots before the festival starts, and once it does, stars and directors mingle at downtown botes while the public queues up outside theaters in numbers that suggest that free whiskey is being handed out. The festivals main sponsor, American Express, just signed up for five additional years.

title: Quests Separate Soldier and Olympic Hopeful
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  She longed to compete in the Olympics. He always wanted to join the Army. She started BMX racing at age 5. He stocked his movie collection with war films.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column on April 22, about unusual advertising like scratch-off scents, taste strips and pocket squares, misidentified the creator of a pop-up vertical fin for Discovery Channels Shark Week. It was the work of Americhip, a design and production firm in Torrance, Calif.  not Structural Graphics, a firm in Essex, Conn.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about World Wrestling Entertainments comeback efforts misidentified the employer of Chris McCumber, who likened the wrestling show W.W.E. Raw to Monday Night Football. He is the senior vice president for marketing and brand strategy of the cable network that broadcasts the show; he does not work for World Wrestling Entertainment. The article also misspelled the name of Mr. McCumbers network. It is USA Network, not Networks. And the article misstated the beneficiaries of a recent increase in W.W.E.s quarterly dividend. The dividend will be received by Class A shareholders; it will not benefit the McMahon family, which controls the company but owns Class B stock.

title: Port Authority Liable in 1993 Trade Center Attack
description: A state appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the Port Authority was liable for damages caused by the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, because it knew about but chose to ignore an extreme and potentially catastrophic vulnerability that would have been open and obvious to any terrorist who cared to investigate and exploit it.

title: Pulling Back the Immigration Posses
description: Many parts of the nation have tilted severely toward harsh, unyielding policies to catch and punish illegal immigrants, but not everyone has gone over the edge. Gov. Janet Napolitano of Arizona on Monday pushed back, vetoing a bill that would have required all police and sheriffs departments in the state to join the federal immigration posse.

title: Lord & Taylor Considers Stores Outside U.S.
description: Lord & Taylor, the quintessentially American department store, is thinking about opening stores outside the country, possibly in Mexico and Canada, its chairman said Tuesday.

title: What You Get for... $7 Million
description: Middletown, R.I.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts Quarterly Loss, Evidence of the Reach of the Financial Crisis
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank, which won praise and envy in financial circles for seeming to weather the credit storm better than most of its peers, reported on Tuesday that its luck had run out.

title: No Menu Choices at Ad Hoc, a Luxury in Itself
description: WHEN I was growing up and it was dinnertime, we answered to a higher power: Mommy.

title: Against Odds, New Orleans Schools Fight Back
description: NEW ORLEANS  No road leads to George Washington Carver Senior High School here. It sits on no street and has no address. No sign announces it.

title: Emir of Qatar Tours New Orleans to See Fruit of His $100 Million Donation
description: NEW ORLEANS  One of the worlds richest men toured one of Americas poorest cities on Tuesday, a whistle-stop visitor from a distant land come to see his good works in a place still needing a strangers kindness.

title: Lennon Peace Lyrics
description: In 1969, when she was 16, Gail Renard evaded heavy security at the Queen Elizabeth Hotel in Montreal and managed to sneak into Suite 1742, where John Lennon and Yoko Ono were staging their eight-day bed-in for peace. Ms. Renard, now a prize-winning comedy writer and comic, stayed for a week with the couple. On the final night of the bed-in, Lennon led a recording of Give Peace a Chance, sung by him and 50 or so guests, including Timothy Leary, Tommy Smothers, Petula Clark and Allen Ginsberg. He also gave Ms. Renard a few mementos, including the lyrics, above, and told her that one day they will be worth something. On July 10 the lyrics and some rare photographs will be offered in London by Christies South Kensington at a sale of rock and pop memorabilia. A Christies announcement said the items were expected to bring $400,000 to $600,000.

title: Actresss Parents Tell of Stalker Suspect
description: At first, Robert Thurman said, his celebrity-stalker alarms did not go off when a stranger named Jack Jordan began sending him e-mail messages at Columbia University, where he is a professor of Indo-Tibetan studies. title: Different
description: When I first read Housekeeping I was living in a house my maternal grandparents had built in the 1920s in a small town in western South Dakota. Its location had been determined by a railroad company; in 1907 the laying of track for the Milwaukee Road stopped for the winter, and the town was born, as a row of tents and a few ramshackle businesses. By the time my mother was born, 10 years later, people were living in frame houses and had planted trees. When she was a child, nearly everyone she knew was from somewhere else, back East, all the way to Sweden, Norway or the Russian steppes. But by the time I spent childhood summers there, the place had become densely layered with human history of the sort so vividly depicted in the novel. It is the first place I heard people  the parents of a friend my grandmother disapproved of  described as shiftless, not likely to remain in the town for long. As I knew my grandmother to be a tolerant and compassionate woman, this got my attention.

title: Assigning Fault in the 1993 Trade Center Attack

In its decision, the court noted that the Port Authority, a bistate New York and New Jersey agency that owned the trade center, did not argue that the bombing was unforeseeable, only that it was unlikely, since its own consultants and an internal study group had predicted with exact prescience how an attack could be carried out. title: Our Ms. Spindler & More
description: Lots of us think about Amy Spindler, the mind of Amy Spindler, and Im glad people are again discovering her writing. She came to life, I think, in the latter part of her run as fashion critic of the NYT and then again when she became Style Editor of the Magazine. Amy was a good writer and an excellent, tireless reporter who had an energetic mind that sought out new ideas. She loved the nostalgia piece; one of my favorite articles that I wrote for her at the Magazine was a profile of Jacques Tiffeau (a wild, brilliant guy and a lover of Diors, by the way). She saw the charm and evergreen news in those kinds of pieces. But Amy was also someone with strong moral beliefs and maybe that was the source of her contentiousness. She loved catching a fashion exec in a lie, and, of course, there was the heroin chic piece. You felt her rage, her high sense of standards. And she could REALLY yack during a fashion show. Amy would be talking away during a show and youd be looking at the clothes and going, Yeahahumyeahahum. Somehow, she saw everything. Her deputy at the mag, Andy Port, gave a marvelous speech at Amys memorial, which was held at the Rainbow Room. Amy had a knack, as Andy said, of persuading people to her side. We all knew that special power of hers pretty well.

Renovations included upgraded boilers, wheelchair ramps, automatic entrances, improved common areas, window replacements and energy efficient lighting. title: About that GDP report
description: Ive had time to look at it a bit more closely  and its much weaker than the headline number suggests (and MUCH weaker than the previous quarter, even though the growth rate was the same.) Its not just that final sales fell, so that the economy grew only because of inventory accumulation. If you look at consumer spending, purchases of goods actually fell substantially. Only service purchases rose  and much of that was housing and medical care. As Michael Mandel at Business Week has pointed out, those arent really consumer decisions: housing consumption is largely imputed rents on owner-occupied homes, and medical care is mostly paid for by insurance.
